DOC.HEAD: Democrats Starting to Take Aim at Bush
DOC.TEXT: After months of appearing paralyzed by President Bush's high poll ratings, the Democrats have shifted into a campaign mode and begun to sound like a party ready to challenge Bush in the 1992 election. During weekend meetings in New Orleans and Indianapolis, the Democrats took on the popular Republican president on a range of domestic issues including Social Security, the environment, abortion and education. The party's newly aggressive stance was not arrived at easily. It exposed the differing approaches of state party officials hungry for effective campaign issues and the congressional wing, whose members must often search for compromises with their Republican colleagues and the White House. Regardless of their differences on specific issues, the Democrats clearly agreed with party Chairman Ronald H. Brown's assessment that the president has been getting a ``free ride'' and that it was time to challenge him. The party officials gathered in Indianapolis for a meeting of the Democratic National Committee, while the elected Democrats were in New Orleans for a session convened by the Democratic Leadership Council. Brown attended both meetings and was instrumental in pushing his party to endorse Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security payroll tax _ a plan some of Moynihan's fellow Democrats flatly oppose. ``I'm not concerned there is going to be a debate,'' Brown told a news conference on the closing day of the DNC meeting. ``There ought to be a debate.'' The chairman was asked if he would feel a litle uncomfortable with the stand of his party if he were an elected official _ say Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who is decidedly unethusiastic about the proposal by his New York colleague. ``I think I'd feel good that my national party was committed to winning elections,'' Brown replied. That response reflected the dominant view in Indianapolis: to win elections, the Democrats must make clear to voters what they stand for. It was with that in mind that Brown also stepped up his attacks on the administration's record on the environment and education, issues the president threatens to steal from the Democrats. Bush convened the governors for an education summit last fall and rarely misses an opportunity to proclaim himself the ``education president.'' He recently pleased environmentalists by endorsing legislation to upgrade the Environmental Protection Agency to a Cabinet department. ``We're not satisfied with sound bites and press conferences about education when children in Eastern Europe are outscoring American kids on standardized science exams, and 60 million Americans can't read at an eighth-grade level,'' Brown told the DNC. He was equally scornful of the administration record on the environment. He recalled the Bush campaign commercials on pollution in Boston Harbor and chided the president for failing to clean it up. Party officials recognized the risk of endorsing strong action on Social Security. ``I think it's a little bit of a dangerous issue,'' said Jim Ruvolo, Ohio Democratic Party chairman and president of the Association of Democratic State Chairs. Ruvolo said the Democrats must be careful not to allow the Republicans to ``frame the debate as the Democrats are threatening Social Security. We know what kind of issue that is.'' Throughout the 1980s, even at the height of Ronald Reagan's popularity, Social Security was an issue that won votes for the Democrats because some elderly voters were convinced that Reagan wanted to freeze benefits. ``The cornerstone of the Moynihan proposal is to say this fund ought to be sacrosanct,'' said Brown. The proposal, however, has not received strong support from groups representing the elderly. The Democrats are hoping they can calm the fears of the elderly that Moynihan's plan would lead to a freeze or cutback in benefits. At the same time, the Democrats are banking on the appeal of cutting the payroll tax, which has risen steadily for several years. Brown had another weekend victory when he got his party to act quickly and quietly to set the rules for the 1992 campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. ``This is the most peaceful accord on rules we have had in the past two decades,'' he said with obvious satisfaction. What made the Democrats so willing to adopt their chairman's strategy? The answer might lie in the underlying unease felt by many at the DNC meeting. Despite election successes in 1989 races, Democrats can't escape the reality of their national election losses. ``We are not the majority party in this country,'' said Rep. Sander Levin of Michigan, challenging a basic Democratic tenet. ``The party that loses five of six presidential elections is not the majority party.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Ruling Helped Pilot Avoid FAA Scrutiny
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to clarify that Johnson pled guilty to DWI, add other details of agreement. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Eden Prairie...'
DOC.TEXT: Veteran Northwest Airlines pilot Robert Ralph Johnson was so drunk leaving a racquet club that he fell on his way to his car. A judge would later say it was amazing he could walk at all. But the judge sealed police and court records to keep Northwest and the Federal Aviation Administration from learning of the case in exchange for a guilty plea to driving while intoxicated in July 1988. The reasons: to save Johnson's job and to get him into a treatment program. Johnson continued to fly for Northwest, as he had for almost 30 years, the Star Tribune reported Sunday. The issue of pilot drunkenness gained new attention with the arrest March 8 of three other Northwest airmen. They were accused of drinking before a flight that day and of flying a plane with 91 passengers aboard while intoxicated. Northwest fired Captain Norman Prouse, First Officer Robert Kirchner and Second Officer Joseph Balzer, who allegedly had blood-alcohol levels above .04 percent, the legal limit for pilots, officials said. The Star Tribune said at least 41 pilots of passenger aircraft, including 28 employed by Northwest, have lost their Minnesota driver's licenses in the past seven years because of alcohol abuse. In Johnson's case, if Eagan-based Northwest had learned of the incident, he could have been grounded for at least two years under a strict alcohol policy that since has been relaxed. If convicted of an alcohol-related traffic offense, Johnson would have been required by the FAA to report it on his medical exam, raising the possibility that his fitness to fly would be examined. But following Johnson's guilty plea, Hennepin County District Court Judge David Duffy decided not to accept it, Timothy Ostroot, Johnson's lawyer, told The Associated Press. As part of the deal, the judge ordered Johnson to complete alcohol treatment and stay in contact with a probation officer. If Johnson upholds his part of the agreement, the judge will dismiss the case in July without ever convicting Johnson of drunken driving, Ostroot said. Northwest and FAA officials declined to comment on the report, as did a national spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association. Eden Prairie police had stopped Johnson from driving his car out of the racquet club's parking lot; a breath test showed he had a .33 percent blood-alcohol content. ``Nothing is to be disclosed to anybody regarding this,'' Duffy said during a hearing, according to the newspaper. ``And that would include the FAA. And that does not go on the driving record. It goes nowhere but here.'' When Duffy asked what the FAA could do, Johnson answered, ``If it doesn't get out of this room, they would never know.'' Duffy opened the file last week to a Star Tribune reporter who challenged the legality of sealing the records. While Johnson avoided FAA scrutiny through that unusual court ruling, other pilots do so in a more routine way, the Star Tribune said. In reviewing Northwest pilots' driving records, the newspaper found seven cases in which alcohol-related charges were reduced to non-alcohol offenses, such as careless driving. One was reduced to a charge of running a red light. With alcohol removed from the convictions, the pilots were under no obligation to tell the FAA they were involved in a drunken-driving case, thus avoiding evaluation of their alcohol use. Should such an evaluation show them to be alcoholic, they could be suspended from flying until they could prove they could overcome alcoholism and abstained from drinking for two years, the Star Tribune said. Duffy said last week he sealed Johnson's records because it was the only way to get him to plead guilty and go into treatment, without costing him his job. Under the old Northwest policy, Duffy said, if a pilot ``pled guilty to drunk driving, he lost his job. Or if he went into treatment, he lost his job. Under those circumstances, nobody was going to plead guilty.'' By this July, if Johnson has met the conditions set by the judge, his case will be dismissed and his record will be clear. Since he was sentenced, Johnson has completed treatment and remained sober, Duffy said. Johnson's attorney, Timothy Ostroot, said Duffy's decision was proper under the circumstances. ``This (the drinking incident) was completely unrelated to his job,'' he said. ``There was never any allegation he was going to fly the next day. ... To me, the price of losing his job, which he worked very hard at and he was very good at, for an alcohol-related incident ... would be a heavy price to pay.''

DOC.HEAD: Gerald Bull, Weapons Designer and Arms Dealer, Dead at 62
DOC.TEXT: Gerald Bull, a Canadian-born arms dealer and weapons designer, was killed in his home, authorities say. He was 62. Bull was shot to death Thursday night in his apartpment in a fashionable suburb of Brussels. Police said they have ruled out robbery as a motive because more than $20,000 was found in Bull's pockets. Bull was convicted in Vermont in 1980 on charges of smuggling arms to South Africa. The Canadian news agency Southam News, based in Ottawa, reported Sunday that he had been working more recently with Iraq to help it develop advanced weapons systems that were used in the Iran-Iraq war. He also had extensive business dealings with Communist China, Southam reported. The Belgian newspaper Derniere Heure said Bull had helped South Africa develop the G5 long-range artillery gun. The Howitzer-type guns were said to be more sophisticated than anything in either the NATO or Warsaw Pact arsenals. But in a statement issued to the Belgian news agency, Bull's son Stephen strongly denied that Space Research Corp., Bull's company, or its foreign affiliates, were involved in arms dealing. ``The Space Research Corp. ... has never been involved in activities breaking the (arms) embargo with South Africa,'' the statement said. It said Bull for several years had been involved in aeronautic and defense research. Bull was born in North Bay, Ontario, but gave up his Canadian citizenship for a U.S. passport sometime before 1977, the Canadian Embassy in Brussels said. Once tabbed by Maclean's magazine as Canada's boy genius of rocket science, Bull became in 1951 the youngest person to graduate from the University of Toronto with a doctorate. He was 22. He first appeared on the Vermont scene in 1967, when, as a professor at McGill University in Montreal, he established an aerospace science program at Norwich University in Northfield. In 1970, Bull began trying to perfect his plans to orbit nuclear warheads in space. Although he was Canadian, Bull won access to highly classified American military files. When the impropriety was discovered, a special act of Congress sponsored by Sen. Barry Goldwater, R-Ariz., backdated his U.S. citizenship application. Only two other aliens, the Marquis de Lafayette and Winston Churchill, have had such honorary citizenship bestowed upon them. Space Research ran into trouble in the mid-1970s, when it failed to win the major military contracts it was seeking, and lost a $12 million contract to build 28 simulators for the Federal Aviation Administration. The company's demise came after U.S. and Canadian authorities and news media investigations found that it had struck a deal to sell advanced Howitzer technology to the South African government, in violation of U.S. munitions laws and a United Nations arms embargo against the white minority-ruled country. Reports at the time indicated that the deal was accomplished through shipments through ports in Antigua and Spain, commercial jet flights from New York and Montreal and visits by Space Research Engineers to a remote test range in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Six Months Later, Hugo-Downed Timber Poses Fire Threat
DOC.TEXT: Six months after Tropical Storm Hugo's powerful winds cut a swath of destruction through North Carolina, the big threat now is forest fires. ``Mother Nature lashed out against us not once but twice,'' said State Forester Harry Layman. ``First we got the hurricane and now we've got to face the threat of forest fires.'' Layman estimated that Hugo destroyed or damaged 2.7 million acres of trees worth about $250 million. That's more timber than was destroyed by the Mount St. Helen's volcano, the fires in Yellowstone National Park and Hurricane Camille combined, he said. As the springtime temperatures begin to rise, tons of downed and shattered pines, oaks, hickorys and other trees continue to pile up and dry out on the floors of western North Carolina's mountains. It's the worst fire threat the state has ever faced, say Layman and other experts. Authorities in South Carolina also are concerned. ``It's real bad this year and its going to get worse in the second and third years,'' Layman said. ``Right now, the twigs and branches are falling, providing lots of kindling. Later the big trees are all going to be down. It's going to be a big bonfire. ``Any fire larger than five acres will soon be out of control and turn into a holocaust,'' Layman said. Charlotte was in the direct path of the eye of the storm after it came ashore 200 miles south near Charleston, S.C., in the predawn hours of Sept. 22. While Hugo was officially downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm just before it hit Charlotte, winds were clocked at 90 mph and higher when the eye of the storm passed just over the western outskirts of the city. Piles of debris, including tree stumps, are still a common sight on some streets. At some city parks, youngsters play baseball and soccer games in open areas between large uprooted trees. The city has carted away an estimated 100,000 truckloads of Hugo debris. Seven emergency landfills were opened to take the debris, and four are already full. ``We're still getting 250 to 300 calls a day from people who want us to come to their homes and take away their debris,'' said Larry Johnson, assistant director of transportation, who's in charge of the remaining cleanup. Back in the forests, officials are preparing for a dry spring. Using a $3.3 million grant from the Federal Emergency Managment Administration, 65 additional firefighters were hired. Abandoned fire towers were reactivated and new equipment _ including helicopters and bulldozers _ were brought in. The state leased a tanker plane from the Quebec government; South Carolina has leased two of the planes. The North Carolina Forestry Division has two planes combing the path of the storm looking for any signs of fire. ``We're working our hearts out to open up as many (fire) trails as we can,'' Layman said. ``But we need 500 miles of trails in Burke County alone and our crew can only do two miles a day.'' The state may use prisoners to help clear paths into the forests that were blocked by downed trees. Timber companies are only able to clear about 7 percent of the damaged trees. Layman is considering imposing a strict burning ban beginning next month. ``The worst time is April and May,'' he said. ``We're hoping Mother Nature will cooperate, but sooner or later we're going to face it.''

DOC.HEAD: Illegal Aliens: Census Will Include Them in Count
DOC.TEXT: If one state includes 5 million U.S. citizens and another has 4 million citizens and 1 million illegal aliens, which gets more seats in the House of Representatives? The answer: they both get the same. That's not fair, say politicians from states that don't have many undocumented residents. But that's what the Constitution requires, respond their counterparts in states with large numbers of them. The dispute has provoked battles in federal court and Congress as the Census Bureau prepares to go forth and count Americans once again. The national head count, taken every 10 years, got under way last week. The results will be used to redistribute seats in the House in 1992, and officials in states that have few illegal aliens fear losing political influence to states with many undocumented residents. The number of House seats assigned to each state depends only on the total population of that state, whether composed of citizens, legal resident aliens or the undocumented. ``The question is simple. Are people who have entered our country illegally entitled to representation in the United States Congress? I say no,'' Rep. Tom Ridge, R-Pa., said recently in remarks echoed by Rep. Tim Valentine, D-N.C., and others. Rep. William F. Goodling, R-Pa., contended that including illegal aliens gives undue influence to the citizens who live near them. Because non-citizens cannot vote, it would take fewer citizens to elect a congressman in a district with a lot of aliens than in one with few, Goodling said. Ridge fought a losing battle in the House to require the Census Bureau to ask people if they are here legally, and then to leave who aren't out of the numbers used for apportionment. A lawsuit filed by Ridge and 41 other House members seeking the same result also was dismissed by a federal judge in Pittsburgh. Despite the defeats, he hasn't given up, said aide Mark Campbell. It's too late to have changes made in the 1990 census, but Ridge is now aiming at the next count, in the year 2000. ``Congress cannot by legislative action make persons into non-persons for its political purposes,'' Rep. Esteban E. Torres, D-Calif., argued for those who want an all-inclusive count He stressed that while the Constitution requires citizenship for certain public offices, it specifically calls for the counting of all ``persons'' in the census. A proposal to base House apportionment only on citizens was rejected a century ago, when Northern states included many new immigrants, noted Arturo Vargas of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund. ``Excluding undocumented residents from census counts would compel the Census (Bureau) to adopt untested techniques to determine the citizenship and immigration status of every person counted in the census,'' Vargas said. This, he said, could have a ``chilling effect'' on the Hispanic community, discouraging participation of many legal residents. Trying to count legal and illegal residents separately ``will only lead to misrepresentation and inaccuracy, both in the count numbers and in the reapportionment process,'' said Jaime B. Fuster, Puerto Rico's resident commissioner in Washington. Undersecretary of Commerce Michael R. Darby, whose department includes the Census Bureau, said, ``We believe there are compelling legal and public policy grounds for counting all persons irrespective of their citizenship.'' Changing the policy of counting everyone would undermine efforts to get a complete census, would discourage participation of minorities and could damage public perception of census confidentiality, said Darby. In addition, he said, there is no effective way to know who is legal and who isn't. Of all the questions on the long and short forms, none asks people if they reside in the country legally. However, estimates developed in 1985 indicated that excluding illegal aliens from the 1980 national head count would have affected two House seats. Then-Census Director John G. Keane told a Senate subcommittee that the bureau estimated that it had counted 2 million illegal residents in 1980. Had those people not been counted, he said, New York and California would each have lost one House seat, with those seats going to Georgia and Indiana. Keane stressed, however, that his estimates were not accurate enough to use in actual reapportionments. To the Census Bureau it doesn't really matter. The Constitution simply directs them to count all the people residing in the country. A lot of illegal aliens will probably try to avoid the census anyway, officials acknowledge. Wary of government efforts to return them to their homelands, these people are often reluctant to deal with officials despite promises than any answers they give will be kept confidential.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Former President Nixon says that he expects historians to judge him more by Watergate than by his diplomatic overtures to China. ``Historians are more likely to lead with `He resigned the office,''' Nixon said in an interview in the latest issue of Time magazine. ``The jury has already come in, and there's nothing that's going to change it. There's no appeal. Historians will judge it harshly.'' Nixon discussed the Watergate break-in in his new book ``In the Arena,'' excerpted in the magazine. The former president said he made the ``inexcusable error'' of asking the CIA to block an FBI probe of the Watergate break-in, but that the CIA declined. Nixon said a decision by then-CIA Director Richard Helms and his deputy, Vernon Walters, to ignore the request discredits Watergate's ``most serious myth _ the one that ultimately forced me to resign:'' that the CIA in fact obstructed the FBI probe on his orders.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former Detroit Tigers pitcher Denny McLain says his past as a drug felon will never be forgotten, but he is enjoying life as a morning radio personality. ``It's going to be with me for the rest of my life. All I can do is say sorry and move on,'' said McLain, who recently signed a three-year contract with WXYT-AM in the Detroit area. ``I let a lot of people down. I work every day at repairing all the bridges.'' McLain, 45, was sentenced in 1985 to 23 years in prison for possessing 6.6 pounds of cocaine, loan-sharking and racketeering. He served 29 months in prison. McLain won the Cy Young Award during the Tigers' 1968 World Championship season. He became baseball's last 30-game winner that year.

Donald Trump is asking $8 million for ``Ivana,'' the sleek, black helicopter named for the wife he's divorcing. The chopper has served as the flagship of Trump's helicopter service between New York City and Atlantic City. Trump purchased the 10-seat Aerospatiale AS 332L Super Puma for about $2 million from Warner Communications when that company was cutting its flight operations three years ago. He customized the interior with trademark Trump touches, such as 24-carat gold plating on the seat belts, doorknobs and ashtrays. Linden Airport operator Paul Dudley said Trump has been offered $7 million for th aircraft but is holding out for $8 million.

Former Mayor Henry Cisneros will be host of a new syndicated series of TV specials featuring interviews with Texas celebrities. ``Texans,'' scheduled to debut in April, will be shown in Texas, New Mexico and Oklahoma. The first show will feature former Dallas Cowboys coach Tom Landry, country-western singer Janie Fricke and Dr. Red Duke, a trauma surgeon in Houston, executive producer Bob Phillips said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: He fought his last fight in 1981, but to many of his followers Muhammad Ali will always be the champ. Five hundred people lined up Saturday to get an autograph from the former heavyweight champion for a $20 fee. ``I'm still the greatest,'' the 48-year-old Ali said as he feigned a punch at a 10-year-old boy. ``I'm getting back into the game,'' he said in the autograph signing session at the Holiday Inn-Expo Center in suburban Chicago. ``George Foreman is going to beat Buster Douglas. Then I'm coming back and I'm going to take care of Foreman agin.'' Ali, dressed in a black silk suit with white pinstripes, said he is still on the go as a goodwill ambassador. Ali said he was in Indonesia last month and next month will travel to Australia. ``The aborigines are having a celebration and want me there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: US Policy Refocusing on Salvadoran Situation
DOC.TEXT: With Nicaragua and Panama added to the democratic column, U.S. policy in Central America is focusing anew on the hottest remaining trouble spot: tiny, war-torn El Salvador. A shadow version of El Salvador's conflict is being played out in Washington, between supporters of the current government who argue for more time to resolve the country's decade-old civil war, and opponents who want to immediately cut or attach strings to U.S. military aid. The issue has been taken to the streets as well as the halls of government. About 10,000 people calling for a halt to military aid marched in front of the White House on Saturday and 5,000 participated in a similar demonstration in San Francisco. Police arrested 83 protesters at the Washington march for demonstrating without a permit and blocking traffic. The clash over aid is occurring at a particularly delicate time in El Salvador. The two warring sides have agreed to come together for peace talks under United Nations auspices, and as a scheduled trial approaches for the military officers accused of murdering six Jesuit priests. In addition, the leftist FMLN rebels are under pressure as never before to make concessions. The electoral defeat last month of the Sandinista government in neighboring Nicaragua is expected to close off their most reliable military supply line. ``I honestly believe conditions have never been better in the history of this conflict than they are right now,'' Bernard Aronson, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs, said last week. ``I think we can end this war this year.'' But Aronson added: ``If it becomes politicized ... we will once again screw it up.'' Liberals on Capitol Hill claim broad support for an effort to impose strict new conditions on U.S. aid to El Salvador, which is among the largest per-capita recipients of American largesse. Military, economic, development and food aid total $315.4 million this year to the nation of 5 million, and President Bush has asked for about $375 million next year. Opponents contend that nearly $4 billion in aid over the past decade has not bought an end to the war that has claimed some 70,000 lives, and that the Salvadoran military remains beyond the control of the civilian government and prone to human rights abuses and death-squad activity. House supporters of aid restrictions are drafting legal language that would withhold half of the money that goes to the Salvadoran military _ $84.6 million this year, an expected $90 million next year _ and make its release dependent on both sides' behavior. The provision, a variation of legislation introduced in the Senate by Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., is aimed at adding pressure to keep both sides at the bargaining table and to minimize hostilities in the field. Those who would restrict the military aid see the potential for strong leverage with Bush if they succeed in adding their proposal to an $870 million supplemental appropriations bill the president is seeking to reward new democracies in Panama and Nicaragua. The administration believes that the new governments of President Guillermo Endara in Panama and President-elect Violeta Chamorro in Nicaragua could falter unless they are able to quickly demonstrate tangible benefits of democracy to their people. The aid would go to revitalize Panama's private sector and to plant spring crops and create jobs in Nicaragua's devastated economy. But with the backing of House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., the administration is hoping to defer any fight over U.S. policy toward El Salvador. When the Panama-Nicaragua bill came before the House Foreign Affairs Committee last week, Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., pleaded with liberals to attach their restrictive language to an aid measure for fiscal year 1991, rather than the emergency funding bill. Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, the panel's senior Republican, promised that Secretary of State James A. Baker III would come to Capitol Hill this week to hear the liberals' concerns. Fascell vowed that the fiscal 1991 aid bill would not become sidetracked, as a similar measure did last year. The bill-drafting session broke up without agreement, and is scheduled to resume on Tuesday. But regardless of the outcome there, the same issues are virtually certain to arise when the Panama-Nicaragua bill goes to the Senate sometime in the next two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Partisanship Returns to the House Floor
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Ever since Thomas Foley took over as its speaker last June, the House of Representatives has enjoyed uncommon cooperation and goodwill between the majority Democrats and minority Republicans. It appears this unnatural state of affairs is finally coming to an end. To the casual observer, the House chamber always seems a civil place, and that's not going to change. Lawmakers address each other as ``the gentleman from Kentucky'' or ``the distinguished gentlewoman from California.'' They can pile on the politeness, especially when angry. But there is a natural partisan tension behind the smiling facades. It isn't often the stuff of headlines, just a parliamentary bully match in which each side puts a finger on the chest of the other. This sort of partisanship peaked during former Speaker Jim Wright's reign. Toward the end, Wright was barely on speaking terms with Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. Near-monolithic Republican contempt for Wright helped hasten his resignation after the House ethics committee hit him with a list of charges. The ever-courteous Foley, D-Wash., was greeted by the Republicans in the House the way Mikhail Gorbachev has been received by Western Europe. The natural enemies began speaking warmly of each other. They held frequent ``summits'' on the issues of the day. Oh, there were some ideological battles, such as the fight over President Bush's capital gains tax. But the hallmark of the post-Wright House has been collaboration, culminating with bipartisan passage last fall of the big pay raise for House members. The GOP's leading Democrat-basher, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, capped the year with a resolution honoring Foley. The warm, snugly feeling lasted through Congress' long winter recess and almost into the spring. Then, last week, it began to crack. Foley, under election-year pressure to finish work on child care legislation, put the Democratic bill on last week's schedule. The measure wasn't ready, but he wanted to pressure his own Democrats to settle differences that had been delaying action since last year. Everyone from the speaker down to the doorkeepers recognized that the schedule was just a parliamentary ploy. Nevertheless, House Republicans who had gone too long without a good spat took offense that they weren't consulted about the schedule change. ``I think up until now that we thought we had been treated fairly ... as partners in the legislative process,'' said Rep. Robert Walker of Pennsylvania, a member of the GOP leadership. ``That partnership seems to have been unilaterally dissolved.'' The Republicans soon got revenge. Without fanfare, and without telling the Republicans, the House counsel asked the Supreme Court to delay until fall its consideration of the federal anti-flag burning statute that Congress passed last year. Two lower courts have ruled it unconstitutional. In the logic of politics, Republicans are hoping that the flag-protection law is thrown out _ the flag left unprotected _ before the fall elections. They then could force a House vote on a flag-protection constitutional amendment supported by President Bush. Many Democrats last year were willing to approve a flag-protection statute, but didn't want to alter the Constitution and especially the Bill of Rights. If the court throws out the law, Republicans then could attack them as unpatriotic unless they vote for the amendment. Michel, angry that he wasn't consulted before the counsel asked for a court delay, saw a political opportunity and introduced a resolution ordering the brief withdrawn. Democratic leaders tried to fight it, but their parliamentary maneuvering backfired. A series of House votes culminated in a 309-101 victory for Michel and a trouncing for Foley. The embarrassment brought the speaker to the House floor to defend his motives. ``I emphatically state that there was no political and is no political motive in the filing of this brief other than to undertake the fullest defense of a statute of this House,'' Foley said. He quickly met with the Republican leaders and a new brief was sent, minus the section on delaying court review. Michel, meeting with reporters after the vote, conceded the issue could have been handled ``much more simply.'' But then the Republicans would have been denied a chance to make the Democrats squirm, a morale-booster in short supply for the GOP minority. And Foley's Democrats wouldn't have learned something about the limits of their majority and party loyalty in the face of political threat. There's little threat that the House will soon return to the animosity of the days of Jim Wright. But perhaps the natural tension that keeps lawmakers sharp and the House an interesting place to watch has returned.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Steven Komarow has covered Congress for The Associated Press since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: 1989's Top Grossing Pictures
With PM-Oscars, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The following is a list of the top grossing movies of 1989 and the number of 62nd Academy Award nominations they received: 1. ``Batman,'' $251 million, one nomination _ art direction. 2. ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' $196 million, three _ musical score, sound and sound effects editing. 3. ``Lethal Weapon 2,'' $147 million, one _ sound effects editing. 4. ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' $130 million, none. 5. ``Rain Man,'' $126 million, 1988 release _ won 4 Oscars last year. 6. ``Look Who's Talking,'' $115 million, none. 7. ``Ghostbusters II,'' $112 million, none. 8. ``Parenthood,'' $96 million, two _ supporting actress, Dianne Wiest; original song, ``I Love to See You Smile.'' 9. ``Back to the Future Part II,'' $95 million, one _ visual effects. 10. ``Dead Poets Society,'' $95 million, four _ best picture; best actor, Robin Williams; best director, Peter Weir; best screenplay, Tom Schulman.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent's Departure Throws Connecticut Race Into Disarray
DOC.TEXT: Gov. William A. O'Neill's decision not to run for re-election is tempting various would-be Democratic successors and strengthening the hand of Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the former Republican senator. Weicker, running as an independent, is leading in the polls for what promises to be a tough three-way gubernatorial race. U.S. Rep. Bruce A. Morrison, a four-term liberal congressman, has been campaigning against O'Neill for several months on the Democratic side. O'Neill's moderate-to conservatives backers have been touting Rep. Barbara B. Kennelly, a popular four-term congresswoman who is the daughter of the late national Democratic Chairman John M. Bailey. But Kennelly has refused to run against Morrison, preferring to stay in Washington, where she is viewed as a rising star. None of the Democrats drawn into the race since O'Neill's announcement have significant statewide recognition. They include state Rep. William J. Cibes Jr. of New London, who announced two hours after O'Neill withdrew. His platform includes a proposal for a state income tax that has proved politically unfeasible in the past. O'Neill became governor on Dec. 31, 1980, when Gov. Ella T. Grasso resigned because of poor health. He was elected to four-year terms in 1982 and 1986. In withdrawing, O'Neill said he wanted to avoid the nasty campaign he assumed would be directed at him, chiefly for the way he has handled the state's crumbling finances. O'Neill and the Democrats who control the General Assembly raised taxes last year by almost $1 billion. Big deficit problems remain this year. The Republicans, who have won the governor's office only once since 1954, had dreams of victory with the vulnerable O'Neill as the Democratic candidate. But that was before Weicker, who lost a 1988 Senate re-election bid, announced his candidacy on March 2. During 18 years as a liberal Republican senator, Weicker pulled votes from among the state's 700,000 Democrats, 485,000 Republicans, and 600,000 unaffiliated voters. Other Demococrats mentioned as possible candidates include former West Hartford Mayor Christopher Droney, brother of state Democratic Chairman John F. Droney Jr.; Senate President Pro Tem John B. Larson of East Hartford; and state Treasurer Francisco L. Borges. Any candidate receiving the support of 20 percent of the delegates to the Democrats' summer convention can qualify for September's primary. Things are far quieter on the Republican front, where U.S. Rep. John G. Rowland, a three-term congressman, has been leading the race for months. His campaign has been based entirely on the O'Neill record. Now, he'll have to look elsewhere for issues. Two are ready made for him: Morrison's perceived liberal record in Congress and the tax increases of the past year in Hartford, shaped by some of the other Democrats thinking about running, including Cibes and Larson. Trailing far behind Rowland for the GOP nomination are state Senate Minority Leader Reginald J. Smith of New Hartford; Joel Schiavone, a millionaire developer from New Haven; and Joseph McGee, a bank vice president from Fairfield. Financial matters dominate the campaign. Abortion has not become much of an issue in this strong pro-choice state.

DOC.HEAD: California Tops Again in Farm Exports
DOC.TEXT: California was the top farm export state in 1989 for the fifth consecutive year, leading Nebraska, Iowa, Kansas, Texas and Illinois, according to Agriculture Department estimates. Analysts in the department's Economic Research Service listed California at the top of the export chart for the first time in 1985, replacing perennial winners Iowa and Illinois. California has many high-value crops such as fruits, nuts, vegetables and seeds. Thus, as foreign demand builds for those items, so do their export values. The ratings included the top 15 states during the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, when export values totaled nearly $39.7 billion, up from $35.4 billion in 1988. In all, the 15 states accounted for more than 71 percent of the total U.S. export value last year, about the same proportion as in 1988. Only Minnesota showed a decline last year, with the state's export value dropping 2 percent to about $1.76 billion from slightly more than $1.8 billion in 1988. ``The drop in Minnesota was mainly because of the emphasis the state puts on soybeans, and soybean export dropped tremendously,'' said analyst Steve Milmoe of the USDA agency. Milmoe, in a telephone interview, said total U.S. soybean export values dropped $1.2 billion last year from about $7 billion in 1988. Thus, Minnesota's share declined accordingly. Illinois, another huge soybean producer, was reported at $2.63 billion, virtually unchanged from 1988. The annual rankings are not meant to be absolute, since USDA does not monitor state origins as products move into export channels. Mostly, the estimates are based on an assumption that each state's contribution to exports is equal to its share of production and marketing. According to the report, last year's top 15 export states, in order, in millions of dollars, and their percentage increase (a decrease for Minnesota) from 1988, included: 1. California: 3,561; 5 percent. 2. Nebraska: 2,984; 41. 3. Iowa: 2,978; 5. 4. Kansas: 2,845; 22. 5. Texas: 2,640; 17. 6. Illinois: 2,638; unchanged. 7. Minnesota: 1,763; -2. 8. Indiana: 1,424; 3. 9. Washington: 1,242; 53. 10. Missouri: 1,225; 11. 11. Arkansas: 1,212; 34. 12. Ohio: 1,160; 6. 13. North Carolina: 918; 5. 14. Colorado: 884; 31. 15. Kentucky: 841; 15.

The Agriculture Department is amending federal regulations this week to allow the identification of swine shipped across state lines at the first point of concentration after leaving the farm. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said a final rule allowing the change will be published on Tuesday. Previously, he said, hog producers were responsible in many cases for identifying swine before the animals moved into interstate commerce. But the changes are necessary ``to provide for effective traceback of diseased or adulterated swine, without unnecessarily disrupting standard marketing procedures,'' Glosser said. Federal rules requiring the interstate identification of swine took effect in November 1988 to help the agency locate hogs infected with disease. An exception was made for hogs moving directly to slaughter plants from farrow-to-finish operations. The regulations define ``first points of concentration'' where identification may be performed. For example, Glosser said that could include the point of first gathering or commingling of swine from more than one source, such as a truck picking up hogs from different farms for delivery to market. Swine identified at this point could be traced directly back to herds of origin. Glosser said the rules also clarify the agency's list of approved devices used to identify swine in interstate commerce. The devices, used to identify hogs being shipped to slaughter plants, include tattoos and USDA backtags.

Maybe it won't rank with Madonna or Janet Jackson, but the producers of a new video about farming are hopeful. The 15-minute television production, ``America's Most Crucial Industry,'' was created by the Agriculture Department to inform groups of all ages about the contributions of the nation's agriculture. Paul E. Kindinger, the department's director of public affairs, said the video can be ``an excellent educational tool'' to help explain the immensity of the U.S. agricultural system. The video was written by Vic Powell, chief of USDA's radio and television division, and is narrated by Pat O'Leary, one of the division's television producers. Copies are available on half-inch VHS tape for $12 each from: Video Transfer, 5709-B Arundel Ave., Rockville, Md. 20852. Telephone 301-881-0270.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Policy on Forwarding Mail Comes Under Fire
DOC.TEXT: Elderly-rights advocates are battling a longstanding Postal Service policy they say treats nursing home residents like prisoners by denying them the right to have their mail automatically forwarded when they move. While other people may submit change-of-address cards to the local post office, nursing home residents _ like inmates _ must rely on the institution to write their new address on individual letters. The policy is being questioned by activists in Florida and Pennsylvania, and by members of a Senate panel. ``It would be much better if the post office could treat the nursing home residents like any other citizens,'' said Daniel Greenawalt, a state-employed ombudsman for the elderly in Pennsylvania. Since residents of a nursing home are at the same address, the Postal Service says the home should be ``the agent'' of their mail. The mail is delivered in bulk, like at a prison, and then distributed. Allowing nursing home residents to file address forwarding cards ``would mean the person doing the sorting in the postal facility has to have a record of each person in the nursing home, where there may be quite a deal of turnover _ not so much in moving but in departing this earth,'' Postal Service spokesman Lou Eberhardt said last week. When a resident moves, Eberhardt said, the nursing home need only write the new address on letters, and the Postal Service will redeliver the mail for free. ``I think it represents a minuscule problem for everyone concerned,'' Eberhardt said. ``If we didn't forward mail free of charge, it would then be an additional irritant. It's probably a very short period of time before correspondents are advised that the person has moved from one institution to another.'' Eberhardt said the service wanted to be flexible about the policy and could envision helping out, for example, in the event of a nursing home bankruptcy. But Sister Mary Gregoria Rush of the Roman Catholic Diocese of St. Petersburg, Fla., has been writing to the postmaster general and members of Congress to try to get the policy changed. She recalled the case of Virginia Killilae, a 96-year-old former circus publicist whose mail did not all follow her when she transferred from one Florida nursing home to another. Some of the letters were ``returned to sender'' because the post office did not accept a forwarding address card and the institution was not always cooperative, Sister Rush said. ``This lady had traveled all over the United States, and she had all her mail stacked up and the date she received it and answered it. But she spent many hours crying because she was so lonely,'' Sister Rush said. ``If I were a friend writing to a 96-year-old and I got `Return to Sender,' I'd assume she was dead.'' Republican staff members of the Senate Special Committee on Aging recently prepared a memorandum concluding that the Postal Service policy ``cannot be justified by arguments for the convenience or efficiency of the institution or the post office.'' As a result, Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., the panel's ranking Republican, told Postmaster General Anthony Frank in a letter last week: ``Mail service provides nursing home and mental health facility residents with important links to the outside world. I question whether these individuals should be classified with inmates, who have lost important civil rights, or with short-term hospital patients and other persons who maintain permanent addresses in the community.'' Heinz asked Frank to determine the cost of changing the policy. Heinz's letter is being considered by officials in the rates and forwarding section of the Postal Service, spokesman Eberhardt said.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Who Challenged License Law Turns 18; Eligible to Drive
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who challenged the nation's first law taking driving privileges from school dropouts becomes eligible to get his license back today, but he'll keep fighting the law. The West Virginia law, which has been copied by a number of states including Arkansas, Florida, Louisiana and Texas, suspends the driver's license of minors who continually cut class. Its effectiveness ends when the dropout turns 18, as Michael Means does today. ``If I have to work Monday, I'll work, but one of the main things on the list is going to get the license,'' Means said as his birthday approached. ``I think I'm just going to ride around the courthouse several hundred times.'' Means, who does odd jobs to support his family, expressed some remorse for leaving school early. ``I know I lost something I can never regain, but they think they can keep you in school by taking your license away and that's not very bright,'' Means said. ``You can't train kids like you can dogs by taking something away.'' The law was passed by the Legislature in 1988 to help curb the state's 17 percent dropout rate. It revokes students' licenses until they are 18 if they miss more than 10 consecutive days of school or have more than 15 unexcused absences. Means, a married father who gave up on a formal education at age 16, was among the first to become entangled in the law after he lost his license and applied for a new one. The Department of Motor Vehicles, citing the dropout law, refused to issue another license without the consent of the Kanawha County Board of Education. And the school board rejected Means' hardship argument that he was unable to support his family without driving. Means took the officials to court, but he lost in circuit court in August. He has appealed to the state Supreme Court, which is likely to hear the case in September. Means' attorney, Chris Butch, argues it is illogical to take a ``shotgun approach'' to force teen-agers to return to school, while at the same allowing them to drop out at age 16. Butch also argued the policy is discriminatory because rural youths, unlike city dwellers, lack access to public transportation. Means lives on the outskirts of Charleston. Despite the controversy, education officials say the law has helped trim the dropout rate to 16 percent. ``It's not the answer. It's another strategy we're using to help deal with the dropout program,'' said Therese Wilson of the state Department of Education. ``If we look at the number of kids who came back because of the law ... when over 300 come back, that's 300 kids we would not have gotten if it had not been for the law,'' she said. The law resulted in 687 suspensions for the 1988-89 school year, said Tom Madden, general counsel for the motor vehicle division. By the end of the year, nearly 250 of those teen-agers had their licenses reinstated by returning to school or enrolling in a high school equivalency degree program. Hardship exemptions were given to 43, and 157 dropouts got their licenses back when they turned 18. Madden said 376 suspensions have been issued during the current school year, and 74 young people got their licenses back by returning to school or enrolling in an equivalency-degree program. Means, who lives in his parents' home with his 17-year-old wife, also a dropout, and his 7-month-old son, said he would continue his fight even though he now is old enough to get a license. ``I guess the only thing I really want is my license back, but I just want to give other people a chance that don't have one,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's highly publicized distaste for broccoli will only increase consumption of the vitamin-rich vegetable, one proponent says. ``It's wonderful stuff. We sell tons of it,'' said William Quinn, produce manager for the Outpost Natural Foods supermarket. Asked if Bush's move to ban the vegetable from Air Force One's larder might affect sales of broccoli, Quinn said: ``Yes, among our customers, I think it will increase them.'' ``The man can't enjoy one of the best fruits of the earth,'' piped in Harriet Behar, whose Sweet Earth Farm near Gays Mills in southwestern Wisconsin markets about 15,000 broccoli plants annually. Bush's thumbs-down for broccoli made headlines when he told questioning reporters on Thursday, ``I do not like broccoli and I haven't liked it since I was a little kid and my mother made me eat it and I'm president of the United States and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli.''

Tommy Bengaff won $25,000 at a blackjack table in Atlantic City, and forked out $23,000 of it on his mother's 60th birthday bash. Melba Bengaff and 65 of her closest friends celebrated her birthday in grand style in a Bellevue Avenue mansion. Her 25-year-old son laid on a five-piece band, 20 chauffeured limousines and a $45-a-plate meal, put up five guests from New York City at a hotel and arranged a family vacation on the Caribbean island of Aruba. ``It's my mother's 60th birthday and she means the world to me,'' Bengaff said. ``You only have one mom. Mom and I are like brother and sister. I know if she had the money she'd do it for me.'' Bengaff, a $25,000-a-year manager at a grocery store in Cranston and owner of King's West Bay Limousine Service, said that last October ``it came into my mind that I wanted to do something big. I just didn't know where or how big.'' A three-hour visit at a blackjack table in Atlantic City on New Year's Eve took care of the money problem. ``My father told me to save it or put into an IRA, not to spend it on one night in Newport,'' Bengaff said.

A social worker paid $3,000 for the large wooden crate that was used to ship Charles Lindbergh's plane back to the United States after his historic flight to Europe in 1927. Larry Ross, 38, of Canaan, Maine, the executive director of a social service agency, said he is convinced the crate is historically significant. He wants to renovate it as a summer cottage. The crate has lain for years in woods near Contoocook, and has been used by passers-by in search of free housing. It has windows and a door, and at one time had electricity and a phone, but it has fallen into disrepair in recent years. ``It's not an awful lot to look at,'' said Ross, who plans to load up the crate early this week. Ross bought the crate from David Price Sr., who took possession of it five years ago when he bought the land from the grandson of Admiral Guy Burrage. Burrage's ship brought Lindbergh and the crate back to the United States. They became friends, the aviator gave him the crate and Burrage turned it into a summer cottage. Lindbergh made the first solo flight across the Atlantic Ocean from the United States to France in the Spirit of St. Louis. ``It struck me as a unique piece of Americana that has a certain New England eccentricity to it,'' Ross said. ``Some people look at me like, `Are you crazy?' Other people get a real charge out of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says Move on Lithuania Would Harm Superpower Relations
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says a Soviet military crackdown in Lithuania would ``undermine a lot of the good work'' done in recent years in improving U.S.-Soviet relations. Cheney said Sunday that a move to crush the independence movement in the Baltic republic would have ``significant negative consequences in terms of U.S.-Soviet relations'' on arms control and other issues. And he said it ``obviously would undermine a lot of the good work that's been done in recent years.'' ``We'd like to see the Lithuanians ... granted the same prerogative that the East Germans were: self-determination,'' Cheney said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' program. President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said Saturday that any Soviet use of force ``would be counterproductive'' and that the United States ``would not ignore it.'' Bush himself had no comment Sunday on the situation in Lithuania as he returned from a weekend at Camp David, his mountain retreat in Maryland. Soviet troops occupied two communist schools in Vilnius, capital of the Baltic state, on Sunday, one day after tanks rolled through the streets in the middle of the night. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Kremlin officials have been pressuring Lithuania's newly elected leaders to back off attempts to secede. Bush said Friday that any Soviet attempt to ``intimidate or forcibly intervene against the Lithuanian people is bound to backfire.'' The United States and the Western world have never recognized the Soviet Union's forcible annexation of Lithuania and its sister Baltic states, Estonia and Latvia, in 1940 as war swept over Europe. But the United States now says it will not grant formal recognition until the breakaway republic establishes control over its territory, and Bush has urged the Lithuanians to recognize ``certain realities'' about its relationship to Moscow. Asked if the United States had lured Lithuania into rebelling, Cheney said, ``We have not been out actively soliciting revolution, if you will. On the other hand, we've made it clear that we share the aspirations of the Lithuanian people for self-determination.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Attends Gala Honoring Ford's Theatre
DOC.TEXT: After sitting through 15 acts over 2{ hours in historic Ford's Theatre, President Bush quipped that Abraham Lincoln ``would have really enjoyed this program _ parts of it.'' The show was the annual presidential gala for Ford's Theatre itself, which drew a black-tie crowd of more than 500 on Sunday night, including Bush and his wife Barbara. The president's instant criticism evoked laughter. Bush also got a loud hand when Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., who was honored at the event, applauded the president's ``great statement ... in support of the arts.'' Bush said last Friday that he opposes efforts to write anti-pornography restrictions into the law governing grants by the National Endowment for the Arts. He said he was ``deeply offended by some of the filth'' that has gotten federal money, but rather than ``risk censorship,'' he trusts his NEA director, John Frohnmayer, to make the right judgments. Ford's is the theater where Lincoln was shot on the night of April 14, 1865, while attending a comedy. Bush, an avid theater-goer himself, recalled that Lincoln loved the performing arts. ``He loved entertainment. ... and I believe he would have really enjoyed this program _ parts of it,'' said Bush, to laughter and applause. The show featured such country talent as the Gatlin Brothers, guitarist Roy Clark and singer Tanya Tucker, crooner Tony Bennett and jazz singer Diane Schuur. Television's Valerie Harper and John Forsythe hosted the affair. Impersonator Jim Morris did impressions of both Bush and Ronald Reagan. He had Bush asking Solidarity's Lech Walesa a Polish light bulb joke (``He's an electrician _ he ought to know'') and a doddering Reagan confusing the Great Wall of China with the Berlin Wall. The show, entitled ``A Festival at Ford's,'' will be broadcast by the Turner Broadcasting System on July 4. Ford's Theatre, which was closed after Lincoln's assassination, was restored in 1968 as both a museum and an active theater. The box where Lincoln sat sits empty now, draped with flags and a picture of George Washington against the railing, as it was that night 125 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection To Begin In Guard-Biting Trial Of AIDS-Infected Inmate
DOC.TEXT: The trial of an AIDS-infected inmate accused of trying to spread the deadly disease by biting a guard marks a disturbing trend in criminal justice, according to some AIDS litigation experts. Jury selection was to begin today in Superior Court in the case of Gregory Smith, 26, who faces an attempted murder charge. ``There's never been a case of HIV being transmitted through a bite or saliva,'' said Larry Gostin, executive director of the American Society of Law and Medicine, which recently completed a nationwide AIDS litigation project for the U.S. Public Health Service. As a result, ``it's not a realistic attempted murder charge,'' he said. Gostin and others fear Smith's case will fuel hysterical fears of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Smith is one of 10 prisoners around the country charged last year with trying to kill or injure law enforcement officers by infecting them with AIDS, according to Judy Greenspan, information director for the American Civil Liberties Union's National Prison Project in Washington, D.C. ``Most unfortunately, this is an alarming trend in the criminal justice system,'' said Ms. Greenspan, who tracks AIDS-related cases for the ACLU. ``The whole fact that prisoners who are HIV-infected are being treated differently in the courts is a very serious problem.'' AIDS, an affliction that attacks the body's immune system, is most often transmitted through sexual contact and among people who share needles while abusing drugs. Its spread in this country began among gay men. It also can be transmitted through transfusions of blood or blood products. Medical experts say it is unlikely that the virus can be transmitted by biting. Smith was indicted last summer by a county grand jury on attempted murder charges after he allegedly bit a guard three times on the hand on June 11. The guard was trying to put Smith into a patrol car to transport him back to the jail after he underwent treatment for a back injury at Cooper Medical Center. Smith, who was serving a five-year sentence for a robbery conviction, allegedly yelled, ``Now die, you pig,'' prosecutors said. The officer was not wearing protective gear or gloves _ although Smith was known to have tested positive for the AIDS virus. Smith has denied biting the guard. Shortly after the incident, he was transferred to Trenton State Prison. Assistant Camden County Prosecutor Harold Kasselman, who is handling the case, declined to be interviewed last week, citing concern over pretrial publicity. Smith's attorney did not return telephone calls seeking comment. Over 100 lawsuits have been filed against AIDS-infected individuals charging them with attempting to spread the disease through biting, spitting, throwing feces or splattering blood, according to Gostin. Other cases include: _ An infected Minnesota inmate was convicted of assault with a deadly weapon after biting a guard. A federal appeals court upheld the conviction. _ A Centre County, Pa., inmate was convicted of assault after throwing feces on a state prison guard. The conviction has been appealed. _ An attempted suicide victim in Indiana who threw blood at emergency personnel was convicted of three counts of attempted murder and sentenced to 120 years imprisonment. The verdict was set aside by the trial judge, but reinstated at the appellate level. The case is pending before the Indiana Supreme Court. ``In some ways it's almost akin to sticking a pin in a voodoo doll and hoping that someone will die,'' said Gostin, an associate professor at Harvard's School of Public Health. Prosecution of the inmates constitutes ``pretty much a a travesty of the legal system,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,840.49, up 1,468.33 points, or 4.83 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: First Novel Written by a Black Depicts Racism in the North
LaserPhoto CR1
DOC.TEXT: The first American novel known to be written by a black person described racism in the North just before the Civil War, an unwelcome message that may have helped keep the 1859 book obscure, researchers said. ``I think it's the kind of statement that white New Hampshire resents in 1990,'' said Barbara White, an associate professor of women's studies at the University of New Hampshire. ``Think of what people would have thought in 1859.'' Harriet E. Wilson's ``Our Nig'' also depicts hypocrisy among white abolitionists and, for the first time in American literature, a successful interracial marriage. The book was published again in 1983, and more recently has attracted attention from researchers, like White, who are trying to find out more about the author. White plans to make her research public sometime this summer. Published in Boston under a pseudonym identical to the title, the book's lengthy subtitle doesn't mince words: ``Sketches from the Life of a Free Black, In a Two-Story White House, North. Showing That Slavery's Shadows Fall Even There.'' The title itself undoubtedly ruffled feathers at the time, White said. ``People who ordinarily would've been sympathetic to a black woman writing a narrative weren't going to be sympathetic to that,'' she said. Cornell University professor Henry Louis Gates has written that Wilson ``dared to entitle her text with the most feared and hated epithet by which the very humanity of black people had been demeaned.'' Gates discovered an original edition of ``Our Nig'' in a Manhattan book store when he was a graduate student. He traced it to Wilson with the help of several locals, including Amherst librarian Erna Johnson and Milford town clerks Nancy Schooley and Helen Draper. Milford, where Wilson lived in the 1840s, was known to have had an active abolitionist community. Gates said ``Our Nig'' not only would have offended whites, but also blacks who feared it would hurt the anti-slavery movement. ``That such a significant novel, the very first written by a black woman, would remain unnoticed in Boston in 1859, a veritable center of abolitionist reform and passion, and by a growing black press eager to celebrate all black achievement in the arts and sciences, remains one of the troubling enigmas of Afro-American literary history,'' Gates wrote. But Melvin Dixon, a professor of Afro-American literature at Queens College in New York, said he believes the relative obscurity of black authors in general _ not the book's views _ played a major role in keeping the book little known. ``White readers were not taking seriously the writing of Afro-American scholars,'' Dixon said. White said she is still establishing basic facts about Wilson, like her birth and death dates. She also is trying to determine whether a real family was the white family depicted in ``Our Nig.'' ``Our Nig'' is the story of Frado, daughter of a white woman and a black man, raised as a servant by a white family in the fictitious community of Singleton, N.H. Abandoned by her impoverished mother at a young age, Frado grows up working for the Bellmont family and suffering verbal abuse and beatings at Mrs. Bellmont's hands. Wilson wrote that Frado was ``maltreated by professed abolitionists who didn't want slaves in the South, nor niggers in their own houses North'' and could not bear ``to lodge one; to eat with one; to admit one through the front door; to sit next one; awful!'' Later, Frado all but abandons her faith, and decides that if Mrs. Bellmont is going to heaven, she'd rather go to hell. Elsewhere, Frado asks the kindly James Bellmont, ``Who made me so?'' James answers, ``God.'' ``Who made your mother?'' Frado persists. ``God.'' ``Did the same God that made her make me?'' ``Yes.'' ``Well then I don't like him.'' ``Why not?'' ``Because he made her white and me black. Why didn't he make us both white?''

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Released From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater is home from the hospital after physicians adjusted the medication he is taking for a brain tumor, an aide said. Atwater, 39, was released Sunday after undergoing a radiation treatment the day before at George Washington University Hospital, said Leslie Goodman, a spokeswoman for the Republican National Committee. He had been admitted on Friday complaining of queasiness, she said. ``He's home and is in good spirits again,'' Ms. Goodman said Sunday. ``He said he was feeling fine.'' A small, non-malignant tumor was discovered earlier this month on the right side of Atwater's brain after he collapsed during a speech. He is taking radiation treatments five days a week to reduce the tumor. Atwater was named head of the RNC after managing George Bush's presidential campaign in 1988.
DOC.HEAD: Jail Cells More Crowded Despite New Construction
DOC.TEXT: Crowding increased at local jails between 1983 and 1988 as new construction failed to keep pace with a 54 percent jump in the number of prisoners, the Justice Department says. The amount of space for each inmate shrunk 6 percent from 54.3 square feet in 1983 to 50.9 square feet in 1988, despite a 43.7 percent increase in total jail space, according to a study released Sunday by the department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. A census of the nation's 3,316 jails found that on June 30, 1988, there were 341,636 prisoners living in 17.4 million square feet of space. Five years earlier, 223,272 inmates occupied 12.1 million square feet. The bureau's study found that 28 percent of the nation's jails in 1988 housed more than 40 percent of their inmates in cells smaller than the standard of 60 square feet recommended by the American Correctional Association. In 1983, only 23 percent of the jails housed inmates in cells smaller than the standard. The proportion of jails placing five or more people in a ``housing unit'' increased from 24 percent in 1983 to 28 percent in 1988, the study said, and the average occupancy rose from 2.4 inmates per unit to 2.5 inmates. In 1988, 61 percent of all jail inmates lived in the most crowded facilities.
DOC.HEAD: Agent Orange Study Expected This Week
DOC.TEXT: A study expected to be released this week will help determine officially whether Vietnam veterans who were exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange suffered cancers and other ailments as a result. The study by the federal Centers for Disease Control, which the Veterans Affairs Department says will be released Thursday, examines the incidence of five kinds of cancer among Vietnam vets. It is another step in a 12-year battle to gain benefits for veterans who blame the powerful foliage killer for cancers, skin disease and miscarriages in their spouses. VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski last Novemer said he would postpone a determination on whether to award benefits until after the study was completed. Following its release, the study must be reviewed by a VA advisory committee of outside scientists. Derwinski will make a determination at the end of May after the committee meets, VA spokesman Don Smith said last week. Final rules should be in place in October. The decision also could influence legislation in Congress requiring compensation to veterans. Nearly 35,000 claims have been filed citing Agent Orange, which was sprayed to remove foliage and kill crops, as a cause of disabilities. An additional 230,000 veterans have told VA they were exposed to the herbicide, which contained highly toxic dioxin and other suspected harmful ingredients. The new Selected Cancers Study by the CDC in Atlanta does not look at whether veterans were exposed to Agent Orange. According to the VA, the new study will determine whether Vietnam veterans are at higher risk of developing soft-tissue sarcoma, lymphoma and nasal, nasopharyngeal and liver cancer. The study began in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Six `Flags' For Skin Cancer
DOC.TEXT: People with one or more of six characteristics run higher than normal risks of getting the deadliest form of skin cancer, a new study suggests. Because of its high curability in early stages, and the ease in identifying likely susceptible people, ``no one should die from melanoma,'' said researcher Darrell Rigel of New York University. Melanoma is expected to kill 6,300 Americans this year, according to the American Cancer Society. Some 27,600 new cases of melanoma, caused chiefly by excessive exposure to the sun, are expected this year. Rigel described the new study Sunday at a science writers conference sponsored by the cancer society. The work included data from 200 people with or without melanoma, and considered 43 possible factors that might have been found to contribute to the disease. Six factors appeared to raise the risk of melanoma: blond or red hair; marked freckling of the upper back; the presence of rough red bumps on the skin called actinic keratoses that come from sun exposure; a history of other family members with melanoma; a history of three or more blistering sunburns during the teen-age years; and having spent three or more years at an outdoor summer job as a teen-ager. Having any one or two of these factors gives a person a three to four times increased chance of developing melanoma, the study suggested. The combination of three or more factors gave an increase of 20 to 25 times, Rigel said. The overall risk of getting melanoma for Americans is estimated to be about one in 120, Rigel said. It was one in 250 in 1980 and is forecast to be one in 90 in the year 2000, he said. Scientists blame much of the trend on increases in the time people spend on the beach, and skimpier swimsuits. Because melanoma takes 10 to 20 years to appear after damage from the sun, Rigel said, the behavior of people in the 1960s and 1970s has only recently begun to show up in melanoma rates. Lawrence Garfinkel, the cancer society's vice president for epidemiology and statistics, said previous research gives ``good evidence'' to support the conclusions of Rigel's study of risk factors. Rigel said people at high risk of melanoma should learn the so-called ``ABCD'' method of identifying melanoma early. The ``A'' refers to the asymmetry of melanoma's mole-like growth, in which one half does not match the other. ``B'' stands for border irregularity, because the edges of the growth are ragged, notched or blurred. ``C'' refers to color, which varies within the growth. And ``D'' stands for the growth's diameter of greater than six millimeters, about the size of a pencil eraser. Rigel said research suggests that if melanoma is detected while the lesions are still thinner than about one thirty-second of an inch, the 15-year survival rate is about 98 percent. In contrast, if lesions are more than about one-eighth of an inch thick when the cancer is discovered, the survival rate is about 53 percent, he said. Melanoma spreads to other parts of the body more quickly than many other cancers, he said. A melanoma growth that is the size of a dime has probably already spread cancer cells elsewhere, he said. In a separate presentation, another researcher said experimental treatments that use the body's disease-fighting immune system show some promise against melanoma in early studies. One approach uses a ``theraccine,'' an abbreviation of ``therapeutic vaccine,'' so-named because it aims to fight cancer rather than prevent disease, said Malcolm Mitchell of the University of Southern California School of Medicine in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Workplace Schools: Youngsters Go to School Where Parent Works
DOC.TEXT: A three-year-old program under which youngsters go to school where mom or dad works is going strong in Miami, helping employers attract and keep working parents. ``I think the way society is going right now, it's almost a necessity in very many situations,'' said Joseph Reynolds, a Pan Am worker who each day drives his son Brian home from first grade at the satellite learning center at Miami International Airport. His wife, Linda, another Pan Am employee, takes Brian to school in the morning. Dade County operates the satellite schools, which are built by major employers for employees' children at the airport, a suburban insurance company and a community college. Three other Florida cities have schools in place or in the works, and inquiries have come from as far as Japan and Australia. New York City schools Chancellor Joe Fernandez, the former superintendent of Dade County schools, earlier this month proposed setting up satellite schools in Manhattan office buildings. The Miami program, designed for kindergarten to second grade, has gotten some rave reviews. The three satellite schools, with 160 children enrolled in six classes, help the district with overcrowding, capital outlays and transportation costs because parents are responsible for driving their children, say school officials. Employers say turnover, absenteeism and tardiness are down, while productivity and morale are up. ``It changes the attitudes of the workers. Their attention at the job site changes because they don't have to worry about where their children are,'' said Dade County School Board Chairman William Turner. About the only drawback, some say, is that the mini-school students are not exposed to the ``big school'' assemblies, big libraries and other benefits that come with size. There is only one class per grade at each satellite school. At American Bankers Insurance Group, absenteeism is 25 percent less for employees with children in the company's day care and satellite school, said Philip J. Sharkey, senior vice president of human resources. Companywide turnover was 14.5 percent last year but only 5 percent for parents with children in the programs. Recruitment is easy. ``Tardiness among those employees has almost become non-existent,'' he said. ``That all translates to better productivity within the organization.'' Under the program in Miami, the 280,000-student district provides the staff and teaching materials. The employer can spend up to $350,000 on the school building and is responsible for maintenance and utilities. The next satellite schools are expected to open in September at a suburban hospital and a downtown government office tower. ``Anywhere you have a skilled female work force, you've got to have it,'' said Joe Tekerman, executive assistant to the superintendent in Dade schools. He sees hospitals as a natural site, saying: ``In years to come, that'll be a perk. They won't be able to get nurses if they don't have child care or a satellite learning center.'' The question of student performance is still an unknown. Second-graders take the first formal standarized tests used for comparison, and the inaugural second-grade class at American Bankers will be tested this spring. But satellite schoolteachers boast that their parent-teacher meetings often draw perfect attendance, compared to a teacher's estimate of 30 percent at her previous suburban school. ``Academically, they will have achieved more than most elementary school kindergartners have achieved, and I attribute that to parental involvement,'' said Thomasine Morris, kindergarten teacher and administrator at the airport school. At American Bankers, where everyone from a vice president to a maintenance worker has a child enrolled, Sharkey sees pluses all around. ``The program is outstanding,'' he said. ``There really are no negatives. The school district likes it, the corporation likes it, the parents like it, and most importantly the children like it. It really has been a phenomenal success, far more than anyone realized.''
