DOC.HEAD: Mongolia's Hidden Dissidents Break Silence
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Boshigt this month became Mongolia's first Communist Party member to hand in his membership card, ending a lifetime of waiting to speak out against political repression. ``I had to wait for favorable conditions,'' the 49-year-old physician said in an interview, speaking fluent English. He had waited for decades. Boshigt joined the ruling Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party even though it had purged his physician father. He worked for the semi-official Peace and Friendship Association, acting as Mongolia's liaison to Socialist international groups such as the African-Asian Solidarity Committee. For the scholarly, soft-spoken Boshigt, as for many Mongolians, the time to speak came last fall. ``With all this democratic change in East European countries and the perestroika policy this was the time to do something,'' he said, referring to the reform policies of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Boshigt, who uses just one name, said he met like-minded supporters of reform in this longtime Soviet client state wedged between China and the Soviet Union. He and the young intellectuals organized their first rally days later, on International Human Rights Day, Dec. 10. Thus was born the Mongolian Democratic Association, the nation's first opposition group in nearly seven decades. ``Always (before) there were people who wanted to do something,'' the physician said. ``It was impossible.'' His father, Gongorjav, was jailed for several years then banished to the countryside when he objected to replacing Mongolia's ancient script with the Cyrillic letters used in the Soviet Union. But voices of protest remained few and unorganized. Mongolia never developed a dissident community with its own literature and mutual support network. That is why the speedy and effective organization of the Democratic Association came as such a surprise to Mongolians. By mid-March, it claimed 70,000 members in 17 branches nationwide and tens of thousands more supporters for its program of democratic reforms. ``There is a scientific base, a logic'' to the association's program, said Boshigt, who became one of the group's chief strategists. ``That is why we are going on so smoothly.... ``The only thing we accept from Marxism-Leninism is its scientific methodology.'' Mongolia's economic and political problems must be solved pragmatically, he said, resorting not to ``isms'' but a careful study of the country's past, much of which was labeled feudal and blotted out of history books by the Communists. Mongolia ``had a basis for building a society. We had political, cultural, religious traditions. Why should we cancel all that by building socialism?'' Determined to let young intellectuals take the lead, Boshigt stepped out of his mentor role only twice _ when he joined younger activists in a three-day hunger strike this month, and when he turned in his party card. ``They strongly criticized me in Unen,'' the party newspaper, he said. When the Communists staged their own rally March 11, some carried a banner that read ``Boshigt a traitor.'' A second intellectual of Boshigt's generation, economist P. Nerguye, later followed suit. Many other ruling party members have kept their cards even while joining or helping the Democratic Association or other new opposition groups. But the physician said he has not been harassed by authorities. He dismissed younger association members' dire predictions the government may still use force to crush the opposition. The Communists and the government they have long controlled have shuffled their top ranks in response to the opposition pressure, but have yet to provide legal guarantees of political freedom. Boshigt said the Communists remain strong, with their control of the media and bureaucracy _ perhaps strong enough to win hoped-for multiparty elections this year. But he said: ``You cannot stop the young people, because they really hate this Stalinist regime. There was no one I had to convince. All were ready to give anything to end it.''

As Oscars Approach, Calm Reigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf, `Already, the...' to remove INCORRECT statement that `Henry V' nominated for best picture. Picks up 18th graf, `Videocassettes for...
DOC.TEXT: Tom Hanks brought his kids, Dan Aykroyd wore shorts and Paula Abdul couldn't stop giggling. Tonight's 62nd Annual Academy Awards were a day away, and the pressure was mounting. Yet the final rehearsal Sunday for the Oscar ceremony had all the gravity of a frog-jumping contest. With overcast skies in the forecast and overanxious fans settling in the bleachers outside, Oscar presenters Hanks, Aykroyd, Abdul, Tom Selleck, Gregory Peck, Jane Fonda, Jeff Bridges and Jessica Tandy playfully practiced their corny award introductions. About 500 family, friends and related hangers-on settled into the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion to hear the patter. Chevy Chase joked with a rotund Aykroyd that Chase should have been nominated for his work in ``National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation.'' And so it went. One camera operator was so bored by the proceedings that he spent the better part of an hour scanning the Sunday comics. Other technicians collapsed on a couch to watch NCAA tournament basketball. The producer of this year's Oscar show is Gilbert Cates. He has been asked to avenge the legacy of last year's Las Vegas-like celebration of Oscar glitz. This year's show will feature muted tones and conservative production numbers. In one of the most daring departures from tradition, Bugs Bunny will present the Oscar for best animated short film. ``I hope the outfits people wear are more spectacular than the sets,'' said rehearsal watcher Linda Alexander. An estimated 1 billion viewers in 90 countries will tune into the ABC telecast to see if ``Born on the Fourth of July'' can triumph over its own hype and four other acclaimed films. The world will be watching, too, to see if ``Fourth of July'' star Tom Cruise is more popular than Daniel Day-Lewis from ``My Left Foot.'' All of the advertising, primping and interviewing is over. The only drama that remains _ outside of what Cher will wear _ is whose names are hiding in the envelopes. The Academy Awards are wrapped in fancy clothes, ornate parties and elaborate production numbers. But the glitz only obscures a common, rather artless pursuit: winning. In an industry where good accounting often is more important than good acting, the Oscars now represent the ultimate marketing tool. The motion picture studios spend combined millions on Academy Award vote campaigns, and not because acceptance speeches are fun to watch. Oscar trophies mean money. After winning last year's best picture prize, ``Rain Man'' went on to make $36 million more in theaters. In four of the last seven years, the best picture winner has been one of the top five highest-grossing films of the year, according to Entertainment Data Inc. Best picture nominee ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' one of the Oscar favorites, is wilting at the box office. An Oscar would certainly brighten its future. Already, Oscar nominations have given new life to two independent films, ``My Left Foot'' and ``Henry V,'' still playing strongly months after their debut. Videocassettes for ``Dead Poets Society'' and ``Field of Dreams,'' also up for best picture, have been shipped to stores. An Oscar triumph would give each a kick in the pants. Prognosticators are split over predictions for the top five categories. The favorites for best picture, according to critics and oddsmakers, are ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' If Aykroyd wins for best supporting actor, it could be ``Driving Miss Daisy's'' night. If Brenda Fricker takes the early award for best supporting actress, the ceremony may belong to ``My Left Foot.''

DOC.HEAD: Utah Homosexuals Claim Victory as Holocaust Exhibit Opens
DOC.TEXT: Gay activists claimed victory after an international exhibit about the Holocaust opened with references to homosexual victims of Nazi persecution that some Utah education officials had wanted removed. About 200 homosexuals and civil libertarians rallied outside the exhibit Sunday, then walked to a nearby Episcopal cathedral for a Holocaust memorial. Many wore on their lapels the pink triangle, which the Nazis used to tag homosexuals and the gay rights movement has appropriated as its symbol. ``No one is allowed to rewrite history,'' said Robert Austin, who said he represented a loose-knit coalition of Utah gay and human rights organizations. ``I want you to know that not one word has been deleted. We won.'' Utah Office of Education officials earlier this month told Orem-based Geneva Steel Co., the corporate sponsor of ``The World of Anne Frank: 1928-1945,'' that references to homosexual Holocaust victims in materials given to teachers and guides might violate a state law prohibiting promotion of homosexuality in schools. The company, in turn, deleted two pages dealing with the treatment of homosexuals after Adolf Hitler's rise to power in 1933. Thousands of homosexuals were rounded up and sent to concentration camps where they were often castrated, exterminated or worked to death. A third page showed the pink triangle surrounded by the words ``Gays Against Facism,'' and a brief history of how the symbol was adopted by the gay liberation movement in the 1970s. School officials worried the reference might be construed as promulgating homosexuality and asked that it be removed. Protests from homosexuals, Utah's Jewish community and others resulted in the materials being restored. School board and Geneva officials called the incident a misunderstanding. The exhibit contains more than 600 photographs depicting the life and times of the young Jewish girl whose diaries have been read by millions since she perished in a concentration camp in 1945. Only a single caption refers to the persecution of homosexuals under Nazi rule. Officials said nobody wanted that reference removed. Cornelius Suijk, international director of the Anne Frank exhibit, said he found the incident ``unfortunate,'' but understood how it occurred. ``You have to remember that it took 20 years before homosexuals in Holland were allowed to take part in the annual Holocaust remembrance,'' he said. ``But they were victims of Hitler and should be memorialized.'' Suijk, who was accompanying the exhibit throughout its 38-city tour, said Geneva officials have made every effort to maintain the exhibit's integrity. The exhibit opened at noon Sunday at the City-County Building and in the evening, homosexuals and others held a ceremony to honor homosexual Holocaust victims outside. Michele A. Parish-Pixler, executive director of the Utah Chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, congratulated Utah homosexuals for risking their anonymity _ and in some cases their livelihoods _ in protesting the deletions. ``If the fear is not allowed to grow, we won't find ourselves being hauled off to concentration camps,'' she said. ``We cannot let past oppressions be smothered under a blanket of silence.'' The gathering marched to the nearby Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. Mark for a Holocaust memorial, where Bishop Michael Coburn asked for prayers not just for those who died in the death camps, but for victims of discrimination worldwide. Geneva President Joseph A. Cannon, who was critical of the deletions when he learned of them, said prior to the opening of the exhibit that his company was committed to an accurate portrayal of history, including the Nazi persecution of homosexuals. ``All in all it's been a good experience,'' he said. ``Basically I'm just president of a steel company, but I've had a lot of nice letters from the gay community.''

DOC.HEAD: Glittering Parties Celebrate Hollywood's Exercise in Vanity
With PM-Oscars, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tacky, vapid and glamorous, Hollywood's big Oscar night out gives stars a chance to party and fans an irresistible opportunity to gaze at the brightest newcomers as well as the tarnished has-beens. Filmdom's exercise in vanity has become an unabashed rite of spring where vulgarity often meets good taste. Will Cher wear a tattoo-revealing outfit? Will bubbly Allan Carr show up? Reclusive Marlon Brando? Rob Lowe? Snow White? While a world TV audience focuses on the horse race inside the 2,800-seat Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, thousands of back-slapping voyeurs will gather at who's-who galas at Spago, the Mondrian Hotel, Vertigo and Nicky Blair's. Movie academy president Karl Malden made it clear in recent weeks that ``the tickets are already gone'' for the pavilion bash. ``There are lots of great awards night parties around town, many of which benefit worthy charities. Please consider enjoying the show at one of those this time around,'' Malden said in an open letter in industry trade papers. Oscar winners, losers and the industry's upper strata of movers and shakers will step outside the pavilion into a white circus tent for the prestigious after-show Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences Governor's Ball. Compliments will spew and deals will be discussed, but the Oscar winners themselves will indulge in only brief conversations for what will become a whirlwind evening for those crowned the best by their peers. Kevin Kline lingered for hours at the ball last year, but winner Jodie Foster couldn't wait to down pizza at literary agent Irving ``Swifty'' Lazar's party at Spago. Lazar's is the ``in'' event. Nicky Blair's restaurant, another haute spot, plans a comparatively subdued affair, two dinner seatings with giant TV screens in the dining rooms. Former President Reagan and wife, Nancy, the royalty of Hollywood's black-tie circuit, will not be part of the ceremony or any big-screen TV party audience. They will watch the Academy Awards in their Bel Air home, allowing them to watch the pre-Oscar appetizer ``The Barbara Walters Special'' and her rare interview with Reagan neighbor Warren Beatty. Fans and papparazzi by the hundreds will gather outside the parties to hoot, holler and take snapshots of those alighting from a fleet of limousines. The young and hip will gather downtown at the Vertigo nightclub, which boasts such party guests as Oscar-nominee Oliver Stone, actor James Woods and Frank Zappa's kids, Dweezil and Moon Unit. For the socially conscious, Stephen Stills, Rita Coolige and Dr. John will perform at the Mondrian Hotel party on the Sunset Strip benefiting El Rescate, a group that helps Central American refugees. Fans-a-plenty doubtlessly will ring the entrance for arrivals of such stars as Johnny Depp, Kris Kristofferson, Roseanne Barr, Jane Fonda, Richard Gere, Bonnie Raitt and Robin Williams. At the Directors Guild of America headquarters, the AIDS Hospice Foundation party features celebrity sign-ins to raise money for those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

DOC.HEAD: Canterbury's Retirement Starts Succession Struggle
DOC.TEXT: Maneuvering to select a new leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans began today after the Archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie, announced he was resigning. One newspaper said today the battle for succession, which involves the prime minister, church leaders and the monarch, was likely to be the ``most divisive this century.'' The process was expected to take six months or more. It is widely expected Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher will want to appoint someone more in step with her conservative views than the liberal prelate, who said he would retire in January. Runcie made his announcement after morning service at Canterbury Cathedral on Sunday, the 10th anniversary of his enthronement as the 102nd archbishop since St. Augustine in 597. ``I am resigning now because it is 10 years and I think it is time to leave and hand over to somebody else,'' he said.``That takes a bit of time in the Church of England, so I judged that the beginning of next year was the best time to go.'' Under church rules bishops must retire by their 70th birthday, but Runcie, who will be 70 on Oct. 2, 1991, is giving up the post eight months early. The church recommends who should occupy the throne of Augustine as spiritual head of the state Church of England and leader of all Anglicans, including 2.5 million American Episcopalians. The Crown Appointments Commission _ set up by the church's governing General Synod _ consults the Anglican Communion's 27 self-governing churches worldwide, then submits two names to the prime minister. The prime minister is expected to choose the commission's first choice but may choose either candidate or suggest her own. Queen Elizabeth II, the head of the Church of England, will make the formal appointment. In theory, any Anglican bishop can be appointed, but the Church of England is more likely to choose an English bishop, who church leaders feel would be more in touch with the faith's internal workings and personalities. Speculation about possible successors touched on Richard Harries of Oxford, David Sheppard of Liverpool, Michael Baughen of Chester, John Taylor of St. Albans and Colin James of Winchester. Relations between the archbishop and Mrs. Thatcher's governing Conservative Party have been strained. Runcie and many other 42 diocesan bishops have been critical of the government's conservative economic and social policies. Runcie preached forgiveness at the end of the Falklands war with Argentina in 1982, offered support to striking miners during a yearlong strike and appealed for the Conservatives to do more for the homeless. He has been credited with holding together the Anglican church during bitter disputes over allowing women priests and church tolerance of homosexuality. The Church of England refuses to admit women to the priesthood, but other Anglican churches including the United States, Canada and New Zealand, support women's ordination. Runcie also has said he supports ordaining women. In addition, evangelicals within the church argue against the tolerance of homosexuality shown by the Anglo-Catholic high churchmen. The Times of London said today Runcie's announcement ``launched the church into a period of intense infighting and uncertainty.'' The paper said the battle for succession ``is likely to be the most divisive this century and the prime minister will find herself having to arbitrate between factions who regard the possession of the church's leadership by their camp as vital.'' Runcie's spokeswoman, Eve Keatley, said the prelate and his wife, Rosalind, a concert pianist, would retire to St. Albans, where they recently bought a home.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Contenders In Hungary's Election
With PM-Hungary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are brief profiles of the main parties contesting Hungary's Sunday parliamentary elections:
DOC.HEAD: The Hungarian Socialist Party:
DOC.TEXT: Formed Oct. 7, 1989 by leading Communist reformers who embraced multiparty democracy and declared their old Communist party defunct. Advocates Western European socialism, gradual transition to market economy mixing state and private ownership, westward-looking foreign policy while maintaining good relations with Soviets and other eastern European nations. Membership: 60,000. Party chairman: Rezsoe Nyers. Top Candidates: Imre Pozsgay, who spearheaded Hungary's reform drive; Gyula Horn, the current foreign minister who tops popularity polls; Miklos Nemeth, the current premier; Matyas Szueroes, the interim president.
DOC.HEAD: The Hungarian Democratic Forum:
DOC.TEXT: Loosely formed Sept. 17, 1987 by a diverse group of intellectuals, artists, and a few former Communists. Center-right party espousing Christian values and emphasizing Hungarian traditions. Favors gradual evolution to market economy with some mixed ownership and limited foreign investment, state support for those worst hit by the changes. In foreign policy, seeks improved ties with Europe, particularly continued strong ties with West Germany. Membership: 21,000. Party chairman: Jozsef Antall, the party's candidate for premier. Top candidates: Antall.
DOC.HEAD: League of Free Democrats:
DOC.TEXT: Formed Nov. 13, 1988, by dissidents of the 1970s and 1980s. Liberal, backs more rapid transformation to a market economy with emphasis on privatization of state-owned property and private enterprise. Seeks closer economic and political ties with the West, closer political links with central Europe without ignoring Moscow. Membership: 20,000. Party chairman: Janos Kis. Top candidates: Ivan Petoe, Laszlo Rajk, Balint Magyar.
DOC.HEAD: Independent Smallholders' Party:
DOC.TEXT: Reestablished Nov. 18, 1988. Originally founded in 1930, it was forced out of existence by the Communists after World War II. Strong rural base, espouses Christian, nationalist values. It wants to return land confiscated by the Communists to its original owners. Membership: 60,000. Party chairman: Vince Voeroes, who belonged to the party when it was part of a coalition government before the Communists' takeover. Top candidates: Voeroes.
DOC.HEAD: The League of Young Democrats:
DOC.TEXT: Formed March 30, 1988 by mostly college-educated young professionals. Liberal party favoring market economy, but urging orderly transition to private ownership and some worker control of enterprises through shareholding. Seeks improved ties with Western Europe and surrounding countries. Membership: over 5,000. Party chairmen: Victor Orban, Tamas Deutsch, Gabor Fodor. Top candidates: Orban, Deutsch, Fodor.
DOC.HEAD: Social Democratic Party of Hungary:
DOC.TEXT: Re-established Jan. 9, 1989. It was first founded Dec. 7, 1890, but was forced out of existence under the Communists. Moderate leftist party favoring market economy with a monetary reform and and strong trade unions. Seeks less reliance on West Germany as trade partner, stronger trade ties with other Western and Asian countries. Membership: 12,000. Party chairman: Anna Petrasovits. Top candidates: Petrasovits.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Woman's American Dream Shattered By Bronx Fire
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For Alva Romero, who left Honduras for a better life in the United States, an American dream ended in the deaths of six relatives who were among 87 victims of a fire at an illegal social club. Her daughter, her two brothers, a sister, a cousin and a niece perished in the fire early Sunday morning at the Happy Land club, a hangout for Latin Americans. A grieving Romero, who came to America 2{ years ago, said it wasn't severe dissatisfaction with Honduras or the country's political and economic upheavals that prompted her and her relatives to leave. ``This is America. We all would have a chance to do better here,'' she said as she dabbed her eyes and clutched a picture of her daughter. ``Now, I don't know.'' ``We came here to better ourselves,'' Romero said soon after viewing her relatives' bodies at a morgue, ``but this is what we get.'' Her husband remained behind in Honduras, Romero said. Would she stay in the United States? ``I don't know. Everything is changed. I don't know.'' Romero, 34, worked as a home attendant, helping to feed and clothe the elderly and sick. But now, it was friends and relatives who were helping Romero as they gathered at a high school where officials posted snapshots of the dead on the wall. Among them were Romero's brothers, aged 33 and 21; her 18-year-old sister, her daughter, also 18, a cousin, 18, and a niece, 17. ``They had been to the club before and they liked it,'' Romero said. ``It had been three weeks since they had been there.'' ``And, last night,'' she said, her voice choking with emotion, ``They all decided to go back to the club. I don't know why.''

DOC.HEAD: Milwaukee Plan Will to Send Low-Income Kids to Private Schools
With PM-Workplace Schools, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Tommy Thompson planned to sign a first-of-its-kind bill that would let 1,000 low-income Milwaukee students use public education funds to enroll in private schools. Under the plan, the state would pay up to $2,500 _ the per-capita state education allotment _ for full tuition in non-sectarian private schools for each student who chooses to leave the public-school system next fall. The amount spent would be subtracted from the budget for the city's public schools, which have nearly 100,000 students. The Legislature sent the bill to the governor on Thursday. At the Bush administration's invitation, the bill's sponsor, state Rep. Annette ``Polly'' Williams, D-Milwaukee, has spent the past few months traveling around the country to tout the plan as a model for school choice. ``Money talks,'' Ms. Williams said. ``For the first time, poor people will get respect because they can take their $2,500 to a school of their choice and say, `I want my children educated.''' Thompson, a Republican, has hailed the school-choice bill and said he plans to sign it soon. ``We as a state have acknowledged that private schools play an important role and provide an effective option in the education of our children,'' Thompson said Thursday. But Robert Peterkin, superintendent of Milwaukee schools and supporter of some kinds of school choice, said the bill the Legislature passed is ``a threat to education.'' The bill, he said, could upset the city schools' racial desegregation plan. He also complained it would drain resources from inner-city schools and do nothing to improve schools that lose students. ``The concept that the competitive marketplace will magically make the public-school system improve is simplistic,'' Peterkin said. He had no immediate plans to challenge it in court, however. The state's largest teachers union, the Wisconsin Education Association Council, initially also opposed the proposal. But the union changed its position when the governor promised not to use his partial veto power to expand the program, said Thomas Fonfara, Thompson's education advisor. Fonfara said the union's decision was the key to winning legislative support for the plan.

DOC.HEAD: Doomed Club Had A History of Problems
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Happy Land social club might better have been called The Disaster Waiting to Happen, according to city officials. ``It was a fire trap,'' said Anthony De Vita, the Fire Department's command chief. A fire that spread rapidly through the two-story brick building early Sunday killed 87 people. A vengeful former boyfriend of the club's ticket seller allegedly set the fire with gasoline. City inspectors had ordered the illegal club closed 16 months ago. ``We close them today; they open them tomorrow,'' Deputy Fire Commissioner Robert Ungar said. The club was riddled with safety faults, inspectors said. They included: _Not enough exits. There were only two doors on the front of the building, one of which was shuttered at the time of the fire. The other was in flames. _Bars on the sole window, which was in the coat-check room. _A staircase so narrow that only one person could use it at a time. It was so steep at 60 degrees that fire spokesman John Mulligan said he was reminded of the stairs on a ship. _Employees who were unequipped and untrained to deal with fires. _No sprinkler system on the first floor. _A lack of proper emergency lighting or signs to show patrons the way to safety. _No certification the structure was flameproof. The fire was apparently set at the front door, where Julio Gonzalez, 36, allegedly sprinkled gasoline from a plastic jug. Only three people were able to escape. ``To save themselves, they would have had to pass through the fire to get to the exit,'' said Fire Department Chief of Operations William Feehan. The club had no liquor or cabaret license. Its patrons paid a $5 entrance fee to enjoy alcohol, dance on a large upstairs dance floor or a small one downstairs and mingle with a clientele that included Hondurans and, more recently, other Hispanics. Many of its most loyal customers were from Trujillo, Honduras. The disk jockey played music ranging from salsa and reggae to the calypso popular on Honduras' Atlantic Coast. Patrons would knock on the front door to be admitted before the door was closed and locked again. It usually was open until 6 a.m. On Nov. 21, 1988, the city ordered it vacated. It was unclear if the club remained open or reopened later, but on July 24, 1989, its manager was arrested by police and charged with selling liquor illegally, said Buildings Commissioner Charles Smith. It was ordered vacated again on Nov. 1 but it didn't stay that way. Mayor David Dinkins said he didn't know the building's current owner. Residents said the manager of the club was Elias Colon. One former patron, Arthur McIntyre, said he convinced his girlfriend not to go to Happy Land Saturday night. ``It was a dangerous building from the beginning but it was a lot of fun,'' he said. ``But a few months ago it got bad. People started bringing guns and drugs and wearing knives. I figured something was about to explode.'' Denice Garcia, another area resident, called the club ``sleazy'' and said the building did not seem sturdy and the large dance floor sometimes moved.

DOC.HEAD: Pravda Lashes Out at Demonstrations In `Alarming, Tense' Period
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda lashed out today at growing numbers of demonstrations and protests in the Soviet Union, saying they amounted to ``legalization of extremism.'' The newspaper said this winter was ``one of the most alarming and tense periods in our contemporary history.'' ``Thousands and thousands of honest people take to the streets to say `da' to the processes of accelerating the perestroika, to the development of democracy,'' Pravda said in a front-page editorial. ``But we cannot help seeing the other side of it ... protests and demonstrations increasingly become one of the forms of legalizing extremism, of further undermining the situation which is complex in itself.'' Describing the situation as critical, the newspaper assaulted radical reformists as well as fundamentalists, saying they are trying to form ``organized opposition to the existing structures of state authority'' and to seize the power by ``non-constitutional methods.'' Pravda was especially critical of activists and Parliament members who were behind ``destabilizing'' rallies of Feb. 25, when about 1 million people took to the streets in Moscow and a dozen other cities, demanding swift democratic change. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Soviet citizens have become much freer to express opinions in rallies, print and politics. But Gorbachev has appealed to his countrymen to move past what he has called a period of demonstrations to work hard to improve their country. Pravda said that between Jan. 1 and Feb. 23, some 6.4 million people took part in more than 1,500 rallies throughout the country. It said almost 500 demonstrations with a total of more than a million participants took place on Feb. 24 and Feb. 25 alone during the rallies to press for for reform. Seventy-three protests with more than 1.2 million participants occurred for three days ending March 10, the newspaper said. In 1989, Pravda counted more than 5,000 rallies in which 12.4 million people took part.

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Offers Poland as Transit Point for Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: The head of Poland's new government is offering to help Soviet Jews get to Israel now that their main route has been lost because of terrorist threats. Last week, Hungary's airline said it was ending charter flights to Israel for the emigrants because of threats from Arab extremists. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland told leaders of the American Jewish Congress on Sunday night that his country was prepared to step in and provide assistance. ``Just as in the Middle Ages Poles gave refuge to Jews fleeing persecution, Poland will not evade humanitarian assistance to Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union,'' he said, bringing cheers from a crowd of about 300 people. Mazowiecki's spokeswoman, Malgorzata Niezabitowska, said there was no formal plan, but that if asked, Poland's LOT national airline would be willing to provide charter flights for Soviet Jews. The Polish leader's offer ``is a decision of great moral and political significance that will be welcomed by Jews all over the world,'' said Henry Siegman, the congress' executive director. In Israel on Sunday, a LOT official said both the Polish flag carrier and Israel's El Al Airlines would add a weekly flight between Warsaw and Tel Aviv, doubling each carrier's weekly flights on the route. Mazowiecki, 62, received the congress' Freedom Award for his efforts in helping end more than four decades of Communist rule in his country and for speaking out against anti-Semitism. On Friday, Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said Hungary's state-run Malev airline was ``surrendering to terror'' by deciding to stop flying Soviet Jews to Tel Aviv via Budapest because of the threat of terrorist attacks. Budapest, the Romanian capital of Bucharest and several other European cities had become transit points for Soviet Jews arriving on the Soviet airline Aeroflot, which has deferred to Arab allies in refusing to fly the emigres directly to Israel. Palestinian and Arab leaders view the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel as a grave threat and have launched an unprecedented anti-immigration campaign. They became concerned after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel suggested his country needs to keep the occupied territories to settle Soviet Jews. According to official Israeli figures, about 16,700 Soviet Jews emigrated to Israel in January and February, already higher than the 12,900 for 1989. Israeli officials say they expect 750,000 Soviet Jews to arrive in the next decade because of the Soviet Union's more liberal emigration policies and stricter U.S. entrance requirements. Mazowiecki said in his speech that now that the Poles have cast off totalitarian rule the time has come ``to make a breakthrough in relations between Poles and Jews.'' Predominantly Roman Catholic Poland was a thriving seat of Jewish culture until the Holocaust, in which 3 million of the country's 3.5 million Jews were killed by the Nazis. Many Poles risked their lives by sheltering Jews from the Nazis, but others turned Jews over to the Germans. Three million other Poles also died World War II. Most Polish Jews who survived left Poland immediately after the war. Even more fled after a government-led anti-Semitic purge in 1968, leaving Poland's mostly elderly Jewish population at less than 10,000. Mazowiecki, a former Solidarity newspaper editor, has offered to reinstate citizenship for any Jews forced out in 1968, and reiterated the offer Sunday. The prime minister today winds up a six-day U.S. trip that began in Washington, where he met with President Bush, and included a stop in Chicago. On Tuesday, he flies to Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Anybody that had an opportunity to view those 87 bodies knows that we're not going to tolerate this.'' _ New York Mayor David Dinkins, vowing to close unlicensed social clubs following the deadliest city fire in 79 years.

``It's like any devastation. It's like Chernobyl or medical waste washing up on my back yard in Long Island (N.Y.). ... It was a terrible tragedy. There's no getting around it.'' _ Former Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood on the March 24, 1989, oil spill in Prince William Sound, Alaska.

``We will be an opposition party. This, to use a religious term, will be penance for the party. We will come through it and we will be strong.'' _ Rezsoe Nyers, chairman of Hungary's former Communist Party, the Socialist Party, on his party's poor showing in the country's first free election in 43 years.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Minister Quits, Unhappy With Anti-drug Effort
DOC.TEXT: The interior minister resigned the same day an assassinated presidential candidate was buried, and reports said he accused the government of no longer being interested in fighting drug traffickers. President Virgilio Barco said in a communique late Sunday that contrary to the insinuations of Interior Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds, the government had no intention of easing its 7-month-old campaign against cocaine barons. To succeed Lemos, Barco named Sen. Horacio Serpa Uribe of his governing Liberal Party, saying Serpa Uribe ``had demonstrated a clear and upright position against drug trafficking.'' The radio networks RCN and Caracol said they obtained a copy of Lemos' resignation letter, in which he accuses the government of no longer being committed to fighting drugs. The networks did not elaborate. The government announced its U.S.-backed offensive in August, after traffickers shot and killed the leading presidential candidate. Since then, 14 accused traffickers have been extradited to the United States. Lemos resigned amid a dispute over responsibility for the assassination by suspected traffickers of a second candidate, Bernardo Jaramillo of the leftist Patriotic Union. Jaramillo was buried Sunday in Manizales after thousands of Patriotic Union supporters marched through the city's streets. The Patriotic Union's president, Diego Montana, demanded Lemos step down, saying the interior minister made comments that probably led traffickers to kill Jaramillo. Lemos had said the Patriotic Union was the political arm of the country's largest guerrilla group, the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces. The Colombian attorney general's office said two years ago that many of the right-wing death squads that kill leftists have been organized by drug traffickers. But the Patriotic Union has said army and security forces participate in the death squads, which are blamed for killing 1,044 members of the party in six years. Meanwhile, the Liberal Party held its convention in Bogota and formally nominaed Cesar Gaviria, 43, for president. Gaviria, who won a March 11 primary with 51 percent of the vote, will face Rodrigo Lloreda, the candidate for the opposition Conservative Party, in general elections scheduled for May 27. The convention delegates observed a minute of silence for Jaramillo and Luis Carlos Galan, the Liberal Party candidate assassinated in August. Gaviria had served as Galan's campaign manager. Jaramillo, 36, was fatally wounded at Bogota's airport on Thursday. Authorities said the gunman was hired by traffickers. His death prompted the Conservatives and the Patriotic Union to call for a postponement of the elections while the government takes additional measures to protect candidates. But Gaviria, heavily favored to win, said the vote should be held on schedule. ``The only antidote for violence is more democracy,'' he said in his acceptance speech Sunday. The candidate repeated his pledge to fight traffickers. He said an effective battle requires reforming the judicial system so it can bring cocaine traffickers to justice. In the past, drug barons have been able to evade justice by bribing, threatening and killing judges in Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Community Mourns Fire Victims
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Wails and cries echoed from inside a school where friends and relatives gathered to confirm their worst fears _ that one of the 87 who died in a Bronx fire was their daughter, husband, lover. Many emerged pale and distraught from Public School 67 after identifying dead family members in photos. A Honduran flag was draped over a fence outside the school; many of those who died were immigrants from Honduras. ``They tried to live the American dream: to get a job and make something of themselves,'' said Cheo Garcia, a former patron of the Happy Land social club. ``They all dreamed of returning home _ but with more money,'' said Miguel Reyes, coach of Club Deportivo Adrana, an amateur soccer team. Reyes counted team members among the dead: Orvin Garbutt, 22, Bagoberto Echeverri, 18, and a third player, all from Puerto Cortez, Honduras. They lived in East Tremont, a neighborhood populated by Hondurans, Dominicans, Puerto Ricans and Ecuadorans. The area is blighted by poor housing, drugs, unemployment and truancy. Graffitti marred the rolled-down security gates on Sunday as trash blew down streets and across vacant lots. A rat lay dead on the sidewalk. Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said the neighborhood did not have an especially high crime rate. But some young men were snorting cocaine in full view of police officers. Residents are trying to renovate the impoverished area, said the Rev. Ruben Diaz of the Christian Community Benevolent Association, a Protestant group. On Saturday nights, some took a break and flocked to an illegal social club called Happy Land. ``We have to try hard to close these places. They are killing our people,'' Diaz said. ``Sometimes we say, let them have it because they have nothing better. Now we have to say, 'What is more important, to have a good time or to stay alive?''' About 1,000 people gathered outside Happy Land, next to a union hiring hall where the victims' bodies were assembled in rows on the floor. Loved ones were allowed through police lines to look at the photos at P.S. 67. ``We're looking for friends and relatives and nobody's telling us anything,'' complained Rosemary Green, who believed her sister-in-law and cousin had gone to Happy Land. ``It's a slow process,'' said the Rev. A.B. Duncans, pastor of the nearby First Glorious Church Inc., who was assisting and counseling some of the bereaved. One woman collapsed on the sidewalk outside the school and had to be helped inside, where her son's picture was displayed with those of other victims. Jorge Pineda lost five friends, all from Honduras. A friend called Pineda's apartment at 8 p.m. Saturday, and asked his wife if he was going, as usual, to the Saturday night dance. Pineda's wife hung up; she didn't approve of the place. Eight hours later, Pineda was identifying his friends' bodies from police photos. ``I'm the only friend they had,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: City on a Sandbar Marks 75th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Founded as a vacation hot spot built on sand pumped into a mosquito-ridden mangrove swamp, Miami Beach, now 75, is growing old in style. Cruise ships blew their horns Sunday to kick off a year of birthday celebrations for the city. A treasure hunt followed on Lincoln Road, a once-glamorous avenue of shops now being revitalized as an art center after years of neglect. The prize _ a diamond _ was fitting for a 75th anniversary and a subtropical resort known for glitz. Hokey, maybe, but this town's fame grew from tropical visions and corny promotional schemes. In the 1920s, Indiana auto parts magnate Carl Fisher spent millions developing the island. He also hired Rosie the elephant to do the heavy lifting. ``There was a whole lot of smoke-and-mirrors type of publicity. Now the beach obviously has substance to it,'' said Ruben Aguilar, president of the non-profit corporation organizing the anniversary. Officially, Miami Beach was founded on March 26, 1915. On that date, 33 of the island's 300 residents voted to incorporate a failing coconut plantation and what was left of the swamp into the city limits. Publicists then sent pictures of bathing beauties to the nation's newspapers and the first droves of northern tourists soon began arriving. In 1926, a hurricane wiped out the golf courses, polo grounds and early hotels. It also cleared the way for hundreds of colorful art deco hotels and apartment buildings built in the 1930s. Today, most of those buildings remain, distinguishing Miami Beach from the concrete canyons along beaches in so many other Florida cities. Their timely protection came in 1979, when preservationists got the city's South Beach district listed on the National Register of Historic Places. In the 1980s, the successful ``Miami Vice'' television show and millions of dollars in public and private investment led to the refurbishment or replacement of the chic hotels where Arthur Godfrey and his band taught America to dance and Jackie Gleason made the nation smile. Nowadays, Europeans often choose the city's broad white beach over the packed French Riviera. Artists, yuppies and families now are settling down here, driving up rents. The city's population is 98,000. One result of all the attention is that members of the chamber of commerce now admit the outspoken art-deco protectors helped rekindle outside investors' interest in the city. ``You've got to give the art deco and preservation people a great deal of credit for what's happening now,'' Aguilar said. ``If nothing else, they brought people back here. And once they got back here, they saw what the beach was all about.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain in South; Rest of Nation Mostly Dry
DOC.TEXT: Mild and dry weather spread across much of the nation today. Rain fell over parts of the South and snow flurries were forecast for New York and Pennsylvania. Rain was falling early today in Little Rock, Ark., and Birmingham, Ala., the National Weather Service reported. Some flurries were expected in western New York and northwestern Pennsylvania. Light rain and drizzle spread from northern Texas and southern Oklahoma across southern Arkansas and northern Louisiana to northern Mississippi late Sunday. Light rain and a few thunderstorms were reported over western Oregon and the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas. Light snow fell over parts of eastern Colorado. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation late Sunday and early today. Skies were generally fair from New England through the Midwest into Montana and Wyoming and down into the Southwest. A storm that hit the mid-Atlantic region late Saturday and early Sunday left 4.2 inches of snow at the Dulles Airport in Washington D.C. It also dumped 3.8 inches of snow on Atlantic City, N.J. The high for the nation Sunday was 96 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Stallone, Derek and Shatner Take Razzies for Movie Muffs
With PM-Oscars, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sylvester Stallone and Bo Derek were named the worst actors of the '80s and William Shatner and his ``Star Trek V'' were the big losers of 1989 in the 10th Annual Golden Raspberry Awards. ``Mommie Dearest'' was named worst film of the decade in awards ceremonies Sunday at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel. Razzies, as the awards are known, were bestowed for worst achievement in film for both the past year and past 10 years. For 1989, Shatner was named worst actor for ``Star Drek V,'' as the Golden Raspberry selectors prefer to call the film. The science-fiction sequel also was conferred as the worst film of 1989 and worst director of the year for Shatner. Heather Locklear, who starred with Shatner in the television series ``T.J. Hooker,'' was also honored with a Razzie as worst actress of 1989 for her work in ``The Return of Swamp Thing.'' Brooke Shields was singled out for worst supporting actress for 1989's ``Speed Zone,'' while Christopher Atkins got the Razzie as worst supporting actor for last year's ``Listen to Me.'' ``Harlem Nights'' took the award for worst screenplay of the year, written by Eddie Murphy. The tune ``Bring Your Daughter to the Slaughter'' from ``A Nightmare on Elm Street 5'' was chosen as the worst original song of 1989. In the decade competition, Stallone was named as worst actor for his appearances in ``Rhinestone,'' ``Rambo II,'' ``Rocky IV,'' ``Cobra,'' ``Over the Top,'' ``Rambo III,'' ``Lock Up'' and ``Tango and Cash.'' Bo Derek was recognized as worst actress of the '80s for ``Tarzan the Ape Man'' and ``Bolero.'' Pia Zadora was picked as worst new star of the decade for ``Butterfly'' and ``The Lonely Lady.'' The winners were picked by the more than 275 members of the Golden Raspberry Award Foundation. The organization includes film makers, frequent moviegoers and movie journalists.

DOC.HEAD: Acting Director Named For Beleaguered Youth Agency
DOC.TEXT: Monsignor William J. Toohy, a Harvard-educated lawyer, on Tuesday will become acting director of the beleaguered Covenant House program for homeless and runaway youth, Cardinal John O'Connor announced. Toohy will hold the post while a Covenant House search committee looks for a successor to the Rev. Bruce Ritter, the Franciscan priest who founded the institution. Ritter resigned last month after some former clients accused him of sexual impropriety, which he denied. More recent allegations have involved possible financial irregularities. ``Obviously Covenant House has had a great number of legal problems,'' O'Connor told reporters after Sunday mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. ``So it's hardly a disadvantage for a man to have a legal background to go in there.'' The Covenant House board of directors approved O'Connor's nomination of Toohy on Saturday. Toohy, 59, is associate executive director of Catholic Charities and director of the Archdiocesan Office of Legal Affairs. He is a member of the New York state bar. Covenant House directors also approved O'Connor's nomination of Monsignor Timothy A. McDonnell, 52, pastor of Holy Trinity Church in Manhattan, as Toohy's deputy.

DOC.HEAD: Estonian Communists Vote to Split From Moscow, Set Transition Period
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following the Lithuanians' lead, Communist leaders in neighboring Estonia have voted overwhelmingly to break with the Moscow-based national party. To soften the blow for Soviet authorities, however, the Estonian party's Central Committee agreed to wait six months before voting to finalize the split. Sunday's move by Estonia's ruling party follows a similar vote in December by its sister party in its fellow Baltic republic of Lithuania, whose Communist Party broke with Moscow in December. On March 11, Lithuanian declared itself independent, touching off a war of nerves with Moscow, which called the secession illegal and invalid. But shows of military strength and decrees asserting Soviet sovereignty over the republic have not deterred the Lithuanians, whose republic was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 along with Estonia and the third Baltic state, Latvia. Most Latvians and Estonians appear determined to follow Lithuania, though move at a slower pace, in the drive for independence. Sunday's vote to establish an independent Communist Party in Estonia was 432-3 with seven abstensions, said Lembo Taning, an adviser on economic affairs to the party's Central Committee. But the official Soviet news agency Tass said 228 delegates, including many ethnic Russians, boycotted the polling. Estonia's 106,000-member Communist Party has been far more cautious than its Lithuanian sister party. It voted to wait for a party congress scheduled for October before finalizing its split with Moscow. The party also cautiously backed appeals for independence. At Sunday's meeting, Communist Party deputies agreed to support ``the independence of the Estonian people on the basis of the free expression of the people's will,'' but they described the road toward independence as ``an arduous and controversial process that requires ... legal foundation and the establishment of a solid economic and social basis.'' Tass said the party would hold its October congress to ``make a final decision on its relationship'' with Moscow. Russians, Poles and other ethnic groups make up 40 percent of Estonia's 1.6 million people and strongly oppose secession. In Lithuania, by contrast, ethnic minorities make up 20 percent of the 3.8 million people. In Estonia, 55 out of the 105 lawmakers elected earlier this month to Parliament are members of the Communist Party, where there is deeply division among supporters of independence and ethnic Russian groups that oppose it. The pro-independence People's Front political movement holds 46 seats and is supported by some small parties. Russian groups have 27 seats and the Free Estonia group holds 13 seats. These divisions would make it difficult for the Estonian independence movement to obtain the necessary two-thirds majority and push through a vote on secession. Tass said ethnic Russian lawmakers may join with Free Estonia to block such a vote. But Estonian activists said they expect Free Estonia to support the independence drive.

DOC.HEAD: Ray of the Bob and Ray Comedy Team Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Elliott sted Elliot throughout
DOC.TEXT: Raymond Walter Goulding, half of the Bob and Ray comedy team whose low-key humor and gentle satire delighted radio and TV audiences for more than four decades, died after a long battle with kidney failure. He was 68. He died at about 6 a.m. Saturday, said his son, Bryant Goulding. Goulding and Bob Elliott created their comedy team in Boston in the late 1940s and performed together until about two years ago, when Goulding became ill. ``I have a terrible feeling of loss,'' Elliott said Sunday. ``I think the main reason we worked well together was that we really appreciated each other, as opposed to some comedy teams. ``We had no rivalry, just great mutual respect.'' The two brought their act to New York City in the early 1950s, creating a stable of improbable yet totally recognizable characters. Among the most memorable were Wally Ballou, the bumbling interviewer, cooking authority Mary McGoon, the Piel brothers and a writer named O. Leo Leahy. They did commercials for bogus businesses as well as real ones. Among them were ``Height Watchers International: Offering six ample servings of low vitamins and nutrients in artificial colorings'' and ``Einbinder Flypaper: The brand you've gradually grown to trust over the course of three generations.'' Goulding, a native of Lowell, Mass., and Elliott made separate starts in Boston radio around 1940, then entered military during World War II. They met in 1946 at radio station WHDH, where Elliott was a disc jockey and Goulding was a newscaster. Their early-morning quips soon put them in demand as a team. ``We never said, `Let's be a comedy team.' But the chemistry was there, and nobody told us to stop,'' Elliott told The New York Times. They also appeared in numerous radio and television productions and motion pictures. Elliott recently appeared on ``Garrison Keillor's American Radio Company of the Air,'' the new show performed live in New York and broadcast on public radio stations. Goulding's films include ``Cold Turkey'' in 1969 and ``Author! Author!'' in 1982. He also acted in the 1970-1971 Broadway play, ``The Two and Only.'' He co-wrote a book with Elliott, entitled ``From Approximately Coast To Coast ... It's the Bob And Ray Show.'' It was published in 1983. Goulding is survived by Elizabeth, his wife of 45 years, six children and six grandchildren. Funeral services were scheduled for Wednesday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

DOC.HEAD: Hawke Likely To Keep Power; Crucial Outback Vote Not in
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke and his Labor Party appeared likely to win a record fourth consecutive term despite a strong challenge from their conservative opponents, media reports said today. The reports said a victory could hinge on Outback voters stranded by floodwaters who were unable to get to the polls on Saturday. Hawke, who has governed for seven years, appeared to have an edge over the conservative coalition led by Andrew Peacock in the 148-seat House of Representatives. Latest returns indicated Labor had won 73 seats, the coalition 70 and the Independents two. Labor, which had 85 seats in the previous lower house, needs 75 seats for a working majority. Hawke said in a ``worst case scenario'' his party would win 73 votes, against 73 for the Liberal and National coalition. The remaining two seats would go to independents. Peacock, 51, making his second bid for the prime ministership, refused to concede defeat, but acknowledged Labor might have the numbers to win a fourth term. The House of Representatives chooses the government. The vote seemed to hinge on several thousand voters in the Outback town of Kennedy who were unable to get to polling stations because of flooding, newspapers said. By today, some were still prevented from casting ballots. Representatives from both parties were sent to Kennedy to try to influence the vote. Votes still were being counted in the state of Western Australia. Final results were not expected until Thursday, when mail-in ballots are counted. Hawke on Sunday estimated his party would return with a majority of at least one seat. Newspapers said Hawke, 60, seemed likely to lead his party to victory despite dissastisfaction over high interest rates and a $100 billion foreign debt. Economic issues were central in the campaign. The Sydney Morning Herald today predicted Labor would win by at least two seats. The daily Australian said Labor appeared to have a slim lead. The Daily Mirror, in an editorial today said: ``At this stage it looks as though Labor will be returned with a small majority, although the possibility of a hung parliament or a Liberal party victory still cannot be discounted. The paper said Australia might benefit from the close result. ``Both sides have effectively been given notice that their performances must vastly improve and that they cannot distance themselves from the concerns of the electorate,'' the editorial said. Hawke came to power in 1983, was re-elected the following year and again in 1987. He has said that if re-elected in this race, he will seek a fifth term before retiring.

DOC.HEAD: Tar Balls Wash Up on Beach
DOC.TEXT: Tar balls that washed up on a beach may be remnants of last month's 394,000-gallon spill or oil stirred from the ocean bottom by offshore earthquakes, Coast Guard officials said. The balls are about 2 to 5 inches in diameter but pose no serious health threat to swimmers, officials said. ``There is a moderate amount of tar balls from the Huntington Pier south to Huntington Street,'' about a half-mile stretch of beach, said Lt. j.g. Donna Davis of the Coast Guard's marine safety division. ``It seems to be new oil, since it has a gooey consistency,'' she said. Results of tests at a Coast Guard laboratory were expected in about a week. If the tar balls were from the Feb. 7 oil spill, British Petroleum would be asked to clean them up, officials said. Oil gushed from the American Trader after the tanker apparently ran over its own anchor, puncturing the hull. The spill occurred while the ship attempted to moor at an oil pipeline off Huntington Beach. British Petroleum, which chartered the ship, took responsibility for cleaning up 20 miles of Orange County coast. Costs have totaled nearly $20 million so far.

DOC.HEAD: Big Ben's Hourly Bell Stopped For 12 Weeks For Repairs
DOC.TEXT: Big Ben's hourly bell, one of Britain's best-known sounds, resounded over central London at 8 a.m. today for the last time for up to 12 weeks to allow essential repairs. The famous clock over the Houses of Parliament will continue to tell the time, but its hourly bong has been silenced. The hammer arm that strikes the bell to sound the number of dongs for every hour is suffering from metal fatigue and will be replaced, government minister Christopher Chope said last week. The clock's quarter-hourly chimes were also stopped for two days while the hammer was being removed, a spokesman for the government's Property Services Agency said. They will be stopped again for the two days before the hourly bong resumes. The British Broadcasting Corp., which starts radio news bulletins with a live broadcast of the hourly bells, said it would substitute Big Ben with the clock known as Big Tom at St. Paul's Cathedral. Big Ben, named after Sir Benjamin Hall, a government works commissioner, first sounded in 1859. It is normally silenced only twice a year when the hands are moved forward one hour for British Summer Time in March _ the equivalent of daylight savings time _ and backward to revert to Greenwich Mean Time in October. Big Ben's longest silence was 22 days in August 1976 when a shaft supporting the clock works shattered inside the clock room. It last stopped for three hours in October due to a mechanical failure. The name Big Ben actually applies only to the 13{-ton bell, but it has become the nickname for the whole 20-story tower.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Wounds 8, Damages 100 Homes in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: Residents cleaned up today after an Irish Republican Army bomb exploded behind a police station, wounding eight people and damaging more than 100 homes. Explosives packed into four large metal drums in a hijacked van exploded without warning Sunday at the station in Castlederg's town center, police said. A spokesman for the Royal Ulster Constabulary said the police station and a nearby church were damaged. Many homes suffered minor damage, but some were so badly damaged they will have to be demolished, police said. The IRA claimed responsibility in a statement distributed to news media in the British province, and said the bomb contained one ton of explosives. Four civilians, two policemen and two soldiers were wounded. Three civilians and one policeman remained hospitalized today, but the police spokesman said their injuries were not serious. The attack was the second on a Northern Ireland police station in less than 24 hours. Earlier Sunday, a 1,000-pound bomb badly damaged a station and dozens of homes in Ballymena, County Antrim. The IRA is fighting to end British rule of Northern Ireland and unite the predominantly Protestant province with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Serbian Policemen Take Control, Round Up Suspects
DOC.TEXT: Serbian police in Kosovo province began rounding up ethnic Albanians blamed for attacks on minority Slavs following a mysterious illness that affected hundreds of teen-agers, a newspaper said today. Slavs were accused of poisoning the youths last week, but the government has charged that the illness was faked and was ``an action of Albanian separatists'' intended to stir more unrest in the troubled province. The Yugoslav republic of Serbia, which administers the southern province bordering Albania, took control of local police over the weekend after the attacks that media reports said injured 30 Slavs. Radmilo Bogdanovic, Serbia's chief of internal affairs, in a statement to the newspaper Politika said the largest Yugoslav republic sent ``special units of police in all municipalities and settlements (in Kosovo),'' and that the the province ``is now fully secured by forces of public order and peace.'' Bogdanovic said Serbian police were involved in identifying the ``executors of indignant attacks on Serbs and Montenegrins'' and of the organizers of the allegedly sham poisoning. An undisclosed number of ethnic Albanian policemen were suspended after allegations that they watched impassively as Serbs were beaten by Albanians in apparent retaliation for the alleged poisoning of Albanian children. Nearly 1,000 schoolchildren, most of them members of Kosovo's ethnic Albanian majority, were hospitalized last week, complaining of lung and skin problems and alleging they were poisoned by a mysterious gas. Federal health officials and the Belgrade-based Military Medical Academy said no traces of poisoning could be established in more than 100 blood and urine samples analyzed. More than 60 people have died in ethnic violence in the past year in the province, where 90 percent of the population consists of ethnic Albanians. Albanian nationalists seek to regain autonomy lost last year when Serbia assumed direct control of Kosovo's judiciary and schooling.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Jolts Tadzhikistan, Buildings Crack
DOC.TEXT: A powerful earthquake jolted Soviet Tadzhikistan and cracked buildings in several settlements, the official Soviet news agency Tass said today. There were no reports of casualties. The earthquake occurred at 6:18 p.m. Sunday. Its epicenter was located 235 miles southeast of the republic's capital of Dushanbe, Tass said. The National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., said the quake registered 6.2 on the Richter scale of ground motion. A reading of 6 is capable of causing severe damage in a populated area. The earthquake registered eight on the Soviet 12-point scale in the epicenter, Tass said. According to the Soviet scale, an eight-point earthquake is termed ``destructive'' and may cause serious damage to buildings. Tass said the quake registered five to six in Khorog, a city in the southeast of Tadzhikistan, and three in Dushanbe. In the Pamir mountains, several buildings ``of the old type'' cracked but there were no casualties, Tass said without elaboration.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Hospitalized For Hernia Operation
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel underwent a previously planned hernia operation and is recovering normally, his spokesman said today. Havel, 53, will stay in the hospital about a week, and then need another week to convalesce, spokesman Michael Zantovsky said. Havel, a dissident playwright who became president after the country's hard-line Communist rulers were ousted, suffered from bouts of ill health while in jail for his opposition to the Communist government from 1979 to 1983. He has maintained a punishing schedule since the whirlwind peaceful revolution started in November and propelled him to the presidency in December. Since taking office, he has visited both Germanys, Poland, Hungary, Iceland, Canada, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain, besides receiving a steady stream of foreign visitors in Prague and making trips around Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Adds Three More to Advisory Panel
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has named three more people to his new advisory council, a panel designed to transfer power from the Communist Party to the government. The new members, announced Sunday, are Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin, who is responsible for maintaining law and security in the country; Valery Boldin, a department head at the Communist Party's Central Committee; and the Academy of Sciences' Vice President Yuri Osipiyan, a specialist in theoretical and applied physics. The Communist Party, which has renounced its 70-year-old monopoly on power, has been under widespread attack for its handling of the economy and other issues. Gorbachev was appointed president earlier this month and the new Presidential Council provides him with a mechanism for bringing his aides into the government. Constitutional amendments adopted when Gorbachev was elected president March 15 provide for the council to put into effect domestic and foreign policy and ensure security. The official Soviet news agency Tass said the panel will also supervise implementation of the economic policy approved by the Soviet parliament. On Saturday, Gorbachev named his key advisers, Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and Alexander Yakovlev, to the council along with the chiefs of the military and secret police. Other nominees announced that day included two well-known writers, an economist and two parliamentarians.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea, Mongolia Agree on Diplomatic Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Yondon has one name only
DOC.TEXT: South Korea and Mongolia have agreed to establish full diplomatic relations for the first time, South Korea's Foreign Ministry announced today. The accord was signed in the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator by South Korean Assistant Foreign Minister Lee Kie-joo and Mongolian First Vice Foreign Minister Yondon, ministry officials said. Mongolia became the sixth East bloc country to establish formal ties with capitalist South Korea after Hungary, Poland, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria. Mongolia also maintains diplomatic ties with Communist North Korea, an archrival of South Korea. Ministry officials said South Korea and Mongolia also planned to sign agreements to promote trade, economic and technical cooperation and cultural exchanges. They said efforts to set up diplomatic ties between the two countries began in mid-1987 in contacts between South Korean and Mongolian diplomats stationed in Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Revive Lawsuit in California McMartin Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to revive a lawsuit stemming from one of the nation's most publicized cases of alleged child abuse, at the now-defunct McMartin Preschool in Manhattan Beach, Calif. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out the suit against a private child welfare group and one of its therapists by two of the preschool's former teachers. Seven people connected to the preschool were indicted in 1984 on child-molesting charges, but charges against five later were dropped. The two remaining defendants, Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted of most of the charges Jan. 18 after a three-year trial. Jurors deadlocked on some of the charges, and prosecutors in Los Angeles plan to retry Buckey on some of those counts. The appeal acted on today stems from a lawsuit by Buckey's grandmother, Virginia McMartin, and his sister, Peggy Ann Buckey. The women were among the defendants against whom criminal charges were dropped. They said their rights were violated by the Children's Institute International and Kathleen MacFarlane, head of that organization's diagnostic unit. The institute was hired by Los Angeles County and Manhattan Beach officials to help investigate the child-abuse allegations. The child welfare organization concluded that numerous acts of child abuse had occurred at the school. In their suit, the two former teachers alleged that Ms. McFarlane leaked confidential information about the case to a television news reporter with whom she was involved romantically. The teachers also said the institute manipulated children attending the preschool to support the abuse charges. A California appeals court last year threw out the suit, saying the institute and its employees cannot be sued because California law requires child care custodians and others to report to authorities any known or suspected instance of child abuse. ``Those subject to this mandatory reporting requirement are absolutely immune from civil or criminal liability for making such a report,'' the state court said. Lawyers for the two teachers said such protection unfairly goes beyond even that accorded prosecutors. ``If the prosecutor ballyhooing his prosecution before the media is not absolutely immune for that performance, how can one say that Kathleen MacFarlane's pillow-talk leaks of inside information ... is entitled to absolute protection?'' they asked. The case is McMartin vs. Children's Institute International, 89-1257.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Consider Giving Federal Regulators More Authority on Electric Rates
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to consider giving federal regulators more authority to lower electricity rates, setting the stage for a decision that could affect more than 49 million homes. The court said it will review a ruling that barred the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from slashing rate increases to customers in 15 Ohio communities. A decision is expected sometime in 1991. At stake is the commission's power to prevent public utilities from passing on to consumers allegedly inflated costs of buying coal, and possibly other goods and services, from utility subsidiaries. The Bush administration joined the Ohio communities in urging the court to study the case. The dispute stems from rate hikes first proposed by Ohio Power Co. in 1982. The utility asked the commission to approve higher rates to cover the cost of buying coal from its subsidiary, the Southern Ohio Coal Co. The commission concluded that Ohio Power from 1982 to 1986 paid its subsidiary between 25 percent and 33 percent more for coal than the prevailing market prices. The commission ordered the utility to refund $13.4 million to its wholesale customers for that period. But a U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here, which has authority over such actions by federal regulators, overturned the commission's decision last year. The appeals court interpreted a 1935 federal law to give the Securities and Exchange Commission primary authority to regulate sales contracts between holding companies and their subsidiaries. ``The SEC is charged by the statute with regulating the terms of affiliate contracts in the interest of consumers, as well as investors and the public, and has not exempted'' the contract between Ohio Power and the Southern Ohio Coal Co., the appeals court said. Justice Department lawyers said the ruling ``creates the potential for a serious regulatory gap with respect to federal, and by implication state, regulation of utility rates.'' The decision ``could hinder effective regulation of utilities that directly or indirectly serve 49 million households'' nationwide, the goverment said. Directly affected by the appeals court ruling are the Ohio communities _ most of them tiny villages _ of Arcadia, Bloomdale, Carey, Cygnet, Deshler, Greenwich, Ohio City, Plymouth, Republic, Shiloh, Sycamore, Wharton, Bryan, St. Clairsville and Wapakoneta. The case is Arcadia vs. Ohio Power Co., 89-1283.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Review Desegregation in Oklahoma City Schools
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to review a ruling that, if upheld, could reinstate forced busing for the racial desegregation of Oklahoma City, Okla., elementary schools. The court must decide whether the city school board acted lawfully when in 1985 it returned to a neighborhood schools plan for children in kindergarten through fourth grade. At issue is the effect of a federal judge's ruling in 1977 that Oklahoma City's public schools had become fully integrated and no longer had to be under court supervision. The issue gained national attention when the Reagan administration helped bring about a halt to court-ordered busing of elementary school pupils in Norfolk, Va. The Norfolk school district was allowed to return to a neighborhood schools plan in 1986. William Bradford Reynolds, head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division when it entered the Norfolk case in 1984, said the same legal principles could apply to ``many, many other school districts around the country.'' Hundreds of school districts, including those in most major cities, operate court-ordered busing plans for racial desegregation. But only a few have persuaded courts, as did those in Norfolk and Oklahoma City, to declare their once-segregated systems fully integrated. In the Oklahoma City case, a federal appeals court last Oct. 6 disapproved the neighborhood schools plan. Oklahoma City public schools once were racially segregated by law. Black parents sued in 1961 to end the lasting effects of such segregation, and in 1972 forced busing was begun as part of a court-ordered desegregation plan. U.S. District Judge Luther Bohanon ruled in 1977 that the school district had become fully integrated, and ended court supervision. School officials continued the crosstown busing, however, until 1985 when children in kindergarten through fourth grade were allowed to attend the school nearest their home. By 1986, 33 of the school district's 64 elementary schools were 90 percent black or white. Some black parents challenged the neighborhood schools plan, calling it a tool of ``resegregation.'' Other black parents had criticized the busing program. Judge Bohanon refused to reopen the case, ruling that school officials did not intend to discriminate on the basis of race when they adopted the neighborhood plan. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, however, ordered Bohanon to give the challengers a chance to prove that adopting the neighborhood plan was unconstitutional. The Supreme Court in late 1986 refused to disturb the appeals court's ruling. After conducting a trial, Bohanon ruled that the 1972 desegregation plan no longer had to be enforced because federal court supervision ended with his 1977 declaration that the school district was fully integrated. But the 10th Circuit court's October ruling said federal court supervision in such cases ``extends beyond the termination of the wrongdoing.'' The appeals court said the Oklahoma City school board has a continuing duty to refrain from any action that could weaken racial balance in the public schools. It ordered Bohanon to study ``alternatives to maintain racially balanced elementary schools.'' In the appeal acted on today, school board lawyer Ronald L. Day said the 10th Circuit court's ruling directly conflicts with federal appeals court rulings in the Norfolk case and one from Austin, Texas. In each of those, the appeals courts ruled that court supervision ends when a previously segregated school district is found to be fully integrated, or ``unitary.'' In a friend-of-the-court brief, the National School Boards Association urged the justices to use the Oklahoma City case ``to resolve what constitutes a unitary school system and determine the effect of a declaration of unitary.'' The case is Oklahoma City Board of Education vs. Dowell, 89-1080.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Extend Law to Protect Non-Citizens from Private Bias
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to extend a key civil rights law to protect non-citizens from private, as well as governmental, bias. The court, over two dissenting votes, let stand a ruling that the First National Bank of Commerce in New Orleans did not discriminate illegally against Jeetendra Bhandari when it denied his application for a bank credit card because he is not a U.S. citizen. Justices Byron R. White and Sandra Day O'Connor voted to hear arguments in the case, but four votes are needed to grant such review. Today's action does not set a national precedent, but merely leaves intact a federal appeals court ruling that has become binding law in three states _ Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, by a 7-6 vote, ruled that federal law does not protect aliens from such discriminatory treatment. Bhandari, a native of India, is a permanent, legal resident of this country. He worked as an accountant in New Orleans before recently moving to Dallas. In 1983, he applied for a VISA Card with First National but was denied one. He was told his application had been denied because he is not a U.S. citizen. Bhandari sued the bank in 1984, invoking a Civil War era law most often used these days to battle private bias against racial minorities. It says that ``all persons within the jurisdiction of the United States shall have the same right ... to the full and equal benefits of all laws.'' The Supreme Court previously has ruled that the law, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, protects racial minorities from private and governmental bias. The court also has ruled that the law protects aliens from governmental bias. But the justices never have ruled specifically on whether the law may be used to fight private, non-governmental, discrimination against aliens. The 5th Circuit court, ruling in 1987, drew a distinction between private discrimination based on race and nationality. ``Racial and citizenship distinctions are things of a different kind. The former is, for the individual, immutable; the latter is not,'' the appeals court said. ``While the alien guest is not without his own special claims upon us, arising from our moral tradition, they are of a different quality from those grounded in our common humanity.'' The justices last June 26 set aside the ruling in Bhandari's case, and ordered the appeals court to restudy it in light of their decision reaffirming that the 1866 law protects racial minorities from private bias. After undertaking that restudy, the appeals court last Nov. 2 reached the same conclusion and reinstated its 1987 ruling. The case is Bhandari vs. First National Bank of Commerce, 89-1258.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Drop Treason Proceedings Against Honecker, Three Others
