DOC.TEXT: East Germany today dropped plans to try disgraced former Communist leader Erich Honecker and three other ousted officials for high treason, saying there was no legal basis for the charges. However, the chief prosecutor's office said the ailing Honecker and two of the officials remain under investigation on suspicion of massive corruption and abuse of power. Also today, efforts to form a non-Communist governing coalition remained bogged down over allegations that leading politicians in the week-old democracy had links to the disbanded secret police. Honecker, 77, and the three other top Communist officials were members of the ruling hard-line Politburo toppled in last fall's peaceful revolt. Prosecutors had said earlier that Honecker, former state security chief Erich Mielke, former economics czar Guenther Mittag and ex-propaganda chief Joachim Herrmann would be indicted and put on trial this month on charges of high treason, which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison. East Germany abolished the death penalty last summer, before the Communists were swept from power. Chief prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph said there were no legal grounds for a treason indictment and also cleared Honecker, Mielke and Mittag of conspiracy charges. Joseph, in a statement carried by the government-run news agency ADN, accused Honecker and his lieutenants of ``persistent breaches of the constitution.'' But he said these were part of a Stalinist system of one-party Communist rule and suggested that individuals could not be charged for abuses. Honecker and Mielke currently are not imprisoned because of their bad state of health, which prosecutors say is also hampering the investigation. Honecker was arrested Jan. 29 but officials released him a day later because he is suffering from kidney cancer. Joseph today ordered Herrmann released. Mittag remains in jail. Remaining allegations against Honecker and Mittag include embezzlement of state funds for a privileged lifestyle, such as construction of private vacation homes. Mielke, 84, faces a range of accusations stemming from his control of the former, all-powerful state security apparatus. Indictments against the former officials are not expected before May or June, Joseph told The Associated Press. The past also continued to haunt the new political forces in East Germany. The leader of the Social Democratic party, denying allegations he had been an informer for the Communist secret police, said today he was temporarily leaving his post until the suspicions have been dispelled. Ibrahim Boehme told a news conference he would also not assume his seat in the 400-seat new parliament until the allegations had been investigated. Boehme said Sunday talks between leading parties to form a coaliiton government should be suspended until the allegations had been investigated and cleared up. He said he was temporarily leaving the chairmanship of the party to his deputy, Markus Meckel. Boehme, whose party finished a distant second in East Germany's first free election on March 18, was the latest non-Communist politician to come under suspicion of having collaborated with the Stasi secret police. Lothar de Maiziere, the likely new premier whose Christian Democratic Union won the election, is fighting similar allegations. De Maiziere has strongly denied reports that he was a long-time Stasi informer. The swirl of allegations is stalling efforts to form East Germany's first democratically elected government and has overshadowed the country's first week as a democracy. Boehme's deputy Meckel said anonymous allegations by former Stasi agents were designed to destabilize the country, disturb the population and discredit the newly elected parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Surviving Crew Members Describe Panic As Trawler Sinks in Bering Sea
DOC.TEXT: Matt Price was asleep in his bunk when a friend shook him awake. It probably saved his life. ``He said, `Get up _ we're going over,''' Price said. The two scrambled to the deck of the Aleutian Enterprise seconds before the fishing trawler capsized and pitched the crew into the frigid Bering Sea. Price and his friend were among 22 crewmen saved after the fishing boat sank Thursday. Nine others are missing and presumed drowned. The survivors, most from Washington state, began returning home during the weekend. They told stories of a panicky dash to get off the sinking ship, followed by an agonizing wait for rescue in near-freezing water. Several said no alarm sounded to warn them as the 162-foot boat heeled and began to sink in calm seas. They also said they had little or no training in the use of survival suits that were designed to save them. Price, 19, said in a telephone interview from his Aberdeen home that he was asleep when his friend Harvey ``Dale'' Philpot, 20, of Hoquiam woke him up. The boat started to capsize 30 seconds to a minute later, he said. ``I ran up and climbed up the ladder and by that time it was almost on its side,'' Price said. Clad only in pants and a shirt, Price tried to locate a survival suit, but couldn't. ``I looked for it but I just didn't have enough time to dig through'' all the material in a locker, he said. Another crew membere, Derrik Santy, said, ``I just went on instinct. The people all around me were screaming, `Help me! Help me!'' Santy, interviewed by the Anchorage Daily News before leaving Alaska on Saturday, said he was below deck when the ship began to roll. Scrambling to the deck, Santy jumped into the water and ``grabbed anything that floated.'' Price recalled gear tumbling across the deck. ``I was out on the railing, then it tipped nearly all the way over and I just jumped out as far as I could jump,'' he said. ``I just swam and swam and there was a round buoy and I grabbed onto that,'' he said. He said he then swam another 50-100 yards to a life raft where he was dragged aboard. The 195-ton cod fishing and processing factory trawler sank about 250 miles northwest of Dutch Harbor, Alaska, the day before it was to return to port after fishing for three weeks. Investigators say the boat was hauling in a netload of fish when it suddenly heeled, rolled and went under in a matter of minutes. The cause of the sinking has not been determined. In addition to the state of Alaska, the Coast Guard and National Transportation Safety Board are investigating the accident. Alaska State Trooper Robert Stevenson said several survivors told him the ship's alarm system had not worked for months. The ships are supposed to be equipped with general alarms, some of which sound automatically when the vessel lists too far, he said. Officials of the boat's operator, Seattle-based Arctic Alaska Fisheries Corp., could not be reached by telephone Sunday. However, Dan Roberts, company executive vice president, said Saturday he did not know why the alarm might not have sounded.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal by Conglomerate in Mississippi Natural Gas Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by a major conglomerate found to have fraudulently obtained a $75 million bank loan to develop natural gas fields in Mississippi. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that could subject W.R. Grace & Co. to substantial punitive damages in a lawsuit by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Continental Illinois National Bank made the loan to Grace in 1980 to finance the company's acquisition of three Mississippi gas fields. Grace discovered before the loan was approved that one of the fields apparently was worthless, but it did not reveal that development to the bank for three years. The bank then sued the conglomerate for fraud in 1984. The bank soon assigned the Grace loan to the FDIC since the government agency was helping bail out the failing bank. A federal jury awarded the FDIC $100 million in damages, including $25 million to compensate the agency for its losses and $75 million to punish Grace. A federal judge reduced the $75 milllion portion of the award to $25 million. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year upheld the jury's finding of fraud but ordered a new trial on damages. The appeals court said there was sufficient evidence the company practiced fraud to obtain the loan. ``Concealment was the essence of Grace's fraud,'' the appeals court said. ``Only after Grace thought it was home free _ in fact three years after it thought it was home free _ did it reveal the fraud.'' But the 7th Circuit court said it was troubled by the way the jury decided the FDIC suffered $25 million in actual damages. ``The jury was allowed to pick a figure out of the air,'' the appeals court said. ``The amount of punitive damages, related as they are to compensatory damages, will have to be redetermined as well in the new trial.'' Grace's lawyers urged the Supreme Court to use the case to decide whether a government agency may be awarded punitive damages in fraud lawsuits. The Grace appeal also said it is unfair to limit the new trial ordered by the appeals court to the size of damages. Justice Department lawyers, in asking the high court to reject Grace's appeal, said it ``borders on brazenness'' for the conglomerate to argue that the FDIC is not entitled to major damages when Grace has failed to repay a $75 million loan. The case is W.R. Grace vs. FDIC, 89-902.

DOC.HEAD: New Ethnic Clashes Reported After Killings of 9 in Azerbaijan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with report of violence today; Picks up 6th graf, ``These bearded ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Armenian nationalists today hurled a homemade bomb from an ambulance and opened fire on a village in Azerbaijan, a local news agency said. No injuries were reported. The attacks reported by the official Azerbaijan news agency Azerinform followed an upsurge of violence over the weekend in which at least nine people died. It was the worst outbreak of violence in the region in two months. Extremists hurled a bomb from an ambulance as it traveled through the village of Bala Jafarly in the Kazakhsky district shortly after midnight today, Azerinform reported. Windows in several houses were shattered, it said. Later today, Armenians opened automatic gunfire on the nearby village of Keirumly, again causing no injuries, the news agency said. Officials from Armenia's Armenpress news agency said they could not communicate with the area and had no information about the events there. Armenian nationalists shot up and set fire to buildings in three villages near the Armenian border Saturday, killing at least seven people, including a family of five that burned to death in their home, official media reports said Sunday. Two Armenians died while trying to fire a shell at Azerbaijanis, the reports said. Two bombings also were reported in the southern Transcaucasian region of the Soviet Union, where the mainly Christian republic of Armenia is disputing control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region of predominantly Moslem Azerbaijan. The enclave has an Armenian majority. Azerinform said units of Interior Ministry troops and about 150 police officers were sent to control the violence in the villages of Baganis Airum, Pirili and Chaily in the Kazakhsky district. ``These bearded men armed with machine-guns raided the villages, and burned the houses, and took the cattle away,'' said a spokesman at Communist Party Central Committee headquarters in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital. ``The army helped us, there are about 140 troops in the area and the situation is becoming stable. There was no retaliation from the villagers,'' the official said Sunday, speaking on condition of anonymity. It was the most serious outburst of ethnic violence in the region since the Jan. 13 anti-Armenian riots and nationalist protests in Baku and the takeover of the city by Soviet troops a week later. According to official figures at least 197 people were killed in the January violence, 125 of them after the arrival of Soviet soldiers. The official Soviet news agency Tass and national TV called the weekend reports from the Soviet Caucasus ``bitter and tragic'' and said the attacks threatened ``some softening of the situation recently achieved in the region.'' Tass said firearms were used by both sides in the area Friday and Saturday and reported shooting at vehicles and houses. It reported some ``incidents of hostage-taking,'' without elaborating. But the national media singled out Armenian radicals, saying their acts undermined the interests of the Armenian people. On Saturday, a time bomb destroyed a gas station in Nagorno-Karabakh, the official media reported. Later, a locomotive and two wagons were blown off their rails near the Armenian city of Megri when a bomb exploded under a passenger train traveling from Armenia to Baku. Megri, in southern Armenia, borders on the Nakhichevan autonomous district, a part of Azerbaijan that geographically is separated from the republic by Armenia.

DOC.HEAD: Maine Theater Founder Dead at 81
DOC.TEXT: Victoria Crandall, a theatrical producer who for three decades staged Broadway musicals before summer audiences in Maine, has died at the age of 81. Miss Crandall, a resident of Wiscasset, Maine, died Sunday night at a hospital in New York. She had been in the city to cast roles for the Maine State Music Theatre's upcoming season. A former concert pianist, Miss Crandall in 1959 founded the Brunswick Summer Playhouse, which later became the Brunswick Music Theater. The name was changed again two years ago to the Maine State Music Theatre, with Miss Crandall serving as executive director and artistic director. The theater, located on the Bowdoin College campus, rejected packaged shows in favor of originally designed productions. Over the past three decades, Miss Crandall staged 186 productions seen by more than 1.5 million people. The theater was launched as a for-profit venture, but became a non-profit corporation in the late 1970s in order to advance its educational mission, said William Picher, the theater's director of development and public relations. Born in Cleveland to Swedish immigrants, Miss Crandall was a graduate of the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, N.Y. She went on to become a rehearsal pianist, working with performers Ethel Merman and Jimmy Durante and composer-lyricist teams such as Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe and Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart. During World War II, Miss Crandall performed in Europe under the auspices of the USO. As an assistant to a producer, Miss Crandall honed her skills in putting on Broadway musicals. She made her debut as a producer in 1951 and worked with a touring company. ``But all the time, she was looking for a place where she could settle down and establish a theater,'' Picher said. Miss Crandall is survived by two nieces. A brother died last year. A private funeral service was scheduled; plans for a public memorial were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal From Adult Book Store
DOC.TEXT: An Evansville, Ind., business convicted and fined $5,000 for showing and selling movies ``harmful to minors'' lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, without comment, refused to hear arguments that the conviction and fine infringe the free-speech rights of the Studio Art Theatre's owners and violate the required separation of government and religion. The business was indicted in 1986 on charges of violating the Indiana Criminal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) by selling and displaying movies in violation of state law. The underlying state law bars a business from selling or displaying materials that are deemed harmful to minors within 500 feet of the nearest property line of any church or school. The Studio Art Theatre is located within 500 feet of a church. At a non-jury trial, lawyers for the business agreed to let four sexually explicit movies be considered harmful for children under 18, but noted it was never alleged that any youngster actually saw or bought those movies there. A state judge found the Studio Art Theatre guilty of the RICO violations, and a state appeals court upheld the conviction in 1988 without addressing the constitutional challenge raised. The appeal acted on today attacked the 500-foot law, saying it violates free-speech rights because the offending materials do not even have to be judged obscene and therefore unworthy of constitutional protection. The appeal also said the Studio Art Theatre owners' right to be fair treatment, under equal-protection guarantees, is violated because exceptions to the 500-foot ban are made for materials available at certain libraries, museums and schools. And the appeal said the challenged law impermissibly ``delegates to a church the ability to criminalize conduct that otherwise was constitutionally protected simply because it locates within 500 feet.'' Lawyers for the Studio Art Theatre said the law has the constitutionally impermissible effect of advancing or promoting religion. The justices last year used an Indiana case to rule that states may use anti-racketeering laws to crack down on adult bookstores and other sexually oriented businesses. But the court said in that decision that prosecutors may not use state RICO laws to close down such businesses before trials are held to determine whether any of the material displayed or sold is obscene. The case acted on today is Studio Art Theatre vs. Indiana, 89-847.

DOC.HEAD: Town Angry Over Lack of Warning Before Explosion
DOC.TEXT: Town officials reacted angrily to news that state regulators knew _ but didn't warn anyone _ about safety violations at a propane gas company that has been implicated in a fatal bank explosion. Propane leaks are the suspected source of the blast at the Crested Butte State Bank on March 6. Three people died and 14 were injured in the explosion. Salgas Inc. of Crested Butte owns the underground propane lines that service the town's business district. The Denver Post reported Saturday that state Public Utilities Commission documents show that inspectors have found a host of violations at Salgas' Crested Butte operation. The documents showed that the company had no record of required leak surveys in the business district where the bank exploded, nor a record of leak repairs to the pipeline, installed in 1972. ``I think it is inexcusable that the PUC wouldn't notify jurisdictions of these violations by the gas company,'' said Mike Miller, district manager for the Crested Butte Fire Protection District. ``It's pretty tough to take action on things you don't know about.'' Town Manager William Crank said he learned of the report the week of March 11. He said he requested copies from the Public Utilities Commission and after failing to recieve it, eventually obtained the reports from a Denver television reporter. Mayor Wes Light said he also was upset when he learned of Salgas' safety record. ``I would hope they would notify municipalities in the future,'' he said. Salgas executives say leaks found near the bank were not a cause of the powerful explosion, but resulted from it.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Hear Appeal in Nebraska Death Row Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear an appeal challenging the authority of states to house convicted murderers on ``death rows'' and keep them apart from other inmates. The justices said they will review the appeal of Nebraska death row inmate John Rust, who says such segregation is ``without penological justification'' and ``grossly disproportionate'' punishment. Rust's unusual appeal, which he authored himself, does not challenge his death sentence but only the conditions of his death row confinement. The appeal, in essence, says segregating inmates who are to be executed violates their due-process and equal-protection rights. Rust was convicted of murder and sentenced to death in 1975. From the time of his imprisonment until 1978 he was allowed to remain with inmates who were serving prison terms but were not under death sentences. But in 1978 Nebraska chose to segregate all inmates under death sentences on one death row at the Nebraska State Penitentiary, a kind of ``administrative segregation.'' Most states with death penalty laws also feature a death row where inmates under death sentences are kept, removed from other inmates. Death row inmates generally do not have all the privileges of other prison inmates. Rust was convicted of killing Michael Kellogg, who had come to the aid of police officers during a supermarket robbery in Omaha. Rust is the longest-serving death row inmate in a state that has not executed anyone for three decades. His appeal also argued that switching the conditions of his confinement in 1978 represented a constitutionally impermissible ``ex post facto'' punishment. The case is Rust vs Gunter, 89-5900.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Existing Homes Drops in February
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes dropped 2.3 percent in February as mortgage interest rates continued to rise, a real estate trade group said Monday. The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.44 million units, down from 3.52 million units in January. It was the lowest since a 3.38 million rate in July, although it matched last August's 3.44 million pace. Despite the decline, Realtors president Norman D. Flynn said the sales pace ``shows considerable market strength and sets the tone for a healthy sales year.'' John A. Tuccillo, Realtors chief economist, also predicted increased sales as rates decline in the months ahead. He said the trade group expects existing-home sales to total 3.44 million units this year, down just 0.1 percent from 1989. Flynn said many buyers selected less expensive homes as their purchasing powers slipped when rates rose. Fixed-rate mortgages rose from 10.17 percent to 10.31 percent during February, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. The Realtors survey found the national median price of an existing home to be $95,400, $900 below the median for January and reflecting a larger volume of less-expensive home purchases. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. Sales declines were posted both in the Midwest and South, while sales in the West rose. The Northeast sales rate remained unchanged. Sales in the Midwest dropped 1.1 percent to 930,000 units at an annual rate while those in the South totaled 1.30 million units, down 6.4 percent. In the West, sale rose 14 percent to 650,000 units and were flat at 560,000 units in the Northeast. The median price for a home was $73,800 in the Midwest, $85,600 in the South, $143,000 in the West and $143,400 in the Northeast.

DOC.HEAD: Barge Strikes Shipwreck, Leaks Oil in Texas Waterway
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Coast Guard officials and chemical companies were working to reopen the Intracoastal Waterway today after a barge struck a shipwreck and leaked nearly 35,000 gallons of light crude oil. ``Most of the cleanup has been completed in the Intracoastal Canal, but there is still a lot in the adjacent waters that have been boomed off,'' said Coast Guard Lt. Mike Debettencourt. He said officials had hoped to have the Intracoastal Waterway reopened by 1 p.m. today. The spill occurred near environmentally sensitive wetlands and marshes, as well as a marina and an industrial area. The 190-foot barge, owned by Koch Fuel Oil, was en route from Mobile, Ala., to Corpus Christi when it struck a submerged vessel about 6:15 p.m. Sunday. The barge spewed 830 barrels holding 35,000 gallons of light crude into the waterway, Debettencourt said. Crews stopped the leak by 10 p.m. ``It's not as bad as we might have feared,'' Debettencourt added. ``It seems to be not too bad, considering.'' Most of the damaged barge's cargo was safely stored within its hull, and later pumped into an empty barge, he said. The barge was carrying a light grade of crude oil called condensate, which is extracted from natural gas wells. Wilsey Dupree, vice president of traffic for LeBeouf, said Sunday night the cleanup was going well. ``I got all the people I can get out there going that way to clean up,'' he said. ``I'm not looking at any complications right now.'' He would not give details. Shortly after the leak was reported, Coast Guard units moved into place to put two sets of containment booms around the barge, called the ``MB 2.'' Absorbent pads were also used. Local contractors were hired to start cleaning up the spilled oil, which was carried onto the coastline by strong incoming tides. An Environmental Protection Agency team was dispatched to the spill site. The leaking barge was about one-quarter mile west of the Surfside Bridge in Freeport, a town of about 12,000 people 40 miles south of Houston. The Gulf Intracoastal Waterway parallels the Texas coast for 432 miles from Sabine Pass to Brownsville. Although the Coast Guard had no immediate report on the environmental impact of the spill, shrimpers said they were worried that fishing in the area would be ruined. ``This is where I shrimp,'' said Richard Schriner. ``It's going to be a hell of a season. Shrimping is bad enough, and now this.'' Last June, about 168,000 gallons of oil spewed from the ruptured tank of a barge that collided with a ship near Bayport. In January, about 8,600 gallons of crude oil leaked from the supertanker Olympic Banner, about 60 miles offshore of Galveston, causing an oil sheen 3 miles wide and five miles long.

DOC.HEAD: Maggie Smith in `Lettice and Lovage' Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 4 grafs with what other critics said. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: No PMs planned.

Fustian House in Wiltshire is the dullest stately home in England. Nothing interesting has happened there for the last 400 years. So what is a poor tour guide to do? Make up an interesting history for the old place, says Lettice Douffet, a lady as eccentric and exotic as her first and last names. Her embellishments set in motion ``Lettice and Lovage,'' Peter Shaffer's enormously entertaining comedy about the unlikely friendship between two very different women. And when the women are played by such accomplished actresses as Maggie Smith, as the overimaginative tour guide, and Margaret Tyzack, as her frustrated boss, it makes for a very merry evening indeed. ``Lettice and Lovage,'' a big London hit, opened Sunday night at Broadway's Ethel Barrymore Theater, where the play should run for as long as Smith wants to do it. The comedy, directed with a sure, steady hand by Michael Blakemore, is what used to be a called ``a star turn,'' a chance for theatergoers to see an actor or actress do what they do best. And Shaffer, author of such diverse and weightier plays as ``Equus'' and ``Amadeus,'' certainly gives Smith a lot of opportunities. The play opens with several hilarious short scenes as Lettice describes the history of Fustian House in increasingly inaccurate detail to a group of gullible tourists. Smith, her hair a striking mop of red curls, doesn't just recite this bogus history. She sweeps into it, arms flailing like a dying swan. Her voice, a mixture of murmurs, coos and trills, earns applause from her enthusiastic pupils _ and the audience. Unfortunately, one member of the tour turns out to be Lotte Schoen, her supervisor, who then fires the woman for falsifying history. For much of the play, Shaffer contrasts the two middle-aged spinsters and their different philosophies of life. ``Enlarge, enliven, enlighten,'' exhorts Lettice who learned the three words from her mother, a free spirit who performed Shakespeare's plays in French. Her own translations, Lettice proudly announces. Lotte is a bitter woman, unhappy about her life, but she feels sorry for Lettice and tries to get her another job, this time as a tour guide on a boat traveling the Thames. Gradually, their friendship builds. Their love for the England, and particularly London, of yesterday is what unites them. They lament the destruction of great old buildings and castigate the modern monstrosities that have gone up in their place. The plot falters a bit at the end of the second act, and it's odd that one of the play's major events occurs off stage between the second and third acts. Everyone talks about the incident, particularly a lawyer, crisply played by the wonderful Paxton Whitehead. Tyzack is a worthy foil for the extravagant Smith. Bette Henritze scores as Lotte's dithering secretary and there is a scene-stealing bit by a large, blinking gray cat christened by Lettice _ with typical theatricality _ as Felina, Queen of Sorrows. But there's no doubt that ``Lettice and Lovage'' really belongs to Smith, and she revels in its glorious excesses. It's a perfect marriage of star and story.

What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: This is idiosyncratic theater acting of a high and endangered order, not to be confused with the actress' tightly minimalistic film work. If ``Lettice and Lovage'' is but a modest excuse for it, what theater lover needs any excuse whatsoever to have a rare reunion with Maggie Smith? Howard Kissel, the Daily News: At heart the play is a celebration of the imagination, a celebration of the art of theater. With these celebrants, there's great cause for rejoicing. Clive Barnes, New York Post: This is no mere one-woman triumph. Playwright Peter Shaffer and his director, Michael Blakemore, have conspired with actresses, the ebulliently bewitching Smith and a queen of more stately necromancy, Margaret Tyzack, to produce an evening of enchantment and delight.

DOC.HEAD: White House Expresses Concern Over Lithuanian Developments
EDa: LEADS with 11 grafs new White House comments; picks up 5th graf pvs, President Bush's...
DOC.TEXT: The White House today called the Soviet occupation of two buildings in Lithuania a ``significant event'' in the escalation of tensions and reiterated a call for restraint on both sides. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater also said that the United States had received new private assurances from the Soviet Union _ backing up public ones _ that the Kremlin would not use force to block Lithuanian independence. But Fitzwater said that Moscow's action over the weekend in seizing two Communist Party buildings in Vilnius, the capital of the rebellious Baltic state, amounted to ``a kind of force and we're opposed to any kind of use of force.'' Tensions in Lithuania ``seem to have escalated on a daily basis for the last week or so. We're hopeful that's not continuing. ... Building occupation is a significant event in this sense.'' ``Further actions will not lead to a lessening of the tensions and could have adverse international repercussions and could be counterproductive for U.S.-Soviet relations,'' Fitzwater said. Those comments echoed Sunday's claim by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that a Soviet military crackdown would have ``significant negative consequences'' on U.S.-Soviet relations. The president's spokesman, reading from a prepared statement, said: ``The Soviets themselves have publicly and privately assured us that they have no intentions of using military force to resolve the issue.'' Asked about recent private assurances, Fitzwater cited a meeting at the State Department on Friday between Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger and Soviet Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin. Those are in addition to remarks last week between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and ``other private discussions on a diplomatic level,'' Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said there is now reason to expect that the situation in Lithuania will disrupt President Bush's summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in late June. ``We're prepared to have the summit at this time,'' Fitzwater said. ``We're still hopeful this can all be resolved.'' Cheney, interviewed Sunday on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation,'' said that the United States would like to see the Lithuanians ``granted the same prerogative that the East Germans were: self determination.'' He said a military crackdown would ``undermine a lot of the good work'' done in recent years in improving U.S.-Soviet relations. President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said Saturday that any Soviet use of force ``would be counterproductive'' and that the United States ``would not ignore it.'' Bush himself had no comment Sunday on the situation in Lithuania as he returned from a weekend at Camp David, his mountain retreat in Maryland. Soviet troops occupied two communist schools in Vilnius, capital of the Baltic state, on Sunday, one day after tanks rolled through the streets in the middle of the night. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Kremlin officials have been pressuring Lithuania's newly elected leaders to back off attempts to secede. Bush said Friday that any Soviet attempt to ``intimidate or forcibly intervene against the Lithuanian people is bound to backfire.'' The United States and the Western world have never recognized the Soviet Union's forcible annexation of Lithuania and its sister Baltic states, Estonia and Latvia, in 1940 as war swept over Europe. But the United States now says it will not grant formal recognition until the breakaway republic establishes control over its territory, and Bush has urged the Lithuanians to recognize ``certain realities'' about its relationship to Moscow. Asked if the United States had lured Lithuania into rebelling, Cheney said, ``We have not been out actively soliciting revolution, if you will. On the other hand, we've made it clear that we share the aspirations of the Lithuanian people for self-determination.''

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Will Dismantle Iron Curtain By June
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia will completely dismantle its Iron Curtain border with West Germany and Austria by June, the state news agency CTK reported today. Czechoslovakia had almost 420 miles of barbed wire and other technical equipment along its western and southern borders with West Germany and Austria before the peaceful revolution that overturned one-party Communist rule last November. Border guards began dismantling the border fortifications in December, when the new Foreign Minister, former dissident Jiri Dienstbier, gleefully joined his Austrian and West German counterparts in ceremonies to cut open the barbed wire. Czechoslovaks had received their new freedom for unlimited travel abroad a few days before. Since December, about 90 miles of barbed wire has been removed from the Austrian border, CTK said.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Ease Tension After Soviet Army Seizes Schools In Secessionist Republic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 22nd graf, ``We did ...' with White House comments.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,10
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian officials met with Soviet military officers today and said tensions had eased after their talks about the army's occupation of three Communist Party buildings. The move Sunday, which the army said was at the request of local Communist officials, was Moscow's latest action in a war of nerves with the Baltic republic that declared independence two weeks ago. ``After coming out of this meeting, I can say the mood has changed,'' said Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas. ``It is evident the conflict will not be escalated.'' In Moscow, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev reiterated that he has no plans to use force to bring Lithuania back into the Soviet fold, said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, who met with Gorbachev for 1{ hours. ``President Gorbachev indicated to me that the position of the Soviet Union was that there would be no use of force unless the lives of others were threatened, and that he was committed to a peaceful resolution,'' Kennedy told reporters. Kennedy said Gorbachev did not specify whose lives might be threatened in Lithuania, or whether he thought such threats imminent. Ozolas and Lithuanian Interior Minister Marijonas Misiukonis met with Col. Viktor Smokarev, deputy chief of the Vilnius military garrison and Col. Vladimir Trikoz of the Interior Ministry. They agreed not to take any steps affecting security without first informing the other side, Ozolas told reporters. Ozolas said the military officers alleged that a soldier was beaten and that shots were fired at soldiers from a passing car, though no one was hurt in that incident. Ozolas said Lithuanians complained about the convoy of 100 military vehicles sent through downtown Vilnius early Saturday, military flights over the capital and other cities, and the occupation of the party buildings in Vilnius. Ozolas said while the meeting did not mean negotiations had begun with Soviet officials about the republic's March 11 declaration of independence, ``It seems that these are leading to talks with Moscow.'' Earlier, Premier Kazimiera Prunskeine said the first meeting between military officers and Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis late Sunday had begun to clear the air. ``We began to get relief last night with the beginning of negotiations with representatives of the army,'' she told the Supreme Council parliament. On Sunday Landsbergis spoke twice by telephone with Gen. Valentin I. Varennikov, commander of Soviet ground forces, who in a newspaper interview Sunday accused independence leaders of plotting to arrest Communists and send them to prison. Soldiers appeared Sunday at the Higher Party School and the Institute of Marxism-Leninism. Lithuanian officials said there also were soldiers at the Vilnius Communist Party headquarters. Franciskas Benucius, a director of the Higher Party School, said 30 soldiers who arrived there told him they were sent to guard the building. ``I asked, `What are you protecting it from?' and they didn't know,'' he said. In response to the Soviet move, the Lithuanian leadership passed a resolution calling for prosecution of troops who ``illegally'' occupied the buildings. The resolution was published today but there was no indication the Lithuanians would attempt to arrest the soldiers. The military officers told Landsbergis during the meeting that they had moved into the buildings at the request of Lithuanian Communists who remain loyal to Moscow. The majority of the party split with Moscow in December to found an independent Communist Party. The two opposing parties had been sharing the buildings, but some space recently had been turned over to non-political organizations. ``We expressed surprise and astonishment that the military can occupy buildings at the request of a political organization and we asked if such requests come from other organizations whether they will fulfill them,'' Landsbergis told reporters Sunday. ``We did not receive a concrete answer,'' he said. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that building seizures amounted to ``a kind of force and we're opposed to any kind of use of force.'' Tensions in Lithuania ``seem to have escalated on a daily basis for the last week or so. We're hopeful that's not continuing. ... Building occupation is a significant event in this sense.'' For days, Gorbachev and other Moscow officials have squeezed the defiant Baltic state with displays of military strength and demands of fealty. Gorbachev ordered Lithuanians to surrender all firearms and told them not to sign up for volunteer units under the republic's government. State media sought to portray Lithuania as in a state of anarchy. At the same time, Soviet leaders said they will not use force in their bid to prevent Lithuanians from trying to restore the independence they lost in 1940 when their republic was forcibly annexed along with the two other Baltic states _ Latvia and Estonia.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Injuries Reported as Boston-St. Louis Plane Aborts Takeoff
DOC.TEXT: A TWA flight aborted its takeoff this morning after fire and smoke was detected in an engine, a Logan Airport official said. Seven people suffered minor injuries during the emergency evacuation of the plane. Phil Orlandella, spokesman for the Massachusetts Port Authority, which runs Logan Airport, said the crew aboard an L-1011 jet abandoned its takeoff at around 9:30. The flight was bound for St. Louis. Orlandella said the jet taxied off the runway and evacuation chutes were deployed to help 163 passengers get off the plane. There was also a crew of 13 on board. Seven people were slightly injured, he said. MassPort crews found no smoke or fire when they inspected the engine, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide If Railroads Can Ignore Union Contracts in Mergers
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether railroads can ignore union contracts to complete mergers approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The court said it will review a ruling that restrains the railroads and the ICC from overriding collective bargaining agreements. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled for the unions last July in two separate cases. The first case stems from ICC approval in 1980 of acquisition by CSX Corp. of the Chessie System and Seaboard Coast Line Industries. CXS decided in 1986 to close its freight car repair shop at Waycross, Ga., and to transfer work done there to a Chessie System shop in Raceland, Ky. The transfer meant eliminating jobs and transferring some Waycross workers to Raceland. Transferred workers were told they no longer could count on lifetime income guaranteed by the contract signed by CSX and the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen. In the second case, Norfolk and Western Railway Co. and the Southern Railway Co. announced in 1986 plans to merge operations centers in Roanoke, Va., and Atlanta. The consolidation eliminated some supervisors jobs at Roanoke. The American Train Dispatchers Association said the plans violated the union's contract with Norfolk and Western. The ICC in both cases said the railroads were exempt from the union contracts. But the appeals court here said Congress has not given the ICC such broad power ``with so much potential to destablize the railroad industry.'' ``We can not impute to Congress the intention to make the bargained-for provisions of a collective bargaining agreement contingent upon their not later becoming inconvenient to the full realization of operating economies that a merger might make possible,'' the appeals court said. It ordered further review by the ICC in both cases. The Bush administration urged the Supreme Court not to disturb the appeals court ruling. The cases are Norfolk and Western vs. American Train Dispatchers, 89-1027; CSX Transportation vs. Brotherhood of Railway Carmen, 89-1928.

DOC.HEAD: After First Free Vote In Decades, Heirs To Communists Clearly Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Communist leader's comment, 38 percent of vote in, no clear winner. Pickup 10th graf `The Forum...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: Hungarians voting in their nation's first free elections in more than 40 years ousted the Communists from power and may have even denied them any seats in parliament, according to results today. ``If we're represented in Parliament, we will have achieved the aim we set for ourselves,'' said party leader Gyula Thuermer, who finished a distant fifth in his own district in Sunday's election but still predicted Communist seats in the lawmaking body. With 38 percent of the vote counted, however, the Communists were in eighth place with 3.56 percent. The results, however, also gave no opposition party a clear victory. The conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum led with 24.59 percent and the center-left League of Free Democrats was second with 19.92 percent, the government news agency MTI said. The Independent Smallholders, a revived pre-World War II party popular in Hungary's villages, had 12.69 percent, with the Socialists, the main successors to the Communists, trailing in fourth place with 10.3 percent, MTI said. Rezsoe Nyers, the Socialist chairman, said he had no illusions about his party's future: ``We will be an opposition party.'' Since election law mandates runoff elections for each seat not won by an absolute majority, it was clear most seats would have to be contested again in a second round _ likely on April 8. Even a second round was not expected to determine a clear winner, making a coalition government the most likely outcome. The Forum embodies traditional Hungarian populism and draws most of its support from the provinces. The more urbane Free Democrats have a core of former dissidents. The Independent Smallholders advocate returning land confiscated by the Communists after their takeover. The Hungarian people's rejection of heirs to long-ruling Communists followed similar moves in other former Soviet satellites. East Germany held Eastern Europe's first completely free elections in decades on March 18, and the reformed Communists were rejected there. In June, pro-Solidarity candidates won parliamentary seats in all but one of the races they were allowed to contest. Czechoslovaks are to vote in June in their first free parliamentary elections in decades and nationwide balloting is expected in Bulgaria and Romania in May. Premier Miklos Nemeth, a Communist reformer and key engineer of the nation's two-year reform course, was one of just five candidates reported to have won a simple majority in Sunday's vote. He was running as an independent. Foreign Minister Gyula Horn, another key reformer, was also leading in his race. Interim president Matyas Szueros also led in his constituency but, like Horn, failed to secure more than 50 percent of votes to win outright. Another prominent reformer, Imre Pozsgay, was trailing in another race. Election results trickled in at election commission headquarters in the gothic Parliament building and at the election studio of state television and final results were not expected until late today at the earliest. About 7.8 million people were eligible to vote and election officials said preliminary figures showed turnout was more than 70 percent. Under a complex distribution system devised by the Communists and opposition in talks last year, 176 of the 394 seats in Parliament will go to individual winners. Most of the rest will be distributed on a proportional basis, with eight seats reserved for national minorities. Hungary's last elections were in 1947, when the Communists won a relative majority, largely through fraud. A year later, they consolidated power and forced all other parties out of existence. In October, Communists reformers dissolved the old ruling party and renamed themselves Socialists. They said they were committed to Western-style parliamentary democracy, but most Hungarians still associated them with the autocrats who dominated Hungarian life for decades.

DOC.HEAD: Veggies Headed for White House Despite Presidential Snub
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with broccoli ceremony; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The produce industry today bestowed on Barbara Bush a broccoli bouquet and three cases of the vegetable and urged the first lady to try some new recipes to entice her husband ``into the wonderful world of fresh produce.'' It was actually just the tip of a 10,000-pound iceberg of broccoli that California growers are donating to soup kitchens and shelters in a good-natured riposte to President Bush's refusal to eat his broccoli. Mrs. Bush, who chairs the nationwide ``Second Harvest'' drive to donate food to the hungry, called it ``wonderful'' and joked, `I'm going to overlook the fact you think my cooking is not up to par.'' ``I'm going to tell you the honest truth: the president is never going to eat broccoli,'' Mrs. Bush told a gaggle of broccoli-industry boosters _ all wearing broccoli boutonnieres _ on the White House lawn before more than 200 reporters, photographers and television camera crews. The industry had said beforehand it was shipping 10 tons of broccoli from California. At the event, they halved the estimate. George Dunlop, president of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association, boasted that 10,000 pounds of broccoli was enough to serve 80,000 hungry people. ``We appreciate the fact that the president himself does not like broccoli personally,'' said Dunlop. Refusing to give up the fight, he added that along with the three cases for the White House kitchens he had brought ``along some very good new recipes which you might use ... (and) just might intrigue the president to take the plunge into the wonderful world of fresh broccoli.'' ``Millie and I thank you for the broccoli. We'll eat it,'' said the first lady, whose pet dog stretched out on the lawn beside the three cases of Irish Spring broccoli, spilling over a small table. But just as George Bush has vowed never to bite another sprig of broccoli, she assured her guests, ``I am never going to eat pork rinds ever.'' She indicated Bush was adamant in his stance against broccoli. ``If his own blessed mother can't make him eat broccoli,'' she said, ``then I give up.'' She said that without the broccoli brouhaha, the media would never have turned out in such numbers to cover a donation of food to the Capitol Area Community Food Bank. Bush set the wheels in motion for the protest when it became known that he ordered stewards aboard Air Force One to stop serving him broccoli. He stood his ground at a news conference last Thursday, with words a recalcitrant child could only envy: ``I do not like broccoli and I haven't liked it since I was a little kid and my mother made me eat it and I'm president of the United States and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Burma Colluding in Drug Traffic
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. official today accused Burma's government of colluding with drug traffickers but said Washington had no plans for military action there to stem the massive outflow of heroin. The United States has identified Burma as the biggest single producer of heroin in the world. It recently indicted opium warlord Khun Sa, who operates in northeastern Burma, saying he was probably the largest heroin pusher in the world. Washington is highly skeptical about the Burmese government's commitment to combating the drug trade, Assistant Secretary of State Melvin Levitsky said at a news conference in Bangkok. But even if Rangoon was committed, he said, it would have difficulty catching Khun Sa because it did not control the area of the country in which he operated. Rangoon dropped efforts to eradicate opium growing after its military crushed a mass movement for democracy and seized power in September 1988, Levitsky said. ``Evidence indicates that the government of Burma has a collusive relationship with some of the traffickers and is allowing them to bargain their way to go ahead unfettered,'' he said. It was not clear if Levitsky was referring directly to Khun Sa, an elusive trafficker who has operated in the so-called ``Golden Triangle'' of Burma, Thailand and Laos since the 1960s. After initially emphasizing crack cocaine in its anti-drug drive, the Bush administration is addressing the problem of heroin which is likely to remain a longer term problem in the United States, Levitsky said. But asked what Washington was prepared to do to bring Khun Sa to trial and whether it was considering military force, Levitsky said: ``We have no plans for any kind of military action to get Khun Sa. It would violate another country's borders. ``Obviously if Khun Sa falls into another government's hands or if another government arrests him we would like to have him to try in the United States,'' he said. Thailand, as well as other countries, could exert a positive influence on Burma to toughen its stand on drugs, he said. Most heroin from Burma is smuggled through Thailand.

DOC.HEAD: Police Shoot At Protesters, Killing 2 And Wounding Hundreds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with report of police firing on protesters, killing 2. Pickup 3rd graf `Police said...'
DOC.TEXT: Police today fired on black protesters in a nearby township, killing at least two people and wounding many others, a hospital worker said. Police said protesters in the Sebokeng township had stoned a police station and set fire to municipal buildings. Elsewhere, factional fighting over the weekend left 15 blacks dead, according to police and press reports. Police used shotguns and tear gas to disperse several thousand blacks in Sebokeng and the nearby township of Sharpeville protested high rent and poor housing and working conditions, witnesses said. The townships are just south of Johannesburg, about six miles apart. At least two blacks were killed and hundreds wounded in the conflict in Sebokeng, according to a nurse at the Sebokeng Hospital who declined to give her name. No injuries were reported in Sharpeville. Police said suspected African National Congress guerrillas fired two rocket propelled grenades Sunday night at town council offices in the black township of Soweto outside Johannesburg. The two Soviet-made RPG-7 grenades caused some damage, but police said there were no injuries. An hour later, three limpet mines were detonated at the Langlaagte power station in Johannesburg, badly damaging three transformers, police said. The blasts did not cause any injuries, they said. Hundreds of police and security officers were hunting today for the men responsible for the attacks, the most serious in several months. Police were checking areas of Soweto and questioning possible suspects, officers said. Police officials, who declined to be named, said they believed the ANC's military wing mounted the attacks as ``a show of force'' to back its demands that the South African defense forces agree to a cease-fire. Nelson Mandela and other ANC leaders are to meet with the government April 11 in Cape Town to try to clear the way for talks on ending white-minority rule and sharing political power with blacks. President F.W. de Klerk legalized the ANC and other black opposition groups last month in a bid to clear the way for talks on drafting a new constitution. Police reports said at least seven people were killed Sunday in fighting between rival black factions in the eastern province of Natal. They said four men were shot and killed when a mob burned 20 huts near Hibberdene and that three people were shot and killed in clashes around Gesubuzo. The state-run South African Broadcasting Corporation said eight people were killed and nine injured in a factional fight Sunday near the Natal province town of Tugela Ferry. Fighting flared around the Natal town of Edendale when rival groups attacked buses carrying supporters of the Zulu tribe's Inkatha movement back from a rally. Police attempted to halt the attacks, but 26 buses and cars were damaged by rocks and other objects, police said. Police reported no deaths in the clashes. Hundreds of people have been killed in recent months in Natal in fighting between Inkatha and the rival ANC-backed United Democratic Front. Both groups oppose apartheid, but the more conservative Inkatha wants separate states for Zulus and other ethnic groups. Efforts by Mandela and other black leaders in recent weeks to end the factional killings in Natal have been ineffective.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Try To Trade Congress for Top Title in Statehouse
DOC.TEXT: Eight members of Congress are trying to prove this year that you can go home again _ as governor. Potomac fever rarely goes into remission, but among those politicians who have had enough of Capitol Hill, an increasingly popular career path leads to places like Little Rock, Tallahassee, Hartford and Montgomery. Seven members of Congress won governorships from 1982 to 1989, about a third of those who tried. Those odds are hardly comparable to the 98 percent return rate for members of Congress who seek re-election, but the higher risk hasn't discouraged a crop of eight new gubernatorial aspirants this year. ``You can do more in an afternoon as governor than you can in a career in Congress,'' said one gubernatorial hopeful, Republican Rep. John Rowland of Connecticut, attributing the quip to former Delaware Gov. Pete du Pont. It is theme sounded often among those hoping to return home. Many say they want to take on greater challenges, test their executive skills, set their own agendas and leave their marks on education, drug abuse, budgets, the business climate and the environment. ``I've spent the last seven years pushing and pulling, trying to get the federal government to deal with its deficit. It's a very difficult process,'' said Democratic Rep. Bruce Morrison, another Connecticut gubernatorial hopeful. ``The federal government has lost its capacity to really be the source of solutions to many problems.'' Larry Sabato, a University of Virginia political scientist who wrote a book about the American governorship, calls Congress ``an increasingly depressing place to work.'' ``The budget deficit is a permanent excuse for inaction. Democrats and many Republicans are frustrated. The money isn't there to do what they want to do, and the will to raise taxes isn't there,'' Sabato said. In contrast, he said, ``the states have both the resources and the will to innovate. Being in a state capitol is much more invigorating than it was 25 years ago.'' The desire to head home to the statehouse may run even deeper in Congress than what is apparent on the surface. ``For everyone that runs for governor out of Congress, there is generally a substantial number greater than that who are thinking about it, particularly in the off-years,'' said Rep. Joseph Brennan, a Maine Democrat who is trying to reclaim his old job as governor. ``Many people here, if they had a choice, would prefer to be the chief executive of a state.'' Members of Congress cite career advancement and personal fulfullment as primary reasons to return to the statehouse. But they also see the move as a chance to escape the pressures they face in Congress from constant travel, continuous fund-raising and little time for family. ``The pace and the back and forth and the commitments are a hardship on any family, but it's even worse on a young family,'' said Rowland, who has children aged 5, 3 and 1 who live in Connecticut. Roots are another element of the pull towards home. Rowland, for instance, said his family has lived in Connecticut for 150 years. Democratic Rep. Ronnie Flippo, hoping to become governor of Alabama, tells home state audiences he can't get used to ``a place that serves their tea hot and their green beans cold.'' Other members of Congress running for governor this year are Republican Sen. Pete Wilson of California and Reps. Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; Tommy Robinson, R-Ark.; and Wes Watkins, D-Okla. At least two more members are eyeing other state jobs as potential stepping stones. Republican Sen. Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire is retiring from the Senate and considering a run for a $100-a-year job in the part-time state Senate while he awaits a shot at the governorship. That won't be until his friend, Republican Gov. Judd Gregg, decides to retire, which might not be until 1996. Rep. Michael DeWine, R-Ohio, considered a gubernatorial bid this year and opted to try for lieutenant governor on a ticket with former Cleveland mayor George Voinovich. DeWine, whose family moved back to Ohio last year, would take a pay cut from $96,600 to $51,000 if the GOP ticket wins. The tradeoff, he said, is ``a greater opportunity to get things done.'' He'll also have a statewide organization to activate when it's his turn to run for governor or senator.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested for Role in Fatal Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Police Monday announced the arrests of three men suspected of flying a helicopter over a prison and trying to free a colleague who fell to his death. The suspects were arrested Saturday and Sunday around Paris after being identified by the helicopter pilot and another witness, police said. The pilot had not been told in advance of the nature of the flight Feb. 18. His passengers dropped a line from the aircraft as it passed over the prison in Fresnes, south of Paris. Emile Dieudonne, convicted of leading a series of holdups, grabbed the line. The escape attempt went awry when another inmate seized Dieudonne's legs in hopes of getting an unplanned ride to freedom. Both prisoners fell. Dieudonne was killed and the other man seriously injured. Police said the suspected mastermind of the escape attempt was Francis Jacottin, 33, who had escaped from a different prison in September. Also arrested were Bruno Vaird, 26, and Claude Cousseau, 45, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Denies Amnesty Claims of Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: The government Monday denied allegations by Amnesty International of human rights abuses in Kuwait but said it was establishing a special panel to deal with the organization's queries. At least two statements from Amnesty International over the past six weeks have accused the Kuwaiti government of detaining without trial a number of Shiite Moslems in connection with bombings at Mecca last summer. Kuwait is a predominantly Sunni Moslem country. A spokesman for the special Justice Ministry panel denied the Shiites were the victims of discrimination. He said the government was adhering to articles in its constitution that ``provide for equal treatment of citizens and expatriates on human rights considerations to the exclusion of any discrimination due to sex, origin, language or religion.'' ``The allegations compiled in a recent press release about illegal practices towards human rights by Kuwaiti authorities are completely baseless,'' the spokesman added. He spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Out of Kuwait's interest in the humanitarian role of Amnesty International, the government has set up an ad hoc panel to answer all its messages and queries,'' the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Original Eiffel Tower Staircase Goes To Auction
DOC.TEXT: A piece of French history goes up for bid April 4 with the auction of the last three available sections of the Eiffel Tower's original spiral staircase. The sale is to take place in Toyko at the Hotel Okura and will be transmitted by satellite to bidders at the Eiffel Tower. The staircase, which links the second and third stories of the famed symbol of Paris, was inaugurated March 31, 1889, when Gustave Eiffel climbed to the top and unfurled the French tricolor emblazoned with the gold initials ``R.F.'' for the French Republic. At the time, the tower was the tallest structure ever built, rising 1,000 feet from its base. The narrow, winding staircase was the only way to the top. In 1983, engineers had the staircase removed for security reasons. The other sections of the staircase were sold earlier for prices ranging from $8,500 to 25,000.

DOC.HEAD: Poaching Depleting Rhino Population, Says Minister
DOC.TEXT: Poachers hunting the rhinoceros for its so-called aphrodisiac horn have severely reduced the animal's population in West Bengal state, Environment Minister Maneka Gandhi said Monday. Ms. Gandhi told Parliament only 39 rhinoceroses remain in the eastern state, compared to 88 in 1970. But in neighboring Assam state, the rhrew from 400 in 1966 to 1,543 today because of a special government project, she said. Of these, 1,250 were in the Kaziranga National Park. The park is the main sanctuary for the Indian one-horned rhino. At least 20 rhinos are killed each yearino population g in India. Their horns are removed and sent to Hong Kong or Singapore to be turned into powder and sold as an aphodisiac. The Indian rhino was nearly extinct at the turn of the century but its numbers have increased substantially, primarily because of government projects like that in Assam.

DOC.HEAD: Flash Flood Maroons 10,000
DOC.TEXT: A rain-swollen river burst its embankments and triggered flash floods that marooned about 10,000 people in northeastern Bangladesh, a newspaper said Monday. The Khowai River, which runs down the hills from neighboring India, overflowed Sundatering a zone in Nicosia on the Turkish Cypriot side of the Green Line, which divides the capital. Judge Yasar Atasagun said the law called for at least two years' imprisonment but that he was lenient. Paris Christoforou, 17, was convicted of the same crime but received a 15-day sentence because of his age and because he surrendered to Turkish Cypriot authorities after crossing the line, the judge said. Two other Greek Cypriot youths have been jailed recently on similar charges. Petros Papaleontiou, 17, was sentenced to three months in prison and Nicos Nicolaou, 20, to 20 days. They were both convicted of entering a restricted military area and pulling down, or attempting to pull down, Turkish and Turkish Cypriot flags. Cyprus has been divided since the 1974 Turkish invasion. It was prompted by a coup by Greek Cypriots who favored union with Greece. Only Turkey recognizes the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, which was proclaimed in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant in U.S. Murder Wins Libel Case
DOC.TEXT: A journalist was ordered Monday to pay a man $6,500 for an article that concluded the man arranged his wife's murder. The victor is currently in jail on charges he tried to arrange the slaying. Kazuyoshi Miura, the plaintiff in the libel suit, is also on trial along with a friend in connection with the eventual murder of his wife, who was shot to death in Los Angeles in November 1981. Miura filed suit against magazine writer Joji Abe in October, one year after the article appeared in the Weekly Asahi. The Tokyo court found that Abe's conclusion that Miura ordered his wife, Kazumi, slain was not based on sufficient evidence. Miura, 42, had sought $32,000 from Abe. He also demanded that Asahi Shimbun Co., the magazine's publisher, pay $12,900 in compensation and publish an apology. Judge Hiromi Emi turned down that demand. Miura was convicted in August 1987 of enlising a mistress' aid in an unsuccessful bid to kill his wife and is serving a six-year sentence. That attempt occurred three months before the fatal shooting. Miura is appealing the sentence. At the same time, he is on trial along with a friend for his wife's murder. The murder charge was filed in November 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Some Filipinos Question Wisdom of Letting U.S. Prosecute Mrs. Marcos
DOC.TEXT: The trial of Imelda Marcos in New York has spared the Manila government a political dilemma, but it also has raised questions about whether she should have been prosecuted first on foreign soil. Mrs. Marcos, widow of former President Ferdinand Marcos, went on trial last week in a Manhattan federal court on racketeering charges in connection with the alleged looting of the Philippine treasury during her husband's 20-year rule. President Corazon Aquino's administration claims Marcos, his family and associates embezzled up to $10 billion before he was ousted four years ago. Despite the allegations, neither Marcos nor his widow was ever charged in the Philippines with a criminal offense, although they have been named in more than 30 civil suits. The Philippine Constitution forbids trials in absentia, and officials feared the Marcoses would invoke their right to return from exile if criminal charges were filed. Marcos died in Hawaii in September. The absence of criminal charges has impeded efforts to recover the fortune Marcos allegedly transferred abroad. Authorities in Switzerland, where much of the wealth is believed deposited, stalled on lifting banking secrecy laws pending criminal charges. Officials hope that a conviction by an American court will speed the transfer of Marcos' assets. It would also make it unlikely that Mrs. Marcos could return to the Philippines before Mrs. Aquino's term expires in 1992. When the trial began, many Filipino commentators expressed satisfaction that Mrs. Marcos would finally have to answer in court to allegations of profligacy and corruption. Even though the opening days have been devoted to the mundane problems of jury selection, the trial has been front-page news in the Philippines. ``She went on fabulous shopping sprees and gave lavish parties,'' wrote The Manila Standard. ``Now, she faces charges which suggest that these were made possible in large part by the money she has embezzled.'' Others, however, questioned the wisdom of allowing the Americans _ the former colonial power _ to determine her guilt or innocence. The United States had the right to do so because the alleged offenses violated U.S. law. ``This means the loss of the nation's supreme legal authority to give and enforce the law within its own territory,'' said Francisco Tatad, a former Marcos spokesman who later broke with the late president. ``The state lost its most important attribute and became much less than a state.'' Predictably, Marcos' supporters have been at the forefront of those who feel the trial infringes on sovereignty. ``It is an insult to the country's sovereignty because a former first lady deserves the dignity to defend herself in her own country,'' said Rep. Salvador Escudero, a member of Marcos' New Society Movement party. ``Whatever crime she has committed, it should be defensible within the context of Philippine laws.'' But the trial also reminded other Filipinos of the limitations of their own judicial system, where proceedings are often influenced by money and political power. The retrial of 40 defendants in the 1983 assassination of Mrs. Aquino's own husband, Benigno Aquino Jr., has been dragging on since April 1987. ``Could it really be an affront to our national dignity, not because an erstwhile leader is being tried by a foreign government but because it only highlights our own failure in serving the ends of justice,'' asked the independent daily Malaya?

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors Say Accused Arsonist Was a Decent Man
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Gonzalez emigrated...', with 6 grafs to ADD background information on Gonzalez from immigration officials. Picks up 16th graf, `Luis Rolan...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: His neighbors say Julio Gonzalez was a quiet man who sometimes helped them with their chores. But police said the Cuban immigrant, angered by the rejection of a former girlfriend, set fire to the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx and killed 87 people. ``I ... right now I'm stuttering, I can't ... I'm still in shock. To have somebody with a demented mind do that and living here,'' said Yvonne Torres, 29, who lived two rooms away from Gonzalez. The 36-year-old man moved into the rooming house about three months ago, after he and his girlfriend stopped living together, police said. Gonzalez lived in a sparse room with a bed, a clothes closet and a picture of Jesus on one wall. Many of his neighbors said Gonzalez often offered to help them carry groceries or do other chores. ``He's neat, tidy and well-mannered,'' said the building's manager, Ray Davis. ``He's not loud or the type of guy you would notice in a crowd.'' A police spokesman, Lt. Raymond O'Donnell, said Gonzalez, who was arrested at home 12 hours after the fire started at 3:40 a.m. Sunday, used to work in a warehouse but had been unemployed for the past six months. When questioned by police, he broke down and cried and was remorseful, O'Donnell said. Early Sunday, police said, Gonzalez went to the club and argued with his 45-year-old former girlfriend before he was kicked out by a bouncer. ``He's drinking at the club. He wants to get back with her. She says, `Leave me alone, leave me alone.' The bouncer ejects him. He comes back and sets the place on fire,'' O'Donnell said. He was charged Sunday with arson and murder, O'Donnell said. He was led out of the stationhouse Sunday night wearing a bulletproof vest, which police asked him to wear as a precaution. Gonzalez said nothing as reporters bombarded him with questions. At the boarding house, neighbor Celia Lopez, 37, described Gonzalez as someone who did not seem to have many friends. ``Not many people came to visit him. He never caused any problems or arguments,'' she said. Gonzalez came to the United States in 1980 as part of the Mariel boatlift that brought 125,000 Cubans to the United States, O'Donnell said. Gonzalez was detained by U.S. immigration officials at Camp McCoy, Wis., and Fort Chaffee, Ark., until his release on Feb. 21, 1981, said Verne Jervis of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington. Jervis said Gonzalez was granted parolee status and sent to live with a sponsor family in New York City, adding, ``We've had no contact from him since.'' Gonzalez never applied for permanent residency, which he could have sought in 1982, and therefore could be deported if ever convicted of a crime. U.S. officials have long accused Cuba of including hardened criminals among those traveling on the boatlift, but Jervis said Gonzalez's only criminal record in Cuba was serving ``some time'' in prison for desertion from the Cuban army. Luis Rolan, 30, lived next door to Gonzalez's 10-foot by 12-foot room, which has a small balcony and rented for less than $100 a week. The two would drink beer together, but Gonzalez never mentioned problems with his girlfriend. ``That was just too personal. We didn't get into things like that,'' he said. ``He's a nice guy. He didn't talk to nobody. He wasn't the kind who would do this,'' Rolan said. ``But you know what they say,'' Davis said. ``It's the quiet guy you have to watch for.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Nominate Alabama Banker to S&L Oversight Board
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he will nominate Philip C. Jackson Jr., an Alabama banker, to the oversight board of the Resolution Trust Corporation. That is the new agency created last year to regulate the ailing savings and loan industry. Jackson is currently an adjunct professor at Birmingham Southern College in Birmingham, Ala. He is a former vice chairman of Central Bankshares of the South in Birmingham. The White House also said Bush will appoint James D. Wolfensohn to the board of trustees for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Wolfensohn, president of James D. Wolf Inc. of New York, would succeed Joe L. Allbritton.

DOC.HEAD: Former Director of Princeton's Center of International Studies Dies
DOC.TEXT: Klaus E. Knorr, professor emeritus of public affairs at Princeton University and a former director of its Center of International Studies, has died of cancer. He was 78. The German-born economist and political scientist died at his home Sunday. In his writings, Knorr argued against use of military force during the nuclear age. During the buildup of U.S. military involvement in Vietnam in 1968, Knorr called for the withdrawal of American and North Vietnamese forces, introduction of an international peacekeeping force and the formation of a neutral government in South Vietnam. The war continued for seven more years. Knorr earned his law degree in Germany and left for the United States in 1937 after resisting pressure to join the Nazi party. He earned a Ph.D. at the University of Chicago in 1941 and taught economics at Stanford, Yale and Princeton, where he remained for 28 years. He directed Princeton's Center of International Studies from 1960 to 1968. His works included ``On the Uses of Military Power in the Nuclear Age,'' ``Military Power and Potential'' and ``Power and Wealth: The Political Economy of International Power.'' Survivors include his wife, Marianne; daughters, Monica of Washington and Jean of Alexandria, Va.; and son Nicholas of Glencoe, Ill.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Dragnet In New England Nabs Top Alleged Organized Crime Figures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `He appeared...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Providence hearing. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Alleged underboss...'.
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents arrested two top members of New England's organized crime families this morning as part of a three-state dragnet targeting 21 suspected mobsters on a total of 113 criminal counts. Paul Cavanaugh, a spokesman for the FBI's field office in Boston, said alleged mob figures in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut were being arrested on unsealed indictments alleging a variety of crimes, including murder, racketeering, kidnapping, drug trafficking, gambling, obstruction of justice and witness intimidation. At least six people were already under arrest this morning after agents began zeroing in on alleged mobsters about 6 a.m., Cavanaugh said. ``Dozens of agents are out making arrests all over the three-state area,'' he said. ``It's one of the biggest strikes against organized crime in law enforcement history.'' Raymond Patriarca Jr., reputed boss of the Patriarca crime family that formerly was headed by his late father, was arrested at about 6:30 a.m. today at his home in Lincoln, R.I. Patriarca appeared this morning before a U.S. magistrate in Providence, who ordered him transferred to Boston for arraignment on Tuesday at the earliest. Attorney John F. Cicilline had argued his 45-year-old client should be given three days to determine whether he was medically fit to make the 50-mile trip to Massachusetts. Cicilline said his client suffers from cancer and cataracts. Alleged underboss Nicholas Bianco was also arrested, along with a lower-level figure, alleged Mafia captain Matthew Gugliemetti, according to Lincoln Almond, the U.S. attorney in Providence. The names of the other three people arrested by late morning were not immediately released. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was en route to Boston, where he and FBI Director William Sessions were scheduled to detail the indictments at an afternoon news conference. ``This is definitely a megacase,'' Cavanaugh said. ``It's a real blow to the leadership and activities of all the alleged criminal organizations.'' Almond said the unsealed indictments cover four of five alleged captains of the Patriarca crime family and the legal adviser. ``It involves the whole hierarchy of the family,'' he said. ``We've broken the family.'' Patriarca Sr., who died in 1984, was identified as head of the New England Cosa Nostra during 1969 Senate committee hearings. An eighth-grade dropout, he shined shoes and worked as a bellhop in the Biltmore Plaza Hotel in Providence before allegedly working his way into small-time rum running and armed robbery. The alleged mob kingpin was arrested more than 40 times and convicted of 18 crimes, ranging from playing dice on Sunday to armed robbery and conspiracy to murder. He served seven years in prison. The ailing Patriarca was indicted in September 1981 on charges of taking part in a scheme to skim $11 million from the Laborers' International Union, but a federal magistrate found him too ill to stand trial on the racketeering charges in Florida. Law enforcement officials generally believe that Patriarca's son inherited control of the New England mob on his father's death.

DOC.HEAD: Barco Government's Drug War Position Comes Under Fire
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco came under attack Monday after his top Cabinet minister resigned and suggested the government's resolve has weakened against drug traffickers. Interior Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds stepped down Sunday night. His replacement, former Attorney General Horacio Serpa, said the government's position against drug traffickers has not changed since Barco launched his crackdown against them Aug. 18. However, Lemos, who was in charge of internal security and led the fight against traffickers, disagreed. He said he tried to block special deals sought by the traffickers but that the Liberal Party government was less firm in its resolve to fight the cartels. On Monday, the presidential candidate of the opposition Conservative Party, Rodrigo Lloreda, accused the Barco government of being ambiguous and insincere in its stated effort to fight the traffickers.
