In his resignation letter, Lemos said that in the last three months ``there has been an almost imperceptible change in some parts of the government as to the position on drug trafficking, and now it is not as decisive, instransigent and firm.'' Referring to the traffickers, Lemos wrote that he fought to block ``special deals and arrangements through which they look for less rigorous and more flexible treatment for their crimes.'' He did not elaborate. The president's press office sent copies of the resignation letter to the news media after radio stations obtained copies and broadcast portions of it. Lemos did not mention it specifically, but the government has not extradited any trafficking suspects since Jan. 21. Between Aug. 18 and Jan. 21, 14 suspects were extradited to the United States. There are currently 17 people in Colombian custody who are wanted on drug-related charges in the United States. Barco has not explained why the extraditions ended. They ground to a halt just three days after the Medellin drug cartel appealed for a negotiated settlement in the crackdown and asked for an end to extraditions. Lemos' resignation apparently was demanded by Barco after a leftist party alleged that a statement Lemos made led to the assassination of the party's presidential candidate. Lemos said two weeks ago that the leftist Patriotic Union Party was the political arm of the country's biggest leftist guerrilla group, the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces. The Patriotic Union's candidate for the May 26 presidential elections, Bernardo Jaramillo, was assassinated Thursday in Bogota. The party said Lemos' statement had drawn the attention of right-wing death squads. The death squads have killed 1,044 members of the Patriotic Union since the party was organized in 1984. Gen. Miguel Maza of Colombia's secret police said the killer, who was wounded and captured, had been hired by drug traffickers. The government said two years ago that many of the dozens of right-wing death squads in Colombia had been organized by drug traffickers. The new interior minister, Serpa, was an attorney general under Barco for one year. Serpa resigned last year to run for the Senate. He will surrender the Senate seat he won in elections two weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Told Reagan U.S. Not Involved in Contra Crash
DOC.TEXT: John Poindexter told President Reagan the U.S. government had no connection to a Contra resupply plane that crashed in Nicaragua, a former National Security Council employee testified today at Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial. Poindexter made the statement to Reagan on Oct. 7, 1986, two days after the plane carrying ammunition was shot down and one of its crewmen, Eugene Hasenfus, was captured, Rodney McDaniel testified. Actually, the Hasenfus flight was part of the network overseen by Oliver North to keep the Contras armed during a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the rebel force. Poindexter told Congress in 1987 that ``obviously'' there was knowledge and coordination by the NSC staff of North's network that handled the Hasenfus flight. Appearing as a defense witness, McDaniel, then the NSC's executive secretary, took notes during Poindexter's briefing of the president. ``The president had either watched TV or read the newspapers and started'' out by asking ```what is this all about?''' testified McDaniel. ``Admiral Poindexter reported that he didn't have all the facts, but he understood it was not a U.S. government operation,'' said McDaniel. Poindexter told Reagan the flight was ``not connected to the U.S. government'' and that Poindexter ``does not know who Hasenfus is involved with,'' said Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb. Webb was referring to McDaniel's notes. Did Poindexter ever tell the president that Hasenfus was connected to North's Contra resupply network? asked Webb. ``Not in my presence,'' said McDaniel. The day after being briefed by Poindexter, Reagan replied ``absolutely none'' when asked by reporters whether the Hasenfus plane had any link to the U.S. government. Poindexter is charged with five felony counts of obstructing Congress, conspiracy and making false statements to congressional committees in the Iran-Contra affair. On another matter, McDaniel testified that it was not unusual to delete computer messages. More than 5,000 messages in Poindexter's computer file were killed out in the days before he resigned, according to previous testimony. The former national security adviser is accused of deleting them to cover up from Congress the U.S. role in a 1985 Hawk missile shipment to Iran. Under cross-examination, McDaniel acknowledged it was unusual to delete an entire computer file. McDaniel also said that North tended to exaggerate his own role in events. North testified he saw Poindexter tear up a presidential document that depicted the U.S. government as being involved in an arms-for-hostages deal with Iran. North also testified that Poindexter send his aide to a meeting with congressmen, where North lied by denying he was assisting the Contras militarily.

DOC.HEAD: Flight 103 Victim's Family, Estate And Another Customer Sue Pan Am
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `A message...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Pan Am. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Grossman said...'.
DOC.TEXT: A group including the parents of a Pan Am bombing victim sued the airline today, contending it collected a $5-per-ticket surcharge for security on international flights but never spent the money to protect passengers. Among those filing suit against Pan American World Airways were Peter and Aphrodite Tsairis, parents of Alexia Tsairis, who died when Pan Am Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, Dec. 21, 1988. Richard A. Grossman, an attorney handling the case, said the lawsuit was intended to be a class action for customers who purchased Pan Am tickets from 1986 until 1989. ``Damages could amount to over $100 million, with more than a million passengers in line for refunds plus punitive damages,'' he said. ``The truth is that these passengers paid for something they did not get. That something was effective security.'' The crash of the Boeing 747 killed 259 passengers and crew, and 11 people on the ground. Besides the Tsairises of Franklin Lakes, also part of filing suit was T. Jennifer Vail of Wilmington, Del., and Miss Tsairis' estate. Named as defendants were Pan Am Corp.; Pan American World Airways Inc.; Pan American World Services Inc.; Alert Management Systems Inc.; C. Edward Acker, a former president and chief executive officer of the corporation; and Martin E. Shugrue Jr., a former vice chairman of the corporation and chief executive officer of Pan Am World Airways, Grossman said. Ms. Vail is a customer of Pan Am seeking reimbursement of the surcharges. ``She's a representative of the group, in effect,'' said Grossman. Elizabeth Manners, a Pan Am spokeswoman, said the company has not seen the lawsuit and would have no immediate comment. Generally, however, she said Pan Am takes the position that its flight security is sufficient. ``American carriers do have quite stringent requirements and we cetainly do abide by them,'' she said. Grossman said other targets of the suit were former board members and officers of the corporation. There names were not available before the suit was filed, he said. Grossman said Pan Am has acknowledged collecting $18 million in surcharges. He said the airline's own security expert, Isaac Yeffet, told Pan Am officials almost two years before the Flight 103 crash that the carrier's security was ``almost totally ineffectual'' and that leveling a surcharge ``could be regarded as fraud.'' The lawsuit said Pan Am ignored Yeffet's call for sweeping changes in the airline's security system, yet continued to impose the $5 surcharge. Yeffet was previously head of security at El Al Airlines in Israel, the lawyer said.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Claim Oina Inspired Baseball
DOC.TEXT: Fans across America might eagerly be awaiting the start of the oina season if an American here had not changed a few rules and renamed it baseball, according to a Romanian sports official. Adding his voice to the decades-old debate over the origin of baseball, Cristian Costescu said the American pastime derived from the ancient game of oina, which was introduced to the United States by a pair of Transylvanians. Costescu, president of the new Romanian Baseball Federation, says the two immigrants from the Romanian village of Alba Iulia joined the U.S. Army and taught the game to their comrades. Among their comrades was a young officer named Abner Doubleday, who changed a few rules and created baseball in 1839, Cotescu said in an interview. ``We are not saying that Romania invented baseball. We would not like someone else to tell us oina was invented by others,'' said Costescu. ``But we are saying this: some little inspiration for baseball was from oina. Baseball is more sophisticated than oina, but the structure is the same.'' Romanians claim oina was invented by shepherds in the first century and say documents from 1310 describe a variation of the game called hoina being played in southern Romania. Oina has 11 men per side, with one team batting and the other in the field. Each side is allowed one at-bat, in which all 11 players take the plate. A pitcher is provided by the team at bat and he serves up a lazy underhand toss. The batter tries to hit the ball as far as possible, then has to run 120 yards through nine bases. But if the batter is tagged by a fielder or hit by a thrown ball, the fielders can score points _ so teams can score even while not at bat. Oina uses a ball almost the same size as a baseball but filled with horse hair. The bat is similar to a cricket bat and fielders do not wear gloves. Oina still is a Romanian national sport, with forms of the game being played in various regions of the Balkan country. Though there are 1,675 teams around Romania, as opposed to about 15 baseball teams in the country, its popularity has slumped in recent years. ``Fifty years ago everybody was playing oina, all the high schools and elementary schools,'' Costescu said through a translator. ``But handball, basketball and volleyball appeared and oina started disappearing.'' It has been a quarter-century since the heyday of Eugen Cocut, the Babe Ruth of oina whose height and huge hands allowed him to hit powerful shots and fire the ball with terrifying speed. If Costescu is successful in his post with the 2-month-old baseball federation, he may assure that the next Cocut plays baseball instead of oina. Costescu used to head the Romanian Oina Federation, back in the days when baseball was banned as ``a capitalist sport.'' That stigma was removed after the December revolution that overthrew dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, and the baseball federation was formed. ``Baseball will be more popular than oina in cities, but in the villages oina will remain,'' Costescu said. ``Even though I am the head of the baseball federation now, oina is always in my heart.''

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
FETAL PROTECTION
The court, accepting a case that could affect millions of working women, said today it will review a ruling that lets employers exclude all women of child-bearing age from some hazardous jobs. The justices agreed to study an automobile battery manufacturer's policy of banning women who cannot prove they are infertile from jobs that expose them to lead. A decision is expected sometime in 1991. The case is International Union vs. Johnson Controls, 89-1215.
ELECTRICITY RATES
The court agreed to consider giving federal regulators more authority to lower electricity rates, setting the stage for a decision that could affect more than 49 million homes. The court said it will review a ruling that barred the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from slashing rate increases to customers in 15 Ohio communities. The case is Arcadia vs. Ohio Power Co., 89-1283.
DEATH ROW
The court agreed to hear an appeal challenging the authority of states to house convicted murderers on ``death rows'' and keep them apart from other inmates. The justices said they will review the appeal of Nebraska death row inmate John Rust, who says such segregation is ``without penological justification'' and ``grossly disproportionate'' punishment. The case is Rust vs. Gunter, 89-5900.
SCHOOL DESEGREGATION
The court agreed to review a ruling that, if upheld, could reinstate forced busing for the racial desegregation of Oklahoma City, Okla., elementary schools. The court must decide whether the city school board acted lawfully when in 1985 it returned to a neighborhood schools plan for children in kindergarten through fourth grade. The case is Oklahoma City Board of Education vs. Dowell, 89-1080.
McMARTIN PRESCHOOL
The court refused to revive a lawsuit stemming from one of the nation's most publicized cases of alleged child abuse, at the now-defunct McMartin Preschool in Manhattan Beach, Calif. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out the suit against a private child welfare group and one of its therapists by two of the preschool's former teachers.
ALIENS
The court refused to extend a key civil rights law to protect non-citizens from private, as well as governmental, bias. The court, over two dissenting votes, let stand a ruling that the First National Bank of Commerce in New Orleans did not discriminate illegally against Jeetendra Bhandari when it denied his application for a bank credit card because he is not a U.S. citizen. The case is Bhandari vs. First National Bank of Commerce, 89-1258.
W.R. GRACE
The court rejected an appeal by a leading conglomerate found to have fraudulently obtained a $75 million bank loan to develop natural gas fields in Mississippi. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that could subject W.R. Grace & Co. to major punitive damages in a lawsuit by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The case is W.R. Grace vs. FDIC, 89-902.
SEX MOVIES
The court turned away an appeal by an Evansville, Ind., business convicted and fined $5,000 for showing and selling movies ``harmful to minors.'' The court, without comment, refused to hear arguments that the conviction and fine infringe the free-speech rights of the Studio Art Theatre's owners and violate the required separation of government and religion. The case is Studio Art Theatre vs. Indiana, 89-847.
RAILROADS
The court agreed to decide whether railroads can ignore union contracts to complete mergers approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The court said it will review a ruling that restrains the railroads and the ICC from overriding collective bargaining agreements. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled for the unions last July in two separate cases. The cases are Norfolk and Western vs. American Train Dispatchers, 89-1027; CSX Transportation vs. Brotherhood of Railway Carmen, 89-1928.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item to include day of surgery in 2nd graf; pick up 3rd graf, `Havel, a ...
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel is expected to be hospitalized for about a week following a hernia operation, a spokesman said Monday. Havel, 53, is recovering normally after Saturday's operation, spokesman Michael Zantovsky said. He will need about a week to convalesce after his hospital stay. Havel, a dissident playwright who became president after the country's hard-line Communist rulers were ousted, suffered from bouts of ill health while imprisoned from 1979 to 1983 for his opposition to the Communist government. He has maintained a punishing schedule since the whirlwind peaceful revolution started in November and propelled him to the presidency in December. Since taking office, he has visited both Germanys, Poland, Hungary, Iceland, Canada, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain, besides receiving a steady stream of foreign visitors in Prague and making trips around Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Rat Study Suggests Soybeans May Prevent Breast Cancer ^Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by sources
DOC.TEXT: Soybean products may help prevent breast cancer and a new laboratory test may enable doctors to better choose therapy for breast cancer patients, according to two preliminary studies released Monday. Rats fed a soybean-containing diet showed lower breast-cancer rates in a laboratory experiment, said Stephen Barnes, an associate professor of pharmacology and biochemistry at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. He tried the experiment after noting that soybeans are prominent in diets of Asian countries that have lower breast-cancer rates than the United States, he said. But he stressed that his work only studied rats, and his hypothesis is not ready for experiments in people. ``Don't get too excited yet,'' Barnes told science writers at a seminar sponsored by the American Cancer Society. ``I think what we've got here is a possibility that needs to be pursued. ... People shouldn't be encouraged to rush into this.'' Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute, said he found the soybean idea ``fascinating,'' but agreed that it is not clear whether it applies to people. ``This is just a hypothesis,'' he said. ``Please do not write headlines that soybeans are good'' for preventing breast cancer. He also cautioned that many factors other than soybeans could explain the low breast-cancer rates in Asian countries. In Barnes' study, 300 rats animals were fed diets in which amounts of total protein and carbohydrates were kept constant but the amount of soybean protein and carbohydrates varied. After the animals ate the diets for four weeks, they were given a cancer-causing substance. Tumors began to show up after another four weeks or so. Animals that ate soybean diets showed only about half as many tumors on average as those on the soybean-free diet, Barnes said. Barnes said his work was financed largely by the cancer society, with no funding from soybean companies. He said it is not clear what component of soybeans may suppress breast cancer. But he said molecules of one component, called isoflavones, bear a structural resemblance to tamoxifen, a substance used in treating some breast-cancer patients. Tamoxifen works by blocking a cancer cell's ability to absorb and use estrogen, which some cells use to fuel growth. Perhaps isoflavones do the same thing, thus suppressing breast cancer, he said. The other study presented also dealt with the use of estrogen by breast-cancer cells. Cells take up estrogen by snaring it with proteins on cell surfaces called estrogen receptors. Doctors routinely check breast-cancer tumors to see if they have these receptors. If they do, doctors prescribe an estrogen-blocking agent such as tamoxifen to be used after surgery. If the breast-cancer tumors do not show estrogen receptors, doctors prescribe chemotherapy instead as a followup to surgery. However, a woman whose tumor contains estrogen receptors may have only a 40 percent to 80 percent chance of being helped by anti-estrogen therapy, said Christopher Benz of the University of California, San Francisco. Other tests can identify women with higher chances of responding, but most community doctors decide on therapy after just checking for presence of the estrogen receptor, Benz said. His study suggests that a new lab test may be able to identify women who have estrogen receptors but who would not respond to anti-estrogen therapy. The problem with the current test is that it fails to determine whether the estrogen receptors it finds will work normally, he said. Receptors are supposed to bind to a cell's genetic material after they snare estrogen. In a study of 40 human tumors that had estrogen receptors, Benz found that 40 percent contained only abnormal receptors that failed to bind to genetic material. Such tumors might behave as if they lacked the receptors altogether, and so not respond to anti-estrogen therapy, Benz said. To test that idea, the women from whom the tumors were taken will have to be followed for several years, he said. If it turns out to be true, the new test might help doctors make better decisions about what kind of therapy to prescribe after surgery, he said. Broder said the work raises an exciting question for future research, and that ``we have to keep an open mind'' on whether the test would be useful in treatment decisions.

DOC.HEAD: Split by Hard-liners Threatens Unity of Uprising Leadership
DOC.TEXT: A hard-line Palestinian faction on Monday openly challenged the PLO-backed leadership of the uprising and staged a wildcat strike, widening a rift over tactics in the anti-Israeli revolt. The strike marked the anniversary of the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. It was the latest act of defiance by the Syrian-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. In two recent leaflets, the group accused the three other factions in the leadership coalition of softening in their struggle against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Palestinian activists who insisted on anonymity said contacts were under way to try to resolve the feud within the leadership of the 27-month-old rebellion. The leadership groups the Popular Front with Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction, the Palestine Communist Party, and the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine. ``This is not the first time there have been differences, and we were able in the past to surmount them,'' one Fatah activist said. Rising concern about the Popular Front's tactics prompted a rare rebuke from the other Palestinian leadership groups recently, including the dominant Fatah faction. A two-page letter, made available to The Associated Press, criticized the group for actions that ``help nobody but the enemies.'' It also charged that allowing disputes to break into the open ``will not help solve the problem but will lead to a civil war.'' The Popular Front strike closed stores and offices in the West Bank town of Bethlehem and the neighboring villages of Beit Jala and Beit Sahour. Slogans on walls, signed by the Popular Front and the fundamentalist Islamic Jihad group, called for ``burying the Camp David accords.'' The accords led to the Israel-Egypt peace treaty signed March 26, 1979. Past disputes on goals and tactics already have splintered the uprising leadership. The Moslem fundamentalist movement Hamas, which rejects any compromise with Israel, has for more than a year set its own strike agenda. It often is at odds with the main underground coalition's schedule of strikes. The other factions largely have acted together since a five-point pact last July pledged cooperation and ended a rash of torchings of rivals' cars. The latest rift was sparked by the decision of the united leadership to allow merchants to open their stores for five hours a day starting March 20. Earlier, merchants were restricted to a three-hour work day. The Popular Front, in its leaflets, said the longer hours were a sign of weakness. They said Palestinians should increase civil disobedience by lengthening strikes, intensifying the boycott of Israeli-made goods, staging larger demonstrations and throwing more firebombs. The group's militancy has had repercussions. Last week, in the West Bank village of Jadideh, supporters of the Popular Front badgered speakers from the Democratic Front until their joint rally broke down into a brawl, Arab reports said. Ten days earlier, Popular Front activists ransacked and set afire a shop owned by a Fatah supporter. The Palestinian uprising began in December 1987. A total of 669 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis in the revolt. An additional 199 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Attack on Dutch Justice Ministry
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in the Dutch Justice Ministry early Monday, and police said a group protesting the death almost a decade ago of a hunger striker claimed responsibility. The bomb went off at about 4 a.m. It caused no injuries, but damage was estimated at $175,000, according to police spokeswoman Bernadette Maclean. Later Monday, a group identifying itself as the Revolutionary Anti-Racist Action claimed responsibility for the incident in letters sent to an Amsterdam newspaper and the Dutch national news agency, according to Ms. Maclean. She quoted the letter as saying that the bomb attack was to protest the death in 1982 of a Spanish hunger striker identified as Crespo Galendo. The circumstances of Galendo's death could not immediately be established. The same organization claimed responsibility earlier this month for arson attacks on two Dutch military police stations. In December, Spanish government buildings here were targeted in bomb attacks that were believed to have been staged by ETA, the Basque separatist organization.

DOC.HEAD: Court Urged to Wait on Flag Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court was urged Monday to wait until its next term before reviewing a new federal law banning desecration of the American flag. Protesters who burned flags here and in Seattle said the court should reject a Bush administration request that two cases be decided in the current court term due to end by early July. The new term begins in October. The administration is appealing two rulings that said the law violates freedom of speech and is unconstitutional under a high court ruling last year that struck down a Texas law against flag desecration. Lawyers for the protesters said it might be appropriate for the justices to uphold the lower court rulings summarily, without hearing orgal arguments. The attorneys said they don't oppose full-scale review of the law by the court because the issue is so important. Scheduling oral arguments next month, as the administration requests, would not allow the challengers enough time to prepare their case, the lawyers said. The case is U.S. vs. Eichman, 89-1433; U.S. v. Haggerty, 89-1434.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Finds No Grounds for Charging Honecker With Treason
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said Monday there were no legal grounds for charging Erich Honecker with high treason, but the deposed Communist leader still was under investigation for corruption and abuse of power. Efforts to form a new governing coalition continued to be disrupted Monday by allegations that leading politicians had links to the former Communist secret police. The office of chief prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph said two members of Honecker's Politburo _ state security chief Erich Mielke and Guenther Mittag, the economics minister _ also would escape treason charges but, like Honecker, were suspected of corruption and misusing their power. Treason proceedings were dropped against Joachim Herrmann, Honecker's propaganda chief. The former Politburo member was ordered released. Honecker, 77, was arrested in January after undergoing surgery for kidney cancer, but was freed the next day, and Mielke also has been released for health reasons. Mittag remains in custoday. Prosecutors had said earlier that Honecker, Mielke and Mittag would be indicted and put on trial this month for high treason, which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison. Joseph said in a statement Monday, however, that treason indictments were not warranted and the three men also had been cleared of conspiracy charges. His statement, carried by the state-run news agency ADN, accused Honecker and his lieutenants of ``persistent breaches of the constitution.'' It added, however, that the actions were part of a one-party Stalinist system and suggested treason charges against individuals would not be appropriate. Honecker and Mittag, 64, are accused of embezzling state funds to build vacation homes and provide other personal comforts. A range of accusations against Mielke, 84, stem from his control of the formerly all-powerful state security apparatus. Indictments are not expected before May or June, Joseph told The Associated Press. His spokeswoman, Elke Jurkutat, said trials probably would not begin before summer because poor health was slowing interrogation of all three men. Angry citizens forced Honecker and his wife, Margot, a former education minister, to abandon their new home Saturday after only one day. On Friday, the Honeckers moved from a two-room apartment in a parish home outside East Berlin to a better-equipped government residence. They returned to the church refuge after one night because several hundred angry citizens protested in front of the new residence. The past also continued to haunt winners of East Germany's first free elections, held March 18. Ibrahim Boehme, leader of the Social Democratic party, denied allegations that he had been a secret police informer, but said he would leave the post until the suspicions were dispelled. He also told reporters he would not take his place in the new 400-seat Parliament until then. Boehme said he hoped an independent commission would examine the files of the secret police, known as Stasi, within a week and dispose of the allegations. His Social Democrats finished a distant second March 18. Other non-Communist politicians also have come under suspicion of collaboration with the secret police. Lothar de Maiziere of the victorious Christian Democratic Union, the probable new prime minister, has denied allegations similar to those about Boehme. De Maiziere said Monday he believed he could form a government within two weeks. Markus Meckel, who took over the Social Democrats temporarily as Boehme's deputy, said anonymous allegations by former Stasi agents were intended to undermine the country, cause turmoil and and discredit the new Parliament. Under Honecker, who ruled for 17 years, the Stasi was used to suppress dissent and keep tight control on all walks of life. It had 85,000 agents and more than 100,000 informers, and kept files on 6 million of East Germany's 16 million citizens. Dismantling of the secret police began after Honecker's downfall in October. On Monday, the mayor of Rostock resigned after 50 people occupied the city hall to protest plans for 44 former Stasi agents to become local teachers. Gregor Gysi, chairman of the Party of Democratic Socialism, the Communist Party's new name, urged all 66 of its parliamentary deputies to acknowledge any links with Stasi. He also proposed that departing Premier Hans Modrow, a Communist, be made speaker of the new Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court to Rule on Hazardous Jobs Ban for Women
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it will study the power of employers to exclude females of child-bearing age from hazardous jobs, a case that could affect millions of working women. The court agreed to review a ruling that let a Milwaukee-based manufacturer of automobile batteries ban women who cannot prove they are infertile from jobs that expose them to lead. The fetal protection policy is being challenged as a form of illegal sex discrimination because it bans women from high-paying, if hazardous, jobs. Exposure to lead, the principal material used in making batteries, can be a health risk to workers and to the fetuses of pregnant workers. But one judge, who dissented from an appeals court decision last year that upheld the fetal protection policy, said the ruling also could be applied to a broad range of employment, including ``traditional office jobs.'' The high court's decision is expected sometime in 1991. In other action, the court: _Agreed to decide in an Oklahoma City case whether some school districts may abandon forced busing after achieving racial balance. _Voted to study an appeal from Nebraska challenging the authority of states to house convicted murderers on ``death rows'' and keep them apart from other inmates. _Said it will consider giving federal regulators more authority to lower electricity rates, setting the stage for a ruling that could affect more than 49 million homes. _Refused to extend a key civil rights law to protect non-citizens from private, as well as governmental, bias. The justices let stand a ruling that a New Orleans bank did not discriminate illegally against a man when it denied him a credit card because he is not a citizen. _Let stand the conviction of an Indiana business for showing and selling movies ``harmful to minors,'' rejecting arguments that the conviction and $5,000 fine infringe free-speech rights. In the fetal protection case, the court must interpret a federal law that bans sexual bias in employment. Since 1982 the battery division of Johnson Controls Inc. has barred women at its factories in several states from jobs involving exposure to lead. Eight employees and the United Auto Workers union challenged the policy in court. Among the women who sued was one who had submitted to sterilization to preserve her job and another who was a 50-year-old divorcee. The suit alleged that the policy violated a part of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, called Title VII. A federal judge ruled for Johnson Controls based on both sides' pretrial arguments. No trial was held. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld that ruling by a 7-4 vote last Sept. 26. Judge John L. Coffey wrote for the appeals court that the differing treatment of female employees was based on a ``business necessity,'' and added, ``We are also convinced that Johnson Controls' fetal protection policy could be upheld under the bona fide occupational qualification defense.'' The appeals court concluded that the policy ``is reasonably necessary to industrial safety.'' Three of the appeals court's four dissenting judges wrote opinions, the most scathing by Judge Frank Easterbrook, an appointee of President Ronald Reagan. Calling it ``likely the most important sex-discrimination case in any court since ... Congress enacted Title VII,'' Easterbrook said, ``If the majority is right, then by one estimate 20 million industrial jobs would be closed to women, for many substances in addition to lead pose fetal risks.'' ``The law would allow employers to consign more women to `women's work' while reserving better-paying but more hazardous jobs for men,'' Easterbrook said. ``Cases ... show that many additional women are affected by restrictions placed on other jobs, such as the X-ray technician jobs that exposed embryos to radiation. Concern about emissions from computers and their terminals has led to proposals that could restrict access even to traditional office jobs,'' he said. A California appeals court recently ruled that Johnson Controls fetal protection policy is illegal sex discrimination under that state's law. Judith Lichtman, president of the Women's Legal Defense Fund, said she was pleased that the court agreed to hear the case. ``Employers have used women as the scapegoat of their failure to properly evaluate the harm caused by workplace hazards on both men and women,'' she said. ``They choose to avoid cleaning up the workplace by excluding virtually all women from the jobs in question _ literally avoiding their responsibility by shifting the burden onto the backs of women workers.''

DOC.SECOND: PM-Social Club Crackdown, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0539,0875
DOC.HEAD: Mayor Orders Crackdown on Illegal Clubs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with details of sweep, more than 200 clubs visited, other detai. Picks up 15th graf pvs, `Sunday's fire...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Inspectors this morning visited more than 200 social clubs in a crackdown ordered by Mayor David Dinkins following the deadliest city fire in 79 years. Only a fraction of them were found to be open, but 52 safety violations were cited, authorities said. ``I will tell you it will not be an endless battle,'' Dinkins said Sunday after touring the charred Happy Land social club in the Bronx. ``Anybody that had an opportunity to view those 87 bodies knows that we're not going to tolerate this.'' Previous mayors have waged a long and unsuccessful battle to close clubs that are operating illegally. The dancing and drinking nightspots are popular among immigrants because they are cheap. A task force put together by then-Mayor Edward Koch after a 1988 Bronx social club fire that killed seven people will be beefed up, Dinkins said. Before Sunday's fire, only one team remained from the 10-team task force. A sweep of social clubs was conducted between midnight and 7 a.m., police said. Officers and task force inspectors went to 241 suspected illegal clubs citywide and posted vacate orders at 187 of them, said Sgt. Dick Vreeland, a police spokesman. In most cases, the orders were posted on closed doors, because just 23 of the clubs were found to be open for business. Fifty-two safety violations and 30 summonses were issued. During the sweep, five people were arrested for weapons possession, 11 loaded firearms recovered, cars were towed and parking tickets issued. Sunday morning, in raids unrelated to the fire, a police task force raided several social clubs in Brooklyn and arrested five people for weapons possession, said Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman. Albert Scardino, the mayor's press secretary, said police list about 1,220 clubs without liquor licenses, with about 1,000 considered inactive. The Happy Land was considered inactive. ``They range from a group of elderly men who get together to play cards and watch a ballgame on a Sunday afternoon to full-fledged nightclub operations,'' said Richard Chernela, a state Liquor Authority spokesman. The number of clubs citywide is hard to pin down since they can spring up overnight, often in a dank basement or abandoned building. A review of city records Sunday turned up 173 social clubs that had been ordered vacated. Inspectors were told to make sure the 173 are closed. There was no immediate explanation of how other clubs visited today were selected. If the illegal clubs are not shut immediately, Dinkins had said, ``we'll see to it that they certainly aren't open come the next weekend.'' Sunday's fire occurred 79 years to the day after a blaze at the Triangle Shirtwaist Co. in New York City that claimed 145 lives, many of them immigrant garment workers. That blaze led to reforms around the nation in workplace safety. Just about anyone can go to a social club, despite the term's implication of exclusivity. The Happy Land charged $5 for admission. Despite periodic campaigns to close them, many of the clubs have become centers of urban problems, from noise and double-parking to gambling, prostitution and drug dealing. The clubs often are rife with building, health and fire code violations that can lead to tragedy. Five people died in a Brooklyn club fire in 1985, and 25 people were killed in a Bronx fire in 1976. ``People are literally taking their lives in their hands at these clubs,'' Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said. Dinkins said a vacate order was issued in November 1988 against the Happy Land because the club did not have a proper sprinkler system, exits, emergency lighting and signs. City records show an arrest was made there on July 24 and the club was closed again on Nov. 1, he said. City officials said the building was sold last year to Karl Rubman, but Dinkins said it was unclear who owns the property now. Residents said the manager of the club was Elias Colon. The Daily News reported that Colon's wife, Elena, was one of the survivors of the fire. Some said it may be impossible to close the social clubs completely. ``Our experience in the city in the last 20 years demonstrates that clearly,'' said William Kornblum, director of the Center for Social Research at the City University of New York Graduate School. Many people, especially those from poor neighborhoods where affordable alternatives are scarce, go to the clubs looking for a place to socialize where they feel welcome. Some clubs are closed under the city's 1984 padlock law, which allows police to shutter a location for a year if two crimes are committed on the site within a 12-month period. But the owners, if they can be located, are rarely convicted. Even when the clubs are shuttered, an owner may reopen around the corner or down the street, attracting the same crowd.

DOC.HEAD: Daughter of Jailed British Nurse Visits Prison
DOC.TEXT: The daughter of a British nurse jailed in Iraq for driving a journalist to an Iraqi military installation visited her mother Monday, a Foreign Office spokesman said. The journalist, Farzad Bazoft, was accused of spying and hanged March 15. The nurse, Daphne Parish, was ordered imprisoned 15 years. Michelle de Vries saw her mother Monday, and also visited her Saturday and Sunday at Abu Ghraid prison, the Foreign Office spokesman said. Mrs. Parish, 53, last saw her daughter in December when the two were allowed a 20-minute visit, the spokesman said. Mrs. Parish is sharing a cell with four Iraqi women, the British news agency Press Association reported. The British government is continuing a low-key campaign to get Mrs. Parish released, according to a variety of press reports. She and Bazoft were tried and convicted in connection with a visit Bazoft made to an Iraqi military complex in September. The Iraqi government accused him of spying, a charge he denied. Bazoft was working for The Observer, a London weekly newspaper.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Social Club Fire, 5th Ld - Writethru, a0587,1188
DOC.HEAD: Fire Allegedly Set By Spurned Lover Kills 87 at Unlicensed Social Club
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11-12th grafs, `Authorities early...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with number of clubs visited citywide, 52 safety violations cited. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `It was...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6,7
DOC.TEXT: A man bounced from a Bronx social club for quarreling with an ex-girlfriend returned with a jug of gasoline and set a fire that killed 87 people at the nightspot, which had been ordered closed, police said. Julio Gonzalez, 36, was charged with multiple counts of murder and arson in the pre-dawn blaze Sunday at the Happy Land social club, police Sgt. Edward Burns said. He appeared early this morning in Bronx County Criminal Court and was ordered held without bail and placed in an isolated cell under a suicide watch in a Rikers Island jail, Burns said. Meanwhile, authorities launched a crackdown on social clubs, drinking and dancing nightspots that proliferate in New York's poor neighborhoods and often operate without proper licenses and safety features. Happy Land was operating despite a 1988 closure order that cited safety violations including improper exits. Most of the dead suffocated in thick smoke in the pre-dawn blaze Sunday, authorities said. Some people were trampled to death; others broke a hole through a wall to an adjoining hall in a desperate attempt to escape. Emergency workers described bodies felled by smoke so quickly that they still had their legs wrapped around a bar stool, gripped drinks or held hands. Only three people managed to reach safety by way of the two doors on the front of the two-story Happy Land social club. ``People literallywere stacked on top of each other,'' said Anthony De Vita, the Fire Department's command chief. ``It was a firetrap.'' Gonzalez, a Cuban immigrant and former boyfriend of a Happy Land's ticket seller, was thrown out of the club after a quarrel in which he tried to woo back the woman, police said. After warning, ``I'll be back,'' he returned with a jug of gasoline, sprinkled the fuel on the floor and lit it, said Lt. James Malvey. Gonzalez cried with remorse under questioning, said Lt. Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman. ``Basically, he's saying he did it,'' O'Donnell said. Authorities early today inspected more than 200 social clubs across the city, finding most of them closed. Vacate orders were posted at 187 of them, and 52 safety violation notices were issued, said Sgt. Dick Vreeland, a police spokesman. In addition, five people were arrested for weapons possessions. On Sunday, officials had said a review of city records showed at least 173 social clubs had been ordered to shut down in the past, and Mayor David Dinkins ordered officials to make sure they were closed. It was the deadliest fire in the continental United States since the 1977 blaze at the Beverly Hills Supper Club in Southgate, Ky., that killed 164 people. A New Year's Eve 1986 fire at a hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, killed 97. The fire occurred exactly 79 years after a blaze at the Triangle Shirtwaist Co. in New York City, a garment factory, that claimed 145 lives. That blaze led to reforms around the nation in workplace safety. At a ceremony today marking the Triangle fire, Dinkins referred to Sunday's club fire, noting that in both cases most of the victims were immigrants. As in 1911, he said, ``there are those operating in the shadows, running sweatshops and illegal social clubs and pursuing other schemes, turning the lure and promise of America into a nightmare for those who seek to redeem the promise.'' The ceremony had been scheduled long before Sunday's fire. After Sunday's fire, the impoverished Latino neighborhood near the Bronx Zoo was thick with mourners, who were asked to identify relatives from snapshots of the bodies posted on the wall of a high school. Killed were 61 men and 26 women, most of them Honduran and Dominican immigrants. ``Most of the bodies were in dance clothes,'' Emergency Medical Services specialist Christopher McCarthy said. ``They were out to have fun.'' Alva Romero, a Honduran immigrant, lost six relatives, including a daughter, both brothers and a sister. Jerome Ford lost five relatives. The local Honduran soccer club lost several players. The government in Honduras today expressed regret over the fire. Foreign Ministry spokesman Eugenio Castro said officials were ``deeply moved by the deaths of many countrymen in New York.'' Happy Land was ordered shut in November 1988 and again a year later because of inadequate exits, sprinkler systems, emergency lighting and signs, Dinkins said. It had no liquor or cabaret license. City officials said the building was sold last year to Karl Rubman, but Dinkins said it was unclear who owns the property now. Residents said the manager of the club was Elias Colon. The Daily News reported that Colon's wife, Elena, was one of the survivors of the fire. Despite their name, the social clubs admit anyone. Happy Land charged a $5 admission price at the door; its illegally served drinks cost about $3 each. ``I will tell you it will not be an endless battle,'' the mayor said in announcing the crackdown on illegal clubs. ``Anybody that had an opportunity to view those 87 bodies knows that we're not going to tolerate this.'' Mayor Ed Koch, Dinkins' predecessor, made a similar promise after a 1988 Bronx social club fire killed seven people. The clubs are popular among poor immigrants. Two rickety staircases lead to the second-story dance floor where most of the bodies were found. Disc jockey Ruben Valladares, who spun reggae, salsa and calypso records, ran through the flames and was hospitalized with severe burns. At least two other women escaped. Their condition was unknown. ``People were screaming; they were all burned,'' said Rosemary Green, who found the club on fire when she arrived to meet her sister-in-law and cousin. ``Once you got in the entrance there was no way to get out.'' Gonzalez, an unemployed warehouse worker, came to the United States on the Mariel boatlift in 1980, O'Donnell said. Police said he went into the club about 3 a.m. and began arguing with the woman. ``He's trying to talk her into making up; she's saying `Leave me alone,''' O'Donnell said. The man's ex-girlfriend left before the fire, which was reported at 3:41 a.m., Brown said. Police withheld her identity. Denise Garcia, 20, a filing clerk who lives in the neighborhood, said she and her friends avoided the club because they considered it ``too sleazy.'' The building was rickety and the dance floor sometimes trembled, she said. One firefighter broke a leg; 13 of his colleagues also were injured. Gonzalez was charged with two counts of arson, 87 counts of murder in the course of arson, 87 counts of murder by depraved indifference to human life and one count of attempted murder.

DOC.HEAD: John Dexter Dead, Outstanding Theater and Opera Director
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with more biographical detail.
DOC.TEXT: John Dexter, a theater and opera director whose productions included such stage hits as ``Equus'' and ``M. Butterfly'' as well as operas at Covent Garden and New York's Metropolitan Opera House, has died at age 64. The Times of London said his death Friday in a London hospital was due to heart failure. Dexter was best known on Broadway for his direction of ``Equus'' in 1974 and ``M. Butterfly'' in 1988, both of which won him Tony awards. He made his Broadway debut in 1963 with Arnold Wesker's ``Chips with Everything.'' Among his other notable Broadway productions were ``Black Comedy'' and ``The Royal Hunt of the Sun,'' both written by Peter Shaffer, and ``Do I Hear a Waltz?,'' the Richard Rodgers-Stephen Sondheim musical. Dexter's last Broadway assignment was the ill-fated ``3 Penny Opera,'' starring rock idol Sting, which closed in December after a short run. Dexter began his theater career at the Royal Court in 1957 and then was asked by Laurence Olivier to join the National Theater as an associate director. There he directed ``Othello,'' with Olivier playing the title role and Maggie Smith as Desdemona. Among his other successes at the National were ``The Misanthrope,'' with Alec McCowen and Diana Rigg, ``Hobson's Choice'' and ``Phaedra Britannica'' with Rigg. Dexter directed his first opera in 1966, a revival of Berlioz' ``Benvenuto Cellini'' at Covent Garden and later worked at the Hamburg State Opera, the Paris Opera and the Metropolitan Opera in New York. At the Met, he directed productions of such diverse operas as ``I Vespri Sicilani, ``Dialogues of the Carmelites,'' ``Lulu,'' ``The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny,'' ``Billy Budd'' and ``Parade,'' a triple bill of French operas with scenery by artist David Hockney. Dexter, the son of a plumber, was born in the northern England town of Derby. He left school at 14 to work in a factory and discovered acting while in the army. There was no word on survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court to Rule on School `Resegregation' Case
With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it will decide whether school districts may abandon forced busing of students after once achieving racial balance in their schools. The justices will review a ruling that, if upheld, could reinstate forced busing for the racial desegregation of elementary schools in Oklahoma City. At issue is the effect of a federal judge's ruling in 1977 that the city's public schools had become fully integrated and no longer had to be under court supervision. The city in 1985 returned to a neighborhood schools plan for children in kindergarten through fourth grade, ending the racial balance achieved by crosstown busing of elementary school pupils. By 1986, 33 of the school district's 64 elementary schools were 90 percent black or white, and some parents called the neighborhood schools plan a tool of ``resegregation.'' Hundreds of school districts, including those in most major cities, operate court-ordered busing plans for racial desegregation. Only a few have persuaded courts to declare their once-segregated systems fully integrated. Nevertheless, the potential impact of the high court's decision, expected sometime in 1991, is enormous. The issue gained national attention when the Reagan administration helped bring about a halt to court-ordered busing of elementary school pupils in Norfolk, Va. The Norfolk school district was allowed to return to a neighborhood schools plan in 1986. William Bradford Reynolds, head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division when it entered the Norfolk case in 1984, said the same legal principles could apply to ``many, many other school districts around the country.'' In the Oklahoma City case, a federal appeals court last Oct. 6 disapproved the neighborhood schools plan. Oklahoma City public schools once were racially segregated by law. Black parents sued in 1961 to end the lasting effects of such segregation, and in 1972 forced busing was begun as part of a court-ordered desegregation plan. U.S. District Judge Luther Bohanon ruled in 1977 that the school district had become fully integrated, and ended court supervision. School officials continued the crosstown busing, however, until 1985 when children in kindergarten through fourth grade were allowed to attend the school nearest their home. Some black parents challenged the neighborhood schools plan, although other black parents had criticized the busing program. Bohanon ruled that the 1972 desegregation plan no longer had to be enforced because federal court supervision ended with his 1977 declaration. But the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in October that federal court supervision in such cases ``extends beyond the termination of the wrongdoing.'' The appeals court said the Oklahoma City school board has a continuing duty to refrain from any action that could weaken racial balance in the public schools. It ordered Bohanon to study ``alternatives to maintain racially balanced elementary schools.'' The 10th Circuit court's ruling appears to conflict with federal appeals court rulings in the Norfolk case and one from Austin, Texas. In each of those, an appeals court ruled that judicial supervision ends when a previously segregated school district is found to be fully integrated, or ``unitary.'' In a friend-of-the-court brief, the National School Boards Association urged the justices to use the Oklahoma City case ``to resolve what constitutes a unitary school system and determine the effect of a declaration of unitary.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Congratulates 100th Point of Light
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs `You know ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT spelling to Tomblinson, sted Tomblison
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday called a once-homeless woman who established a program to help homeless families in Kansas City, Mo., to congratulate her on being his 100th ``point of light.'' ``You know what it is. You've been through it yourself, been homeless,'' Bush told Barbara Tomblinson. Mrs. Tomblinson founded New Start-New Life Ministries, which provides transitional housing for homeless families. The families are required to find employment within two weeks and save half their earnings. ``Barbara and I were so moved by your own effort, your own history of helping homeless families and setting a great example for a lot of other Americans,'' Bush said. ``So for that reason I wanted to call and say congratulations.'' Mrs. Tomblinson is the 100th recipient of Bush's daily award recognizing individuals and groups that exemplify his ``thousand points of light'' theme of volunteerism and community service. The president's phone call was piped in over the PA system in the White House press room. Bush told Mrs. Tomblinson he knew there were many volunteers working in the program. ``I just hope you'll be able to give each one a hug and say thanks,'' he said. ``I'll do that just for you,'' Mrs. Tomblinson said. Those honored as points of light get a plaque and a letter from the president.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Some towns have favorite sons. In James T. Kirk, Riverside has a future son. Each year, futuristic enthusiasts in this eastern Iowa town of 800 celebrate the upcoming March 22, 2228, birthday of Kirk, captain of the Starship Enterprise in the TV series ``Star Trek.'' The Trekkies gathered for Kirk's minus 238th birthday Saturday night at a Riverside hall dressed in their space-age finest. They have marked the birthday since Riverside adopted Kirk as its hometown boy in 1985. Creators of the show say Kirk was born in an Iowa barbershop but don't reveal his hometown. ``If you saw this in New York City, you wouldn't think anything of it. To see it in Riverside, Iowa, is what makes it bizarre,'' said Shawn Paris, a self-described ``galactic artist.'' Paris has created an art piece he calls ``Quantum Destiny'' that will be placed in a titanium time capsule and buried in 1991 behind the site of a former barbershop in Riverside to mark the series' 25th anniversary. It will be opened on Kirk's birthday.

If the price of groceries should rub you the wrong way and you need a quick fix, try a supermarket massage. For $5, one of 14 therapists at the Whole Foods Market will give a 10-minute neck and shoulder massage. The program began about six months ago, and customers are lining up. ``It should be self-explanatory why we have it,'' said night manager Colin Marsh. ``Dallas is a highly stress-inducing city. ``It's a very integral part of our business,'' he said. ``Some people come in just for massages. It's very popular.'' The massage area had been in the center of the store, but is now in a less conspicuous area because of objections from some customers. ``The customer is fully clothed and no oil is used,'' said therapist Bridget McGee. ``And you just hit pressure points.'' ``A lot of people come in every day, and others just once a week,'' she said. ``Weekends are busy, and weekdays about noon.'' Some of the staff are partaking. ``Sometimes I'll get one when I'm in the middle of the shift and have had to deal with what you might say are some very diplomatic-oriented situations,'' Marsh said.

A pair of peregrine falcons whose high-rise hijinks captivated cable television viewers last summer return to the airwaves Monday. The all-day broadcast of two birds who don't do much more than putter about on a 21st-story ledge proved more popular than expected. ``It amazes me that someone can sit and watch the birds hour after hour,'' said Brian Lambert, general manager of Continental Cablevision. ``I am one of them. It stays on in the office all day long. We just kind of wait to see the bird move or the eggs or whatever. It's mesmerizing.'' The 43,000-subscriber cable company mounted a camera near the falcons' nest on a ledge of the 23-story Monarch Place office building last year and televised the video on a channel devoted to educational programming. Tom French, director of the state's endangered species program, said the show is more than an entertaining glimpse of nature. ``It's an incredible opportunity,'' he said. ``It's absolutely incredible that they're so visible. We can look at the egg tooth. That's minute.'' Among last season's highlights were the first hatchings of young peregrine falcons in western Massachusetts in 40 years and a thriller episode in June when French rappelled down the side of the building to rescue a baby falcon that was choking on a piece of meat. Alert viewers had noticed the chick's distress and jammed the company's switchboard. This season, the first egg is expected to appear in early April, the first hatching in mid-May and the first fledgling flights near the end of June.

DOC.HEAD: Shriner Sentenced in Sexual Mutilation of Boy
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of raping and sexually mutilating a 7-year-old boy was sentenced today to more than 130 years in prison, three times the standard term for the crime. In sentencing Earl Shriner, Pierce County Superior Court Judge Thomas R. Sauriol said the case left him more troubled and outraged than any in his 37-year legal career. ``I don't think that I have ever heard of a case that borders on extreme cruelty more than this one,'' Sauriol said. ``The reality is, Mr. Shriner, you present a danger to the defenseless.'' Shriner, 40, has a long history of violence toward young people. He was convicted Feb. 7 of first degree attempted murder, two counts of first-degree rape and first-degree assault. The child was choked and his penis was cut off in the attack May 20 in a wooded area near his south Tacoma home. The victim's mother, Helen Harlow, dabbing her eyes and comforted by numerous friends, said she was satisfied with the sentence because it would in effect be a life sentence. The attack created an uproar in the state about sex predators, and was one of the cases cited as being instrumental in passage of legislation to deal more strictly with them, including longer sentences, civil commitment and registration of sex offenders. Under state law, the standard range for the offenses with someone of Shriner's record is 34 years to 43 years, eight months. The approximately 131-year sentence was three times the high end of the standard range. In reaching his sentence, which the defense said would be appealed, Sauriol accepted almost all the 13 aggravating factors cited by prosecutors as reasons to go above the standard sentence. But he rejected the state's proposal for a sentence of more than 250 years _ six times the maximum under standard sentencing guidelines. The boy's mother has said her son continues with his recovery, including reconstructive surgery. A trust fund of hundreds of thousands of dollars that poured in after the attack on the boy is paying for the surgery. Shriner has a 24-year history of violent attacks on young people. He has been confined at Rainier School for the retarded; Western State Hospital, a mental institution; and the Washington Corrections Center. The 7-year-old boy was found by neighbors after the attack, bloody, naked, covered with mud and practically incoherent. A fellow jail inmate testified during the trial that Shriner admitted mutilating the boy.

DOC.HEAD: Sasser Says Pentagon Renovation Out of the Question
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a Senate panel on military construction said Monday that a Bush administration request for $1.1 billion to renovate the Pentagon is ``out of the question.'' Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., acknowledged that the 47-year-old building is in need of repair but said the administration's call for $1.1 billion over seven years would be difficult to heed in a time of shrinking budgets. ``The military construction bill is going to get smaller not larger,'' Sasser told Pentagon officials at a Senate hearing. ``There's simply no room for such an undertaking.'' The chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on military construction faulted past defense secretaries for failing to get the General Services Administration to provide sufficient funds for the building's upkeep. The GSA owns the Pentagon building, with transfer of control to the Defense Department expected some time this year. ``I'm not persuaded that we ought to ask the taxpayers to come up with another billion dollars to provide new office space for those who work in the Pentagon and to expand it,'' Sasser said. ``Perhaps it's time to take a hard look at scaling back some of the Pentagon staff.'' David J. Berteau, the Pentagon's principal deputy assistant secretary for production and logistics, said that if he cut his staff in half he would ``not leave a dent in the Pentagon because those people are not located in the Pentagon as it is now.'' Sasser, who also chairs the Senate Budget Committee, said spending a billion dollars or more ``to buy new offices for the Pentagon is just out of the question ... in the budgetary climate that I see coming.'' The Pentagon, the largest office building in the world, has 17.5 miles of corridors, 131 stairways, 19 escalators and 13 elevators, and covers 29 acres in northern Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Injuries Reported as Plane Aborts Takeoff
DOC.TEXT: Flames were spotted Monday in an engine of a TWA jetliner carrying 176 people, forcing the pilot to abort takeoff. Seven passengers sustained minor injuries while sliding down evacuation chutes, officials said. The Logan International control tower alerted the crew of Flight 31 less than a minute into the 9:30 a.m. takeoff for St. Louis and Los Angeles, said Thomas J. Kinton, deputy director of aviation with the Massachusetts Port Authority. The L-1011 jetliner taxied off the runway and chutes were deployed to help the 163 passengers get off the plane, said Phil Orlandella, an agency spokesman. The injured were taken to Massachusetts General Hospital for treatment of floor burns and twisted ankles. He said ground crews found no smoke or fire when they inspected the engine.

DOC.HEAD: From Underwear to Outerwear _ a Splashy Style Show
DOC.TEXT: Borrowing from the ski slopes, the riding ring, the great outdoors or the bedroom, splashy ready-to-wear styles for next fall are heavily influenced by active sportswear or fetching lingerie styles. The opening of the East also was celebrated during shows last week in folkloric Russian or Central European looks called ``International Ethnic'' by Women's Wear Daily. South-of-the-border and African animal-print themes inspired other clothes that were happily more wearable than costume-like. The main younger silhouette is usually a leggy form clad in colorful tights, cigarette-slim trousers or stretch stirrup pants a la St. Moritz. Sometimes a miniskirt or tunic tops the tights, but fitted jackets, redingotes and swirly babydoll toppers add to looks that go from flippy to top-heavy. Th runways ran riot with drawstring parkas or fur-lined anoraks with hoods. Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel even dressed up his evening wear with shimmering satin quilted ski jackets. Castelbajac, who always does bright sportswear-based clothes, was still a winner with his handsome mohair-hooded greatcoats, his primary color parkas or duffels, his tunic-and-tights knitwear. As sportswear and outerwear became indoor wear, underwear also took a flirtatious bow in cocktail clothes, with wasp-waisted lacy merry widow looks at Lacroix, Hanae Mori, Lecoanet-Hemant and elsewhere. And then there was the super appeal of the ethnic clothes. They looked great as done by the top creators: Ungaro, Lacroix, Romeo Gigli and Yves Saint Laurent. Saint Laurent, who showed the first great Russian rich-ethnic styles in 1976, was in a hospital suffering from mental and physical exhaustion, missing his opening. But his bouncy, quilted and flowered new versions of the happy peasant look were a charming update. Watch for shimmering velvet-printed long skirts and bright quilted toppers shot with lame threads, moire skirts and belted tunics in neon-hot colors, plus tassels, sequins and ``passementerie'' ribbon decor. But styles marched right back from the 1960s as well, updated with elegant thigh-high suede or flower-printed boots at Ungaro teamed with some of the stretch pants and mini-tunics. With eye-catching tricolored lean tunics or minis with tights and the high boots, plus clothes in big Mondrian-inspired blocks of color, many were talking about Pierre Cardin's ghost hovering over it all. Cardin, whose avant-garde ideas of the 1960s still seem to work in the leg-baring 1990s, is in fact alive and doing so well he doesn't even need to give a ready-to-wear show. In the pyramid or trapeze coat line, look for the basic shape and fabulous fabrics at Montana, a master at styling this silhouette. For the best redingote, look to Dior, where designer Gianfranco Ferre gave the house refinement and new kick with superb cuts and hot reds like the ``pink'' riders' coats. Another popular coat was the full-skirted or slimmer trench, which turned into a dress at Chanel. Day wear was not totally for the leggy, as many designers showed slim pants and a few paraded fullish longer skirts. Daytimes were sometimes festively dressed up with lame and sparkles or touches of satin and chiffon in blouses in outfits that might pass at a liberal office before the wearer leaves for the cocktail hour. Evening wear was one big fete, with acres of passementerie, gold-braided ``galloons,'' jeweled and velvet embroidery. Minxy decollete styles and bubble dresses were tempered with plenty of little black dresses in all kinds of soft fabrics and silhouettes. Color schemes for next fall run the gamut from subdued chocolate, khaki, mustard, camel, gray and wine to neon pinks or greens. Brights are a big hit as Paris is seeing red: with flame red, crimson, orange, fuchsia and cyclamen leading the way. Little touches make the difference in Paris fashion. You can look for all kinds of silky print shawls and fringed stoles, velvet berets or pillboxes, chain belts with big cabochon stones, chunky bracelets, necklaces and drop earrings to dress up a wardrobe. After the marathon week of ready-to-wear with at least 100 shows under tents raised in the Louvre's Cour Carre courtyard and other locations around town, Paris was being touted as the world capital of fashion. Now that top Japanese, Italian and English creators like Katherine Hamnett and John Galliano have defected to show in Paris, the big question is whether Americans will hop on the bandwagon. Jacques Mouclier, president of the French Fashion Federation and Chambre Syndicale de la Couture, said a $77 million underground fashion complex is planned under the Tuileries gardens near the Louvre.

DOC.HEAD: Western-Style Elections With the East's Slow Count
DOC.TEXT: Hungarians applied the West's rules of fair play to their first free election in 43 years, but not its efficient tabulation of results. Only 69 percent of the votes cast in Sunday's election were counted by late Monday. The state news agency MTI said the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum led with about one-quarter of the votes, the center-left League of Free Democrats had roughly 20 percent and the Socialists, the new name adopted by the Communists, were a distant fourth after the Independent Smallholders party. With no party given a chance of winning a majority in Parliament, a coalition government is likely after runoff elections next month. Hungarians like to consider themselves closer to the modern West than to the East, which they derisively call ``The Balkans'' or ``Asia,'' but the election provides little evidence of Western technical efficiency. International monitors expressed satisfaction with the vote's fairness, but the reporting of results has been an agonizing process. East Germany held the first free election among former Soviet satellites on March 18, and provided projections of the outcome soon after polls closed. Provisional final results were available five hours after the last vote was cast and official results were announced the next morning. The East Germans had West German computers and knew how to use them. The Hungarians had modern computers, but appeared incapable of using them. Gleaming banks of computer terminals were on prominent display at election committee headquarters in the parliament building and in state television's election studio. Shortly after the polls closed, the television began a scheduled 24-hour broadcast, complete with an inspiring musical theme and elaborate graphics. The computer screens remained blank. Election officials decided at the last minute, not explaining why, to tally the more than 5 million ballots by hand and use computers only for a final check. That also crippled state television's computer system, which depended partially on feeds from the election committee network. Commentators mumbled excuses and read handwritten partial results. Some attempts to draw on the computers were embarrassing. Commentators presented an analysis of early partial results from a rural election district, only to find that it was a test graphic with imaginary candidates and percentages. Members of a television panel trying to explain inconclusive and sometimes misleading data gave up before dawn Monday. ``What do you expect? This is Hungary,'' philosopy professor Mihaly Vajda said to the other panelists. ``I would suggest we try to analyze what we have. We could only be wrong. For all we know, we may be the only people up.'' Panel member Peter Kende, a Hungarian who teaches political science at the Sorbonne in Paris, said: ``It's a little hard to believe that we've been sitting around for seven hours and we still don't know anything.'' Television reporters across the country were reporting local results of less than 10 percent hours after the pollis colsed. Hostesses at the International Press Center tried to placate hundreds of journalists with a trickle of results from MTI, the state news agency, but the large television screen that was supposed to carry quick results and projections remained blank. Attempts to obtain substantive comment from party leaders were frustrated because it was impossible to be certain who was ahead. At dawn, more than 12 hours after the voting ended, MTI made its initial report of a trend.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Hails Elections in Hungary
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration Monday hailed initial results of Hungary's first free parliamentary elections in more than four decades. ``We are encouraged by the elections as an indication of further movement along the path of democratic development for the Hungarian people,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Partial results of the weekend election indicated voters overwhelmingly chose opposition candidates over Communist reformers, and that it appeared likely that a coalition of opposition parties would run Hungary. Fitzwater noted that there was a tight contest between two non-communist factions _ the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum and the liberal League of Free Democrats. The Socialists, the successor to the Communists who once ruled the Warsaw Pact nation, were trailing badly. ``Eastern Europe is undergoing dramatic economic and political changes,'' Fitzwater said. ``Hungary has been one of the countries in the forefront of these changes.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother Seeks Residence, Practice In New Zealand To Be With Daughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `` I expect ...' to CORRECT attribution to Michel, sted Morgan.
DOC.TEXT: A mother who went to jail for two years rather than reveal her daughter's whereabouts during a custody battle wants to stay in New Zealand to live with the girl, it was reported Monday. The TV3 television network quoted Dr. Elizabeth Morgan's current husband, Paul Michel, as saying his wife hopes to resume her career as a plastic surgeon in New Zealand and live with 7-year-old Hilary Foretich. Ms. Morgan flew last month from Washington to New Zealand, where Hilary had been secretly living with her maternal grandparents, after investigators for Ms. Morgan's ex-husband found her. Ms. Morgan was jailed for 25 months until last fall for refusing to say where Hilary was living. She alleged the girl's father, her ex-husband Erich Foretich, sexually abused the child. Foretich, of Falls Church, Va., denies abusing Hilary. He said in an interview from his home Monday that he expected his wife to take up residence in New Zealand. ``I have known that for several days, and had predicted that would be her course of action long before that,'' he said. Michel said he was prevented from applying for permanent residency because he is a federal judge and must live in Washington. ``I expect that my wife will stay here. So I hope to be a frequent visitor to your lovely city,'' Michel told TV3. Hilary's maternal grandparents spirited the child to Britain and then to Christchurch, New Zealand, where Foretich's investigators found her last month. She had been attending a private school. Foretich was accused by his former wife of hunting his daughter ``like an animal'' when he arrived in New Zealand last month to see the girl. A New Zealand court is to rule on the girl's future. Lawyers for the two parties have not announced a date for the court hearing, and reporters have been barred from the proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Labor Ministry Official Sentenced to One Year in Prison
DOC.TEXT: A former Labor Ministry official accused of receiving bribes from a company at the center of a major political bribery scandal was sentenced to one year in prison Monday, an official at the Tokyo District Court said. Shigeru Kano, 56, former head of the ministry's Job Security Division, was also fined $8,700. Judge Akinori Matsumoto suspended the prison term for three years. ``He maintained a corrupt relationship with Recruit Co. without reservations, and should be held responsible for being repeatedly entertained from the company,'' Matsumoto said. The sentencing was the first in a series of trials in the widespread influence-peddling affair known as the Recruit scandal, which rocked Japanese politics for more than a year. The scandal centers around the information and publishing conglomerate Recruit Co., which tried to buy influence by spreading cash and bargain-priced shares in a subsidiary to hundreds of politicians, bureaucrats and business leaders. The affair led to the indictment of 12 politicians, public officials and corporate executives for bribery. They are being tried in five separate trials which began last November. The governing Liberal Democratic Party's links to Recruit triggered strong public distrust toward the party and government. The scandal led to the resignations of two prime ministers and cost the party its long-held majority in Parliament's upper house last July. Kano, who was in a position to supervise the employment information industry between 1982-85, was wined and dined by Recruit at least 41 times, and received various gifts including golf sets and wristwatches, prosecutors said. In return, Kano leaked confidential information to Recruit and influenced ministry decisions on tightening employment regulations in favor of Recruit, they said. Kano resigned from the ministry in January 1989 after he was implicated in the scandal. Recruit Co. does 60 percent of its business by publishing employment-related information.

DOC.HEAD: Deputies Tear Down Protest Tents in Selma Schools Conflict
DOC.TEXT: Deputies removed two tents from the City Hall lawn Monday after a judge temporarily limited a protest over the impending dismissal of Selma's first black school superintendent. ``It went rather peaceful,'' Dallas County Sheriff W.D. ``Cotton'' Nichols said after the tents, pitched by demonstrators on Saturday, were removed at about 6 a.m. City police later arrested a man who allegedly tried to take a video camera from a police officer who was recording the dismantling of the tents. One of the demonstrators, Ronald Peoples, 28, was charged with theft and disorderly conduct, said police Chief M.E. Summerlin. The protesters are seeking a three-year contract extension for Superintendant Norward Roussell, whose $80,000-a-year contract expires in June. The six white members of the 11-member Selma Board of Education voted in December not to renew the contract. Roussell has filed a racial discrimination lawsuit against the board. Circuit Judge Leslie Johnson signed the temporary order Sunday night limiting the demonstrations conducted by a group called Best Education Support Team. The judge ordered the sheriff to remove tents if the group refused to take them down. Nichols said Monday his office ``was just carrying out the court order.'' The judge's order also barred the group from cooking on City Hall property. The sheriff referred to this as ``no more chicken eating and watermelon cutting.'' The order also bars the protesters from disrupting traffic or encouraging disorderly conduct. The order by Johnson followed unsuccessful rounds of negotiations between attorneys for the city and the protest group. It also came after demonstrators renewed their campout at City Hall and directed chants at tourists taking part in Selma's annual Historic Pilgrimage tour. ``We are protesting the pilgrimage because they refuse to deal with current issues,'' said a demonstration leader, Dallas County Commissioner Perry Varner, referring to city officials.
