City Attorney Henry Pitts said the demonstrators showed ``a complete lack of respect for the judicial system'' by violating a March 10 order limiting the protest. ``It makes it very difficult to negotiate with people who want to negotiate with mob rule,'' he said. J.L. Chestnut, an attorney for the protesters, said some supporters of the demonstration ``have been disappointed that the negotiations have gone on so long, and they may have run out of patience.''

DOC.HEAD: Bomb, Shooting Attacks Reported in Azerbaijan
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Assailants opened fire with submachine guns and rifles on a bus carrying Azerbaijanis in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh, killing at least one person, a report from Azerbaijan said Monday. The assailants were not identified, but the attack followed an outbreak of violence in the ethnically torn Caucasus region that left at least nine people dead. Reports from Azerbaijan on Monday also said Armenian nationalists hurled a homemade bomb from an ambulance in the republic. The official Tass news agency reported the bus attack Monday night but did not make clear when it occurred. It said one person was killed and four were injured. Nagorno-Karabakh is at the center of the Armenian-Azerbaijani dispute and has been in a state of virtual civil war for two years. Azerbaijan's Azerinform news agency said Armenian extremists hurled a bomb from an ambulance as it was traveling through the village of Bala Jafarly in the Kazakhsky district of Azerbaijan. Windows in several houses were shattered, but there were no reports of injuries, the news agency said. It said the attack occurred shortly after midnight Sunday. On Monday, Armenians fired automatic weapons on the nearby village of Keirumly, again causing no injuries, it said. Officials from Armenia's Armenpress news agency said they could not communicate with the area and had no information about the events there. Independent confirmation of the Azerinform account was not possible. In recent days, seven people have been reported killed in attacks on Azerbaijanis in the Kazakhsky district, and two Armenians reportedly died when an anti-aircraft shell exploded prematurely. The outbreak of violence was the most serious in the region since anti-Armenian riots in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku broke out Jan. 13. Soviet troops entered the city a week later to quell the unrest. According to official figures, at least 197 people were killed in the January violence, including 125 who died after the arrival of Soviet soldiers in Baku. The dispute between Armenians, who are mostly Christians, and Azerbaijanis, who are mainly Moslem, goes back decades. It erupted anew two years ago over Nagorno-Karabakh, a mostly Armenian enclave that is located in and administered by Azerbaijan. Armenians want to annex the region. Soviet media said the latest deaths included an Azerbaijani family of five who were burned to death. The U.S. Armenian National Committee denied this in a statement released Monday. It alleged that the reports were ``fabricated'' by the Azerinform news agency.

DOC.HEAD: Ivana's Lawyers Say She Wants Half
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS that papers were filed in court in response to Trump move to enforce contract; picks up 5th graf pvs, `This contract ...
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for Ivana Trump filed papers Monday demanding that their client receive half of her estranged husband's fortune, which they estimated at $5 billion. The lawyers said they had filed papers in state court in Manhattan in which they said Mrs. Trump had no intention of seeking a divorce and had never waived the right to an ``equitable share'' of the money Trump made during their 13-year marriage. ``Marital property is property gained by the husband and wife during marriage regardless of in whose name it is held,'' said Michael Kennedy, lawyer for Mrs. Trump. Trump did not have any immediate response. The papers were filed in response to an attempt by Trump's lawyers to enforce a post-marital contract, signed Christmas Eve 1987. That contact, Kennedy said, ``does not waive or release Mrs. Trump's right to such marital property.'' ``This contract was unfair at the time it was made and is unconscionable now that Mr. Trump is trying to enforce it,'' he said. Kennedy denied reports that the contract called for Mrs. Trump to receive $25 million in the event that their marriage broke up. In fact, he said, under the contract Mrs. Trump is to receive $10 million in cash, the couple's house in Greenwich, Conn., and an additional $4 million if she and the couple's three children move out of Trump Tower. This, Kennedy said, was less than 1 percent of Trump's assets. The Trumps' marital problems came to light last month when the developer left his wife, setting off much speculation about Trump's relationships with other women.

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Prepare for Holy Month of Fasting
DOC.TEXT: Moslems across the world scanned the skies after twilight Monday in hopes of sighting the luminous crescent moon that heralds the festive but arduous dawn-to-dusk fasting month of Ramadan. First to announce the sighting from the Arabian Peninsula was North Yemen, where a panel of Islamic judges declared Ramadan will start Tuesday. Sightings also were reported in South Yemen and Saudi Arabia, who declared Tuesday the start of the Moslem holy month. Many of the world's Islamic nations automatically follow the Saudi decision because the kingdom harbors Islam's holiest shrines. Ramadan is venerated by the world's estimated 1 billion Moslems as the month during which the archangel Gabriel imparted the verses of the Koran to Mohammed, the prophet of Islam, more than 14 centuries ago. It is the 9th month in the Moslem lunar calendar. For the 30 days of Ramadan, Moslems must abstain from eating, drinking, and smoking from dawn to sunset. They are to avoid pleasures of the flesh. Even an innocent kiss can be a violation. The more devout will even avoid swallowing their own saliva. Only Moslems who are traveling, ill, or pregnant during Ramadan are exempt from the fast, according to the Koran. But they must make up for this in subsequent months. For weeks, Moslem countries stockpiled food in preparation for the night-time feasts that follow the days of deprivation. Some scholars accuse Moslems of turning Ramadan into a month of feasting rather than fasting, especially since many people actually gain weight. Moslems, however, say they achieve ``boundless spiritual gains'' during Ramadan, purifying their souls and giving themselves peace of mind. Tradition has it that the fast starts each day when a black thread can be distinguished from a white one, and it ends when the two cannot be distinguished. Large cities often fire off a cannon to tell citizens when to stop and start eating. The Koran, the holy book of Islam, prescribed fasting as one of the five pillars of the faith. The others are to recognize the unitarian nature of Allah and that Mohammed is his prophet, pray five times a day, give alms and make the pilgrimage to Mecca at least once. The pillars are supposedly the primary factor that unite Moslems. But the fast has been manipulated by dissident factions and secular states to demonstrate divergent brands and practices of the same religion. It is generally said that when the crescent is sighted in one Moslem country with the naked eye, other Moslems everywhere in the world are required to observe the start of the fast. However, Shiite Moslem Iran, along with Shiite communities in countries ruled by Sunni Moslems, mark the start and end of Ramadan ahead or behind the Sunnis, never on the same day. Turkey, with a secular constitution, has announced that Ramadan commences Wednesday, under simple calendar count. Interior ministries along the Persian Gulf told non-Moslem citizens and expatriate workers to avoid eating, drinking and smoking in public during Ramadan. Moslems who eat, drink or smoke publicly will be fine, flogged and imprisoned, the ministries warned. Liquor is strictly banned during Ramadan, and hotels are instructed to keep their restaurants shut between sunrise and sundown. Room service for foreigners, however, is permitted in most countries.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Existing Homes Slowest in 7 Months
DOC.TEXT: Rising mortgage interest rates last month curbed demand for existing homes, causing sales to drop 2.3 percent to their slowest pace in seven months, a real estate trade group said Monday. The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family homes dipped to 3.44 million units at a seasonally adjusted annual rate as mortgage interest rates remained in the double digits. John A. Tuccillo, the Realtors' chief economist, said Wednesday's Commerce Department report on sales of new homes in February also will show a decline. But Tuccillo predicted rates will begin to drop in the months ahead and renew buyer interest. Fixed-rate mortgages had risen from 10.17 percent to 10.31 percent last month, according to national surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., but slipped to 10.26 percent by last Friday. The February sales rate was the lowest since a 3.38 million-unit pace last July and matched a 3.44 million rate in August. Existing homes, which represent about 80 percent of home sales, posted a sales rate of 3.52 million units in January. Norman D. Flynn, the Realtors' president, said the February pace ``shows considerable market strength and sets the tone for a healthy sales year.'' Tuccillo agreed, saying the trade group expects existing-home sales to total 3.44 million units this year, down 0.1 percent from 1989. As a result of higher mortgage rates, Flynn said many buyers selected less expensive homes as their purchasing power slipped, resulting in a $900 drop from the January median price of a home to $95,400 in February. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. Sales declined 1.1 percent to 930,000 units in the Midwest, where the median price for a home was $73,800. Sales also fell in the South, down 6.4 percent to 1.3 million units, where the median price totaled $85,600. Sales were up 14 percent to 650,000 units in the West and were unchanged at 560,000 units in the Northeast. The median price for a home in the West was $143,000 and, in the Northwest, $143,400.

DOC.HEAD: Glenn Says Pentagon Lacks Manpower Plan
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Sen. John Glenn on Monday accused the Bush administration of failing to provide any estimate of the number of uniformed men and women who will comprise the nation's future armed forces. ``None of the defense officials who have testified before us thus far have been able to give us any definitive manpower strength figures beyond fiscal 1991,'' said Glenn, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services subcommittee on manpower and personnel, in a speech on the Senate floor. The Ohio Democrat also stressed the need for a review of the armed forces, saying he believes that the allocation of roles and missions between active and reserve units has deteriorated. ``The sad fact is that the Army cannot sustain a conventional war for any length of time because the combat support and combat service support forces that must roll in as early as 10 to 30 days after a shooting war starts are not rated as combat ready,'' Glenn said. ``War games make this very point.'' The Ohio senator said that with the collapse of the Warsaw Pact as a military alliance, there is a greater need for ``more definition of our required level of combat capability.'' But the administraton's decisions appear to be driven by fiscal concerns rather than force structure decisions, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Memo on Taxes Introduced in Keating Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Aides to millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. ordered Lincoln Savings and Loan Association to advance its holding company $14.2 million for taxes in 1986, a federal judge was told Monday. However, the government alleges that the money, requested a month before it was due, never was paid to the Internal Revenue Service. The contention came in the 13th day of a hearing in U.S. District Court on Keating's lawsuit, which alleges that the government takeover of the Irvine, Calif., S&L was capricious and arbitrary. He wants the thrift returned to him. A June 30, 1986, memo containing the instructions was introduced to support government allegations that Keating was illegally siphoning federally insured deposits from the thrift. Regulators say the subsequent collapse of the $5.5 billion thrift could cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion, making it the most expensive S&L failure in history. In the memo, Lincoln's chief financial officer was instructed by her counterpart at the thrift's holding company _ Keating's American Continental Corp. of Phoenix _ to make the $14,186,000 payment a month earlier than it was due. Government lawyer James Murphy said the memo bolsters regulators' contention that Lincoln was using complicated real estate, stock and junk bond transactions to book phony profits to bolster Keating's faltering real estate empire. In its April takeover of the thrift, the government contended that American Continental looted Lincoln of $94 million through the tax-sharing arrangement. Under the agreement, the holding company collected taxes due on the phony profits but never paid them to the IRS, the government contends. Although an outline of the tax-sharing arrangement had been approved by regulators on the West Coast, government attorneys contend it was illegal. Meanwhile, Andre Niebling, Lincoln's chairman from mid-1985 through mid-1987, has refused to testify, citing a Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination. Niebling said in an affidavit that a federal grand jury in Los Angeles is weighing possible criminal charges against Keating and other American Continental and Lincoln officials. Mark Sauter, Lincoln's general counsel, refused earlier to testify. Government lawyers alleged Monday that during a July 1986 meeting with federal regulators Keating cited an upcoming meeting with Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the powerful chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Keating's top aide, American Continental President Judith Wischer, testified that she could not recall Keating making that remark or referring to Dingell. Keating would not comment to reporters on what he said at the meeting. He said he did meet with Dingel later to voice complaints about regulators, but did not discuss Lincoln's particular problems. Keating said he had met with about 50 members of Congress since 1984 to complain about the way then-chairmen Edwin Gray, and Gray's successor, M. Danny Wall, were running the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the thrift industry's chief regulator. Dennis Fitzgibbons, a spokesman for Dingell, confirmed that Dingell and Keating met in late July 1986. ``He (Keating) wanted Dingell to go after Gray and Dingell refused,'' Fitzgibbons said. The Senate Ethics Committee is investigating five senators' intervention with bank board officials in 1987 on Lincoln's behalf. The senators, who together received $1.3 million in political funds from Keating, have denied any ethics violations. They are Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.

DOC.HEAD: 94 Percent of Business Leaders Oppose National Health Plan
DOC.TEXT: An overwhelming majority of the nation's business leaders oppose a government-run national health plan, according to a poll released Monday by the Health Insurance Association of America. The poll, conducted by the Roper Organization Inc., found that 94 percent of the business executives surveyed would reject a health-care system with a budget controlled by the states or the federal government. A majority of the executives, 62 percent, said they favored improving private-sector efforts to control health-care costs and relying on the current level of government regulation, while 31 percent said they would favor more government regulation to control physician and hospital prices. Two-thirds of the executives said that in the last year their corporate health care costs rose by 11 percent to 20 percent; one in six said their costs were up 21 percent to 30 percent. The poll also found that nine of 10 business leaders have made major changes in their health plans over the last two to three years to contain costs. The most popular option, chosen by three-quarters of them, was to shift more of the cost to employees by increasing deductibles and co-payments and the workers' share of premiums. Also, 62 percent said they have adopted managed care programs, such as those based on health maintenance organizations and referred provider organizations. Asked to comment on various solutions to the problems in the health-care system, 85 percent said costs could be saved by reducing unnecessary services through utilization reviews and increasing physician and hospital efficiency by applying standards for good medical practice. The survey was based on 100 interviews conducted in January

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Flares Again in Christian Enclave
DOC.TEXT: Gunbattles flared in Beirut's Christian sector Monday after night-long artillery and tank fire duels in the hinterland northeast of the capital. Police said four people were killed and 14 wounded. That raised the overall toll to 772 killed and 2,143 wounded since Jan. 30, when army Gen. Michel Aoun moved to crush Christian warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese forces militia. It was the third straight day of violations of a March 3 cease-fire, sharpening fears of a new round of full-scale fighting to resolve the inconclusive power struggle for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. Police reported Aoun's troops and Geagea's militiamen were engaged in battles on the streets of east Beirut's residential district of Sin el-Fil, the industrial Dora neighborhood and a cluster of abandoned government compounds in Badaro. ``They are shooting at each other with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, but neither side seems trying to push for territorial gains thus far,'' said a police spokesman at midday. He cannot be named under standing rules. Both sides also traded sniper fire across the coastal highway tunnel on the Dog River boundary between Aoun's positions in the Metn province and Geagea's lines in Kesrouan region, the spokesman said. Ten of the wounded were hit by sniper fire on the Dog River crossing. He said Lebanon's main power-generating plant in militia-controlled Zouk just north of the river took several direct hits in the nighttime shelling. The plant has been out of order since the first day of the confrontation, the worst intra-Christian fighting since the civil war with Moslems broke out 15 years ago. That left the Lebanese capital and its environs without city power or water for nearly two months. Officials of the state-run electricity authority have said repair works on the Zouk plant would take at least five months. The police spokesman said Lebanese Forces gunners retaliated for the Zouk bombardment by shelling a makeshift harbor that Aoun's troops reportedly set up in Antelias, five miles north of Beirut. Geagea's militia captured Beirut port in the early days of the showdown, stripping Aoun of the only facility to get replenishments of arms and ammunition for his army by sea. The general has no airport and all overland inlets to his enclave are blocked by hostile Syrian troops. Military sources close to Aoun, speaking on condition of anmonymity, said his engineering corps turned the Golden Beach Hotel in Antelias into a tiny shipping harbor three weeks ago. Ships have since unloaded consignments of 155mm howitzer shells and 120mm mortar rounds from Iraq and France for Aoun's army, the sources said. Police said they could verify neither the reports. Aoun set up his command at the bunker of the Baabda palace after he declared a ``war of liberation'' to drive out Syrian peacekeeping troops from Lebanon on March 14, 1989, charging they had become an ``occupation army.'' The general has refused to turn over the traditional seat of power to Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi, who was elected by parliament Nov. 24 to fill a 13-month presidential vacuum. Hrawi promptly fired Aoun as army commander and prime minister of an interim three-man military cabinet appointed by former President Amin Gemayel when his term expired Sept. 22, 1988 with parliament unable to elect a successor. Hrawi's Defense Minister Albert Mansour said in a statement published Monday that 1,090 troops and 76 officers of various ranks have defected from Aoun's 20,000-strong army to Hrawi's government in Moslem west Beirut. Aoun's command declined to comment. Aoun's treasury, meanwhile, was declared empty by his finance minister, Brig. Gen. Edgar Maalouf. He said in a statement published by several Beirut newspapers that Aoun's cabinet was unable to pay the salaries of civil servants or teachers at state-run schools in the Christian enclave for March and April.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Donating Sorghum To Mexico's Needy
DOC.TEXT: The United States will donate 45,000 metric tons of surplus sorghum grain to help needy families in Mexico, the Agriculture Department said Monday. Christopher Goldthwait, acting general sales manager of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the $3.8 million worth of grain will be provided to World SHARE, a private voluntary organization. The grain will be sold to the Mexican private sector and the proceeds used to provide food assistance to the needy and to support program management and development activities, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lung Surgery Scheduled For Joy Baker
DOC.TEXT: Joy Baker, wife of former Senate Republican leader Howard H. Baker Jr., will undergo lung surgery Wednesday, a family spokesman said. Mrs. Baker was admitted Monday to St. Marys Hospital in Rochester, Minn., said spokesman Tom Griscom. The facility is affiliated with the Mayo Clinic. In 1982, Mrs. Baker underwent surgery for lung cancer. Griscom said he did not think she had experienced a recurrence of the disease, but that Baker wanted to wait until after the surgery to provide any details. Mrs. Baker is the daughter of the late Senate Republican leader Everett Dirksen. Howard Baker served in the Senate from 1966 until 1984 and then was White House chief of staff for President Reagan from February, 1987 until July, 1988. The Bakers' primary residence is in Huntsville, Tenn., but they also maintain a home in Washington, where Baker practices law.

DOC.HEAD: Broccoli Arrives; Bush Stays Away
LaserPhoto WX10
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with later Barbara Bush comment, subbing 2 grafs for 11th graf, The Bush
DOC.TEXT: There was broccoli, broccoli everywhere Monday at the White House _ broccoli on the lawn, broccoli in the boutonnieres, broccoli in the bouquet in Barbara Bush's hand. Everywhere, that is, except on President Bush's plate. And that apparently is how it will stand given the president's adamancy against the vegetable his wife and mother forced him to eat for decades. The broccoli lobby rode the wave of publicity right onto the White House lawn, where hundreds of reporters turned out to watch the broccoli-boosting first lady accept three boxes of the vegetable and a bouquet. That was just the edge of a 10,000-pound avalanche of broccoli California growers shipped east to donate to soup kitchens and shelters in the nation's capital in a riposte to the president's predilections. ``We appreciate the fact that the president himself does not like broccoli personally,'' said George Dunlop, president of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association. But Dunlop, sporting a broccoli boutonniere, offered Mrs. Bush ``some very good new recipes ... (that) just might intrigue the president to take the plunge into the wonderful world of fresh broccoli.'' ``I'm going to overlook the fact you think my cooking is not up to par,'' cracked Mrs. Bush. ``But I'm going to tell you the honest truth: The president is never going to eat broccoli. ``But I am never going to eat pork rinds, ever,'' she promised. In a vive-la-difference aside, she added, ``That's why you stayed married 45 years.'' Later, at a separate White House reception for florists, Mrs. Bush confided that her daughter and four daughters-in-law ``have all checked in and said, `Mother! What are we going to say to the kids now?''' But, as she told the broccoli growers, ``if his own blessed mother can't make him eat broccoli, then I give up.'' ``Millie and I thank you for the broccoli. We'll eat it,'' said Mrs. Bush, whose dog stretched beside the three cases of Irish Spring broccoli, bursting over a small table. Mrs. Bush also said it was ``marvelous'' the needy in the nation's capital were getting tons of free broccoli. Trying to evoke guilt in the media horde, she said, ``You probably wouldn't have come if we'd come out to talk about the food bank.'' The industry had said earlier it was bringing 10 tons of broccoli. At the event, they halved the estimate. Bush set the wheels in motion for the protest when it became known that he had ordered stewards aboard Air Force One to stop serving him broccoli. The president, in words a picky child could only envy, told a news conference last Thursday: ``I do not like broccoli and I haven't liked it since I was a little kid and my mother made me eat it and I'm president of the United States and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli.''

DOC.HEAD: Dorothy Bush LeBlond Wants To Take Divorce Before Mediator
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's daughter wants to go before a mediator next month to see whether she and her estranged husband can agree on the terms of a divorce without waging a court fight. Dorothy Bush LeBlond of Cape Elizabeth, who filed for divorce from William LeBlond on Jan. 3, filed papers in Superior Court here asking to go before the mediator on April 17. A mediation session had not yet been set by Monday, court officials said, although William LeBlond's attorney is also prepared to appear in the April 17 closed-doors session. ``It's a way to get a neutral party involved,'' attorney Thomas H. Allen of Portland said Monday. ``There are financial issues and issues related to children.'' Asked whether he thinks the LeBlonds can reach agreement with a mediator, Allen said, ``I don't make predictions, and I don't have any comment on the matter itself.'' Mrs. LeBlond's lawyer, Phyllis G. Givertz, of Portland, was out of her office Monday, a secretary said. Mrs. LeBlond's divorce petition said ``there are irreconcilable marital differences between the parties and the marriage has broken down,'' without mentioning any specifics. The couple has two children: Samuel, 5, and Nancy, 3.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-White House Broccoli
DOC.TEXT: A florists' society gave Barbara Bush a crystal rose and inducted her into the American Academy of Floriculture on Monday, even though the first lady confessed that nowadays ``I just weed.'' Mrs. Bush, speaking at a reception for the Society of American Florists, said White House florists ``make life a joy for all of us and ... for the 90,000 tourists that come through this house every month.'' ``I was supposed to tell you what an avid gardener I am, but somehow or other I don't think you'd buy it if I told you that I'm out there digging in the garden because I'm not,'' she admitted. Mrs. Bush does do some digging outside her summer home in Kennebunkport, Maine, but even there ``I have someone who puts the garden in for me because I'm not there enough. So I just weed, and plot and plan.'' The White House has four in-hourse florists. National Park Service gardeners tend the Rose Garden and other outdoor flora. She said her late mother, Pauline Robinson Pierce, once conservation chairman of the Garden Clubs of America, must be ``spinning at this moment.'' ``My poor mother, she knew I hated gardening when I was young, and now I love it so,'' said Mrs. Bush. ``I know she is looking and saying, `This is not true! This is not happening!''' The State Room was bedecked with flowers for the reception, with a centerpiece of roses.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Threatens To Take D.C. Statehood Cause to U.N.
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson threatened to take the case for District of Columbia statehood to the United Nations, but in the meantime Monday urged the city council to provide for electing ``shadow'' members of Congress. ``It would be a last resort,'' Jackson said of appealing to the U.N. ``If the citizens of Prague or Warsaw or Managua or Moscow were excluded from participation in national government and denied self-determination, we would understand that basic human rights were being violated,'' Jackson said. ``The political occupation ... of the people living in the District of Columbia is a cause for global concern and action.'' The city council, which was scheduled to vote Tuesday on a bill that would set terms of office of the ``shadow'' delegation, has three times postponed a similar vote in the past. ``The first step for statehood is to get the election on the ballot for this year,'' Jackson said at a District Building news conference. ``We are the cradle of democracy, but have no voting rights in Congress. It is immoral and unjust.'' City voters approved the ``shadow'' plan in a 1980 referendum. The scheme, first used by the Tennessee territory in 1796, creates the position of two `'shadow'' senators and a `'shadow'' congressman to lobby national lawmakers for statehood. The non-voting representatives would have no other official duties. Jackson predicted that the council will approve the measure, although the version of the legislation that will be voted on tomorrow contains no funding for the posts. An initial draft of the bill included $1.3 million to staff the positions and rent office space, but the measure was dismissed as too costly and impractical for a time when the council is struggling to avoid a deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors and Health Workers Strike, 100 Teachers Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 100 university teachers arrested, details, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Government doctors and medical workers went on strike Monday to protest pay cuts following of an eight-year wage freeze, and riot police arrested about 100 university teachers who threatened to join the work stoppage. Armed troops patrolled the capital and other potential trouble spots where demonstrators protested violently last month against this West African nation's austerity measures, which include reducing salaries by up to 17 percent. The austerity measures were brought on by a sharp drop in the prices of cocoa, the Ivory Coast's top export. Only emergency services were available at Abidjan's main hospital in suburban Treichville. In addition to doctors, the strikers included pharmacists, dentists and veterinarians. The university lecturers were arrested when they tried to hold a union meeting at Abidjan University despite a new ban on meetings and protests. Union leader Marcel Ette said they were to decide whether they would join striking health workers. More than 360 members of the National Union of Senior Health Officers met in Treichville on Monday in defiance of the ban. The medical union had called for its 750 members across the country to strike Monday and Tuesday to protest the cuts, imposed this month in a government bid to avoid bankruptcy in this financially strapped nation. Dr. Assoa Adou, the medical union's secretary-general, said any pay cut on top of a wage freeze already in effect was ``insupportable and unjust.'' A union letter blamed the government of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny for the economic crisis, brought on by the slumping cocoa prices overseas. ``The economic situation actually is the result of bad management of public finances, embezzlement, etc.,'' the letter said. Last month, the economic problems prompted widespread protests led by university students who accused government leaders of siphoning money from state coffers. Protesters set cars aflame, looted stores and stoned cars and buses. They demanded the resignation of Houphouet-Boigny, who has ruled Ivory Coast as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960. The government then closed the nation's only university and all schools, leaving protest leaders without a meeting place. In response to the medical workers' strike, state radio Monday said, ``All demonstrations in and around hospital premises are forbidden, as are all demonstrations and any meetings anywhere in the country. Security forces have been given orders to enforce this.'' Interior Minister Leon Konan Koffi tried to uphold the ban. He went to Treichville University Hospital Center, which was guarded by three truckloads of armed troops, and ordered striking health officers to leave the building. ``We told him they would have to use force to move us and that if they did, the strike will continue beyond Tuesday,'' Adou said in an interview. He said the strikers planned to meet again at the hospital Tuesday. The union letter warned ``the work stoppage will be total and unlimited if a health professional is the objective of measures of oppression, arrest or suppression of salary.'' Adou sent a letter to Houphouet-Boigny complaining about conditions in ill-equipped hospitals where patients have to buy everything, even gloves for the surgeon. ``Many die because it takes a day or two to get together money for the medical prescriptions ... doctors stand by powerless and watch innocent and unjustified deaths,'' his letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Seminoles Switch Hunt to Cameras Instead of Guns
DOC.TEXT: Protests from animal activists led the Seminole Tribe to cancel its planned big-game hunt at a 3-mile preserve, so tourists will now shoot deer and antelope with cameras instead of guns. Seminole officials have decided to offer safari-style excursions for photographers on the fenced preserve they had stocked with the animals sheep and had planned to open for hunters. The tribe dropped the hunting plan after animal-rights groups complained and threatened a boycott of the Seminole-run bingo games and cigarette shops that help finance education and social programs for the tribe. ``We decided it would be more fun to watch them instead of shooting them'' on the preserve on the Big Cypress reservation 65 miles west of Fort Lauderdale, said David Holloway, exotic-game manager for the Seminole Tribe. The tribe paid $30,000 for 68 deer, antelope and sheep and planned to either raise them for food or game on the preserve. In about two months, Seminole guides will begin leading groups of shutterbugs in search of the black buck antelope, axis deer, Corsican sheep, and an African antelope called the scimitar-horned oryx, Holloway said. Plans call for using buses, motorized buggies or other vehicles to transport photo enthusiasts. The more hardy may set out on foot through the brush in search of their quarry. ``I'm glad they have taken a more human approach to the animals. We feel that's the best thing to do with the animals now that they are here,'' said Marian Lentz, Animal Rights Foundation co-founder. ``They may as well let them live out the rest of their days in as peaceful a way as possible.'' The foundation, based in Pembroke Pines, was among the groups opposed to plans for hunting parties. ``It's ridiculous to have hunters converge on the animals in a small area. It's like shooting fish in a barrel,'' Lentz said. About 800 feet of fence was cut at the preserve in January, but none of the animals escaped. Holloway said the animals have established their own territories inside the preserve and would be reluctant to leave. One sheep wandered outside the fence, but was led back in by workers at the preserve, Holloway said. Members of a group calling itself the Animal Liberation Front claimed responsibility for cutting the fence and promised to strike again. Holloway said the tribe was surprised at the intensity of opposition, especially since he said there are about 80 such game preserves in Florida. ``The Indians have great respect for animals,'' he said. ``Everyone made them to be the bad guys, but it's OK for the whites to have game farms.'' Holloway said he was uncertain how much the tribe will charge for the excursions.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative, Center-Left Parties Lead in Hungary Vote Count
With AM-Hungary-Who's On First, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A conservative party and a center-left rival emerged Monday as the front-runners in Hungary's first democratic parliamentary elections in 43 years. The Socialist party, which ruled as the Communist Party until it changed its name last year, initiated the dramatic reforms that led to Sunday's balloting but got little credit from voters. It trailed in fourth place. As election results trickled in Monday, the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum had an edge over the center-left League of Free Democrats. But neither garnered anything close to the absolute majority needed for decisive victory, making a coalition government likely after runoff elections are held next month. Election officials said only five of the 394 parliamentary seats had been decided by Monday, and three were Hungarian Democratic Forum winners. More than 70 percent of Hungary's 7.85 million eligible voters cast ballots. With 3,608,000 _ 69 percent _ of the votes counted late Monday, the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum led with 24.22 percent and the center-left League of Free Democrats was second with 20.84 percent, state radio said. The Independent Smallholders, a revived pre-World War II party popular in rural areas, had 12.62 percent, the Socialists 10.54 percent, the radical liberal League of Young Democrats 8.57 percent and the Christian Democratic People's Party 6.43 percent. The rest of the 29 parties that fielded candidates appeared to fall short of winning 4 percent of the vote nationwide and therefore would not be entitled to any Parliament seats. Up to 14 candidates competed in most races, and the vote was so split that many seats will have to be contested again, election officials said. In the second round of voting, a simple majority will suffice, provided 25 percent of eligible voters turn out. The Democratic Forum and the Free Democrats have said they do not want to govern together, so the Smallholders may be the key to forming a coalition. Smallholder leader Vince Voeroes said Monday his party is ideologically closer to the Forum, which like the Smallholders is based on traditional, Christian values and in the prewar populism of rural Hungary. But he said no decision had been made on whether to ally with the Forum. Democratic Forum chairman Joszef Antall said Voeroes' party would be his first choice as a coalition partner, and like the Free Democrats dismissed any idea of working with the Socialists. ``There will be no place whatsoever in the new government for members of the old government, ministers of state and deputy ministers,'' he said. Premier Miklos Nemeth, a founder of the Socialist Party and one of the chief supporters of full democracy, said his outgoing government should get credit for leading the nation to Sunday's historic vote ``under extremely complex conditions.'' Nemeth, running as an independent in his home village of Szerencs, 70 miles northeast of Budapest, was one of the few candidates to win outright. The Socialists and their Communist predecessors played a role unique in the Soviet bloc by initiating reform rather than being forced into it. But most voters apparently associated the Socialists with the repression of Hungary's Communist rule and rejected the party's candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershocks Rattle Costa Rica after 10 Injured in Quakes
DOC.TEXT: Minor aftershocks rattled Costa Rica on Monday following two earthquakes last weekend that destroyed 30 homes near a Pacific port, damaged several schools and slightly injured 10 people, officials said. Sunday's quakes measured 5.5 and 6.9 on the Richter scale. Sources in the Red Cross and National Emergency Commission said about 10 people were injured in the coastal region closest to the epicenter of Sunday morning's tremors, though none was seriously enough hurt to require hospitalization. The quakes Sunday were centered in the Pacific Ocean, 80 miles southwest of San Jose, according to the U.S. Geological Survey in Golden, Colo. Thirty houses were destroyed in the area of the Pacific port of Puntarenas. Several schools, a Catholic church and a hospital in the area were closed until earthquake damage is repaired, commission sources said. The Volcanic and Seismological Center said Monday at least 700 aftershocks had been recorded, the strongest occurring before dawn Monday and measuring 4.2. Sunday's quakes also cracked the cupola of the cathedral in Alajuela, 12 miles north of San Jose, caused long fissures in the sides of many buildings and caused landslides that blocked the main highway linking San Jose with the Atlantic coast.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Drug Trial of Colombian
DOC.TEXT:
Jury selection began under tight security Monday for a man believed to be a high-ranking member of the Medellin drug cartel. Jose Rafael Abello-Silva of Santa Marta, Colombia, is charged with two counts of conspiring to import drugs. He was extradited Oct. 29 from Bogota to Tulsa, where he was indicted in 1987 on drug charges. Abello was extradited under a decree signed in 1989 by Colombian President Virgilio Barco Vargas that provides for extradition of suspected narcotics traffickers. Security was tight in the courthouse where 100 prospective jurors assembled. Metal detectors were set up outside the courtroom. U.S. Attorney Tony Graham had asked that the juror's names, addresses and employers not be made public and U.S. District Judge Thomas Brett agreed. ``It should not cause you to treat this case any differently from other criminal cases,'' he said. Defense attorneys have asked that the trial be moved out of Tulsa because of publicity. Brett said he would rule on the motion after talking to prospective jurors. Abello, 35, was arrested Oct. 10 in a Bogota restaurant. Police said he had undergone plastic surgery to avoid detection.
He was indicted by a federal grand jury in Tulsa on Sept. 2, 1987, along with Florida stock broker Frank Palmero. Palmero later was convicted on drug distribution charges and sentenced to 16 years in prison. The indictment accuses Abello of involvement in a conspiracy to ship more than 1,700 pounds of cocaine and 6,200 pounds of marijuana to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Psychiatric Tests Ordered for Man Accused in Book Thefts
DOC.TEXT: A federal magistrate Monday ordered psychiatric tests for a man accused of stealing $10 million to $20 million in rare books from collections across the country. An FBI agent, meanwhile, said investigators have begun to match books found in the Ottumwa home of Stephen Carrie Blumberg with books that libraries reported missing or stolen. ``We believe we'll be able to help out several of these libraries,'' said Special Agent Dennis Aiken of the Omaha, Neb., bureau. Blumberg, 41, of St. Paul, Minn., was arrested last week at a home he owns in Ottumwa. The FBI said it found 11,000 rare books as well as antiques in the 14-room house. Defense attorneys and prosecutors agreed to the examination during a hearing before Magistrate Ronald Longstaff. The hearing originally was set to determine conditions Blumberg would have to meet in order to be freed before trial. No trial date has been set. Blumberg did not speak during the appearance. He was returned to the Polk County jail. Blumberg will be sent later this week to the Springfield Medical Center for Federal Prisoners at Springfield, Mo. The examination is to last a month. Blumberg's lawyer, Don Nickerson of Des Moines, said the agreement for psychiatric evaluation does not necessarily mean Blumberg will use mental condition as a defense. Nickerson said he would have little trouble arranging a pretrial bond after the examination. ``If he's released, what's the danger, that he'll throw books at passing cars?'' Nickerson argued. Government lawyer Linda Read declined to comment on what the government has found, saying prosecutors were examining the collection. Many of the identifying marks or labels were removed from the books. But Aiken said finding the owners shouldn't be difficult because the books are rare. Some of the books may have to be held as evidence. Aiken would not say how investigators closed in on Blumberg.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says No to Ex-Hostage Testimony at Poindexter Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with Jacobsen, House staffer out of case, Chafee in; edits throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: John Poindexter's lawyers lost efforts Monday to get the testimony of former hostage David Jacobsen and a House staff member who made political comments about a possible Contra investigation. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said testimony at Poindexter's trial by Jacobsen, who was held in West Beirut from May 1985 to Nov. 2, 1986, would ``inflame'' the jury with the emotional hostage issue. Greene also granted a House motion to quash Poindexter's subpoena for House staff member Victor Johnson, who had said in a 1986 memo that inquiring into Oliver North's Contra-related activities would make a good political issue. Meanwhile, Poindexter's lawyers disclosed that they plan to call Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., as a character witness for Poindexter. Poindexter, a retired rear admiral, served under Chafee when the senator was secretary of the Navy in the Nixon administration. Chafee will testify Tuesday, his office confirmed. Poindexter is accused of concealing from Congress the U.S. role in a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran and North's military assistance to the Contras. Defense attorney Richard Beckler said he wanted Jacobsen to testify about a conversation with Poindexter, which occurred on Nov. 21, 1986. That is the day Poindexter is accused of obstructing Congress and making false statements about the Iran initiative. Beckler said Jacobsen could testify about conveying to Poindexter serious concern that any inaccurate information about the Iran initiative could result in harm to the hostages. As for the House staff member, Johnson had said in a memo to Rep. Ronald Coleman, D-Texas, that delving into North's Contra activities ``places the administration in a coverup posture.'' Coleman introduced a resolution of inquiry into North's activities. Greene said whether there was ``political motivation'' for the resolution of inquiry is irrelevant to the criminal case against the former national security adviser. In testimony earlier Monday, a former National Security Council employee said Poindexter told then-President Reagan the U.S. government had no connection to a Contra resupply plane that crashed in Nicaragua. Poindexter made the statement to Reagan on Oct. 7, 1986, two days after the plane carrying ammunition was shot down and one of its crewmen, Eugene Hasenfus, was captured, Rodney McDaniel testified. Actually, the Hasenfus flight was part of the network overseen by North to keep the Contras armed during a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the rebel force. The Iran initiative resulted in the release of three hostages _ Jacobsen, the Rev. Benjamin Weir and the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco _ though three other U.S. citizens were seized in Lebanon during the period of the releases in 1985 and 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Videotape Distributer Files Complaint Against Justice Department
DOC.TEXT: A distributor of sexually oriented videotapes accused the Justice Department on Monday of abusing its powers by trying to force the company to choose between prosecution or going out of business. PHE Inc., which does business as Adam & Eve, contends that the Justice Department was trying to force it to stop distributing ``sexually oriented expressive material'' that officials have acknowledged is not legally obscene. Justice Department officials ``have abused their prosecutorial powers in a deliberate effort to coerce plaintiffs to cease distribution of expressive materials defendants could not, and would not, prosecute as obscene,'' said the complaint filed in U.S. District Court here. The officials ``have varied the threats and pressures they have brought to bear on plaintiffs in order to coerce the self-censorship of as broad a range of non-obscene expressive materials as plaintiffs can be coerced to forego.'' The lawsuit seeks an injunction to bar the government's National Obscenity Enforcement Unit from bringing federal charges for distributing books and videotapes. The suit also seeks a court order barring the Justice Department from threatening to bring ``simultaneous multiple prosecutions'' around the country unless the company agrees to stop distributing the books and videotapes. The lawsuit notes that in 1987 a state-court jury in North Carolina acquitted the company and owner Philip D. Harvey of felony obscenity charges. The company has been threatened with federal prosecution in North Carolina, Utah and Kentucky. Harvey said in a statement that the government ``is clearly targeting us as part of a political persecution campaign intended to pacify a tiny minority of intolerant right-wing extremists.'' Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett declined to comment on the lawsuit. The action was filed a day before Karl Brussel and his Pak Ventures Inc. were set to go to trial in nearby Alexandria, Va., on federal obscenity distribution charges. Brussel faces similar federal charges in North Carolina and in two different federal jurisdictions in Alabama. The charges have drawn criticism from free-speech advocates who have accused the Justice Department of trying to bludgeon mail-order companies into going out of business rather than pay high legal bills. In 1988, a federal judge barred the Justice Department from prosecuting mail-order operator Avram Freedburg in more than one federal jurisdiction. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson held that such multiple prosecutions ``cannot possibly be consistent with due process.'' To settle the dispute, Freedberg's company, Consumers Marketing Group Ltd. of Stamford, Conn., agreed to plead guilty to mailing obscene matter, pay a $600,000 fine and stop distributing sexually oriented material.

DOC.HEAD: Tanks Pull Back, School Reopen in Troubled Transylvanian Town
DOC.TEXT: Army tanks pulled back and schools reopened Monday in this northern Translyvanian city, which has been the scene of deadly street battles between ethnic Hungarians and Romanians. Despite easing tensions, scattered small-scale incidents between the two groups were reported in the region Monday. No casualties were reported. In addition, several hundred troops and policemen remained around Tirgu Mures, a picturesque Transylvanian town of 170,000 people. Authorities were trying to prevent a repeat of running street battles last week between extremists from both communities. At least six people were killed, and about 300 were injured, according to an official communique. On Monday, 12 army T-55 tanks that had been used to block the main square in Tirgu Mures were withdrawn. Classes resumed in all schools, including the Institute of Medicine and Pharmacy, whose ethnic Hungarian students had been on strike the past three weeks, Radio Bucharest reported. It said ``social and economic activities are being carried out almost normally.'' ``We are all willing to give it another try, so let's hope that peace here will last,'' a Romanian high school student told The Associated Press. In a statement Monday, however, the provisional committee of the Democratic Union of Hungarians in Romania, an ethnic Hungarian political party, accused Romanians of splashing paint on the statue of a 19th century Hungarian hero. The statue hero stands in the Transylvanian town of Zalau, where occupying Hungarian troops killed a group of Romanians in 1940. The Hungarian statement described the purported attack on the statue as a ``profanity.'' Romanians, who make up nearly 70 percent of Transylvania's 7.5 million people, accuse ethnic Hungarians of seeking to secede from Romania and rejoin neighboring Hungary. Hungary had ruled Transylvania for centuries, although Romanians were in the majority. However, the region was ceded to Romania in 1918 at the close of World War I. Ethnic Hungarians deny they want to secede. They say they only want more cultural autonomy. The conflict has come to the surface in recent weeks in the atmosphere of freer expression that has prevailed since the December revolution ousted hard-line Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu.

DOC.HEAD: Two Suspected Kurdish Guerrillas, Village Guard Killed
DOC.TEXT: Two suspected Kurdish guerrillas and a village guard were killed in a clash near the Iraqi border, the semi-official Anatolia news agency said Monday. The agency said the clash took place Sunday night when a group of Kurds attempted to raid Dogan village. It said the Kurdish insurgents escaped after exchanging fire with village guards loyal to the government. Anatolia did not say what organization the insurgents belonged to, but most rebels operating in the region are linked with the outlawed Kurdish Labor Party, also known by its Kurdish initials PKK. The Marxist group, with headquarters in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa valley in Lebanon, seeks to set up an independent state in southeastern Turkey. More than 2,300 people including civilians, security personnel and rebels have died since the PKK started hit-and-run attacks six years ago. Ethnic Kurds make up about one-fifth of Turkey's 55 million populace.

DOC.HEAD: Police Shoot At Blacks During Protest, Two Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with conflicting reports of two to 12 killed, details. Picks up 4th pvs, `In Sebokeng...' with minor editing thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Police on Monday clashed with demonstrators protesting living and working conditions in two black townships, and at least two blacks were killed, witnesses said. There were conflicting reports on the number of deaths in Sharpeville and Sebokeng, townships just south of Johannesburg. Independent 702 radio station quoted local residents as saying up to 12 people were missing and feared dead. However, government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. said there were five deaths and independent South African Press Association said two to eight were killed. Those stations did not cite their sources, and police said a more detailed statement wouldn't be issued until Tuesday morning. Also Monday, officials blamed guerrillas of the African National Congress for attacks the night before on town offices in Soweto and a power station in Johannesburg. The attacks came less than three weeks before the anti-apartheid ANC is scheduled to begin negotiations with the white-minority government. Police said they used birdshot, rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse several thousand demonstrators in Sharpeville and Sebokeng, townships about six miles apart. In Sebokeng, the protesters stoned a police station and set fire to the municipal buildings, police said. ``Police (are) coming on constant attack, mainly by stone-throwing mobs,'' said a statement from police headquarters in Pretoria. At least two blacks were killed and hundreds wounded during the clash in Sebokeng, according to a nurse at the Sebokeng Hospital who declined to give her name. Other witnesses gave similar accounts, and some said more than 300 were injured, but it was not immediately clear how the two blacks were killed. Police said there was an undetermined number of injuries, but they had no information on deaths. No casualties were reported in Sharpeville. The demonstrators were protesting rents, housing conditions and working conditions in the townships, witnesses said. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok met with local police officials and promised to increase staffing and patrols in the troubled region. Also, police accused African National Congress guerrillas of firing two rocket-propelled grenades Sunday night at town council offices in Soweto, another township outside Johannesburg. The two Soviet-made RPG-7 grenades caused damage but no injuries, police said. An hour later, three mines were detonated at the Langlaagte power station in Johannesburg, badly damaging three transformers, police said. Hundreds of police and security officers on Monday searched for those responsible for the attacks, the most serious in several months. Police officials, who declined to be named, said they believed the ANC's military wing mounted the attacks as ``a show of force.'' Nelson Mandela and other ANC leaders are to meet with the government April 11 in Cape Town to try to clear the way for talks on ending white-minority rule in South Africa. President F.W. de Klerk last month freed Mandela after 27 years of imprisonment and legalized the ANC and other black opposition groups in a bid to bring blacks to the negotiating table. In Nairobi, Kenya, Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa's Anglican Church said Monday that the ANC should renounce its policy of armed resistance. ``Anybody who says that they want to continue to fight when there is a possibility to talk will find they have very few supporters in South Africa and internationally,'' Tutu told a news conference. Police reports said at least seven blacks were killed Sunday in fighting between rival black factions in the eastern province of Natal. The South African Broadcasting Corp. said eight blacks were killed and nine injured in a faction fight Sunday near Tugela Ferry, also in Natal. More than 3,000 blacks have been killed since 1986 in Natal in fighting between the ANC-aligned United Democratic Front and the Inkatha movement. Recent efforts by Mandela and other black leaders to end the violence have proved ineffective.

DOC.HEAD: Social Club Fire: Cruel Incarnation of a Familiar Nightmare
With AM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fire raced through a Bronx social club, snuffing out lives in a rush of flame and toxic smoke. The mayor, horrified at the carnage, formed a task force to close down the city's illegal nightspots. That was a year and a half ago. Sunday, the nightmare returned in an even crueler incarnation. Instead of six people, 87 were now dead in a crowded club. The city's crackdown had failed. And given continued failure, experts said Monday, many more may die. ``These places are fire traps. They're supermarkets of crime. They're in violation of every code imaginable,'' said state Sen. Jeremy Weinstein, a Brooklyn Democrat who led an investigation of illegal social clubs in 1981. ``It's not just the city of New York, it's true for every city in the country,'' he said in an interview. ``It's something every urban area has had to deal with in the last decade. And none has been dealing with it.'' Indeed, despite a renewed crackdown announced Monday. ``It wouldn't shock me if this happened again,'' said Charles Ryan, an ex-fire captain and now fire science department chairman at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. ``These places reopen as fast as they shut 'em down.'' The problem is not a new one. In 1942, 491 people lost their lives at Boston's Cocoanut Grove club in the nation's worst fire ever. Like the Happy Land Social Club, site of Sunday's fire, the Cocoanut Grove was overcrowded at the time of the blaze and lacked adequate exits for patrons. That fire led to new national fire codes for emergency exits, lighting and other factors that could contribute to a blaze. Ryan and others said the simple problem is in enforcing such laws. But it also is more complex than that, they said _ a combination of the city's enormous problems, shrinking budget and paralyzing bureaucracy. And there is another, equally daunting factor: Tremendous demand for the illegal but inexpensive clubs, particularly in poor immigrant communities where life is difficult, diversions are scarce and danger is a commonplace. ``People who are living in tough conditions of life are going to look for opportunities to blow off some steam,'' said Prof. William Kornblum, director of the Social Research Center at the City University of New York's graduate school. ``They're going to pay less attention to the dangers around them.'' The hazards can be legion. At the Happy Land club, authorities say there was no open fire exit, no first-floor sprinkler system, no proper emergency lights, and bars on the sole window. The only way out was through the front door. It was blocked by flames, allegedly ignited by an arsonist. Sixty-one men and 26 women died. The deaths are all the more tragic for the city's failed effort to shut down the Happy Land. The task force formed by Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1988 won an order that year that it be closed. Apparently it was, for a time. And at some point, unknown to the authorities, it reopened. ``Most horrifying is that this should never have happened,'' said Mayor David Dinkins. ``That club had been inspected. It had been cited. And it had been ordered closed.'' He immediately launched another crackdown, with police posting vacate orders on 187 social clubs Sunday night. But those orders don't solve the problem. Said Ryan: ``Issuing a piece of paper and saying, `You're closed' doesn't mean anything unless you come around and whack the guy on the head.'' With 2,031 inspections by the task force last year, identification of illegal clubs has been adequate, Ryan said. ``It's the follow-up that's weak,'' he said. ``That's the nut of the problem: inadequate enforcement.'' Fuller enforcement would require substantial manpower. The police estimate there are 1,220 social clubs in the city, with about 1,000 listed as inactive. But Happy Land was one of those ``inactive'' clubs. Kornblum guessed the city in fact has 500 to 600 operating social clubs _ some legal, many not _ with more in nearby suburbs. ``It is true that complete enforcement is futile. The clubs are always moving to new locations, always trying to stay a step or two ahead of the authorities,'' Kornblum said. But he said aggressive followup could save lives, if the city provided the resources. There are other approaches as well. With a view of social clubs as cultural centers, Kornblum suggested low-interest city loans for legally operated clubs that could take the place of illegal dives. Ryan, for his part, suggested cracking down on the liquor merchants who keep the clubs supplied, and possibly placing a legal limit on retail liquor sales. Weinstein said he would investigate the idea. Yet Weinstein noted that little of this is new. In 1981, his panel's report on illegal social clubs included this warning: ``The potential fire hazard alone is of such proportion that numerous lives could be lost at any time no matter how minor the fire was at the outset.'' ``How ironic that after so many years, we're still back where we started,'' he said. ``Now a lot of people are going to be up in arms over this. And then, eventually, it's going to fade _ until it happens again.''

DOC.HEAD: Fire Victims Believed to be from Coastal Region
With AM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hondurans jammed phone lines Monday seeking news of relatives in New York City following a weekend fire that killed 87 people at a Bronx social club. The government expressed regret over the death of the victims, most of them Hondurans and Dominicans, and instructed its ambassador to gather information for relatives. Gov. Dylia Chirinos de Diaz said most of the Hondurans were from coastal towns in Colon province. ``The majority of them traveled to the United States in search of a better way of life,'' said Edith Fajardo, a Honduran consular official in New York. Foreign Ministry spokesman Eugenio Castro said the government was studying the possibility of sending a Honduran air force plane to bring back the bodies of the victims of the fire at the Happy Land social club. Julio Cesar Castro of the northwestern city of San Pedro Sula said his 17-year-old daughter, Janeta Mercedes Castro, died in the early morning blaze. ``My daughter traveled to New York in search of better horizons, to save money and then return to her home in Honduras, but she only found death,'' he said. She had been in New York for two years and was a maid for an American family, Castro said. He said she leaves a 2-year-old son who lives with him. A Cuban man thrown out of the club after quarreling with his ex-girlfriend was arraigned Monday on arson and murder charges. Hondurans seeking information on victims and the welfare of relatives crowded into telephone offices in Colon province. Radio stations broadcast almost continual news of the fire and said they were receiving streams of calls seeking information on victims. Stations are a major means of communication in the country, which has a 57 percent illiteracy rate. In New York, Miguel Reyes, coach of the Club Deportivo Adrana amateur soccer team, said three of its players, all from Puerto Cortes, a northwestern coastal town, were among the dead. ``They all dreamed of returning home _ but with more money,'' Reyes said. Reynaldo Colon Nunez, a Honduran living in New York, told the Tegucigalpa station Radio America by telephone that he normally would have been at the club himself. ``Nearly every Sunday I went to Happy Land to dance but yesterday I didn't want to,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rape Quip Brings More Criticism; Campaign says Short-Lived
DOC.TEXT: Women's groups and political opponents continued to heap criticism Monday on Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams, who joked at a weekend campfire that women should ``relax and enjoy'' rape. ``I don't care if it was made around the campfire, a living room or a formal speech,'' state Treasurer Ann Richards said. ``It indicates a level of thinking that is an embarrassment.'' Richards could face Williams in the November election if she wins a Democratic runoff against Attorney General Jim Mattox on April 10. Williams, who has since apologized, told reporters on a cattle roundup at his Alpine ranch Saturday that the bad weather they were experiencing was a lot like rape. ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it,'' he said. He said he had been joking, but conceded later that the remark was inappropriate. ``I feel just terrible about this. I had no intention in my heart to hurt anyone, especially those women who have been traumatized by rape,'' said Williams in a statement released by the staff Sunday. ``Looking back, I realize it was insensitive and had no place at the campfire or in any setting.'' The Texas chapter of the National Organization for Women issued a statement Monday calling the remark ``degrading'' and ``not acceptable for someone who wishes to govern a society where all human beings can live and function in safety.'' Williams' campaign spokesman, Bill Kenyon, said damage to the Williams campaign may be short-lived. ``We had probably 30 or so calls yesterday, that were most of them rather harsh in tone,'' Kenyon said. ``After the apology that Clayton put out yesterday, most of the calls today have been more sympathetic or not the same kind of tone.'' He said Williams' apology will work in his favor ``because people know that Clayton Williams doesn't have a mean bone in his body.'' Earlier, however, Mattox called the remark in character for Williams. ``It is within his character, and it is within the way he normally deals with people and traditions and institutions,'' Mattox said Sunday. State GOP leaders said the controversy would be a lesson to Williams, a millionaire rancher and businessman making his first political race. ``He should not have joked about it that way,'' said state Sen. Cyndi Krier of San Antonio. ``Claytie is new to public life and he's learning some lessons along the way,'' said Beverly Kaufman, first vice president of the Texas Federation of Republican Women. ``He used an archaic expression to say `Let's make the best of an unpleasant situation,''' she said, adding she could understand why some people would take offense.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in New England, Rain in South
DOC.TEXT: Winter took a late, feeble swing at New England on Monday, depositing up to two inches of snow, and rain fell across the flood-weary South. Scattered snowfall was reported in New Hampshire and Vermont, where two inches piled up in Montpelier by noon. Snow also fell in parts of central New York state and central Pennsylvania. Rain fell along a band from South Carolina through central Texas, and many rivers in the region remained above flood stage. Minor flooding occurred in the Carolinas, Georgia and Texas, according to the National Weather Service. Some flooding was reported Monday along Georgia's Flint, Ocmulgee and lower Savannah rivers; North Carolina's Roanoke River; and the Santee and Great Pee Dee rivers in South Carolina. Flood warnings were in effect in the Sulfur and Cypress Creek basins in Texas, as well as along the Trinity, Sabine and Neches rivers. There also was some lowland flooding in Illinois, along the Illinois River. Freeze warnings were posted for Monday night through the mid-Atlantic states, but daytime highs Tuesday were forecast in the 40s and 50s. Cloudy or partly cloudy skies were expected Tuesday in south and the Plains states, with showers over coastal Georgia, Arizona, New Mexico and west Texas. Skies over the rest of the nation were expected to be clear. The low temperature for the nation Monday was 1 degree at West Yellowstone, Mont. and Yellowstone, Wyo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 17 degrees at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., 89 degrees at Needles Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Some Always Questioned Whether ``Junior'' Patriarca Was Mob Boss
With AM-Mob Arrests, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some law enforcement officials have long doubted that Raymond J. ``Junior'' Patriarca was a strong enough leader to take the helm of the crime family his father had ruled with an iron fist since Prohibition. But others say his low-key demeanor was deceptive. Patriarca, 45, inherited control of the New England mob on the death of his father, Raymond Patriarca Sr., from a heart attack in 1984, authorities say. A five-year FBI investigation culminated Monday in a 113-page indictment naming Patriarca and 20 alleged mobsters on charges ranging from murder and racketeering to kidnapping, drug trafficking and gambling. ``He was so much different than his father,'' said Providence police Cmdr. Richard S. Tamburini, who formerly headed the city's intelligence bureau. ``He was so low-key and very difficult to locate. His father, on the other hand, was out in the open. ``A lot of people would not accept that Junior was running the mob,'' he said. ``I think that should put this to rest.'' But North Kingstown's police chief John Leyden, who also tracked the mob as a Providence detective, said he suspects ``much of the respect is for the No. 2 person, Nicky'' Bianco. Patriarca and his alleged underboss, Nicholas Bianco, were among 15 of the 21 brought into custody Monday afternoon. At a hearing before a U.S. magistrate in Providence, lawyer John Cicilline said Patriarca was suffering from cataracts and cancer. Patriarca was ordered transferred to Boston, where he was detained pending an April 6 hearing. The Patriarca family's alleged involvement in organized-crime activities remains strong, but its influence waned as its membership dwindled over the last decade, both Tamburini and Leyden said. The elder Patriarca became the city's ``Public Enemy Number One'' during Prohibition in the 1920s and early 1930s. By the 1970s, he had been arrested more than 40 times, convicted of 18 crimes ranging from armed robbery and conspiracy to murder, and had served seven years in prison. He was identified as head of the New England La Cosa Nostra during 1969 U.S. Senate committee hearings. According to transcripts of conversations picked up by an illegally hidden FBI microphone, he recruited Bianco in the early 1960s to be an enforcer and mediator between New York gangs. The family operated from a vending machine company and a cleaning business in the predominantly Italian Federal Hill neighborhood. One resident who attended his funeral said Patriarca ``protected the Hill ... there never was any trouble on the Hill. Now there will be trouble.'' The FBI transcripts also revealed a father who wanted his only son to be a lawyer or successful businessman, but who was frustrated that the boy twice had flunked out of the University of Rhode Island. Tamburini said the younger Patriarca has been deeply involved in his father's business since at least 1980, when the crime boss ran into serious legal and health problems. The ailing Patriarca was indicted in September 1981 on charges of taking part in a scheme to skim $11 million from the Laborers' International Union, but a federal magistrate found him too ill to stand trial on the racketeering charges in Florida. Aside from investing in a delicatessen that displayed photographs of gangsters on the walls, Raymond Junior stayed in the background, authorities said. ``When his father was alive, you wouldn't see him very much,'' Leyden said. ``It was only during his father's trial that you saw him.'' His chief rival for control of the New England mob was Gennaro J. Angiulo of Boston, who once was heard on an FBI tape saying of the then 40-year-old Patriarca: ``I can't see the kid stepping into the picture for the simple reason ... he is too young.'' But law enforcement officials said Patriarca's hold was strengthened when Angiulo was arrested on racketeering charges. Patriarca was arrested only once, in 1971 on charges of receiving stolen bundles of fiberglass, and the charges were dropped when two witnesses refused to testify. He grew up on Providence's affluent East Side, but in recent years retreated to his home in Lincoln, R.I., where he spent much of his time working on real-estate developments, authorities said. Patriarca retreated further into the background after reputed underboss William P. Grasso was found shot last June near Hartford, Conn., said law enforcement officials who speculated an internal power tussle. ``They're in chaos now because of a lack of trust,'' Tamburini said.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Victims' Families Seek Donations for Counseling Program
DOC.TEXT: Families of murder victims from across Massachusetts gathered Monday to open the headquarters of a victims support group named for a high school student who was stabbed to death by Willie Horton in 1974. ``The ordeal my family has endured has brought us together with other families of murder victims,'' Donna Fournier Cuomo said in opening the Joey Fournier Victim Services' office across from the Statehouse. The group provides free counseling to relatives of murder victims and plans to lobby for legislation to change the criminal justice system. Cuomo, the group's founder and executive director, was Fournier's sister. Fournier, a 17-year-old vocational high school student, was stabbed, stuffed in a trash can and left to die by Horton. The case of Horton, who escaped while on furlough from prison and attacked a Maryland couple, became a highly publicized issue during the 1988 presidential campaign. Then-candidate George Bush used it to criticize Gov. Michael S. Dukakis' record on crime. Joey Fournier Victim Services already offers counseling in Lawrence in the northeastern section of the state, where Fournier grew up, and wants to open centers in other sections of Massachusetts. About 20 to 30 people attended Monday's opening, including Duane and Phyllis Hotchkiss of Saugus, whose 19-year-old son Brian was slain in 1989 in Lynn. ``I'm determined that our son's death is not going to be in vain,'' said Hotchkiss, who donated $100 to the group. The group needs to raise another $100,000, said Cuomo, who would not say how much has been raised. Counseling ordinarily costs about $100 a session, but not everybody can afford it and not all health insurance plans cover it, said Cuomo. Cuomo's voice wavered as she read the names of victims whose families were present. ``One tragic result of violent crime is the lasting effect it has on the victim's family. I know my family will never be the same,'' said Cuomo, who is no relation to New York Gov. Mario Cuomo. In addition to offering counseling, the headquarters will serve as the center for a coalition of victim support groups, including Parents of Murdered Children, the Young Adult Sibling Group and Victims for Victims. The Joey Fournier group has already introduced bills to repeal the state's criminal records law, which shields criminal records from public scrutiny. The organization also has submitted legislation to limit the governor's powers to commute sentences and another measure to require ``truth in sentencing'' so that convicted criminals will actually serve the time of their sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of Daring Sea Rescue in World War II Dead at 92
DOC.TEXT: Cmdr. Bradwell Turner, who led a daring rescue of 299 seamen held prisoner on a German ship in 1940, has died, according to a news report. He was 92. Turner died last Wednesday, an obituary published in Tuesday's edition of the Times of London said. No cause of death was given. With a cry of ``The Navy's here,'' Turner led a boarding party from the destroyer HMS Cossack, which freed the prisoners from the German supply ship Altmark in a Norwegian fjord in February 1940. The Altmark had been an auxiliary vessel of the German battleship Graf Spee. Seamen taken prisoner from merchant marine vessels sunk by the Graf Spee were put aboard the Altmark. The Graf Spee was scuttled just outside Montevideo, Uruguay, in December 1939 after being trapped by three British cruisers. Some of the Graf Spee survivors still reside in neighboring Argentina. After the elimination of the Graf Spee, the Altmark, with its prisoners, hid in the South Atlantic for two months. Then, in February, it was sighted in Norwegian waters. Pursuing British ships were intercepted by two Norwegian torpedo boats, whose commanders said the Altmark had been inspected, carried no arms and had no prisoners on board. Winston Churchill, then First Lord of the Admiralty, ordered the Navy to board the Altmark and release the prisoners. Cossack entered the fjord on the night of Feb. 16. The skipper of the Altmark steered straight at the British ship, apparently intending to ram it, but instead ran his own ship aground. Turner, then a lieutenant commander, led a boarding party carrying pistols and rifles. Four Germans were killed and five were wounded in the encounter. The rescue was an inspirational moment for the British, who had little to show for their six months at war with Germany. Turner received a Distinguished Service Order in 1940 for his part in the action. He received the Order of the British Empire in 1951. He served as a naval attache in Oslo, Norway from 1954 to 1957, and worked for the Marconi electronics company from 1957 to 1972. He is survived by his wife and three daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Milk Marketing Order To Include Carolinas
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT typo, ``do not'' sted ``to not.''
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department is proposing a federal milk marketing order to include North Carolina and South Carolina, officials said Monday. Daniel D. Haley, administrator of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service, said the recommendation was based on hearings held last year. He said order would require the approval of milk producers before it could take effect. Haley said the marketing order _ which would set minimum prices bottlers would have to pay dairy farmers for their milk _ is necessary to ensure an adequate supply of milk for consumers in the two states.
