The primary milk consumption areas include Charlotte, Greensboro, Winston-Salem, Raleigh, Durham, Asheville and Fayetteville in North Carolina, and Columbia, Charleston and Greenville in South Carolina. Haley said the federal marketing order would resolve milk supply problems in these states. North Carolina regulates its milk production under a state marketing order, and South Carolina has no milk marketing regulations, he said. A federal order will match supply and demand for the entire area, with special circumstances spelled out to deal with the uses of milk in over-supply, and to encourage delivery of milk to bottling plants in under-supply, Haley said. Federal milk marketing orders do not set retail prices paid by consumers for milk, he said. However, the orders do affect consumers by assuring a balance between supply and demand for milk _ and by setting minimum prices that bottlers much pay farmers. Public comments on the proposal can be sent by April 27 to: Hearing Clerk, Room 1083-S, USDA, Washington, D.C. 20250.

DOC.HEAD: Isolated Country Opens Direct Telephone Links With the West
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 4 `the operator' to make it vice versa, sted visa versa. Picks up 5th `But attempts...'
DOC.TEXT: Albania has opened direct telephone service with the West, lifting some of the restrictions that have made it one of the world's most isolated countries. An employee of the Albanian Telegraph Agency in Tirana, Albania's capital, said direct telephone service between Albania and some Western countries began March 20. The operator was reached by direct-dial call from Rome on Monday. The employee, who did not give his name, said 56 countries have direct-dial links with Albania, including the United States, Canada, Britain and France. The operator said it was possible to call Albania directly from France, Canada and Britain and vice versa. The operator said Albanians may call the United States. When asked if calls could be placed to Albania from the United States, the operator said, ``I think so.'' But attempts to do so Monday were unsuccessful, and Rich Wallerstein of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said the service was not yet in place. ``Beginning this past weekend it became possible for Albanians to direct dial into the United States, but we do not, as yet, have service from the United States to Albania,'' he said. Wallerstein said the Albanian Telegraph Agency and AT&T had been discussing establishing service for some time. ``The way it came to our attention was Albanians were phoning relatives in the United States, and people in the United States tried to phone back and couldn't get through,'' he said. Albania, a country of 3.2 million people, is Europe's last bastion of Stalinist isolation. It has pursued orthodox Marxist-Leninist policies since the Communists took over in 1944. But there have been increased signs of openings to the West under President Ramiz Alia, who took over after the death of Enver Hoxha in 1985. Some Western journalists have been allowed into Albania in recent months. They reported seeing apartment houses with homemade antennas to receive TV broadcasts from Italy, Greece and Yugoslavia. Alitalia, Italy's flag airline, started a weekly flight to Albania last year. Olympic Airways, the Greek airline, also flies to Albania. The Italian government signed a wide-ranging economic cooperation agreement with Albania last year that will also involve the country in regional efforts to clean up the Adriatic Sea. Before Americans can call Albania, financial and technical hurdles must be cleared, Wallerstein said. U.S. telephone companies must get paid a share for the calls placed to and from Albania, and a direct-dial system must be established. Albania currently places calls to Western countries though relays in either Greece or Italy, Wallerstein said.

DOC.HEAD: 131-Year Prison Term for Sexual Mutilation of Boy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents, especially 9th graf, `The boy ...'
DOC.TEXT: A judge imposed a 131{-year prison sentence on a man convicted of raping, sexually mutiliating and trying to kill a 7-year-old boy, a crime that triggered a statewide uproar over sex predators. Pierce County Superior Court Judge Thomas R. Sauriol gave Earl Shriner, 40, three times the maximum standard term for the crime under state law. The judge said Shriner, who has a 25-year record of violence against young people, should remain locked up until he dies. He said that if Shriner won time off for good behavior, he would still have to serve more than 88 years. There is no possibility of parole. Sauriol said the case left him more outraged and troubled than any in his 37-year legal career. ``I don't think that I have ever heard of a case that borders on extreme cruelty more than this one,'' he told Shriner. ``The reality is, Mr. Shriner, you present a danger to the defenseless.'' Shriner, who is slightly retarded, stood silent and motionless, leaning forward slightly at the bar. The victim's mother, Helen Harlow, dabbing her eyes and comforted by friends, said she was satisfied with the sentence. Shriner was convicted Feb. 7 of first-degree attempted murder, first-degree assault and two counts of first-degree rape in the May 20 attack in woods near his and the boy's homes. The boy was raped and choked, and his penis was cut off. Neighbors found the youngster naked, bloody, covered with mud and practically incoherent. Following sentencing, defense attorney Dino Sepe gave notice he would appeal the penalty and the verdict. Defense attorneys said Shriner's sentence should have been within the standard range of 34 years to 43 years and 10 months. Sauriol gave Shriner half the sentence prosecutors requested, but deputy prosecutor Barbara Corey-Boulet said the penalty ``served the purpose.'' The judge also ordered Shriner to pay $2,500 toward the cost of his court-appointed attorneys and $1,500 to a Pierce County project to help child abuse victims. The uproar that followed the attack led to legislative adoption of tougher penalties and controls on sexual predators, including longer sentences, civil commitment and registration of sex offenders. Harlow served on the goveror's task force that drafted the law. In sentencing Shriner, Sauriol criticized other legislation that would have permitted a 75 percent reduction in prison terms for sex offenders who voluntarily submit to surgical castration. The measure died in the state House of Representatives after clearing the Senate this year. The judge said any legislator who votes for such a measure in the future ``would be defeated the following time he runs for office, and he would deserve it.'' Harlow, her voice breaking and fighting back tears, told the judge the attack had shattered her and her son's lives and had continued to cause pain as the case came up repeatedly in news reports. She said her son continues with his recovery, which includes reconstructive surgery. The boy, who identified Shriner in court as his attacker, was not present. Shriner did not speak on his behalf, but his brother, John, and mother, Dolores, said his guilt had not been established and that mitigating or extenuating circumstances had been disregarded. Shriner was declared a ``defective delinquent'' in 1965 after choking a 7-year-old girl. The term, now abandoned, referred to violence-prone juveniles with emotional or mental problems. He subsequently was confined at Rainier School for the retarded; Western State Hospital, a mental institution, and the Washington Corrections Center, where he served 10 years for assaulting two 16-year-old hitchhikers.

DOC.HEAD: City's Deadliest Fires Had More In Common Than Date
With AM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 87 people who died in a social club fire were martyrs to the quest for a better life, just like 146 people killed exactly 79 years earlier in a fire in a city garment factory, Mayor David Dinkins said Monday. Dinkins told about 700 people at a memorial service for victims of the 1911 fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist Co. that both tragedies killed immigrants looking for improved living conditions in America. ``With vicious irony yesterday, on the 79th anniversary of the Triangle Shirtwaist fire, history repeated itself,'' the mayor said at the site of the earlier blaze. On Sunday, the bodies of trapped revelers were found packed into the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx. A Cuban immigrant was charged with setting fire to the club's only exit after he was thrown out. Authorities said the club's patrons never had a chance to escape the blaze because the building did not follow fire codes. It was the same lack of concern for people that caused such devastation at the Triangle factory in Greenwich Village, Dinkins said. ``So the lessons of the Triangle Shirtwaist fire are not something we commemorate today, they are lessons that have been driven home for us all to learn, once again,'' Dinkins said. ``Now, the martyrs of March 25, 1911, and the martyrs of March 25, 1990, are joined forever,'' he said. ``Like the victims at the Happy Land Social Club, most of those who died on this killing ground were immigrants to our shores.'' ``They, too, came to America to find a dream. Instead, they found misery, exploitation and an agonizing death,'' he said. ``These 146 workers didn't have to die. Neither did the 87 people in the Bronx.'' Later, a fire truck ladder was raised up to the 10-story building's sixth floor, the highest a fire ladder would go in those days, as a fire bell was rung to mark the deaths. A wreath of white roses was placed above pictures of the fire. ``They died at this building because they were seen as surplus labor. They died because they didn't speak English very well, because they weren't organized, because no one spoke up for them or represented their interests and because their employer didn't care about them,'' Dinkins said. ``In fact, that very day in 1911, their boss went out late in the afternoon and locked all the workers of the Triangle Shirtwaist Co. inside, just to make sure none of them tried to leave early while he did some shopping,'' he said. ``All 146 of them died painfully, horribly, just like the 87 who died yesterday,'' the mayor added. ``And all of them died unnecessarily, just like the 87 who died yesterday.'' He recalled, though, that the workers' deaths inspired the labor movement and brought about lasting changes in laws to protect workers. Sweatshops have re-emerged in recent years and it is necessary again to battle exploitation, Dinkins said. ``And again, there are those operating in the shadows, running sweatshops and illegal social clubs and pursuing other schemes, turning the lure and promise of America into a nightmare for those who seek to redeem the promise,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Anatoly Karpov Tops Timman 6{-2{, to Face Kasparov
DOC.TEXT: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union defeated Jan Timman of The Netherlands on Monday in the ninth game of the world chess playoffs to win 6{-2{ and earn the right to face world chess champion Garri Kasparov. Karpov, 38, who won in 56 moves after six hours of play, will challenge Kasparov in Lyons, France, in October. The Karpov-Kasparov duel renews one of the hottest rivalries in chess history. Kasparov, the 26-year-old Soviet champion, is the highest-ranked player in history, according to the biannual ranking list of the International Chess Federation. In 1986, he defeated archrival Karpov in their second title duel and became, at 22, the youngest titleholder in history. Impatient, outspoken and decisive, Kasparov publicly criticized Soviet sports officials a year before Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed greater openness. Kasparov has a British manager to look after his business interests, appears live on Western talk shows and has been interviewed by Playboy magazine. Karpov held the world title for 10 years before first defending it against Kasparov in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Leader Says Labor Party Ignores Religious Teachings
DOC.TEXT: A spiritual leader of two religious parties Monday appeared to hurt the Labor Party's chances of forming a coalition government by saying Labor had failed to keep Israel on the path of Judaism. Labor leaders had hoped Rabbi Eliezar Menachem Schach, the spiritual mentor of the ultra-Orthodox Degel Hatorah and Shas parties, would in his televised speech break a deadlock in efforts by the left-leaning Labor Party to form a government. But his speech at a meeting of Degel Hatorah members was largely a sermon on Israel's failures to stay on what he called the true path of the Bible. ``The Labor Party was the one who detached the Jew from tradition,'' Schach, 92, said. ``But all of the others have also forgotten about their fathers. We should not be drawn after bodies that have no link to Judaism.'' About 10,000 men dressed in the traditional black garb of the ultra-Orthodox packed a basketball stadium in Tel Aviv to hear the Lithuanian-born rabbi speak. Women were barred from the event but were able to follow on closed-circut broadcasts in the B'nei Brak religious suburb of Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. Peres, who claims to have the support of 60 of the 120 members of parliament, needs the backing of one of the religious parties to rule. The Degel Hatorah party has two seats and the Shas party six. Before Schach spoke, the crowd sang hymns and swayed in religous prayer. When he entered the stadium the crowd sang out: ``May God add days to the life of the king.'' Schach criticized Israel for holding onto the occupied territories. ``Territory doesn't guarantee existence,'' he said. Schach, known for his dovish views, said he believed the left has historically distanced itself from Judaism. This paradoxically gives a boost to the right-wing Likud bloc led by caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, whose party's founding principles included keeping the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Degel Hatorah legislator Avraham Ravitz echoed Schach's criticism of Labor and said he believed the spiritual leader backs Likud. ``We have to identify ourselves with those who identify more with us. That means that for now we will probably support the Likud and push them to support a national unity government,'' Ravitz told reporters. A Shas spiritual leader, Rabbi Ovaida Yosef, also spoke at the Degel Hatorah meeting in a show of solidarity. ``Both our movements take the advice of Rabbi Schach. Our two movements go hand in hand, God forbid if there should ever be conflict between us,'' he said. The comments by the religious leaders made the situation bleak for Labor, but Moshe Shahal, a Labor parliament member, told Israel television there was still room for political maneuvering. President Chaim Herzog gave Peres the task of forming a new coalition government on March 20 after Labor brought down the Likud-led government with a no-confidence motion in parliament over Shamir's refusal to accept U.S. Mideast peace proposals. Peres has 42 days left to form a government. Shamir Monday repeated his belief that the Labor leader would fail and said he would assemble a government when Peres' time runs out. Labor negotiators have been involved in a horsetrading with left-wing parties and religious parties and Monday reached an agreement with the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel party to join a Labor-led coaltion, Israel radio said. Agudat Israel, with five seats in parliament, still must receive the approval of its council of Torah sages before it can sign the agreement, the radio said. Agugat Israel legislator Moshe Feldman said the council could decide to make approval conditional on another religious party joining a Labor-led government.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Not Threatened So Far: Fitzwater
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 13-15: ``In an,'' reported reaction of Lithuanian president to Gorbachev comment
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Monday opposed Soviet military occupation of three buildings in the capital of Lithuania but said Moscow's actions so far don't threaten June's U.S.-Soviet summit. The occupation of Communist Party buildings in Vilnius is ``a kind of force and we're opposed to any kind of use of force,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater.

He said that tensions in the secessionist republic ``seem to have escalated on a daily basis . ... Building occupation is a significant event in this sense.'' Nonetheless, Fitzwater said, ``The Soviets themselves have publicly and privately assured us that they have no intentions of using military force to resolve the issue.'' Addressing the summit planned in June between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Fitzwater said: ``We're prepared to have the summit at (that) time. We're still hopeful this can be resolved.'' On the subject of recent Soviet no-force assurances, Fitzwater said that Moscow's promises were reiterated on Friday during a State Department meeting between Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger and Soviet Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin. Dubinin earlier in the week had offered similar assurances to National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, the White House said. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Secretary of State James A. Baker III sent a private message to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze over the weekend regarding the situation in Lithuania. Tutwiler said a meeting on tap next week between Baker and Shevardnadze was still planned. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat visiting the Soviet Union, said Monday that Gorbachev had told him there are no plans to use force to bring Lithuania back into the Soviet fold. After meeting with Gorbachev for 1{ hours, Kennedy said the Soviet leader ``indicated to me that the position of the Soviet Union was that there would be no use of force unless the lives of others were threatened, and that he was committed to a peaceful resolution.'' In an interview with National Public Radio, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said the situation had become ``very dangerous'' in the light of Gorbachev's reported remarks to Kennedy. ``Before he always said that he would not use force in Lithuania, but now we have a situation where he's qualifying that statement and setting a condition under which he could use force. ``The only danger to the lives and health of the residents of Lithuania is the presence of Soviet army troops themselves,'' Landsbergis said. Soviet soldiers took over two schools in Vilnius on Sunday, the Higher Party School and the Institute of Marxism-Leninism. Lithuanian officials said there also were soldiers at the Vilnius Communist Party headquarters. Lithuanian officials on Monday said tensions had eased somewhat after they met with Soviet military officers on the action. Fitzwater said the negotiations between the military and Lithuanian authorities were ``a good sign.'' ``But that's far from resolving the total issue,'' he added. ``We believe it's important to continue to maintain our position and forcefully state our interest in this matter on a continuing basis.'' He said the building occupations were ``under the general framework of the pattern of intimidation that we have objected to in the past.'' ``We object to a pattern of intimidation,'' he added. ``It is incumbent that both sides maintain open communication and not take any actions that can be misinterpreted,'' Fitzwater said, reading a statement at the beginning of Monday's daily news briefing. ``Further actions will not lead to a lessening of the tensions and could have adverse international repercussions and could be counterproductive for U.S.-Soviet relations,'' he said. The Soviet Union considers Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence illegal. The United States has never recognized the Baltic state's incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940. While urging support for the self-determination rights of Lithuanians, the administration has not opened formal diplomatic relations with Vilnius, citing Lithuanian's inability to exercise any real control over its borders or its destiny.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Cleric Sees `Elements of Solution' with Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The nation's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric believes ``elements of a solution'' exist in the dispute over Western hostages in Lebanon, a newspaper reported Monday. Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual guide for the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, said there was no truth to reports he was asked to help resolve the hostage crisis. Most of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon are believed held by groups linked to Hezbollah, or Party of God. ``There are positive elements, within the context of what we detect through media reports in more than one place, that suggest elements of a solution exist in the hostage crisis,'' Fadlallah said in an interview with the pro-Syrian Ash-Sharq newspaper. Asked whether he was contacted about the hostages by Jimmy Carter during the former U.S. president's recent Middle East peace mission, Fadlallah said: ``There is no connection at all ... because I am not involved directly or indirectly in the core of the problem.'' ``But I always try to raise responsible words, with which I address those concerned with this issue, in order that this case be closed once and for all,'' he said. Fadlallah traveled to Damascus during Carter's visit to the Syrian capital earlier this month, but diplomatic sources said the two did not meet. Fadlallah's remarks came four days after his press office quoted the cleric as saying in a radio interview when asked about the possibility of a hostage release: ``A new situation has emerged, but I don't know when, how or where.'' The statement did not elaborate. Fadlallah's remarks heightened speculation there was movement in efforts to secure the release of the eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian held hostage. Longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Several other captives have been held almost as long. Repeated statements from Iranian and Lebanese officials as well as recent editorials in Tehran newspapers have fueled speculation a release was near. In an editorial Sunday, the English-language Tehran Times said ``Iran will of course use its good offices with the Lebanese groups ... to facilitate the release of Western hostages.'' The Tehran Times, which often reflects the thinking of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, sparked speculation about a possible release when it said last month ``1990 can and will be the last year of captivity for these hostages.'' Moderates led by Rafsanjani have said the issue is moving toward a solution, but his hard-line opponents contradict that. Iran's former hard-line interior minister, Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, argued against the hostages' release in a signed editorial in a Tehran newspaper this month. Mohtashemi helped found Hezbollah in 1983 and is believed to have more clout with the kidnappers than Rafsanjani.

DOC.HEAD: Spurned Boyfriend Charged in 87 Fire Deaths
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to reflect that suspect was charged with two murder counts in each death; SUBS 7th graf, `He was...,' to UPDATE with Gonzalez transferred to psychiatric ward; SUBS 25th graf, `Johnson said...,' to restore dropped word `no'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of setting fire to the Happy Land social club was arraigned Monday on charges of murdering 87 people, and police said he told them ``the devil got into me.'' Authorities began shutting other illegal clubs in response to New York City's worst fire in 79 years. The families of the 87 victims, most of whom were Honduran or Dominican immigrants, sought solace in their grief, and a government task force was set up to counsel them and help make funeral arrangements. Julio Gonzalez, 36, was accused of setting the fire early Sunday with $1 worth of gasoline after arguing with a former girlfriend who worked at the illegal club. He is said to have threatened to ``shut this place down.'' ``I got angry, the devil got into me, and I set the place on fire,'' Gonzalez told authorities, according to a police source who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. During a hearing at Bronx County Criminal Court, Gonzalez was charged with 87 counts of murder committed during the course of arson; 87 counts of murder by depraved indifference to human life; one count of attempted murder; and two counts of arson. The case was turned over to a grand jury, and Gonzalez will not be asked to enter a plea unless an indictment is issued. He was held under a suicide watch at the Rikers Island jail and later admitted to Kings County Hospital Psychiatric Ward, where he will be held indefinitely, said Ruby Ryles, a city jails spokeswoman. The deaths were believed to be the most ever charged to a single suspect in the continental United States. ``He is a double animal,'' said Rene J. Mena, 63, whose son, Rene Jr., 30, died. ``Here, they're going to have good food for him, a book, a movie. In Central America, we don't do it that way.'' District Attorney Robert T. Johnson said he hoped that if Gonzalez is convicted, he would get consecutive prison sentences amounting to 2,000 years. An equally angry Mayor David Dinkins ordered a sweep of other suspected unlicensed social clubs. Police and a special task force visited 241 clubs citywide from midnight to 7 a.m. Monday and posted vacate orders on 187. Only 23 of the clubs were open _ most are closed on Sunday nights. There were 52 safety violations and 30 summonses issued, said Sgt. Dick Vreeland, a police spokesman. In the East Tremont section of the Bronx, families drifted in and out of Public School 67, across from the fire-blackened club. A task force of state, city and private agencies there helped them make funeral arrangements and offered counseling and financial assistance. ``It's orderly, but it's not emotionally orderly,'' said Ken Curtin, a local Red Cross disaster relief director. ``It's highly charged. There are a lot of outbursts of grief.'' In Honduras, a foreign ministry spokesman said the government ``is deeply moved by the deaths of many countrymen in New York.'' The Honduran telephone company said it was swamped with calls from people seeking word about loved ones. The fire broke out at 3:40 a.m. Sunday, and those inside the club suffocated, burned or were trampled to death in a matter of minutes. They had to ``choose between a wall of fire or retreating and dying of asphyxiation,'' Johnson said. Police believe five people escaped from the fire: three patrons; Gonzalez's former girlfriend, Lydia Feliciano; and the club disc jockey. The disc jockey, identified in published reports as Ruben Valladares, was listed as stable at Jacobi Hospital with burns over 30 percent of his body, said hospital spokeswoman Vicki Ciampa. Ms. Feliciano and the others, whose names were withheld, escaped serious injury. Ms. Feliciano is in protective custody. Johnson said Gonzalez had been ejected from the club after arguing with Ms. Feliciano and threatening to ``shut this place down.'' He allegedly bought $1 worth of gasoline at a nearby service station, then returned and faked making a telephone call when he saw a possible witness. When that person left, he allegedly poured gasoline between the street and an inside door of the club and ignited it. After that, Johnson said, he watched it burn for a while, making statements to at least two witnesses about his role in the fire. He then went home, where police found him a few hours later. He made a videotaped admission to police, authorities said. Johnson said Gonzalez knew the two-story club lacked windows, rear exits and adequate staircases. He also knew how crowded it was, authorities said. Gonzalez, who came to the United States from Cuba on the 1980 Mariel boatlift, had no arrest record here, Johnson said. Johnson said he has the name of a possible club owner, but will not release it until it's confirmed. A vacate order was issued in November 1988 and again a year later because Happy Land lacked a proper sprinkler system, exits, emergency lighting and signs. It also had no liquor or cabaret license, the mayor said. The fire struck on the 79th anniversary of the Triangle Shirtwaist Co. fire. That 1911 tragedy claimed 146 lives, many of them immigrant garment workers, leading to nationwide reforms in workplace safety. Dinkins discussed night club tragedy while addressing 700 garment workers and other union members who gathered Monday in Lower Manhattan to commemorate the Triangle fire. ``They came to America in search of a better life. Early yesterday morning their American dream became a fatal nightmare,'' said Dinkins, who inspected the scene of Sunday's fire. ``The sight of those bodies, lined along the walls like so many wax figures, and the realization of the panic and the pain they must have suffered in their last moments, will remain with me for the rest of my life,'' said Dinkins. ``Most horrifying is that this should never have happened.'' Roman Catholic Cardinal John J. O'Connor officiated at an hour-long, English and Spanish prayer service outside the club on Monday afternoon. A thousand mourners began the service by walking a few blocks from St. Thomas Aquinas church, the parish of many of the victims. ``We pray for those who died,'' said O'Connor. ``We pray in a special way for those who survived. We need to pray for the dead and for the survivors. ... Our best is never good enough in circumstances of this sort.''

DOC.HEAD: 25 Atoll Residents on Trial for Religious Murders
DOC.TEXT: A court Monday began trying 25 residents of a South Pacific atoll who are accused of torturing to death six islanders in a hunt for demons and sorcerers. Testimony in the trial, described as the largest ever in French Polynesia, is expected to focus on how a small number of people could terrorize a larger group in the name of religion. Archbishop Michel Coppenrath, the Roman Catholic leader in French Polynesia, said the case involves ``simply a religious perversion due to an abuse of trust and a lack of authority on the island.'' The defendants, representing about an eighth of the population of the South Pacific atoll of Faaite, are accused of murder, inciting violence and other offenses during two horror-filled days in 1987. According to investigators, three women came to the atoll in August 1987 from Tahiti, 310 miles to the west. The trio claimed to be faith-healers connected to the Roman Catholic-affiliated movement Charismatic Renewal, founded in the United States in 1967 and active throughout much of Polynesia. However, Coppenrath, who spent 15 days on Faaite counseling families after the killings, said the women were not authentic representatives of Charismatic Renewal. The women were regarded as priestesses by the islanders and gained enormous influence, investigators said. Faaite's mayor was away, and there were no police or religious authorities posted there. At one point, the women ordered a crippled man to get up and walk. When he failed, they said demons were interfering with their work, investigators said. The women instructed the islanders to repent of their sins and departed within a few weeks. However, they left behind a dozen youthful disciples who divined on Sept. 2 that the assistant mayor, Iaone Harris, was possessed by demons. The disciples held hallucinatory seances in the tiny church and repeatedly dunked the official in sea water to ``purify'' him, investigators say. They say he died, allegedly after severe beatings, and the disciples burned his body at the church. His death set off a two-day hunt for sorcerers conducted by half the islanders against the others, investigators said. Three more men and two women were burned alive, included a mentally disturbed man and a mother who pleaded for the life of her son. Ten children of the atoll were orphaned by the violence. Four more executions planned for Sept. 4 were thwarted when frightened islanders established telephone contact with officials in Papeete, the French Polynesia capital. The mayor, a priest and a police unit arrived and suppressed the witch hunt. Many of the suspects interrogated by police professed to be upholding the Christian faith. The proceeding before the Tribunal in Papeete will feature 15 islanders testifying against 25 neighbors. The jury is expected to have a verdict after two weeks' testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Swedes Propose Strict Tobacco Law: $5 a Pack
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette prices would rise to $5 a pack, tobacco advertising would be banned and minors would be barred from buying cigarettes under a proposal submitted to the government Monday. Everyone should have the right to a smoke-free environment, said an accompanying report, the first government study on smoking since 1973. Its recommendations would give Sweden, along with Norway and Finland, one of the world's toughest anti-smoking laws. The Swedish tobacco industry said it would suffer from an advertising ban and lose out to foreign brands. ``A bunch of well-paid tobacco-hating bureaucrats spent a year on nice trips and came up with nothing sensible,'' Klaus Unger, chairman of Swedish Tobacco Co., was quoted as saying by the Expressen newspaper. Smokepeace, a lobby against laws that would further limit smokers' rights, said the recommendations would give ``hard-pressed supermarket cashiers the duties of policemen.'' Some of the proposals, already adopted by other countries, proved ineffective in stopping youngsters from smoking, the lobby said. The report, submitted to Social Affairs Minister Ingela Thalen, is the first stage of the legislative process that could take several months. It must be submitted for comment to various interested parties, including the tobacco industry, and may undergo major revisions before it becomes law. The report recommended a 15-milligram limit on tar in cigarettes. That would effectively ban 36 popular brands now on sale in Sweden, including 26 imported brands. Finland already has a similar ban, and the report said the European Community will adopt the limit in 1993. Roland Perlstrom, speaking for the industry, said the proposal was unnecessary because smokers are switching to low-tar cigarettes, which already have 60 percent of the market. Under the proposal, cigarette prices would rise 50 percent to $5. Hotels would be required to forbid smoking in half their rooms, and restaurants with more than 50 seats would have to have non-smoking areas. At work places, smoking would be allowed in designated areas or in offices only if the smoke did not spread to smoke-free zones. ``After what we know about the damaging effects of tobacco, the use of tobacco cannot be regarded and treated as a harmless habit or a private matter any more,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Shark Attacks Grandson of Rockefeller off Fiji, Injures Leg
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS two grafs background on Michael Rockefeller's disappearance off Irian Jaya.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FIJI-1
DOC.TEXT: A 30-year-old grandson of James S. Rockefeller left Fiji Monday night, apparently after being bitten on a leg by a shark while swimming at an exclusive island resort. The Fiji Times newspaper said Ola Stillman Rockefeller was injured on Saturday soon after he arrived at Laucala Island, about 120 miles northeast of Fiji's capital, Suva. The isolated resort is owned by the estate of the late American billionaire Malcolm Forbes. Rockefeller, a bachelor, told the newspaper he had been swimming alone in waist-deep water about 30 yards offshore when he felt his right leg being ``pulled.'' Looking down, he said he saw it had been lacerated, apparently by two bites from a shark. He said he managed to swim to shore and crawl to his bungalow where he telephoned for help. Resort workers applied first-aid before a nurse from a village health clinic could assist. A doctor from a nearby hospital was brought in by boat several hours later. On arrival, Dr. Viliame Taoi said he found Rockefeller in stable condition, but he ``appeared to have lost some blood.'' His Achilles tendon had been lacerated and required stiches. At dawn Sunday, Rockefeller was flown by the Forbes' private plane to a hospital in Lautoka, Fiji's second-largest city. He left Fiji on an overnight flight to the United States accompanied by a medical team from Australia and with his right ankle in a plaster cast. ``I have not been discouraged by the experience,'' he was quoted as telling The Fiji Times newspaper before departing. Rockefeller is the grandson of James S. Rockefeller, who was a chairman of the City Bank of New York, which became Citibank. Michael Rockefeller, son of then-New York Gov. Nelson D. Rockfeller, vanished in November 1961, off Irian Jaya, an Indonesian territory that shares its island border with Papua New Guinea. Michael, then 23, disappeared while swimming from his capsized catamaran in shark-infested waters. The island of Irian Jaya and Papua New Guinea is about 1,000 miles west of Fiji.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Dine Out At Favorite Chinese Restaurant With McClure, Hatfield
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife Barbara returned to one of their favorite spots, the Peking Gourmet Inn, for dinner Monday night. Attorney Gen. Dick Thornburgh and Sens. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., and James McClure, R-Idaho, and their wives joined the Bushes on the outing to the Chinese restaurant in this suburb 10 miles outside the capital. The Bushes frequented the restaurant before he became president, and have returned about a half-dozen times in the past 15 months.

DOC.HEAD: Greece Upset With Turkey in Border Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Greece on Monday protested to Turkey over a dam project and a reported shooting incident during a week of escalating border tension between the two Aegean neighbors. In the latest incident Monday, crews from four Greek trawlers claimed a Turkish patrol boat opened fire on them in Greek territorial waters northeast of the Aegean island of Lesvos. A spokesman for the island's harbor authorities reported no injuries. Ambassador Dimitris Makris protested to a Foreign Ministry official in Ankara, Turkey, that Turkish soldiers fired warning shots Sunday at a Greek fisherman at Doiran, an island shared by the two countries on the northern Evros River border. No injuries were reported there either. In the second protest, Makris asked Turkey to dismantle a small sandbag dam that local authorities set up March 18 linking Doiran to mainland Turkey. Government spokesman Prokopis Pavlopoulos, who announced the protests, said Makris repeated a proposal by Greek local authorities that an existing Greek-Turkish committee meet to resolve the problem of the dam. The spokesman said earlier that Turkey used the dam to make the island look as if it were an extension of the Turkish mainland.

DOC.HEAD: Witness: List Announced Murder of Family Before Disappearing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with witness saying List told family he planned to kill them, note implying he killed them because he couldn't support them, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: John E. List told his family he planned to kill them before his wife, mother and three children were slain at their mansion and he disappeared for 18 years, a witness testified Monday. The hearing on evidence in List's murder trial also saw the first public release of a note in which he implied he killed his family because he couldn't support them and because he knew ``they would all be Christians.'' The witness, drama teacher Edwin Illiano, said List's 16-year-old daughter, Patricia, mentioned the threat as he was driving her home from rehearsal at a municipal drama society in 1971. ``The father had announced to the family that he was going to murder the entire family,'' Illiano testified. He said the girl was sobbing and near hysteria. After the teen-ager began missing rehearsals that November, Illiano began driving by the List home. He said he told List's pastor and former Police Chief James Moran, now retired, of his concern, but was not taken seriously. On Dec. 7, police found the family members' bullet-riddled bodies. That was about a month after Illiano learned of the threat, he said outside court. Defense attorney Elijah L. Miller Jr. has moved to exclude evidence collected from List's 18-room mansion in the New York City suburb of Westfield, arguing the home was entered illegally. Evidence in contention includes a note dated Nov. 9, 1971, and left for List's mother-in-law, Eva Morris, and an insurance associate. ``By now no doubt you know what has happened to Helen and the children. I'm very sorry that it had to happen,'' List, a devout church-going Sunday school teacher and accountant, wrote Mrs. Morris. ``But because of a number of reasons I couldn't see any other solution,'' he said. ``I just couldn't support them anymore and I didn't want them to go into poverty. Also, at this time I know that they would all be Christians. I couldn't be sure of that in the future as the children grow up.'' He signed it, ``with my sincere sympathies, John E. List.'' Superior Court Judge William L'E. Wertheimer is expected to decide on Miller's motions before opening arguments scheduled for Friday. Miller apparently called Illiano as a witness because he contradicted police testimony that officers entered the house first out of concern for the safety of List's 85-year-old mother, Alma. Illiano had goine to the house that night with a fellow drama group member out of concern for Patricia List. ``With one fluid movement I opened the window and entered the house,'' he said. He said he was followed by police. However, in a statement to police Dec. 8, 1971, he said the officers went first. Illiano explained the discrepancy by saying he was anxious ``to get out of there.'' Illiano was preceded by retired Westfield police Detective Robert J. Bell, who led the murder investigation. Bell identified five notes taped to file cabinet and desk drawers addressed to List's insurance agent, the estate's administrator and his Lutheran pastor, Eugene Rehwinkel. Bell also said there were notes written on lined yellow paper that included notes to the children's schools explaining that the family had to leave town. The detective said a .22-caliber pistol and a 9mm automatic were found in a desk drawer. Retired patrolman George Zhelesnick testified earlier that he was sent to the home after neighbors expressed concern about Alma List and a suspicious car in the driveway. The car turned out to be Illiano's. The former policeman said he found an unlocked dining-room window after circling the house. He said he entered the house, followed by his partners and two friends of Patricia List. ``It was at that time I saw what appeared to be four bodies lying on the floor,'' Zhelesnick recalled. He said he radioed for help and went back to search the rest of the home. He and partner Charles Haller found Alma List's body in a third-floor storage room. List was arrested last June in the Richmond, Va., suburb of Midlothian, where he had been living as Robert Clark. He has maintained that he is innocent because of his mental condition at the time of the killings.

DOC.HEAD: Yasser Arafat: Soviet Jews Settling in West Bank are a Threat
DOC.TEXT: Yasser Arafat, chairman of the PLO, said Monday the influx of Soviet Jews to Israel and fears that they would be settled in the West Bank posed a threat to security and stability in the Mideast. The danger of such a policy would undermine international efforts, putting the region ``on the brink of war and destruction,'' the Palestine Liberation Organization leader was quoted as saying by the Press Trust of India at a banquet given in his honor by India President Ramaswamy Venkataraman. Arafat arrived in New Delhi Monday on a three-day visit to accept the Jawaharlal Nehru award for peace and international understanding. Nehru was India's first prime minister. On arrival he said of the Soviet Jews migration plan: ``We will continue to deal with our friends in Moscow for the sake of our people and at the same time with respect for the human rights.'' He told journalists it was too soon to say whether an Israeli government headed by Shimon Peres would affect Middle East peace talks. ``We have to wait and see _ not to spoil the cooking.'' Peres, the Israeli Labor Party leader, is trying to form a government after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir lost a confidence vote in Parliament. Peres has been more open to some sort of dialogue with Palestinians on the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip than Likud Bloc leader Shamir, his erstwhile coalition government partner. The PLO leader, a pistol on his right hip, spoke to reporters after receiving the 21-gun salute India accords foreign heads of state. He was received by Venkataraman and Prime Minister V.P. Singh. India was one of the first non-Arab nations to recognize the PLO's declaration of Palestinian statehood in 1988. Arafat was given similar head-of-state treatment on his last visit a year ago. On Wednesday he is scheduled to fly to Calcutta to visit Mother Teresa, winner of the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize. In 1982, at the height of the Israeli war against the PLO, the Yugoslav-born nun went to West Beirut to rescue mentally retarded children who were trapped in a hospital on the edge of a Palestinian refugee camp near the Israeli front line.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Diplomatic Cars Destroyed in Series of Timed Bombings
DOC.TEXT: Bomb blasts within 10 minutes of each other early Tuesday wrecked the cars of nine foreign diplomats in four Athens suburbs. No injuries were reported in the explosions, police said. Three of the vehicles belonged to diplomats from Czechoslovakia, two from the Soviet Union and one each from the embassies of Syria, Hungary, Bulgaria and the Palestine Liberation Organization's envoy in Athens, a police spokesman said. Initial investigations indicated eight of the cars were destroyed by time bombs, the spokesman said, who requested anonymity in line with practice. The blasts in the suburbs of Ilissia, Halandri, Paleo Psychiko and Ambelokipi began about 2 a.m. and ended 10 minutes later, the spokesman said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the explosions. Similar attacks have been carried out in the past by the November 17 urban guerrilla organisation. The leftist group has killed 14 people, including three American officials. None of its members has ever been caught. Anarchist youths have firebombed police cars and party offices in a spate of attacks the past three weeks, injuring one policeman. Greece's general elections are April 8.

DOC.HEAD: Indicates Lack Of Action By Pilot To Deal With Emergency
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of Avianca Flight 52 was aware that he was low on gas but appeared ``inattentive'' to the problem and seemed to take ``little action'' in communicating it to air controllers, a source told The Associated Press Monday. The flight's co-pilot and flight engineer also took no bold steps to alert the captain or controllers to the fuel emergency, a source close to the investigation said. He spoke on the condition of anonymity. The findings were based on conversations recorded in the cockpit of the Colombian flight during the 30 minutes before it crashed into a hillside in Cove Neck, Long Island, Jan. 25, killing 73 of the 159 aboard. The transcripts, which were to be released Tuesday by the National Transportation Safety Board, indicated that the lack of communication among the cockpit crew contributed to the crash. The Boeing 707 from Bogota and Medellin, Colombia, crashed in fog and rain on final approach just northeast of John F. Kennedy International Airport. Investigators believe the plane crashed because it ran out of fuel. They are not certain why the crew members failed to make it clear to air traffic controllers how urgent their fuel shortage had become. The recorded conversations indicate that the crew, mostly in Spanish, discussed the dwindling fuel supply among themselves. The transcripts appear to show a pilot who did not seem to be in full charge of the situation, the source said, and who did not give specific, essential direction to the co-pilot to declare an emergency. They also showed a co-pilot who had just 2{ years of experience flying into JFK and appeared reluctant to assert himself, the source said. The flight engineer had several years' experience but also seemed to be hesitant to speak up, although he appeared to be subtly trying to remind the pilot of the fuel shortage, the source said. All three crew members died in the crash. After aborting his first approach, the captain, a 17-year veteran pilot, asked the co-pilot if he had told air traffic controllers that they had an ``emergency.'' The co-pilot, who handled most of the communications with controllers, did answered: ``I told them we're low on fuel.'' The captain, according to the transcripts, did not respond to the co-pilot, nor did he follow-up by instructing the co-pilot to tell air traffic control that they had an emergency. After the aborted approach, the crew accepted, without challenge, a new route for a second approach that looped over the Long Island Sound. At that point, investigators have said, the pilot and crew made a deadly mistake. They should have made it clear to controllers that they needed to come straight in for a landing. Even a straight in landing, where the plane would have needed to make a tight loop, would have used six or seven minutes of fuel. From the misapproach to fuel burn-out the plane took a little over eight minutes. The Avianca crash seems to be strikingly similar to the crash of United Airline's DC-8 in Portland, Oregon in December, 1978. Both were due to fuel exhaustion. The NTSB determined that the probable cause of the United Airlines accident was ``the failure of the captain to monitor properly the aircraft's fuel state and to properly respond to the low fuel state,'' according to a NTSB report on the accident. The board found that the United pilot's inattention resulted from preoccupation with a landing gear malfunction. Contributing to the Portland accident, the report stated, ``was the failure of the other two flight crew members either to fully comprehend the criticality of the fuel state or to successfully communicate their concern to the pilot.'' The NTSB investigation of the Avianca accident is said to be focusing on the coordination and communications among the pilot, co-pilot and flight engineer. A report on the probable cause of the Avianca accident is expected in about 10 months. Mike Benson, a spokesman for the NTSB, and Fred Farrar, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, were not in their offices when phoned late Monday afternoon and did not immediately return calls for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Sued by Flight 103 Victim's Family, Estate
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am customers, including a couple whose daughter died in the bombing of Flight 103, sued the airline Monday claiming it collected surcharges for a security system that was never developed. The lawsuit charged that millions of Pan Am passengers between 1986 and 1989 were defrauded by the $5-a-ticket security surcharge on trans-Atlantic flights and an advertising campaign on the development of the security system. ``After enticing the traveling public into purchasing tickets on Pan Am flights and subsidizing a supposedly efficient security system, defendants made conscious decisions not to create that system,'' the lawsuit alleged. The lawsuit filed in Superior Court was intended as a class action for customers who purchased tickets affected by the case, said Richard A. Grossman, the attorney handling the case. The lawsuit also alleges that a private consultant hired by Pan Am in 1986 to review security warned the airline was vulnerable to terrorist attack. The consultant warned that the advertising campaign touting beefed-up flight security could be considered fraudulent unless changes were made, Grossman said. The plaintiffs included Peter and Aphrodite Tsairis of Franklin Lakes, and the estate of their daughter, Alexia Tsairis, a Syracuse University undergraduate killed when Pan Am Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988. The downing of the Boeing 747 killed all 259 passengers and crew and 11 people on the ground. ``Damages could amount to over $100 million, with more than a million passengers in line for refunds plus punitive damages,'' Grossman said. Pan Am said in a statement issued by its legal department that the lawsuit's attempt to recover damages for the death of Ms. Tsairis would be handled like all other such claims. But the company said there was ``absolutely no merit'' to the lawsuit's class-action claims. Company spokeswoman Elizabeth Manners said Pan Am would make a motion to dismiss that aspect of the lawsuit. Ms. Manners said about $18 million was collected in 1989 through the security surcharges, but could not provide amounts for earlier years. The spokeswoman said the airline spent nearly $47 million on security last year. Another plaintiff was T. Jennifer Vail, a 20-year-old law student from Wilmington, Del., with no connection to the crash. Ms. Vail is a Pan Am customer seeking reimbursement of the surcharges and represents others like her, Grossman said. The lawsuit alleges the airline's own security expert, Isaac Yeffet, former head of security for El Al Airlines in Israel, told Pan Am officials almost two years before the Flight 103 crash that the carrier's security was ``almost totally ineffectual.'' Named as defendants were Pan Am Corp., and its subsidiaries, Pan American World Airways Inc. and Pan American World Services Inc. Also named were Alert Management Systems Inc., a Pan Am security subcontractor; C. Edward Acker, a former Pan Am president and chief executive officer of Pan Am, and Martin E. Shugrue Jr., a former vice chairman of the corporation and chief executive officer of Pan Am World Airways, as well as the directors of each company. James Stengel, a New York attorney who has defended aircraft manufacturers in similar litigation, said class actions against airlines are not unusual, but connecting the surcharge with a fraud allegation is a novel approach. Most claims filed against Pan Am by relatives of Flight 103 victims have been wrongful death and personal injury cases, and have been combined into a single case, he said. Pan Am was fined $630,000 for security and other violations discovered by the Federal Aviation Administration following the crash. The company has challenged much of the fine, which is pending, said Ms. Manners.

DOC.HEAD: Expert: 70,000 May Have Died In Stalin-Era Internment Camps
DOC.TEXT: Up to 70,000 prisoners may have died in Soviet internment camps on German soil after World War II, a government official who is an expert on Stalin-era atrocities said Monday. The remark by Gerhard Finn followed reports of the discovery of mass graves containing the bodies of thousands of prisoners from a former Soviet internment camp in East Germany. East Germany's Berliner Zeitung newspaper reported Saturday that some Nazi prisoners of war _ such as SS members, police officers, Nazi party officials and former soldiers in Adolf Hitler's army _ died at the former Fuenfeichen internment camp near Neubrandenburg. But the newspaper said the victims also included ``many innocent people'' and teen-agers. It said the youngest victim was 12 years old. Finn, a department chief in the West German Inter-German Ministry, said Monday he expected that even more mass graves will be found. ``We estimate that from 65,000 to 70,000 people died in the internment camps of the Soviet occupying powers'' after World War II, Finn told Saarlandischer Rundfunk radio in Saarbruecken. Finn is the author of a book on the subject, titled ``Political Prisoners in the Soviet Zone.'' He said it would be impossible to give an exact figure because all death certificates of the camps were destroyed. Finn said that between 1945 and 1950, up to 200,000 people were detained in 13 Soviet army camps in East Germany. Brutality during the Soviet occupation was kept secret in East Germany until last fall's popular uprising swept the hard-line Communist leadership out of power.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Official Recommends Veto of Two Forks Project
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATESthroughout with comment from DeHihnsand Denver Water Department, CORRECTS Wilcher's first name in 7th graf to LaJuana, sted Lujuanna.
DOC.TEXT: An Environmental Protection Agency regional official said Monday he will recommend that Denver's proposed Two Forks dam be vetoed because of the damage it would cause to the environment. The 615-foot-high dam to be built near the confluence of the South Platte River and its North Fork would flood 30 miles of scenic river valley and canyon and the town of Deckers to provide drinking water for up to 360,000 new Denver-area residents. Opponents, including several environmental groups, have called the project the biggest ecological disaster in Colorado history. ``It appears the Godzilla of water projects has met its match,'' said Dan Luecke, director of the Boulder-based Environmental Defense Fund. Lee DeHihns, the EPA deputy regional administrator from Atlanta who reviewed the project, said he would recommend that it be vetoed because its ``adverse impact'' on fishery, wildlife and recreation areas ``would be so significant that these resources would be lost forever.'' The final decision will be made at EPA headquarters in Washington, D.C., but DeHihns has said vetoes are rarely overturned. EPA Administrator William Reilly's designee LuJuana Wilcher, the agency's assistant administrator for water, has 60 days to affirm, deny or modify DeHihns' decision unless an extension is granted. Asked at a news conference if the project is now effectively dead, DeHihns replied, ``Nothing is dead until the fat lady sings, as they say. LuJuana is not fat ... but she will make the final decision.'' DeHihns said in his recommendation he is convinced the project would cause unacceptable environmental damage, including the flooding of a trout stream and the loss of high-quality habitat that is home to deer, elk and bighorn sheep. The EPA says there were several alternatives for providing water to Denver's metropolitan area without causing as much environmental damage. Those include smaller dams, water exchanges, conservation measures and increased use of groundwater. Bill Miller, manager of the Denver Water Department, described DeHihns' recommendation as ``no surprise'' and said water officials planned to ``seek consultation at the Washington level with the decision-maker back there.'' The dam, estimated to cost between $500 million and $1 billion, was proposed by the Denver Water Board and about 42 metropolitan water suppliers as the solution to the area's future water needs. Last March, Reilly announced his intention to veto the project and appointed DeHihns to oversee the final review of the project and to make a final recommendation on its fate. Sen. Bob Kerry, D-Neb., said DeHihns' decision ``means we will have to conserve as well as develop in the future.'' ``With the EPA's decision to continue the veto process, Two Forks is about to return to the obscurity it so richly deserves,'' said Luecke.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Register for State-Sponsored Parties
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Nigerians signed up Monday to become members of two political parties created by the military government to return Africa's most populous nation to civilian rule. Popular response during the 40-day party registration that began Monday will show the feelings of Nigerians. Many were shocked when President Ibrahim Babangida in October rejected nominations from 13 groups seeking to register as political parties. Instead, the general's government itself created two political parties, the center-right National Republican Convention and left-leaning Social Democratic Party. The government is also writing their platforms. Babangida said all 13 rejected organizations were tainted by the corruption and ethnic and religious factionalism that he blames for the failure of previous civilian governments. Soldiers have governed Nigeria by force for all but nine years of the West African nation's 29 years of independence from Britain. Babangida's 6-year-old government has promised to return the nation to civilian rule through elections by 1992. Government critics say people are uninterested in voting for parties created by the military. The government countered those charges Monday by publishing results of a survey saying Nigerians are enthusiastic about their evolving political system and keen to register as party members. Thousands lined up to register Monday, but no exact figures were available immediately. All former politicians and leading government members are banned from seeking office in this country of 115 million. But Information Minister Tony Momoh said Monday that some are plotting to ensure their hold on power, for example through surrogates on their payroll. Newspapers have been filled with advertisements from politicians announcing which party they support.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Denies Making Remark Quoted by Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Monday denied a claim by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that he recently said he does not recognize Poland's western border. Thatcher's contention, made in an interview with the Hamburg magazine Der Spiegel, apparently has created tension in relations between the two NATO allies just days before their summit in Cambridge, England. The latest edition of Der Spiegel quoted Mrs. Thatcher as saying: ``I have heard Helmut say: `No, I won't guarantee anything, I don't recognize the current borders.''' Mrs. Thatcher said Kohl made the remark at a recent meeting of European Economic Community leaders in Strasbourg. But Kohl's spokesman, Hans Klein, said Mrs. Thatcher's interpretation of the chancellor's remarks ``is correct neither literally nor in a general way.'' Klein did not disclose what Kohl actually said, but pointed out that the chancellor in ``countless statements'' has said Germans have no designs on lands ceded to Poland after the Third Reich's defeat in 1945. It wasn't the first time Kohl has come under fire for his statements about Poland's western border. Last month, he angered Poland and raised concerns around the world by declining to give assurances that a united Germany would not lay claim to any Polish territory. Kohl, under pressure from arch-conservative voters with federal elections coming up in December, said at the time that only the government of a united Germany could address that issue. He has since reversed himself, however. On March 1, Parliament passed a resolution proposed by Kohl's party saying a united Germany must sign a border treaty with Warsaw. Poland, however, contends that is still not an ironclad guarantee of its western border. Mrs. Thatcher has been among those who have openly voiced concern about German unification. In the Der Spiegel interview, she was quoted as saying: ``We just have to get used to the idea that there will be a country in Europe in the future that will be more powerful than all the others.'' Despite the public tiff between Kohl and Thatcher, Klein said plans have not been changed for their Friday meeting in Cambridge.

DOC.HEAD: Four Tories Rebel Against Thatcher's Party, 35 Abstain
DOC.TEXT: The government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in trouble with voters over an unpopular new tax, ran into new problems early Tuesday when four Tories defected on a vote over subsidies to cushion the levy. An estimated 35 other Conservatives abstained. The House of Commons vote followed a late-night debate on the subsidies. The motion drawn up by the socialist opposition Labor Party was defeated by 305 votes to 233. It was the second revolt by Tory rebels in two weeks. On March 13, 33 Conservatives voted with Labor on an opposition motion _ later defeated on a second vote _ that called for more government help for people in retirement homes. The motion Tuesday called for rejection of government plans to spend $1.3 billion over the next three years to help 7{ million low-income people pay the new tax. Labor legislators said the subsidies are too low. They said they are based on what Mrs. Thatcher's government considers local authorities should charge under the new tax, not what they are actually charging. Critics say the new tax is unfair because it takes no account of people's ability to pay. Recent opinion polls show the Conservatives trailing Labor by up to 28 percentage points, with the next general election due by mid-1992. Voters say the new tax is their main complaint with the Conservatives.

DOC.HEAD: Pipe Bombs Explode at University Campus
DOC.TEXT: Two pipe bombs exploded early Monday at the University of Alaska at Fairbanks and three others were detonated by a military bomb squad in what the campus security director called a ``a dangerous prank.'' No one was injured and no major damages reported, police said. ``The pipe bombs were fairly powerful,'' said Director of Campus Security Dale Florian. ``They were certainly dangerous.'' The bombs exploded at 4 a.m. and sent a metal end cap rocketing about 150 feet through a window of the Fine Arts Building about 40 feet above the ground, Florian said. Other shrapnel was found several hundred feet away, he said. The bombs went off at an ice arch in front of Rasmuson Library where they had been placed in holes in the arch, Florian said. ``There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that it was a prank that went awry,'' he said. Officials said the ice structure, built by members of the student chapter of the American Society of Civil Engineers, each year becomes the target of saboteurs who try to destroy or damage it. But Kevin Curtis, an engineering professor, called Monday's act ``a foolish extreme.'' Florian said his office had received some leads in the case but had no firm suspects. In addition to the two exploded bombs, three undetonated bombs were found by campus security officers. A bomb squad from Eielson Air Force Base was called in to blow up the devices, Florian said. He described them as metal pipes filled with gunpowder set with fuses. The Explosive Ordnance Disposal Team from Eielson blew up the bombs about 9 a.m., after campus police and Alaska State Troopers evacuated about 200 people from the library and three other buildings in the center of campus, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Supporting Actor Award Caps Journey from TV to Big Screen
DOC.TEXT: Denzel Washington completed his journey from television to the movie screen with a best supporting actor Oscar for his role as a soldier in a black regiment in the Civil War story ``Glory.'' Washington becomes the fourth black performer to win an Oscar for best actor or supporting actor. Washington was an Oscar nominee once before, as supporting actor for his role as Steven Biko in Richard Attenborough's 1987 movie ``Cry Freedom,'' but he was most widely known for his role on the TV series ``St. Elsewhere.'' ``My son said he was going to make one of these out of clay for me, now I've got the model for him,'' Washington said in accepting his Academy Award at the Music Center Monday night. Previous black winners were Hattie McDaniel for ``Gone With the Wind,'' in 1939 and Louis Gossett Jr. for ``An Officer and a Gentleman'' in 1982, in supporting categories, and Sidney Poitier for ``Lilies of the Field'' in 1963 as lead actor. ``Glory'' is the story of the formation of the black 54th Regiment in the Union army during the Civil War, its soldiers' struggle for respect and its heroic but fatal charge on a Confederate fort in South Carolina. Washington played Trip, an embittered runaway slave who joins the 54th but remains cynical about the undertaking. In one of his most powerful scenes he tells a fellow enlisted man: ``Let me tell you something boy, you can march like the white man, you can talk like him, you can learn his songs, you can even wear his suits, but you ain't never goin' to be nothin' to him.'' Washington concluded his thanks for the Oscar by paying homage to the 54th, ``the black soldiers who helped to make this country free.'' Also nominated for supporting actor were Danny Aiello in ``Do the Right Thing,'' Dan Aykroyd in ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Marlon Brando in ``A Dry White Season'' and Martin Landau in ``Crimes and Misdemeanors.'

DOC.HEAD: Report: Canceled Flights Increase 42 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 59,000 U.S. airline flights were canceled last year, a 42 percent increase over 1988, according to a report published Monday. The cancellations by 12 major carriers for non-mechanical reasons left passengers stranded on 58,879 domestic flights in the year ending Jan. 31, up from 41,448 for the year ending Jan. 31, 1989, the Saint Paul Pioneer Press reported. U.S. Transportation Department officials declined to discuss the figures, which the newspaper said it obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. Of the six largest carriers, USAir had the worst record, with both the largest number of cancellations _ 15,849 _ and the greatest increase from the year ending Jan. 31, 1989. Its number rose by 8,758 as it struggled through a merger last fall with Piedmont Airlines. Next was American Airlines with an increase of 5,033 cancellations to 10,001, and United Airlines with an increase of 3,330 to 9,190. Northwest Airlines had a better record than USAir, United and American, canceling only 1.1 percent of all flights. Its number of cancellations dropped to 5,081 last year from 5,504 the year before. Officials say weather is a greater problem than it once was because airlines are increasingly reliant on hub-and-spoke systems that dispatch many flights from a single city. Bad weather at one hub can mean hundreds of added cancellations a day, said United spokeswoman Sara Dornacker. She said United's increased cancellations were due largely to weather. But she said some of United's trouble stems from mechanical problems that delay the timely arrival of crews, which means canceling more flights. Others said United's performance during three months last summer may have been affected by labor-contract tensions that kept crews from reporting for duty and resulted in crew shortages. American Airlines did not respond to an inquiry on the matter Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Intensifies After Signing of Contra Dismantling Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to RECAST lead to ADD reports of fighting, ADD comment from top Contra commander Galeano; pickup 13th pvs, `It is...'
DOC.TEXT: Three days after the U.S.-backed Contras signed an agreement to disband by mid-April, rebels were streaming into Nicaragua Monday and there were reports of intensified fighting. International observers and witnesses said Contra bases across the border from Nicaragua in Yamales, Honduras, were practically empty. They ``have become ghost camps. There's just a few of them left there,'' said one international observer, who spoke on condition of anonmity. Journalists who visited the camps last week had similar reports. The Contra leader who negotiated the demobilization pact, Oscar Sovalbarro, said 2,000 rebel fighters have returned since the accord was signed Friday. He said a 2,000-person ``insurgent military contingent is already back in Nicaragua ... and its numbers could increase at any moment.'' The movement of rebel fighters into Nicaragua could undermine hopes raised by the accord, which establishes a demobilization deadline only for the Contras in Honduras. In Miami, the top Contra military commander, Israel Galeano, insisted the fighters in Nicaragua would not disarm until the Sandinista army does. ``We are speaking of total demobilization _ that includes both ourselves and the Sandinistas,'' he said. Sandinista leaders have said their party will not turn over control of the army to the new government unless the U.S.-backed Contras demobilize. Galeano, who did not sign the accord, said it was unrealistic to expect the Contras to demobilize immediately. ``An eight-year process cannot be decided by the dismantlement of an organization in 15 days,'' he said. The Defense Ministry says there have been at least two clashes between the army and the Contras since Friday in which 16 people died. The ministry also said about 100 Contras seized a truck Sunday night, robbed the passengers of cash and jewelry and made the owner pay a $500 ransom to get the vehicle back. All the incidents took place near the provincial capital of Jinotega, 100 miles northeast of Managua on the Honduran border. International observers say there appears to be a split among the Contras over the pact, but Sovalbarro and Galeano denied any rift. ``At the moment we are a very solid organization. We mutually support each other,'' Galeano said. Sovalbarro and a spokesman for Galeano, Alejandro Acevdeo, denied there had been an increase in fighting and said the Sandinistas were lying. ``It is the Sandinistas who are trying to undermine the peace process. We think the Sandinistas are disguising themselves and staging attacks to discredit us,'' Acevedo said. The demobilization agreement signed Friday in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa between representatives of the rebels and of the incoming government of the United National Opposition alliance, or UNO, calls for an immediate cease-fire. It says the Contras in Honduras will demobilize by April 20, five days before President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro takes office. Most of the 12,000-man Contra army that holed up in Honduras after U.S. military aid ended in 1988 began returning to Nicaragua in September. As many as 4,000 were believed to be in Nicaragua by the Feb. 25 election. The demobilization pact says the Contras inside Nicaragua will move into ``secure zones'' monitored by the United Nations and Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the archbishop of Managua. The accord was signed by Sovalbarro _ but not by Galeano. One foreign observer interpreted this as a loophole should Galeano, also known as Commander Franklyn, decide not to adhere to the pact. ``The agreement reached with the new government of Nicaragua surprised our combatants at first,'' Sovalbarro acknowledged. ``But now we are all happy over what happened.'' The observer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there appeared to be a split between Contra forces loyal to Franklyn (Galeano) and followers of Sovalbarro (Ruben). ``We have estimated that Franklyn controls about 40 percent of the Contras and Ruben about 60 percent, and that Franklyn is the toughest of the two,'' said the observer. ``Maybe Ruben wants to demobilize, but not Franklyn.'' President Daniel Ortega has also said he was concerned that Galeano had not signed the accord. Franklyn's brother, Osvaldo Galeano _ Commander Negro _ told The Associated Press last week that his forces would not demobilize unless the Sandinista army and Interior Ministry did the same. In the first reported clash after the pact was signed, about 100 Contras Friday ambushed an undisclosed number of Sandinistas in La Pavona, 33 miles northeast of Jinotega. The Defense Ministry said 12 Sandinista soldiers and four Contras were killed, and eight Sandinista soldiers and civilians were wounded in a 90-minute firefight. The Defense Ministry also reported a 30-minute firefight Sunday evening between about 30 Contras and Sandinista troops. No casualities were reported. Jinotega province is the northern tip of a corridor used by the Contras to infiltrate Nicaragua. The Contras are supported by peasants in the corridor, a strip extending south through the middle of Nicaragua to the Costa Rican border.

DOC.HEAD: Army Deserter From Cuba Came to United States in 1980
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with suspect moved to psychiatric ward, history as street hustler, raise reference status as army deserter, add girlfriend's name and age. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `District Attorney...' INSERTS 1 graf after 11th pvs, `However, he...,' to UPDATE with report suspect had told of drug record. ^By VIRGINIA BYRNE
DOC.TEXT: The man charged with killing 87 people in one of the nation's deadliest fires was a Cuban army deserter who arrived during the 1980 Mariel boatlift and had no arrest record in New York, authorities said Monday. Julio Gonzalez, 36, was reported to have been nonchalant when he was arrested at his home Sunday, but later cried and blamed his actions on the devil, police said. ``I got angry, the devil got into me, and I set the place on fire,'' Gonzalez told authorities, according to a police source who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. Gonzalez, described by police as a street person who ``hustled'' money washing cars or peddling, was arraigned Monday on charges of murdering 87 people by setting fire to the Happy Land social club early Sunday. Police said Gonzalez set the fire after getting into an argument with his 45-year-old former girlfriend, Lydia Feliciano, who worked at the club. He was moved Monday from the prison at Rikers island, where he had been under a suicide watch, to maximum security protective custody at the Brooklyn House of Detention, said prisons spokeswoman Ruby Ryles. From there he was taken to Kings County Hospital for a psychiatric evaluation. He was being held in a prison ward of the hospital, Ryles said. District Attorney Robert Johnson said Gonzalez has no arrest record in New York. He offered little other information about his background, saying he didn't know how Gonzalez made a living or what he has done since entering the country 10 years ago. ``His background is not a priority,'' Johnson said. Gonzalez reportedly had a job in a lamp factory in the Long Island City section of Queens, but is believed to have been out of work for about six months. According to immigration records, he arrived in the United States at Key West, Fla., on May 31, 1980, as part of the Mariel boatlift. About 125,000 Cubans entered the United States during that flotilla, including many convicted criminals and other undesirables. Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said Gonzalez had served ``some time'' in prison in Cuba for deserting from the army. However, he said, ``In our interviews we uncovered nothing to indicate he was criminal in nature.'' Gonzalez, however, said at the time of his arrival that he had told Cuban authorities he had trafficked in drugs in order to qualify for the boatlift, Duke Austin, an INS spokesman, told The New York Times. After arriving in the United States, Gonzalez was detained at Camp McCoy, Wis., then Ft. Chaffee, Ark., until Feb. 21, 1981, when he was granted parole status, according to Jervis. From Arkansas, he was sent to live with a sponsor family in New York. ``We've had no contact from him since,'' Jervis said. He said Gonzalez has never applied for permanent residence, which makes him deportable after serving time for a criminal conviction. For the past three months, Gonzalez has lived in an $80-a-week furnished room on the third floor of a house in the University Heights section of the Bronx, near the Bronx Zoo. Before that he had lived with the girlfriend who was employed at the Happy Land, according to police. His neighbors described him as quiet, tidy and polite. ``He was just a normal guy. This is totally unexpected,'' Ray Davis, the building manager, said. ``He's a nice, quiet, clean guy.'' ``He didn't seem to have many friends. Not many people came to visit him.
