He never caused any problems or arguments,'' said Celia Lopez, a neighbor. ``I still can't believe it _ to have somebody with such a demented mind living next to me,'' said another neighbor, Yvonne Torres. ``There was nothing out of the ordinary about him. We used to shoot the breeze and drink beer,'' said Louis Rolan, another third-floor resident.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of March 12-19:
DOC.HEAD: ASNE Criticizes Cheney's Role in Coverage of Panama Invasion
DOC.TEXT: The American Society of Newspaper Editors on March 20 criticized Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's delay in alerting the 16-member press pool of the U.S. invasion of Panama last December. ``Cheney's decision to delay calling the pool until after the close of office hours and the broadcast of the evening news made assembling the pool difficult and actually increased the security problem,'' said Jean Otto, chairman of the ASNE's Press-Bar-Public Affairs Committee. ``It also assured that the pool would not arrive until hours after the invasion was launched'' on Dec. 20, Otto, associate editor of the Rocky Mountain News, said in a news release. The ASNE statement came as a Pentagon-sponsored report was released saying U.S. reporters missed the start of the invasion because Cheney decided secrecy was more important than ensuring news coverage. The report also criticized Cheney's press secretary, Pete Williams, for not trying to convince the secretary to send a group of reporters and photographers to Panama in time to cover the critical opening battles. ``I take the blame for what happened in Panama,'' Williams said in response to the report. He said the Defense Department was fully committed to the idea of allowing the news media to cover military operations, and that steps already were being taken to correct problems described in the latest study. A pool system was established by representatives of the Pentagon and the news media after the 1983 invasion of Grenada. It is designed to have objective observers inform American citizens from the start of military actions involving U.S. personnel.
DOC.HEAD: Ingersoll Newspapers To Buy Back Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Ingersoll Newspapers Inc. has offered to buy back $159 million of its junk bonds at discounted prices as it tries to meet interest payments. Ingersoll Newspapers, a subsidiary of Ingersoll Publications Inc., offered March 22 to buy the bonds at between 25 percent and 55 percent of the principal amount. One series of bonds has been trading at about $400 per $1,000 in face value. A separate series is trading at about $200 per $1,000. Ingersoll owns 19 daily newspapers in the United States and Great Britain, and also operates a dozen groups of weekly newspapers, most situated in the same cities as Ingersoll daily newspapers. Junk bond analyst Ned Zachar of Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago said Ingersoll, like other newspaper companies in the northeastern United States, is facing financial problems from an overall economic slowdown. Ingersoll spokesman Mark Harnett said earnings have fallen off. Zachar said bondholders should accept some kind of offer to avoid pushing the publishing company into bankruptcy, but he expected a higher purchase price to result from any negotiations. ``I think there's a pretty good chance Ingersoll will succeed with a tender offer,'' he said. ``But whether it will be at this price or another remains to be seen. The bondholders will likely push for a little more.''
DOC.HEAD: Hoiles Retires From Freedom Newspapers Board
DOC.TEXT: Harry H. Hoiles, who filed suit eight years ago seeking a third of the assets of Freedom Newspapers Inc., retired from the group's board of directors March 19. Hoiles, 74 and a former co-publisher of The Orange County Register, was replaced by his son, Timothy Hoiles, publisher of the Freedom-owned Daily Press of Victorville, Calif., said Freedom President D.R. Segal. Hoiles had served on the board since the early 1950s. From 1975 to 1979 he was co-publisher, with his brother Clarence, of the Register, Freedom's flagship newspaper. He was publisher of the Colorado Springs Gazette Telegraph, another Freedom newspaper, from 1946 to 1975. He also once served as president of the group. In 1982, Hoiles sued Freedom and the families of his sister, Mary Jane Hoiles Hardie, and his late brother, seeking a court order giving him one-third of Freedom's assets. Hoiles alleged that his relatives had denied him a meaningful management role after his brother's death in 1981, and conspired to devalue his stock when he sought to withdraw his share of Freedom's assets. An Orange County judge dismissed the suit on grounds Hoiles failed to prove that his relatives violated corporate laws protecting minority shareholders. Hoiles' appeal of the dismissal will be heard April 17.
DOC.HEAD: New York Governor Signs Expanded `Shield Law' for News Media
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo expanded New York's ``shield law'' on March 24 to protect the news media from having to surrender to the courts most information collected by reporters and television crews. ``Enactment of the bill is particularly appropriate this year as we celebrate the bicentennial of the First Amendment,'' Cuomo said in signing the legislation. ``Since 1735, when Peter Zenger was acquitted of libel charges, New York has led the way in the protection of freedom of the press.'' The Democratic governor announced his action just before speaking at a meeting of the New York State Society of Newspaper Editors. Although New York's shield law, adopted in 1970, had protected information gathered on a confidential basis from sources, recent state court rulings had said there was no such protection for information gathered without a promise of confidentiality. Under the expanded law, unpublished information or that supplied without a pledge of confidentiality doesn't have to be given up by news organizations in most circumstances. A court could still order the information divulged if it determined the material was critical to a case and not obtainable from any alternative source. The legislation was passed 47-5 on March 21 by the Republican-controlled state Senate. In January, the Democrat-controlled Assembly had approved it 119-11. The legislation gives New York one of the strictest protections for journalists of any state in the nation, according to lawyers for several news organizations.

DOC.HEAD: School's Carillon Tolls for Terry Anderson
DOC.TEXT: Iowa State University tolled the campus bells 60 times for Terry Anderson on March 19, one for each month the Associated Press correspondent, a graduate of the school, has been a hostage in the Middle East. Yellow ribbons were tied around trees outside the school's Memorial Union and posters with Anderson's picture proclaimed, ``We have not forgotten.'' But most students, just back from spring break, went about their business on campus without stopping as the carillon was played at noon. Some, noticing television news crews, asked reporters, ``What's going on?'' Anderson, a 1974 journalism and political science graduate of ISU and a former Des Moines broadcaster, is chief Middle East correspondent for the AP. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985, and is the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon. The ISU ceremony marking the fifth anniversary of his capture was delayed from Friday to Monday to wait for students to return to the central Iowa campus from spring break.
DOC.HEAD: Daily News Places Ads As Contract Deadline Nears
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News placed advertisments seeking applicants for mailers union jobs in the event the union strikes after a March 30 contract expiration. ``New York Mailers Union No. 6 has authorized a strike against the Daily News and we are seeking a pool of unskilled applicants should it be necessary to hire replacements,'' the ad in March 22 editions of the Daily News read. ``We intend to replace all employees who do not report to work in the event of a strike.'' The head of the Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella group for 10 Daily News unions, said anyone who applied would be wasting their time. ``There's no jobs for them. There's no jobs because we have those jobs and we're not giving those jobs up,'' said George McDonald, who is also head of the mailers union. ``If our employees refuse our sincere offer to work, replacements must be hired,'' said John T. Sloan, the News' vice president for human resources. ``This step by the News is protection on our part against a blatant and potentially disruptive strike by the mailers union.'' Management says union work must be trimmed into order to return the paper to profitability. The company says it will then spend $300 million to $500 million on modernization. The unions say the News is trying to make them strike in order to shut down the paper or sell it.
DOC.HEAD: New York Times Company Sued Over Magazine Title
DOC.TEXT: A suburban Cleveland company that publishes a fashion and lifestyle magazine for distribution to shoppers filed a $10 million lawsuit against The New York Times Company on March 21, contending trademark rights were violated. Mall Network of Beachwood contends a new Family Circle publication called NOW has the same title as that of a 3-year-old fashion and lifestyle magazine the Ohio company publishes. The new Family Circle publication is variously referred to as NOW, Fitness NOW and similar titles, the complaint said. Mall Network said it obtained a registered trademark for the title NOW in 1987. Nancy Nielsen, spokeswoman for The New York Times Company, said she could not comment because she had not seen the lawsuit. Mall Network said the first edition of the new Family Circle publications was published Feb. 19 and the second is scheduled for publication April 2. Mall Network estimated that total readership of its NOW magazine, which is distributed in several states through shopping malls, direct mailing and newspaper inserts, is more than 7 million people.
DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Stays Order Sending Television Newsman to Jail
DOC.TEXT: A television reporter who faced jail for refusing to reveal his sources was allowed to remain free March 20 until a federal court decides his case. A state district judge on Feb. 8 cited KMOL reporter Brian Karem for contempt of court and ordered him jailed up to six months for refusing to turn over notes from a telephone interview with capital murder suspect Henry David Hernandez. Hernandez and his brother are charged in connection with the slaying last year of a San Antonio police officer. Karem interviewed Hernandez while the defendant was in jail. The newsman said he promised to protect confidential sources who helped arrange the interview and who are identified in his notes. Prosecutors and defense attorneys want to find out who helped set up the interview in efforts to use or prevent the use of the interview statements in Hernandez's capital murder trial. Hernandez told Karem in the interview that he shot the officer in self-defense. In citing Karem for contempt, State District Judge Pat Priest said the defendant's right to a fair trial outweighed the First Amendment right to a free press. Karem's attorney appealed the February ruling unsuccessfully to the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals. On March 19 he filed a request for a stay in federal court.
DOC.HEAD: State To Intervene in Bass-Poynter Court Case
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Bob Butterworth said March 23 he will intervene in a lawsuit filed by Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass over dividends paid to the Poynter Institute. Butterworth said the dispute could disrupt funding for the media center, which runs the St. Petersburg Times and other publications. The attorney general said he was getting involved because he has the constitutional authority ``to protect the integrity of charitable interests.'' Times Editor and President Andrew Barnes, who is also chairman of the institute, welcomed the action. Bass questioned it. Butterworth said he will seek to stop an effort by Poynter-Jamison Ventures Ltd., an investor partnership controlled by Bass, to obtain dividends now paid to the non-profit journalism institute. The Bass partnership includes the nieces of the late Eleanor Poynter Jamison, sister of founder Nelson Poynter. It has made a $270 million buyout offer for Times Publishing Co., parent firm of the newspaper, Congressional Quarterly and other magazines. The Bass group owns 40 percent of the voting stock of Times Publishing Co. That organization is controlled by the Times Holding Co., which is in turn controlled by the Poynter Institute. Bass maintains it wants a better return on its investment, while Times Publishing defends the current stock arrangement as beneficial to the journalistic standards of the newspaper and the health of the Poynter Institute.

DOC.HEAD: Court Dismisses Carrier Family's Suit Against Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Sioux City Journal is not responsible for injuries suffered by a youth who was run over by his father's truck while delivering newspapers, the Iowa Supreme Court ruled March 21. The court ordered that a suit brought by the youth against the newspaper's parent company be dismissed. A local judge had earlier refused to grant summary judgment for the company, which appealed that ruling to the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court ruled that Francis LaFleur was not an employee of Sioux City Newspapers Inc. when the 1978 accident occurred. Court records show a truck driven by LaFleur struck his son, Frank, who was 10 years old at the time and was delivering newspapers with his father and other family members. The boy suffered severe and disabling injuries, the court stated in its ruling. The ruling upheld the company's stand that the elder LaFleur was not an employee but rather was an independent contractor at the time of the accident. Companies are not directly responsible for actions of independent contractors under Iowa law.
DOC.HEAD: City Requires Signed Embargo Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The city's requirement that news agencies sign an embargo agreement before obtaining an advance copy of material for a news conference could set a dangerous precedent, a media law specialist said. The mayor's office would not release an internal police report on the custody of mob informant Peter Gilbert before the March 22 news conference unless reporters signed a lengthy embargo agreement. Material commonly is embargoed, but reporters are not required to sign such contracts. ``To my knowledge it's unprecedented,'' said Thomas A. Schwartz, a media law specialist at Ohio State University. ``Historically there has been a matter of trust between media sources and the media,'' he said. ``But I'm sure that many media sources have been burned in recent times and have become more cautious in protecting the release of such material.'' The contract acknowledged the 280-page report ``would be considered to be a governmental record'' covered under Rhode Island's public records law. City spokesman Tad Devine said the arrangement was needed because some of those affected by the report would not have a chance to review it before the news conference. The Providence Journal-Bulletin signed the agreement, but then issued a statement saying it regretted the decision. James V. Wyman, vice president of the newspaper, said his company would not sign such documents in the future.
DOC.HEAD: Media Seek to Block Cult Trial Coverage Orders
DOC.TEXT: A group of news organizations in Cleveland told the Ohio Supreme Court on March 19 that a northeast Ohio judge failed to justify three orders he issued involving coverage of a cult murder case. The case involves the slayings of five family members whose bodies were found in January buried in a barn in Kirtland, about 25 miles northeast of Cleveland. Authorities suspect they were shot by a religious cult, and 13 members of the group are accused in the slayings. Judge Martin Parks of Lake County Common Pleas Court issued the restrictions on coverage. They prohibit those in the trial from talking to reporters, require television stations to maintain any videotapes made in connection with the story, and prohibit photographs of a defendant should there be a trial. The National Broadcasting Co., television stations WUAB, WKYC, WEWS, WJW and The Plain Dealer of Cleveland contend the restrictions ``directly and dramatically'' affect their constitutional news-gathering and reporting rights. The Supreme Court gave no indication when it might rule.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Teachers' Suit Against Newspapers, News Service
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on March 17 dismissed a libel suit a group of teachers at an eastern Kentucky high school filed against The Associated Press and five newspapers. But U.S. District Judge Karl Forester denied requests for dismissal of a related defamation lawsuit against the news service and one of the newspapers, brought by a teacher named in a 1988 AP article. John H. O'Brien, principal of Phelps High School, and 28 faculty members contended the AP story about a parents meeting defamed them and permanently damaged their reputations. Teacher Gary R. Hunt filed a separate suit in which he claimed the story and expanded version in the Williamson (W.Va.) Daily News defamed his reputation and violated his right to privacy. Forester acted on a report filed in early February by U.S. Magistrate Joseph Hood. In his report, Hood said the teachers failed to prove their claims of being libeled as a group. Forester also adopted Hood's recommendation that the newspapers that printed only the AP story be removed from the Hunt case. Hood said the editors had no reason to suspect the article was ``anything other than an accurate account of a public meeting and remarks made therein.'' Dismissed from the Hunt suit were The (Louisville) Courier-Journal, the Lexington Herald-Leader, The Daily Independent of Ashland and the Appalachian News-Express of Pikeville. The AP and the Williamson Daily News remain as defendants in the Hunt suit.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Publicity Won't Affect Trial
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the fraud case against Imelda Marcos expressed skepticism March 21 that publicity would affect the trial, telling a defense attorney that similar negative press didn't prevent one-time Miss America Bess Myerson's acquittal. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan made the comment in the second day of jury selection at the trial of Mrs. Marcos and Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. Outside the presence of would-be jurors, Mrs. Marcos' lawyer, Gerry Spence, told Keenan that he was concerned about publicity. He read from a New York Daily News column about Mrs. Marcos headlined ``Last of the Red-Hot Evil Women.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of participating in the illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Philippines treasury to buy Manhattan real estate, and of defrauding banking institutions of another $165 million to finance the deals.

DOC.HEAD: Persis Buys Media Holdings Inc.
DOC.TEXT: Persis Corp., a Honolulu company that owns two Tennessee newspapers, said March 21 it had acquired Media Holdings, Inc., publisher of metro magazines and specialty books in four Tennessee markets. The purchase price was not announced but two of Media Holdings' magazines, Nashville! and Advantage, had reportedly been offered for sale last summer for $1.7 million to $2 million. Properties owned by Persis include The Knoxville Journal and the Maryville-Alcoa Daily Times in Tennessee, the Honolulu Advertiser, the Journal-American in Bellevue, Wash., and the Valley Daily News in Kent, Wash. Media Holdings also publishes the Nashville Area Business Directory, Nashville Visitor Guide and ``How To Do Business'' books dealing with the Memphis, Nashville, Knoxville and Chattanooga markets.
DOC.HEAD: Post to Publish Quarterly Book Series
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post Co. will publish a series of paperback books examining political and economic issues starting with a slim volume by economist Paul Krugman. ``The Age of Diminishing Expectations'' is the first in a planned quarterly series of ``briefing books'' aimed at institutional buyers such as investment houses, law firms, banks and foreign embassies. Krugman is an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and was a member of the Council of Economic Advisors during the Reagan administration. His 110-page book will cost $195 and will not be sold in bookstores. Noel Epstein, publisher of the Krugman book and the Post's national weekly edition, said the paperback will be marketed through direct mail and other means. Epstein said 2,000 copies will be printed, followed by more if there is a demand.
DOC.HEAD: South Dade Paper Will Publish Weekly
DOC.TEXT: The South Dade News Leader said it will cease daily publication March 30 and cut back to one weekly edition with only local news. ``What we do best is cover South Dade,'' General Manager Glenn Martin said March 22. The newspaper serves 11,800 readers from the southern edge of Miami to Florida City.
DOC.HEAD: Stay Granted in Reuters-UPI Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on March 20 preserved a picture exchange contract between United Press International and Reuters until another hearing in the case next month. Reuters has sued to break the contract. U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure earlier denied UPI's request for a preliminary injunction keeping the agreement in effect. Judge Jon Newman of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan granted a stay until oral arguments are made, sometime during the week of April 16. The contract was entered into in 1984 and called for UPI to supply Reuters, based in Britain, with pictures from the United States, while Reuters provided UPI with pictures from other countries. It was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985.
DOC.HEAD: Man Awarded Millions in Slander Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A man acquitted in 1986 of molesting his young daughter was awarded more than $5 million in damages March 19 for being defamed by members of the audience at Geraldo Rivera's talk show. U.S. District Court Judge Maryanne Trump Barry entered a default judgment granting Lawrence Spiegel $1 million in special damages and $4 million in punitive damages. Spiegel's attorney, Stephen Haft, said Faye Yeager of Atlanta and Lydia Rayner of Gulfport, Miss., defendants in the 1988 federal slander suit, failed to file answers or appear at the hearing. Haft said his client was a guest on the nationally televised show in 1988 when the defendants _ wearing wigs and sunglasses _ began berating Spiegel from the audience. He said the women, who are associated with the national group Mothers Against Raping Children, had previously harassed Spiegel during a speaking engagement in California. Spiegel was indicted in December 1983 on charges of molesting his then-2-year-old daughter. He was cleared of the charges in January 1986. ``If nothing else, I hope this sends the message that I will not be a punching bag for anyone,'' Spiegel, a psychologist from Parsippany-Troy Hills, said of the judge's decision. There was no immediate comment available from Ms. Yeager in Atlanta or Ms. Rayner in Gulfport, neither of whom have listed telephones.
DOC.HEAD: Fired Newspaper Controller Claims He Was Pressured To Show Inflated Revenue
DOC.TEXT: The fired controller of a Jackson newspaper said March 22 he was ordered to inflate revenue on company financial reports so the publication would meet profit goals. O.J. Daniels was dismissed March 15 from his job at The Clarion-Ledger during a biannual audit by Gannett Co. Inc. He told USA Today that he had counted some advertising revenues twice so The Clarion-Ledger would not fall ``several million dollars short'' of its annual profit goal. Daniels said he inflated the revenue at the direction of Robert E. Robbins, who was the newspaper's publisher and has since been assigned to another Gannett post. Robbins has denied giving such orders. USA Today reported that revenues had been inflated $4 million over a two-year period.
DOC.HEAD: Knight Foundation Awards $1 Million for Kent State Chair
DOC.TEXT: The Knight Foundation on March 21 awarded $1 million to Kent State University to endow a chair in writing that will be named for John S. Knight, late editor emeritus of the Akron Beacon Journal and editorial chairman of Knight-Ridder Newspapers. The Akron-based foundation also announced it was awarding $265,000 in grants to Akron-area schools and institutions. ``Good writing meant everything to Jack,'' said Knight's brother, James L. Knight, chairman of the foundation. ``If he were alive today, he would be more concerned than anyone about the large number of college graduates who can't write or communicate effectively. He would be out there leading the fight to do something about it.'' The foundation supports causes and programs in communities in which Knight-Ridder Inc. publishes newspapers. It also awards grants in higher education and journalism.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish-Language Magazine Launched in Conjunction With TV Programs
DOC.TEXT: Creators of an ambitious multimedia effort targeting Hispanics say 90 percent of the $10 million in annual ad time and space was sold as the service debuted March 26. The service will reach an estimated 500,000 Hispanic magazine readers and nearly 90 percent of Hispanic homes with television, says its developer, Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn. Starting later this spring, advertisers also will be mentioned when operators answer calls to a toll-free telephone service for Hispanics seeking information on topics ranging from recipes to immigration. The operator will answer calls by saying the hotline service is ``brought to you by ...'' Sponsors pay $500,000 a year under two-year contracts for a basic package that includes television, telephone time and magazine space. Those who have signed so far include American Airlines, Procter & Gamble, American Telephone & Telegraph and Kinney Shoes, Whittle says. The cornerstone of the service is the magazine La Familia de Hoy, published every other month. It is distributed free to 10,500 medical waiting rooms and beauty parlors in Hispanic neigborhoods in 45 markets. Whittle is also producing two-minute informational programs that will run 31 times a week on the Spanish-language television network Univision, which reaches 6.4 million Spanish-speaking households in the United States.
DOC.HEAD: Car Newspaper Group To Publish Tabloid
DOC.TEXT: An eight-page weekly auto news tabloid will begin publication near the new General Motors Saturn car plant by May, the newspaper's owner says. Car Country News will target the employees of the new Saturn plant and the surrounding community, according to Monday Morning Newspapers, owner of six similar publications in Michigan. The newspapers, which feature and promote U.S. carmaking, have a combined circulation of 41,000. A monthly trade publication, Nashville Automotive Reports, already is published in Middle Tennessee and Automotive News maintains a bureau here.
DOC.HEAD: `Jackpot' Tabloid Promotes Illinois State Lottery
DOC.TEXT: With headlines like ``Human Lotto Balls Bounce to New Heights'' the Illinois State Lottery has produced a quarterly with everything inquiring minds want to know about the game. Jackpot, circulation 2 million, is an eight-page tabloid with color graphs, cartoons and stories, and lots of pictures of lottery players and employees. It's distributed free to lottery agents and outlets where game tickets are sold. Jackpot is meant to help fill the gap lottery officials feel was left when the daily press grew accustomed to the weekly games, now in their 16th year, said Editor Mary Johnston-Clark. ``At the beginning, a $5 million (Lotto) jackpot was big,'' she said, adding that Illinois newspapers and broadcasters were excited about the subject. Now only the big jackpots get much press notice. ``Now, unless it's $20 million, or $30 million or $40 million, they don't bat an eye.''
DOC.HEAD: Gaming Analyst Loses Job Over Negative Remarks About Taj Mahal
DOC.TEXT: A top gaming-industry analyst says he was fired March 23 for remarks he made to The Wall Street Journal about Donald Trump's newest casino. Marvin Roffman, an analyst for 16 years with Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia, said his company was angry about remarks he made to the Journal in a story about the Taj Mahal Casino Resort, scheduled to open April 2. Roffman said the quotes, which said Trump would have difficulty meeting the debt service on the property, were accurate, although many other favorable quotes about the casino were omitted. Roffman said Trump forced the company to make him issue a letter of public apology. Roffman, who was widely quoted in casino stories, said he also was forced to take a pay cut and never talk again to reporters. Roffman said he later had second thoughts and faxed another letter to Trump, saying the first letter contained many inaccuracies. He said the second letter cost him his job because the company told him not to write it.
DOC.HEAD: Political Writer Loses Job at BU Magazine
DOC.TEXT: The political writer for Boston University's Bostonia Magazine lost his job after submitting a column critical of the school president's political campaign. John R. Silber is on leave as president while seeking the Democratic nomination for governor. Bostonia is subsidized by the university and is distributed free to alumni and sold to the public. Martin S. Goldman, the magazine's political columnist for three years, said March 22 his firing raises questions of censorship. Keith Botsford, who was appointed publisher and editor-in-chief of the magazine by Silber last summer, said Goldman had been told not to write about local politics. Botsford said it would be illegal for the magazine to take sides because the university is a tax-exempt, nonprofit corporation. ``I would have done it if it was about Evelyn Murphy or anyone else,'' he said. Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy also seeks the Democratic nomination for governor. ``I expect to take a beating in the press for this. It will look like censorship, but it isn't. Any reasonable editor would have done the same.'' He said Silber was unaware of the incident, and Goldman said, ``I don't see Silber's hand in it.''
DOC.HEAD: Sun Expands Carroll County Edition
DOC.TEXT: The Baltimore Sun Inc. is expanding publication of its Carroll County edition from weekly to twice-weekly. As of May 9, The Carroll County Sun will publish twice a week, on Sundays and Wednesday, said Edward H. Shur, editor of the county edition in suburban Baltimore just west of the city. The Carroll County Sun began publication in 1984 with 16 to 20 pages each Sunday and a news staff of four. It has grown to 36 to 48 pages and a news staff of eight.
DOC.HEAD: ``World's Smartest Person'' Has Some Advice
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn vos Savant, listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the person with the highest IQ ever recorded, has a new book with advice for news junkies _ cut down. Vos Savant has collaborated with her husband, Dr. Robert Jarvik, in artificial heart research and writes an advice column for Parade magazine. Page 184 of her new book, ``Brain Building: Exercising Yourself Smarter,'' offers this suggestion: ``Brain Builder No. 115: Get Less News. ``Exercise: This week, get the news only once a day, and only from the radio. Next week, get the news only once a day and only from the television. The following week, get the news only once a day and only from the newspaper. (At this point, it should be very clear why you should turn to the newspaper permanently.)''

DOC.HEAD: Israel's Censorship of Soviet Immigration Criticized
DOC.TEXT: Human rights advocate Natan Sharansky criticized Israel's censorship of reports on Soviet immigration, saying it was hurting efforts to settle the new arrivals. Sharansky, a former Soviet refusnik, was joined by an official of a resettlement agency in complaining about excessive censorship March 20. The ban on publication of immigration figures was imposed March 1 amid mounting Arab protests the influx could lead to more Jewish settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. Sharansky, who heads the Soviet Jewry Zionist Forum, said some self-censorship might be needed to ensure the security of the immigrants. But he said, ``We need more support from world Jewry and, to make bureaucrats work more effectively, we need more public pressure. We can't do it under conditions of censorship.'' Sharansky and other Israeli activists have said the Jewish state is not preparing enough housing and jobs for the arriving Soviets.
DOC.HEAD: Press Cooperative Protests Gov't Decision That It Be Liquidated
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Poland's largest press cooperative said March 21 the Solidarity-led government had acted unfairly in deciding that it be liquidated. Under Communist rule, the Workers' Publishing Cooperative muzzled unauthorized publications. On March 19, the Cabinet decided to do away with the group because it was seen as an organ of the now-defunct Communist Party. Parliament must still pass the law dismantling the group. Slawomir Tabkowski, chairman of the cooperative, said the government commission that developed the law had submitted to ``neo-Bolshevik pressure'' aimed at attaining ``political revenge.'' He said the cooperative had gotten only a brief chance to display its plans to reform itself, and the government had made an arbitrary decision. The cooperative published the vast majority of newspapers on the market, controlled the sale of newspapers through its monopoly on more than 20,000 kiosks in the country and owned several important publishing houses. Last year, the popularity of the cooperative's publications began to drop as new independent newspapers emerged in Poland's changing political climate.
DOC.HEAD: Some Lithuanian Radio Broadcasts Silenced
DOC.TEXT: Some broadcasts by Radio Vilnius, voice of the Lithuanian capital, have been blocked by the Soviet Union since the Lithuanian parliament declared independence, a state radio report March 19 said. A Radio Vilnius announcer suggested that the Soviet Ministry of Communications was responsible and asked listeners in Europe to tune to frequencies that are not relayed by Radio Moscow. ``Today the leaders of the Lithuanian radio and TV networks and Radio Vilnius people have been getting in touch with high-level or ranking officials of Radio Moscow,'' said the announcer, who by custom in that country was not identified. ``It appears the blockade of Radio Vilnius broadcasts was a surprise to them, and they promised to clear up what the matter was.'' The agency's short-wave broadcasts to North America normally are made on six different frequencies to ensure a good chance of reception in all areas of the continent. The broadcasts are normally relayed by Radio Moscow on its powerful transmitters.
DOC.HEAD: Liberia Lifts Ban on Newspapers, Radio Station
DOC.TEXT: The government said March 22 it is lifting bans on two newspapers and a Roman Catholic radio station that had been accused of reporting false information. President Samuel Doe decided to remove the ban in honor of Namibia's independence that day, according to a Ministry of Information statement. The southern African nation became independent after 75 years of white South African rule. Footprints Today and Sun Times newspapers were banned in April 1988, when the government also barred radio stations from broadcasting reports of the British Broadcasting Corp. and the U.S.-funded Voice of America. Footprints Today was accused of fabricating a letter to the editor signed by an alleged army officer who said secret killings and arrests were increasing in Liberia. Offending stories in the Sun Times reported the arrest of a Ghanaian for possession of explosives and the firing of the commander of a government anti-terrorist squad. ELCM community radio was ordered closed in June 1989 for reporting one person was crushed to death and hundreds were injured in a stampede at a Monrovia football stadium where Liberia lost to Malawi. The independent press of this West African nation, which was founded by freed American slaves in 1847, expressed anger March 17 over the burning down of the independent Daily Observer newspaper building. Four armed men in military uniforms reportedly doused the library, darkroom and newsroom with gasoline, then set them ablaze. Newspaper editors said the act was intended to intimidate them. Also last week, the managing director of the Independent News, Klon Hinneh, was detained for several days under a court order for printing Chief Justice Emmanuel Gbalazeh's picture on the back page instead of the front page.
DOC.HEAD: Glasnost May Come at a Cost for East German Press
DOC.TEXT: Some of the biggest players in West German journalism have begun selling magazines and newspapers in East Germany. Eastern publishers knew when the government of Erich Honecker fell in October that ``we'd be faced with free-market competition, that we'd have to adopt more competitive practices,'' said Matthias Schlegel, deputy editor of the daily Neue Zeit. His newspaper, with a circulation of 150,000 and a price of 20 pfennigs (12 cents) has survived only with state support. ``We're worried we won't be able to survive economically,'' Schlegel said. ``It's a real question for our existence,'' he said. Early this month West German publishers put street vendors to work in a major East Berlin plaza selling such journals as the mass-circulation Bild Zeitung, conservative daily Die Welt, news magazines Der Spiegel and Stern, and a wide range of fashion and sports magazines. The Western publications can be expensive. Under a typical pricing formula Der Spiegel would cost 13.50 East marks, the equivalent of $7.65. Schlegel said there may be a spate of takeovers by West German press barons jockeying for market position, and that small regional or local papers might be targets. Other changes: The East German news agency ADN, which surprised Western journalists with its rapid change to fast, reliable reporting, is said to be planning a merger with the West German agency DPA. And Tageszeitung, a West German tabloid, has set up in East Berlin to print a separate Eastern edition.
DOC.HEAD: Seminar Scheduled on Urban Poverty
DOC.TEXT: Homelessness, income distribution and poverty are among the topics to be covered in ``Urban Poverty in the 1990s,'' a conference next month sponsored by the Foundation for American Communications, The Ford Foundation and the Los Angeles Times. The conference will be held April 20-22 at the Los Angeles Midtown Hilton. It will include a visit to the Weingart Center, a local agency said to be a pioneer in providing public and private services to the poor.

DOC.HEAD: Ad Company Has Designs on Berlin Wall
DOC.TEXT: Part of the Berlin Wall, which was a symbol of socialism and a barrier to capitalism for nearly three decades, could be turned into a giant billboard. The East German advertising firm WuVA has acquired local government rights to a 3,300-foot section of the wall, the newspaper Neues Deutschland said March 22. The company wants to paint the section white and recruit German companies to rent space. Posters advertising such vices as cigarettes, alcohol or sex-related products would not be allowed.
DOC.HEAD: Twentieth Century Fox: No More Previews for Siskel & Ebert
DOC.TEXT: Twentieth Century Fox is banning film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert from advance screenings of its movies over remarks they made during a TV interview about the company's flick, ``Nuns on the Run.'' ``From now on, they can catch up with our films in the theater,'' Bob Harper, the studio's director of marketing, said in an interview published March 19 in the Hollywood Reporter. Ebert, a Pulitzer Prize-winning critic for the Chicago Sun-Times, responded, ``I guess you could call it thumbs on the run.'' Siskel and Ebert both gave the film a ``thumbs down'' on their television show, and also panned the movie in syndicated columns. During a TV interview March 16 in New York, Ebert held up a newspaper ad for ``Nuns on the Run'' with a prominent quote from the Village Voice calling it ``the funniest anti-clerical transvestite movie of the decade.'' He then bantered with Siskel about the ad. ``Yeah, this is 1990,'' Ebert said. ``How many other transvestite, anti-clerical comedies have there been so far in this decade?'' Both critics predicted the ban wouldn't really affect them and would eventually be rescinded.
DOC.HEAD: Dolly Parton Buying Radio Station
DOC.TEXT: Dolly Parton plans to buy the radio station where she taped her first songs and move it to her Dollywood theme park in nearby Pigeon Forge. The country music queen announced March 19 she is buying WSEV-AM and FM, pending Federal Communications Commission approval. No price was disclosed. At age 9, Ms. Parton went with her uncle, Bill Owens, to WSEV to tape two songs they had written together, ``Puppy Love'' and ``Girl Left Alone.'' It was their first single for Gold Band Records. The theme park plans to display the original microphone and other equipment Ms. Parton used to tape the two songs. Visitors also will be able to see the modern station in operation.
DOC.HEAD: Paula Zahn Says Network Job No `Beauty Contest'
DOC.TEXT: Paula Zahn, the new co-anchor of ``CBS This Morning,'' rejects the notion that she is in a beauty contest with two other network blondes, ABC's Joan Lunden and NBC's Deborah Norville. ``I find that very insulting,'' Zahn told TV Guide in its March 24 issue. ``I've been in the news business for 13 years. I'm bringing to this broadcast a lot of experience working in different parts of the country covering many different types of stories. ``I've interviewed world leaders. To reduce it to that kind of battle, I find it very offensive.'' Zahn, 34, is the latest in a line of female co-anchors on CBS's third-place morning show, following Phyllis George, Mariette Hartley and Kathleen Sullivan. She knows there are no guarantees of job security. ``There are bound to be changes if a program isn't producing the kinds of audiences that executives want,'' she told the magazine. ``There will be constant tinkering to deliver the best product, and the most profitable product, that we can. Those changes are an everyday reality.''
DOC.HEAD: Mondale Daughter Resigns From TV Job
DOC.TEXT: Eleanor Mondale, daughter of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, resigned from her job as a TV entertainment reporter just days before a local magazine was due to publish an article called, ``Walter and Joan's Wild Child.'' Ms. Mondale denied she was forced out after only eight months at WCCO-TV, the Star Tribune of Minneapolis reported March 22. ``I'm not upset,'' she said. ``I had to make some decisions on how I want to live my life (with) people in my face.'' ``The resignation is definitely her choice,'' said WCCO news director John Culliton. ``She may have a lot of reasons mixed in there about how she feels about us, but it is her choice.'' ``There is a lot of nervousness at WCCO about what it says and how it portrays her,'' Brian Anderson, editor of the magazine MPLS.ST.PAUL, said of the article. ``I think she's portrayed very positively,'' Anderson said. ``It looks at her career and some of the rumors about her and her performance.''
DOC.HEAD: NBC Defends Brokaw Special on `New Hollywood'
DOC.TEXT: A Hollywood studio representative and NBC-TV exchanged verbal brickbats March 23 over a network program dealing with a ``new'' Hollywood where small producers are likely to get squashed by large competitors. Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said he was outraged over NBC's ``The New Hollywood,'' broadcast March 21. Valenti said NBC failed to disclose its own efforts in Washington to wrest back control of its programs from Hollywood producers. Tom Brokaw, who anchored the program, called Valenti's attack an insult to his journalistic integrity. Valenti, in a letter to NBC President Robert Wright, demanded a opportunity, in television prime time, to ``present a rebuttal to NBC's lack of disclosure.'' NBC spokesman Joe Rutledge said Valenti's demand was ``idiotic. That means no.'' Hollywood producers, including the major studios that make up the MPAA, have been involved in negotiations for seven years over federal rules that prevent ABC, NBC and CBS from having a financial interest in the programs they broadcast or from selling those programs in the lucrative U.S. rerun market. Valenti emphasized that he was not questioning Brokaw's integrity. He said his quarrel with NBC was its failure to disclose that it was in a ``political struggle and a regulatory struggle'' with the studios it was criticizing.
DOC.HEAD: Political Changes Cause Review of U.S.-Backed Stations
DOC.TEXT: The White House will review all the government's overseas broadcasts to determine what changes should be made in response to political upheaval in Eastern Europe. The review will examine the radio programs of the Voice of America and of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, according to a March 21 letter from National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. ``The President strongly shares your view that the dramatic opening of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union requires us to look afresh at all our broadcasting activities,'' Scowcroft wrote Rep. Dante Fascell, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The stations have already begun changing, including new emphasis on ``how-to'' programs that instruct listeners in one-time communist countries about life in the Western world.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Speech Disrupts U.S. Radio Transmissions
DOC.TEXT: A Havana radio speech by Cuban President Fidel Castro was picked up on at least six AM radio frequencies in Florida March 23 in what may be a prelude to a cold-war battle over U.S.-financed TV Marti. The Cuban Communist Party newspaper Granma mentioned in its March 23 editions that Castro's remarks would be broadcast toward the United States that evening. WYFX in Delray Beach was one of the stations affected. ``I have been getting some feedback over the air,'' said disc jockey Lorenzo Fox. ``You hear some kind of broadcast coming through.'' Other stations, such as Spanish-language WQBA in Miami and WVCG in Coral Gables, responded to the interference by boosting their signal. Others were not seriously affected because they are normally off the air at night. TV Marti is expected to begin within weeks. The Cuban government has threatened to jam U.S. broadcast transmissions if the television service is beamed toward Cuba.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Narrows HDTV Field
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission on March 21 further narrowed the field of contestants seeking to market a high-definition television transmission system. Chairman Alfred Sikes said the FCC voted to consider only systems that will not require use of an extra ``augmentation'' channel. Only so-called simulcast systems will be considered for testing at the Advanced Television Test Center this fall, Sikes said. In a simulcast system, a TV station would broadcast its regular signal on one channel and the same program on another channel in high-definition. Augmentation systems also use two channels, but use the second channel to provide a signal that, when combined in the TV set with the regular signal on the first channel, yields the high-definition picture. Peter Fannon, executive director of the test center, said five entrants have been accepted for the test so far: Sarnoff-Philips; an analog simulcast system from Philips; Zenith Electronics Corp.; and the narrow MUSE and MUSE-6 systems from the Japan Broadcasting Corp.
DOC.HEAD: ABC To Show Fewer Commercials in Premiere of New Series
DOC.TEXT: ABC said March 21 it plans to show 20 percent fewer commercials when its new ``Twin Peaks'' series premieres as a two-hour special on April 8. The decision could cost the network up to $650,000. Spokeswoman Janice Gretemeyer said ABC had considered airing the special without commercials to draw attention to the series created by filmmaker David Lynch. But it decided that would have been too expensive, and chose instead to cut back on commercials, she said. The premiere will have 11 minutes and 12 seconds of commercials instead of the usual 14 minutes for Sunday movies. Richard Kostrya, an executive vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, estimated that ABC's decision could cost the network from $600,000 to $650,000. The network did not provide an estimate. The series, set in the Pacific Northwest, is described by ABC as a ``sometimes darkly comic vision'' of commonplace things and events. Lynch is known for such dark works as the movie ``Blue Velvet.''
DOC.HEAD: Plan To Sell Three Texas Radio Properties Squelched
DOC.TEXT: Command Communications Inc. said March 19 it was backing away from previously announced plans to sell radio stations in Houston and Dallas and a Texas-wide radio network for $86.5 million to Evergreen Media Corp. Command, based in New York, said it had secured additional sources of both equity and bank financing and instead plans to buy stations in Texas and other markets. Command signed an agreement in January to sell KRLD-AM of Dallas and The Texas State Radio Networks to Evergreen Media for $58.5 million. Under a separate deal, Evergreen would have acquired KODA-FM in Houston for $28 million from The Sillerman Companies, a New York-based investor in Command and other broadcast properties. Scott K. Ginsburg, president and chief executive of Evergreen Media, of Irving, Texas, said he was disappointed that Command and its principals decided not to sell.
DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Company Says It Will Acquire WUAB-TV
DOC.TEXT: Cannell Communications Inc. of Atlanta announced March 20 that it will acquire WUAB-TV in Cleveland as part of a deal worth $100 million. The station is the leading independent in the Cleveland market and ranks 11th nationally in terms of television households, a Cannell release said. Gaylord Broadcasting Co. of Ohio Inc. is WUAB's current owner. Cannell Communications, which was formed in November, is the broadcasting affiliate of The Cannell Studios, a leading independent producer of prime-time television programming.
DOC.HEAD: Program on Censorship Censored by Tulsa Station
DOC.TEXT: A Tulsa television station pre-empted the ``Donahue'' syndicated talk show that debated harsh language in modern music because station officials felt the program might have struck a bad chord with viewers. KJRH refused to air the hour-long show the afternoon of March 22 because of vulgar content, said general manager Bill Donahue. ``Quincy'' was shown in its place. ``After viewing portions of the show, it seemed that the language was especially vulgar in portions,'' he said. ``The reason it happened was the explicitness of the language.'' On the show, host Phil Donahue talked with performers and a broadcaster about obscenity and censorship in contemporary music. The show featured videotaped excerpts from a rap song by 2 Live Crew, who appeared as guests on the panel.
DOC.HEAD: Network Refuses Commercial That Looks Too Much Like News Story
DOC.TEXT: ABC is refusing to run a yogurt commercial made to look like a television news story because the spot's producers did their job too well. In the Yoplait commercial produced by W.B. Doner & Co., a television reporter tells viewers in a no-nonsense staccato, ``The crime: theft. The loot: frozen yogurt.'' The woman, identified as a ``Frozen Yogurt Reporter,'' interviews a police detective who is dusting empty yogurt cartons for tongue prints. ``These cartons were licked clean,'' the detective says. Janet Gretemeyer, ABC's director of press relations, said, ``The Yoplait yogurt ad contains simulated news techniques. Such representations are reserved specifically for actual news broadcasts.'' CBS asked for a disclaimer explaining that the commercials are not actual news. NBC does not want to run the spot during news broadcasts. The Baltimore advertising agency said it was adding the line, ``Sponsored by Yoplait,'' to the start of each 30-second commercial to avoid confusion. The $3 million campaign began airing March 19 on major cable television networks and stations in 14 markets.

DOC.HEAD: News Service To Be Delivered to Stations by Fax
DOC.TEXT: Zapnews, a low-cost news service to be distributed to radio and television stations via fax machines and personal computers, will begin operations April 2, the company said March 20. Zapnews founder James R. Hood said the company will distribute news, sports and features over dial-up long-distance telephone lines. It subscribes to the Reuters and SportsTicker wires and is forming a network of correspondents of its own, Hood said. The agency will begin supplying state and regional news gradually over the next 18 months from headquarters in Fairfax County, Va., in the suburbs of Washington. Hood was general broadcast editor and deputy director of broadcast services for The Associated Press, leaving in 1986 after 14 years with the company. After leaving the AP, he served for a time as vice president for broadcast services of United Press International. Hood said Zapnews subscribers would pay only for the scripts they order. His announcement at the National Press Club in Washington did not quote prices.
DOC.HEAD: Sportscaster Sorry for Heart Attack Remark
DOC.TEXT: A Portland television sportscaster has apologized for referring in a March 21 broadcast to Loyola Marymount's ``helter-skelter heart-attack'' basketball offense. The remark by KGW-TV sportscaster Eric Johnson as the team mourned the death of player Hank Gathers from heart disease drew calls from upset viewers. ``It certainly was an unfortunate choice of adjectives,'' Johnson said. ``I felt horrible and I still do.'' Johnson was reporting on Loyola Marymount's NCAA regional semifinal game with Alabama when he referred to the team's offense.
DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Named as Director of First Amendment Coalition
DOC.TEXT: A Sacramento lawyer has been appointed as the first executive director of the California First Amendment Coalition, responsible for offering advice in gaining access to public institutions. Terry Franke will assume his new duties in April, according to a statement released March 20 by Mel Opotowsky, president of the coalition and senior managing editor of The Press-Enterprise in Riverside. Franke has served as legal counsel for the California Newspaper Publishers Association in Sacramento since 1980. He has gained recognition as an authority on the public's right to attend government meetings, review public records and observe court proceedings. As executive director, he will operate a public ``hotline'' service and also will direct a membership and resources development program that is expected to include a series of educational seminars and other services. The coalition was formed in 1988 by journalism organizations concerned about the way public officials ignored state and federal laws requiring open meetings and access to government records.
DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Newspapers Official Leaves for LA Times
DOC.TEXT: Eugene Falk, executive vice president and general manager of Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., will become an executive vice president at the Los Angeles Times. Falk will oversee production, operations, information systems and the administrative and technical services of the Times. Falk, 46, joined PNI from the San Jose Mercury News in 1987 as a senior vice president. He was named executive vice president in 1988 and general manager in 1989.
DOC.HEAD: Montgomery Appointed Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Dennis Montgomery, former Associated Press bureau chief in Virginia, has been named managing editor of The Daily Progress, the newspaper announced March 19. Montgomery, 43, directed Virginia AP news operations from May 1985 to May 1989, when he left AP to write an account of hardships during the earliest years of the English settlement of Virginia.
DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Exec Named Newsweek Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Peter W. Eldredge, a Murdoch Magazines executive, has been named to head Newsweek's U.S. edition, it was announced March 22 by the magazine's worldwide publisher, Howard W. Smith. Smith at the same time announced his own planned retirement at the end of the year. Eldredge, who will become publisher of the U.S. edition of Newsweek on April 2, and Peter Luffman, president of Newsweek International, each will report directly to Newsweek President Alan G. Spoon, with no new worldwide publisher to be named, Smith said. The newsweekly, which is owned by the Washington Post Co., is in a fierce battle with Time and U.S. News & World Report for advertising and circulation. Newsweek's circulation was 3.2 million at the end of 1989, which puts it between Time, at 4.3 million, and U.S. News & World Report, at 2.2 million. Its ad revenues rose 5 percent to a record $253.8 million last year, according to a spokeswoman for the publication.
DOC.HEAD: Globe-Times Names Editor
DOC.TEXT: Robert S. Gallagher has been named editor and operations manager of The Globe-Times newspaper in Bethlehem, effective April 1. A New Jersey native, Gallagher, 56, has served as a senior editor at newspapers and magazines in New York, Connecticut, Michigan and Wisconsin. He is a frequent lecturer at the American Press Institute in Reston, Va., and has served as a teaching fellow on newspaper management, content and design at several colleges and universities.

DOC.HEAD: Topeka Capital-Journal Publisher Takes Florida Job
DOC.TEXT: Lee Porter, editor and publisher of The Topeka Capital-Journal, will become editor and publisher of the Winter Haven, Fla., News Chief on April 1. The announcement was made March 20 by Ken Bronson, vice president for newspapers of Stauffer Communications Inc., which owns the Capital-Journal and has agreed to buy the Florida newspaper. Porter, an assistant vice president of Stauffer, also will be responsible for the 11 Stauffer publications in Florida. He previously was editor and publisher of the group's newspapers in Shawnee and Ardmore, Okla., and was the company's director of operations for 10 Southern newspapers. Porter will be succeeded by Peter W. Stauffer, who has been executive editor since 1986. Stauffer previously was editor and publisher of the Independence (Mo.) Examiner from 1982 to 1986, and editor and publisher of the Glenwood Springs (Colo.) Post from 1977 to 1982. Stauffer also worked for the Kansas City Kansan and The Associated Press before joining the Capital-Journal staff in 1974.
DOC.HEAD: AP Names Kissel Correspondent in State College, Pa.
DOC.TEXT: Kelly Kissel, acting Associated Press correspondent in Huntington, W.Va., has been named correspondent in State College. The appointment was announced March 19 by Philadelphia Chief of Bureau George Zucker. Kissel, 30, joined the AP in New Orleans in 1984. He moved to the Jackson, Miss., bureau in 1985 and to Charleston, W.Va., later that year. He served as acting Huntington correspondent for several months in 1988 and returned to that post in May 1989. Kissel is a native of Omaha, Neb., and a 1984 graduate of Louisiana State University.
DOC.HEAD: York Daily Record Publisher Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Berl Schwartz resigned as editor and publisher of the York Daily Record on March 23, three weeks after he was promoted at the start of a joint operating agreement with The York Dispatch. David B. Martens, vice president of Buckner News Alliance, the Seattle parent company of the York Daily Record, declined to say why Schwartz resigned. Schwartz became editor of the Daily Record in October 1988 and was promoted when the two newspapers combined their business and production operations. The editorial departments remain separate and independent. Martens and Ned Cantwell, publisher of the Buckner-owned Carlsbad (N.M.) Current-Argus, will oversee the operation of the newspaper. McClure will be acting chief editorial executive.

Harry Gessing, who covered the police beat for 39 years for The Denver Post, died March 24 after a long illness. He was 75. Gessing was a 44-year veteran of the paper who covered the police beat from 1943 until he retired in 1982. His career spanned eight chiefs of police. ``He was the last of the old-time leg men,'' said Gary Gerhardt, a police reporter for the competing Rocky Mountain News during the 1960s and 1970s. ``He'd get the story and call the facts back to a rewrite man in the newsroom.'' Survivors include his wife of 48 years, Margaret Gorman Gessing; a daughter, two sons and eight grandchildren.

Dorothy Spence Illson, former copy chief at Life and Fortune magazines, died March 20 of lung cancer at New Rochelle Medical Center. She was 70. Mrs. Illson started at Life magazine in 1947 after teaching high school English in Iowa and serving with the Red Cross in the Pacific during World War II. She became chief of the Life copy room in 1972 and moved to Fortune a year later, where she helped convert the magazine to electronic typsetting. She retired in 1986. Mrs. Illson is survived by her husband, Murray Illson, a retired member of The New York Times news staff, three sons and a brother.

Ron E. Kramer, a reporter and photographer for The DailyNews in Iron Mountain for 25 years, died at his home of an apparent heart attack. Autopsy results indicate Kramer died March 16. His body was discovered at his Iron Mountain home the morning of March 19 by police after he failed to report to work. Kramer, 49, joined the News editorial staff November 1965 after being discharged from the Army, where he worked in public affairs and broadcasting. Survivors include a sister and a niece.

Gerald E. Mowery, retired chief of communications for The Associated Press in Ohio, died March 19 at Riverside Hospital. He was 78 and had been in ill health for several months. A native of Lawton, Okla., Mowery joined the AP as a junior operator in Columbus in 1929. He advanced to the position of automatic operator before moving into the technical field. Mowery transferred to Albuquerque, N.M., in 1938 and returned to Columbus a year later. He became head of the AP's technical operations in Ohio in 1957 and retired in 1976. Survivors include his wife, Kay, two sons, a daughter, 19 grandchildren and 34 great-grandchildren.

Detroit Free Press columnist Jim Neubacher, who became an outspoken advocate of handicapped rights after developing multiple sclerosis, died March 22. He was 40. Neubacher died at Providence Hospital in Southfield. He entered the hospital March 16 after lapsing into a coma at his parents' home in Oakland County's West Bloomfield Township. Neubacher joined the Free Press staff in 1971 after graduating from the University of Michigan. He worked as a city desk reporter and as the Free Press' first Canada correspondent and columnist. Neubacher's multiple sclerosis was diagnosed in 1980 at the age of 29. In 1982 he returned to Detroit and began to write his weekly column. Through his column, Disabled in Detroit, Neubacher battled for the rights of handicapped people. He became a leader for disabled activists across the state. Neubacher is survived by his parents, James and Margaret, a brother and three sisters.

Dewey Rand Sr., longtime publisher of the weekly Capital Press, died March 20 in Salem. He was 91. Rand joined the newspaper in his hometown of Baker while a high school student. He took over the Capital Press in 1946 after returning from the service in World War II, assuming control of the newspaper, which had been founded in 1928 by A.M. Church. Under Rand's leadership, the newspaper boasted of being the last Democratic newspaper in the state, appealing primarily to rural Oregon. During his years as publisher, Rand continued in other areas of service, including membership on the Oregon State Fair Commission. The Capital Press has a circulation of about 32,000.

News from the Gannett proxy statement: Chairman John J. Curley received $1,281,250 in salary and bonus in 1989. USA Today Publisher Cathleen Black earned $600,000 ... PBS's Jim Lehrer has a new novel out, called ``The Sooner Spy,'' with an Oklahoma backdrop. The MacNeil-Lehrer stalwart says writing ``is like a low-grade fever. It's there all the time.'' ... Facts on File Inc., a book publisher and information service to libraries, is being offered for sale, publishing executives tell The New York Times. The company made most of its money last year in its book publishing operation, which produced more than 100 titles ... In his autobiography ``Parting With Illusions,'' Soviet journalist Vladimir Pozner, dismissed by some in the past as a Kremlin apologist, includes a moving tribute to dissident patriarch Andrei Sakharov _ whose exile Pozner at one time supported.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: A man bounced from a Bronx social club for quarreling with an ex-girlfriend returned with a jug of gasoline and set a fire that killed 87 people at the nightspot, which had been ordered closed, police said. Most of the dead suffocated in thick smoke in the pre-dawn blaze Sunday, authorities said. Some people were trampled to death; others broke a hole through a wall to an adjoining hall in a desperate attempt to live. Emergency workers described bodies felled by smoke so quickly that they still had their legs wrapped around a bar stool, gripped drinks or held hands. Only three people managed to reach safety by way of the two tiny exit doors on the front of the two-story Happy Land social club. ``People literally were stacked on top of each other,'' said Anthony De Vita, the Fire Department's command chief. ``It was a firetrap.''

In Hungary's first free parliamentary elections in more than 40 years, voters overwhelmingly chose opposition candidates over the Communist reformers who ended one-party rule, partial results indicated today. It appeared likely that a coalition of opposition parties, who say they will not permit members of the long-ruling party in the new government, would be running the former Soviet client state. With 18 percent of the vote in from Sunday's balloting, the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum led with 23.8 percent and the liberal League of Free Democrats was second with 20.5 percent, the state news agency MTI said. The Independent Smallholders, a revived pre-World War II party popular in Hungary's villages, had 13.1 percent, with the Socialists, the successors to the Communists, trailing with 10 percent, MTI said.

Former Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood has left town and the voices of protest that marked the first anniversary of the nation's worst oil spill have quieted. Now, the legal cleanup begins. With more than 150 lawsuits on file against Exxon Corp., Hazelwood and others, Alaska's court calendars will be clogged for years to come. Exxon and Alyeska Pipeline Co., the oil company consortium that operates the trans-Alaska oil pipeline and Valdez terminal, also have been indicted by a federal grand jury on five criminal counts stemming from the grounding of the Exxon Valdez. The tanker hemorrhaged nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and fouling the rocky shore for hundreds of miles.

After months of appearing paralyzed by President Bush's high poll ratings, the Democrats have shifted into a campaign mode and begun to sound like a party ready to challenge Bush in the 1992 election. During weekend meetings in New Orleans and Indianapolis, the Democrats took on the popular Republican president on a range of domestic issues including Social Security, the environment, abortion and education. The party's newly aggressive stance was not arrived at easily. It exposed the differing approaches of state party officials hungry for effective campaign issues and the congressional wing, whose members must often search for compromises with their Republican colleagues and the White House. Regardless of their differences on specific issues, the Democrats clearly agreed with party Chairman Ronald H. Brown's assessment that the president has been getting a ``free ride'' and that it was time to challenge him.

Losing weight is a growing business, and the $33 billion Americans spent to shed pounds last year usually brought poor and sometimes life-threatening results, a House subcommittee chairman and staff charged. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., said federal agencies have failed to provide adequate consumer protection or guarantee medical safety in the unregulated diet business _ including popular liquid diets. ``The result has been a tidal wave of false and misleading advertising in a field already awash in gross over-promotion,''' he said. Wyden was opening a hearing today on the issue by his House Small Business subcommittee on regulation.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Wednesday PMs, March 28 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: August Wilson Turns His Eye on the '60s
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The setting is a tiny Pittsburgh restaurant a month after the death of Martin Luther King Jr., but August Wilson's latest work in his cycle of plays about black America is not about the turbulent 1960s. ``People have written so much about the '60s, so I didn't need to do that. I went at it obliquely,'' said Wilson, whose play, ``Two Trains Running,'' premieres March 30 at the Yale Repertory Theater. In his fifth collaboration with director Lloyd Richards, the acclaimed playwright returns to a dominant theme in all his works: To have a future, blacks in America must first define who they are by reclaiming their past. ``Unless you reconnect to your past, make some accommodation to your past, fully understand your history in the world, you can't have a future,'' said the 44-year-old Wilson. ``Two Trains Running,'' its title taken from a blues song of the same name, is filled with references to death. One of the restaurant's patrons is an undertaker, whose funeral parlor is across the street. As the characters talk about the conditions of their lives, Wilson said, ``what you find is people are dying. Infant mortality rates are high, police are shooting people, drugs are killing people. Everyone is dying young. ``Quickly what you discover is that the real problem is the economic problem. There simply are not any jobs for any of these people in Pittsburgh in 1968. You could have written the same thing for the 1980s. Things haven't changed at all. They have actually got worse.'' Wilson was born in Pittsburgh but has lived in St. Paul, Minn., since 1978. In the play, everything seems to be working against Memphis, the restaurant owner, and the other characters. Memphis is a former sharecropper who was run out of Mississippi in 1931 and whose restaurant is about to be torn down. But in the middle of all this loss and death is that which does not die _ tradition. The main characters tap into that by going to see Aunt Esther, a woman who claims to be 322 years old. Aunt Esther, an offstage character, ``will make you right with your self,'' said Wilson, who with his raspy smoker's voice frequently draws from the play's dialogue to illustrate a point. ``Aunt Esther tells Memphis if he drops the ball, there is no need to continue to run because if you get to the end zone there is not going to be a touchdown. You've got to go back and pick up the ball. Each of the characters gets the same message. You've got to go back and claim what is yours before you can go forward.'' At a meat market next to the funeral home, a man walks in and tells the owner, ```I want my ham.' He says, `take a chicken.' For the past nine years every morning this guy has been showing up. For me that represents black America standing patiently outside the door of American society in 1968 and prior to that. I want my ham. I want my ham,'' Wilson said. While ``Two Trains Running'' is set in the '60s, Wilson's other major works have addressed issues facing American blacks during other decades of this century. All have premiered at Yale, with Richards directing. The theatrical partnership began in 1984 with ``Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' (1920s), and continued with ``Fences'' (1950s), ``Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' (1910-20) and ``The Piano Lesson'' (1930s), which opens on Broadway on April 16. Wilson won a Tony and the Pulitzer Prize for ``Fences.'' Richards received a Tony for best director for the play. Wilson also won the New York Drama Critics Circle Award for three of his plays. With Richards' tenure as dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director at the Yale Rep ending in June 1991, ``Two Trains'' could be the last of Wilson's plays to have its premiere at Yale. But Wilson said it definitely will not be their last collaboration: ``Wherever he goes, that's where I'm going.'' The collaboration has made his string of plays seem seamless, he said. ``They are all the same in the sense you have the same artistic sensibilities working on the play. ``We've developed over the course of the years a kind of shorthand way of working. There is not a lot of talking that goes on.'' Wilson believes he is getting better with each play he writes. He said myth and ritual are also growing to be larger elements, citing the tall tale of the 3-century-old woman as an example. ``I've learned a lot about building characters. I know what is important now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Sunday, April 1, the 91st day of 1990. There are 274 days left in the year. This is April Fool's Day. A reminder: Daylight-Saving Time is in effect in most parts of the country. Clocks should have been set forward one hour. Today's highlight in history: On April 1, 1789, the U.S. House of Representatives held its first full meeting, in New York City. Frederick Muhlenberg of Pennsylvania was elected the first House Speaker. On this date: In 1853, Cincinnati, Ohio, became the first U.S. city to pay its firefighters a regular salary. In 1873, composer Sergei Rachmaninoff was born in Novgorod Province, Russia. In 1918, the Royal Air Force was established in Britain. In 1933, Nazi Germany began its persecution of Jews with a boycott of Jewish-owned businesses. In 1939, the United States recognized the Franco government in Spain following the end of the Spanish civil war. In 1945, American forces launched the invasion of Okinawa during World War II. In 1960, the first weather satellite, TIROS 1, was launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla. In 1963, most of New York City's daily newspapers resumed publishing after settlement was reached in a 114-day strike. In 1977, the Senate followed the example of the House by adopting a stringent code of ethics requiring full financial disclosure and limits on outside income. In 1983, tens of thousands of anti-nuclear demonstrators linked arms in a 14-mile human chain spanning three defense installations in rural England, including the Greenham Common U.S. Air Base. In 1984, recording star Marvin Gaye was shot to death by his father, Marvin Gay Sr., in Los Angeles. The elder Gay pleaded guilty to voluntary manslaughter, and received probation. Ten years ago: President Carter told reporters he'd decided to delay imposing additional economic sanctions against Iran in hopes of resolving the hostage crisis. Carter and Ronald Reagan won the Wisconsin and Kansas primaries. An 11-day transit strike began in New York City. Five years ago: In a major upset, the Villanova Wildcats won the NCAA championship by defeating the Georgetown Hoyas 66-64 in Lexington, Ky. One year ago: Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper announced that a ``strike force'' of state officials and local fishermen were taking over some of the cleanup operations following the massive Exxon Valdez oil spill. Today's birthdays: Actor Toshiro Mifune is 70. Author William Manchester is 68. Actor George Grizzard is 62. Actress Jane Powell is 61. Actor Gordon Jump is 58. Actress Debbie Reynolds is 58. Actor Don Hastings is 56. Actress Ali MacGraw is 52. David Eisenhower is 43. Thought for today: ``Let us be thankful for the fools. But for them the rest of us could not succeed.'' _ Mark Twain (1835-1910).
DOC.NOTE: End Advance for Use Sunday, April 1

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Monday, April 2, the 92nd day of 1990. There are 273 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On April 2, 1917, President Wilson asked Congress to declare war against Germany, saying, ``The world must be made safe for democracy.'' On this date: In 1513, Spanish explorer Juan Ponce de Leon landed in Florida. In 1792, Congress authorized establishment of the U.S. Mint. In 1805, storyteller Hans Christian Andersen was born in Odense, Denmark. In 1834, Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, the sculptor who created the Statue of Liberty, was born in Colmar, France. In 1860, the first Italian Parliament met at Turin. In 1865, Confederate President Jefferson Davis and most of his Cabinet fled the Confederate capital of Richmond, Va. In 1872, Samuel F.B. Morse, developer of the electric telegraph, died in New York. In 1932, aviator Charles A. Lindbergh and Dr. John F. Condon turned over $50,000 to an unidentified man in a New York City cemetery as ransom for Lindbergh's kidnapped son. In 1956, the soap operas ``As the World Turns'' and ``The Edge of Night'' made their premieres on CBS television. In 1974, French President Georges Pompidou died in Paris. In 1982, several thousand troops from Argentina seized the disputed Falkland Islands from Britain. In 1983, Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko rejected President Reagan's proposal for reducing medium-range missiles in Europe, saying the plan was ``unacceptable on all counts.'' In 1986, four Americans were killed when a bomb exploded aboard a TWA jetliner that was en route from Rome to Athens, Greece. In 1986, Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace announced he was retiring from public life. Ten years ago: The prime rate _ the interest rate charged by commercial banks to lowest-risk corporate customers _ rose to 20 percent, continuing an unprecedented upward climb. Five years ago: President Reagan announced the nomination of Clayton Yeutter, president and chief executive of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, to become the U.S. trade representative, replacing labor secretary-designate William Brock. One year ago: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev began a visit to Cuba amid differences with President Fidel Castro over the reforms Gorbachev was instituting in the Soviet Union. Today's birthdays: Actor Buddy Ebsen is 82. Producer Irene Mayer Selznick is 80. Actor Sir Alec Guinness is 76. The Archbishop of Chicago, Cardinal Joseph Bernardin, is 62. Actress Sharon Acker is 55. Singer Emmylou Harris is 42. Actress Debralee Scott is 37. Actor Ron Palillo is 36. Thought for today: ``The only sure thing about luck is that it will change.'' _ Bret Harte, American author and journalist (1836-1902).
DOC.NOTE: End Advance for Use Monday, April 2

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Tuesday, April 3, the 93rd day of 1990. There are 272 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On April 3, 1860, the legendary Pony Express began service between St. Joseph, Mo., and Sacramento, Calif. The service lasted only 1{ years before giving way to the transcontinental telegraph. On this date: In 1776, George Washington received an honorary doctor of laws degree from Harvard College. In 1783, Washington Irving, author of ``Rip Van Winkle'' and ``The Legend of Sleepy Hollow,'' was born in New York City. In 1865, Union forces occupied the Confederate capital of Richmond, Va., during the Civil War.
