DOC.TEXT: Movie director David Lynch, known for his dark and surreal portraits of contemporary America, is making his first venture into television with ``Twin Peaks,'' a new wave Gothic soap opera. The two-hour pilot for ``Twin Peaks'' will be televised by ABC on Sunday and the one-hour drama series begins its regular run on Thursday. Lynch, who has his own little shop of horrors with such films as ``Eraserhead,'' ``Blue Velvet'' and the upcoming ``Wild at Heart,'' says, ``My partner, Mark Frost, and I were fishing for ideas for television and we hit on making it a soap opera with a murder mystery. ``When we talked about television the main pull for me was being able to do a continuing story. One where you can really get to know the people.'' The two main characters are the murder investigators, FBI Agent Dale Cooper, played by Kyle MacLachlan of Lynch's ``Blue Velvet'' and ``Dune,'' and Sheriff Harry S. Truman, played by Michael Ontkean. Laura Palmer is the murder victim. ``It opens with the murder. Laura Palmer is like the center of a little universe of people. What was she up to when she was murdered? Her death is a great way to get into the lives of the other characters. It'll take quite a while to resolve.'' The series has a large ensemble cast, including Joan Chen, Piper Laurie, Madchen Amick, Dana Ashbrook, Richard Beymer, Lara Flynn Boyle, Sherilyn Fenn, Warren Frost, James Marshall, Everett McGill, Jack Nance, Ray Wise, Russ Tamblyn and Peggy Lipton _ who is in her first series since ``The Mod Squad.'' Set in a Pacific Northwest lumber mill town, ``Twin Peaks'' is ripping good fun. FBI Agent Cooper, who's fascinated by the tall trees, dictates his every thought into a small tape recorder. Joan Chen, as the mill owner, is an exotic but determined Dragon Lady. Everybody in town has a nasty little secret, and the lid keeps popping off at inappropriate times. It's all done with a straight face, but the impression is that Lynch is laughing up his sleeve. Lynch says he often puts comedy into his work, and in the future he hopes to do a comedy called ``One Saliva Bubble.'' Frost is a former writer for ``Hill Street Blues,'' which mixed black comedy with gritty drama. ``I like light and dark,'' Lynch says. ``I like a film that has contrast so you can feel both sides. I believe people tend to remember my films as darker than they really are. I think people identify with a struggle. We like the idea of overcoming obstacles in our path. I'm kind of interested in that. ``I believe in a strong story and one that is easily followed. Once the audience is pulled in by the story, you can throw in a few curves. As long as you don't throw them off the track. I like curve balls.'' Despite his fascination with such stories, Lynch looks relentlessly ordinary. His dark brown hair is combed straight back and he wears a black coat over a white shirt that is buttoned to the top. He has a slight facial resemblance to John Larroquette of ``Night Court.'' ``Twin Peaks'' reflects his small town upbringing. He was born in Montana and grew up in the Pacific Northwest and Virginia. His father moved often as a research scientist for the Department of Agriculture. Lynch is a man of strong habits. He frequents the same places and orders the same food day after day, with a preference for junk food. He also tends to use the same actors in his films. MacLachlan starred in ``Dune'' and ``Blue Velvet.'' Jack Nance, the man who finds Laura Palmer's body in ``Twin Peaks,'' has been in every Lynch film except ``The Elephant Man.'' Laura Dern and Isabella Rossellini, Lynch's current romantic interest, were in ``Blue Velvet'' and the new ``Wild at Heart.'' Lynch says he got into television at the urging of his agent, Tony Krantz. ``We kept telling him to go away, but one day we started getting some ideas,'' he says. ``The ideas were perfect for television. ``I really liked working on television. It's very fast. The cast and the crew and everyone helped make it a great experience. I learned a lot about working fast. I like the momentum and the feeling of having to go more quickly. As long as you don't go so fast you hurt the picture.'' Lynch acknowledges that film critics have analyzed his work, but says he operates by a simple credo. ``Be true to the story and the ideas in translating them to the screen,'' he says. ``If you're true to that you will have an honest picture. The rest is up to the audience. They have the final say.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 2 b&w photos.)
DOC.TEXT: From ``Cats'' to ``Nicholas Nickleby'' to ``Aspects of Love,'' Trevor Nunn is among the world's most successful and sought-after directors of both plays and musicals. But blockbuster shows constitute only one aspect of his eclectic career. Shakespeare's plays, T.S. Eliot's verse, a musical about chess, an obscure English novel _ everything is fodder for Nunn's vision of the stage as ``a great populist meeting place.'' ``I'm interested in theater in all its forms, and theater audiences in all their forms,'' the bearded 50-year-old director said one evening after work at his office in London's theater district, where he has four musicals running at the same time. ``Cats,'' based on the T.S. Eliot poems, has been running since 1981; ``Starlight Express,'' a show that casts actors as trains, opened in 1984; ``Les Miserables,'' the Victor Hugo novel-turned-musical, co-directed by John Caird, followed in 1985; and last year came ``Aspects of Love,'' based on a little-known 1950s English novel about the complex entanglements of five lovers. But for 18 years he also headed or co-headed the Royal Shakespeare Company, one of Britain's two major state-subsidized theaters. He left it in 1986, but retains the title ``director emeritus.'' Accordingly, his credits present an intriguing mix of ``Romeo and Juliet'' and roller-skating trains; ``Hedda Gabler'' and anthropomorphized cats; ``Aspects'' and ``All's Well That Ends Well''; ``Les Miserables'' and ``Macbeth.'' ``I don't like categories; I don't like signatures,'' says Nunn, defining a career that began at Cambridge University where he directed the Footlights' Revue. ``I don't see any disparity between different types of work. To have eclecticism only requires a theater community with sufficient variety and sufficient promotion of that variety.'' Whether directing the Bard in Stratford-upon-Avon or a mammoth musical on Broadway, Nunn feels, ``There's no point in doing it for the critics or the already converted.'' But it's musicals that have given Nunn fame and wealth, most often in conjunction with composer Andrew Lloyd Webber. In 1981, they paired up on a song cycle of Eliot's ``Old Possum's Poems for Practical Cats,'' which Lloyd Webber thought might make a charming children's entertainment. Theater insiders were disdainful, but the result was ``Cats,'' currently purring its way toward a gross of over $460 million in the United States alone. Nunn says the show married a love of language to his long-standing interest in musicals. Indeed, he had turned down several previous offers that didn't seem right, including ``42nd Street'' on Broadway, which he felt an American should do. During ``Cats'' rehearsals, Lloyd Webber gave Nunn a copy of the 1955 novel ``Aspects of Love,'' by David Garnett. Nine years later, their musical version, still running in London, is now playing at the Broadhurst Theater in New York. The show concerns a lovestruck quintet pursuing their emotionally dangerous liaisons in the south of France. Four of its stars originated their parts on the West End. Michael Ball, a Briton making his Broadway debut, plays Alex, an English army recruit whose love for a French actress (Ann Crumb) shapes his entire life. Kevin Colson is Alex's dilettantish uncle, George. Kathleen Rowe McAllen plays George's Italian mistress Giulietta. ``It's a piece of work interested in character, and the character is artfully and cleverly and touchingly presented,'' Nunn says. As production costs rise on Broadway and critical pressures mount, Lloyd Webber is one of the few theater artists whose box-office clout makes him impervious to the reviews, which can be harsh. Nunn's career has ridden its own critical roller coaster. In London, plaudits have been tempered with accusations that he has sold out to the commercial theater, sacrificing first-rate work in the classics for the ready money of the major musical. On Broadway, both ``Starlight Express'' and ``Chess'' were poorly received. ``Many of the things I've done have run long periods of time no thanks to critical reactions, which were frequently very hostile,'' he says. ``Therefore I have every reason to trust the general public.'' By and large, that public has confirmed his trust. ``Nicholas Nickleby,'' an adaptation of the Charles Dickens novel, opened to lukewarm reviews in London in 1980, then became a popular favorite on both sides of the Atlantic, despite a Broadway top ticket of $100. ``Les Miserables,'' adapted from Victor Hugo's epic novel, got mixed reviews at its 1985 London bow, but swept the 1987 Tony Awards on Broadway and won international acclaim. Occasionally, Nunn misjudges. His staging of ``Chess,'' the Tim Rice-ABBA musical, ran more than three years on the West End but a scant 10 weeks on Broadway in 1988. A Broadway revival of ``Nicholas Nickleby'' also flopped. In January, Nunn's London production of the American musical ``The Baker's Wife'' closed after 56 performances at a loss of almost $1.7 million. Its flop was ``very disappointing _ denting as well as daunting,'' he says. The musical starred his second wife, Australian performer Sharon Lee Hill, in the lead role. The couple, who met when she appeared in ``Cats,'' have two daughters. He has a son by his previous wife, actress Janet Suzman. Away from the high-stakes world of musicals, Nunn continues to mount landmark productions of the classics. Last fall, he returned to the Royal Shakespeare Company to stage ``Othello,'' with opera singer Willard White as the jealous Moor and Ian McKellen as his nemesis, Iago. Nunn has also triumphed with more obscure Shakespeare works. His 1982 ``All's Well That Ends Well,'' seen in London and New York, made one of the Bard's so-called ``problem plays'' hauntingly clear and poignant. Plans for the future include another collaboration with David Edgar, who adapted ``Nicholas Nickleby,'' and a staging of Shakespeare's ``Twelfth Night,'' which Nunn calls ``one of the unassailable masterpieces of the Western world.''

UAL Corp.'s board of directors said it will let former suitor Marvin Davis again buy company stock, raising the possibility of a rival buyout offer to the $3.8 billion bid by UAL's unions and a major shareholder. Davis sparked a bidding war for UAL last August but later withdrew his buyout proposals after the company, the parent of United Airlines, accepted a higher offer from a group led by senior management and its pilots union. That plan later collapsed. UAL stock finished up $5.12{ at $157.87{ Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, although Coniston Partners, UAL's biggest shareholder and the backer of the union buyout, expressed skepticism that Davis would make an offer.

Former Exxon Valdez Capt. Joseph Hazelwood was sentenced to help clean up Prince William Sound and pay $50,000 in restitution to the state by a judge who criticized his lack of contrition. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone, in sentencing Hazelwood to 1,000 hours of community service by cleaning beaches, said Friday he was disappointed that the fired skipper had not publicly apologized for his role in the nation's worst oil spill.

Negotiators reported the first breakthrough in a host of contentious trade disputes with Japan: an agreement designed to open the Japanese market to American-made supercomputers. Officials at the U.S. trade office said Friday they achieved major concessions that should boost supercomputer sales in the important Japanese government market, estimated to total about $130 million annually.

Sales of North American-built cars and trucks tumbled 9.5 percent in mid-March compared with a weak period last year, reflecting the absence of big rebates, especially on trucks. The nine major automakers with U.S. plants said Friday they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 35,497 during March 11-20 this year, compared with a rate of 39,225 during the same period last year. Car sales slipped 8.9 percent while truck sales were down 10.6 percent.

Orders for home appliances, machinery and other major durable goods rose 3.3 percent last month, the government said. The Commerce Department said Friday that orders to U.S. factories for durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ totaled a seasonally adjusted $121.6 billion.

President Bush's savings and loan bailout got a reprieve when a federal appeals court paved the way for the government to seize a suburban Chicago thrift institution. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit lifted a lower court order Friday that had barred the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision from taking control of Olympic Savings and Loan Association of Berwyn, Ill. However, it forbade regulators from liquidating the thrift and selling its $1.1 billion in assets.

Looming, junk-bond related debt problems are threatening Ingersoll Publications, owner of the new St. Louis Sun newspaper and a host of other publications. So far, a plan by owner Ralph Ingersoll II to buy back some of the company's junk bonds at cut-rate prices is not receiving a warm welcome from analysts and bondholders. ``The bonds are not worth 100 cents on the dollar, but they're certainly worth more than what the company is offering,'' Stephen Unterhalter, senior analyst with R.D. Smith Co. in New York, said Friday.

A Treasury Department official nominated to the Federal Reserve Board promised he would exercise independent judgment rather than serve as an agent of the administration's push to lower interest rates. David W. Mullins Jr. made the pledge Friday before the Senate Banking Committee. He is assistant Treasury secretary and one of the architects of President Bush's savings and loan bailout.

The pork people say their products are just as nutritious as chicken, turkey and fish, but a private group says that's hogwash and is asking the government to do something about it. The Center for Science in the Public Interest said an advertising campaign by the National Pork Producers Council _ which touts pork as ``the other white meat'' _ is ``deceptive and dangerously misleading.'' His group filed a petition Friday asking the Federal Trade Commission to stop the pork council's claims and require advertising corrections. ``We're confident that our advertising is accurate and can be backed up by substantial scientific evidence,'' said Barry Pfouts, director of marketing for the pork council.

The stock market rose modestly Friday, recovering from three straight days of declines as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 8.56 points to 2,704.28. Bond prices posted small gains after a volatile session. The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen but finished higher against other major currencies. Gold futures prices tumbled to 4{-month lows; silver retreated; grains and soybeans fell; energy future advanced and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Producers Expect Weaker Prices in Second Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subroto one word is cq throughout
DOC.TEXT: The price of crude oil should fall in the April-June quarter before rising in the last half of the year, the world's leading oil producers believe. OPEC Secretary-General Subroto said Sunday the 13 Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and more than a dozen independent oil producers differed on how steep the price fall would be but agreed it would not be sharp. ``In the short term we foresee some weakness in the second quarter. But in the third and fourth quarter the market will strengthen,'' Subroto said. ``Everybody seems to agree there will not be a dramatic change in price.'' Subroto made the comments to reporters during a conference of experts from OPEC and independent producers including the Soviet Union and Norway, the U.S. oil-producing states of Alaska and Texas, and the Canadian province of Alberta. Over the longer term, Subroto said delegates expected world crude oil demand to grow about 3.2 percent to 3.3 percent per year. But he said there also were differences of opinion on that subject. The experts met over the weekend following an OPEC ministerial meeting in Vienna last week. The cartel voted to maintain a production ceiling of 22 million barrels per day for the April-June quarter. Oil prices have fallen since the OPEC meeting because of lack of firm guarantees by member states not to overshoot individual production quotas and because of the end of high winter demand. OPEC is believed to be producing about 1 million barrels a day more of crude oil than the market can absorb. OPEC ministers are to meet meet May 25 to consider production and pricing policy for the cartel for the second half of 1990. Delegates to the Muscat conference said no decisions were made on production or pricing policies. Oman, which is not an OPEC member, has played a major role in generating support of other independents to restrict oil output and help OPEC's targeted prices. Omani Minister of Petroleum and Minerals Saeed Ahmed Shanfari said ``common understanding'' was still needed between the two blocs on short-, medium- and long-term policies even though world oil demand was rising. ``We've proved that the independent oil producers and exporters are serious in their efforts and are ready to shoulder part of the responsibility with OPEC to achieve stability of the market and its prices,'' he said Saturday. OPEC, faced with a collapsing oil market in 1986, pressed for the support of major producers outside the cartel to coordinate output to stabilize prices around $18 a barrel. But rising world demand helped strengthen prices beyond $18. A 1988 conference similar to the one in Muscat produced an agreement for a self-imposed 5 percent production cutback to bolster OPEC efforts. The market has steadily improved with an unexpected rise in demand induced by dwindling production levels in the United States and the Soviet Union, as well as other majors. Tapping into possible high demand from Eastern Europe also is being considered.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Up, Gold Sharply Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies except the British pound in early European trading today. Gold prices fell sharply. Foreign currency dealers said trading was a little nervous because of continued yen weakness and market fears about tensions in the independence-minded Baltic republics of the Soviet Union. ``The Lithuania situation is keeping everybody on the edge,'' said one trader at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt, West Germany. ``As long as there is the threat of military conflict, the dollar will remain firm.'' Traders said the dollar was also benefiting from the weakness of the yen following a largely uneventful meeting Friday between U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan. ``Brady made it clear he doesn't want to go to extraordinary lengths for the yen,'' said a trader in Milan, Italy. ``The view is that the yen's weakness is tied to uncertainties about the stock market and fiscal year-end considerations.'' The dollar's scope for upward movement is limited by fear of central bank intervention, traders said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.33 yen to 156.40 yen, its highest close since Jan. 13, 1987. Later, in London, it was quoted at 155.98 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.7165 West German marks, up from 1.7100; 1.5195 Swiss francs, up from 1.5179; 5.7725 French francs, up from 5.7645; 1.9230 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9249; 1,261.00 Italian lire, up from 1,258.50; and 1.1765 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1751. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6127, compared with $1.6040 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $388.50 a troy ounce, up from $386.95 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $379.25. In Zurich, the bid price was $378.00, down $15.05 from late Friday's $393.05. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $5.49 to close at a bid $384.94. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.03 a troy ounce, from Friday's $5.04.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Index Up 5 Percent; Dollar Gains
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index soared by nearly 5 percent today in its second-biggest single-day rise ever, while the dollar gained more against the Japanese yen despite central bank intervention. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 528.82 points last Friday, surged 1,468.33 points, or 4.83 percent, today closing at 31,840.49. The gain was second only to the 2,037.32-point rise on Oct. 21, 1987, when shares prices rebounded from the worldwide ``Black Monday'' crash. Last Monday, the index dived 1,353.20 points at the start of a three-day plunge that took the index below 30,000 before it began rebounding Friday. Many investors believed the index had bottomed out last week, when it fell a total of 2,773.1 points in three days, securities dealers said. ``Shares were broadly bought in anticipation of the actual start of the new fiscal year,'' a dealer with Nomura Securities said on condition of anonymity. Japan's fiscal year formally begins on April 1, but after today, new contracts are counted under the new fiscal year. While share prices rose almost across the board, construction and electric power issues led the gains. Blue-chip electrical shares, such as Toshiba, Hitachi and Sony, were also big gainers. Volume traded on the first section of the exchange was estimated at 700 million shares, compared with last Friday's 668.98 million shares. On the currency market, the dollar closed at 156.40 yen, up 1.33 yen from last Friday's close of 155.07 yen. After opening at 155.65 yen, it ranged between 155.50 yen and 156.40 yen. The dollar's close was its highest since 156.00 on Jan. 13, 1987. It now has gained 4.20 yen in the last seven trading days. Previously, the weak yen has been cited as one factor behind declining stock prices. The sagging bond market was another. The price of benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds, due June 1999, finished today at 86.82 yen, up 0.22 yen from Friday's close of 86.60 points, with the yield dropping 0.045 percentage points to 7.170 percent. Currency dealers attributed the dollar's strength today to the market's disappointment over Friday's talks between Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicolas Brady in Los Angeles. ``Nothing came out of the the talks'' that would help stabilize exchange rates, said Naoto Kawamura, a senior dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Hashimoto and Brady said in a statement that they discussed a range of issues and remained committed to ``cooperation in the exchange markets,'' a reference to efforts to stop the yen's slide against the dollar. The Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, sold up to $1 billion in efforts to support the yen, traders estimated. The bank does not comment on its market intervention activities. ``Due to the relatively weak position on market intervention by the monetary authorities, the bullish sentiment toward the dollar remains strong,'' said Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitui Bank. Yoshida said speculators accounted for most of today's early dollar-buying.

DOC.HEAD: Legal Cleanup Begins in Exxon Valdez Disaster
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `Hazelwood, the...', to CLARIFY charges against Hazelwood.
DOC.TEXT: Former Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood has left town and the voices of protest that marked the first anniversary of the nation's worst oil spill have quieted. Now, the legal cleanup begins. With more than 150 lawsuits on file against Exxon Corp., Hazelwood and others, Alaska's court calendars will be clogged for years to come. Exxon and Alyeska Pipeline Co., the oil company consortium that operates the trans-Alaska oil pipeline and Valdez terminal, also have been indicted by a federal grand jury on five criminal counts stemming from the grounding of the Exxon Valdez. The tanker hemorrhaged nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and fouling the rocky shore for hundreds of miles. As many as 75 people marked the anniversary Saturday with a protest outside Alyeska headquarters in Anchorage. Someone splattered the building with a plastic bag filled with chocolate syrup _ intended to symbolize spilled crude. Environmental groups held low-key events to raise money for spill-prevention efforts and to pursue Valdez-related lawsuits. Gov. Steve Cowper called n Exxon to settle quickly the flood of lawsuits filed by environmental groups, fishermen, native Alaskans and the state. The lawsuits are not scheduled for trial until 1992. If Exxon does not settle all valid spill-related lawsuits, litigation could drag on into the next century, Cowper said. A lawyer coordinating the lawsuits said he wants to set a precedent. ``We have to make it unprofitable to pollute,'' said attorney Macon Cowles of Boulder, Colo. The National Wildlife Federation, Natural Resources Defense Fund and other plaintiffs want Exxon to set up a fund to pay for environmental damage assessment, restoration and the purchase of wildlife preserves. Cowles said he might even try to collect damages on behalf of plants and animals. ``We're trying to come up with a way to put a value on the devastation to life,'' he said. Cowles said it might take 10 years to assess that damage. Hazelwood, the only individual charged criminally in the spill, was convicted last Thursday of a state misdemeanor charge of neglegent discharge of oil, but was acquitted of second-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment and operating ship under the influence of alcohol. In an emotional hearing on Friday, Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone sentenced the skipper to spend 1,000 hours helping to clean up oiled beaches. He also ordered Hazelwood to pay $50,000 in restitution. Hazelwood's lawyers said they would appeal the conviction and the highly unusual sentence, which they asserted was harsher than the law allows. The judge said he will stay Hazelwood's sentence once the appeal is filed. In an interview before he left Alaska, Hazelwood said he was troubled by the enormous environmental devastation in Prince William Sound. ``It was terrible,'' he said. ``It's like any devastation. It's like Chernobyl or medical waste washing up on my back yard in Long Island (N.Y.). ... It was a terrible tragedy. There's no getting around it.'' But Hazelwood, 43, was prevented from giving his own view of what caused the Exxon Valdez to run aground on Bligh Reef. His lawyers feared his comments might affect the outcome of the lawsuits against him. Meanwhile, the Coast Guard plans to hold hearings on whether Hazelwood's maritime master's license should be suspended, renewed or revoked, Coast Guard Commandant Paul Yost said. But Yost appeared to partially absolve Hazelwood of responsibility, saying, ``A fully qualified third mate ran the vessel aground.'' Hazelwood was below deck when the accident occurred. Third mate Gregory Cousins was on the bridge, directing a helmsman at the wheel. Jurors in Hazelwood's trial rejected the claim that the skipper was reckless to leave the bridge in Cousins' control. In the federal indictments, Exxon is charged with staffing the tanker with people who were physically or mentally incapable of performing their duties. Hazelwood's acquittal could weigh in the company's favor on that charge.

DOC.HEAD: Petition Filed to Decertify Union Local at Nordstrom
DOC.TEXT: A petition has been filed to decertify the union representing employees at Nordstrom Inc.'s Tacoma store, the retailer said. Nordstrom said Sunday that it was notified of the filing by the National Labor Relations Board. The store has 310 employees represented by Local 367 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union. To hold a decertification election, at least 30 percent of the employees in a bargaining unit must sign the petition. A union leader said Sunday that the petition was expected and was an attempt by Nordstrom to divert attention from its problems. ``I don't think it's serious,'' said Joe Peterson, president of UFCW Local 1001 in Seattle. Nordstrom, an upscale department store retailer with a near-legendary reputation for customer service, has been embroiled in a bitter fight with the UFCW over labor relations and pay practices. Last month, the state Department of Labor and Industries, acting on a UFCW complaint, ruled Nordstrom had violated state laws by failing to pay some employees for attending meetings, delivering merchandise, checking inventory, writing thank-you notes to customers, and doing other chores outside normal working hours. Later, the NLRB accused the company of bypassing the union and bargaining directly with employees over whether they are owed back wages. Union complaints on other issues remain under NLRB review. The union also filed a class-action lawsuit accusing the company of wage and hour violations. Since June 1989, Nordstrom has been seeking changes in contracts with locals 367 and 1001 in Seattle to allow employees to choose whether to join the union. The UFCW only represents employees in the Seattle and Tacoma area, out of 60 Nordstrom stores and 30,000 employees in six states. In a news release Sunday, the store said that position ``ignited the union's expensive, nationally funded smear campaign against Nordstrom.'' ``It is apparent that many of our employees are unhappy with their union and feel the UFCW has been inaccurately representing their views,'' said Joe Demarte, Nordstrom's corporate personnel director. ``They have been forced to take matters into their own hands. ``We hope an election date will be set promptly, although we fully anticipate the union will file a string of unfair labor practice charges to delay and block the decertification process.'' Peterson had said earlier that the union was preparing more federal labor charges after receiving complaints of management pressure to sign statements supporting Nordstrom, to participate in rallies for the company and to join the decertification campaign. ``Nordstrom is attempting to divert attention from its problems by suggesting its employees don't support our efforts,'' Peterson said. ``The fact is most Nordstrom employees have gone underground in fear of reprisals or of being blacklisted.'' NLRB spokesman Larry McCargar said the agency probably would not act on any decertification petitions until pending unfair labor practices complaints are resolved.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Stalled Nuclear Plant Reaches Power Milestone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Operators briefly...', to CORRECT date of shutdown to Thursday sted Friday.
DOC.TEXT: Seabrook nuclear power plant operators brought the reactor past 5 percent power for the first time as they gear up for long-delayed commercial operation. Opponents, meanwhile, are preparing another appeal they hope will pull the plug on the $6.5 billion plant. Seabrook initially was planned to generate electricity commercially in 1979 at a fraction of the cost but was completed in 1986 and licensed only this month. Plant operators brought the 1,150-megawatt reactor above 5 percent power Sunday evening, spokesman Ron Sher said. During low-power atomic testing in June the reactor remained below 5 percent power. Sher said power would stay between 8 percent and 10 percent for several weeks to test turbines that will drive electrical generators. Seabrook officials have estimated it would take two to three months to bring the reactor to 100 percent power. After repeated construction cost overruns and regulatory delays focusing largely on evacuation plans for crowded beaches less than two miles from the plant, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved Seabrook's commercial license on March 1. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington declined to block the license on March 14, though it has yet to rule on Seabrook opponents' appeals. The commission signed the license the next day and plant operators started the reactor Tuesday. Operators briefly shut down the reactor Thursday because of a false electrical alarm. A commission inspector called the shutdown conservative. A tardy shutdown during last year's low-power testing is the subject of an appeal that Seabrook foes will argue before an NRC panel this week. New Hampshire Yankee, Seabrook's operator, acknowledged improperly delaying the shutdown after a valve malfunctioned June 22, and plant management was realigned. But Seabrook officials said it was an isolated problem. An NRC Atomic Safety and Licensing Board ruled in October that the delayed shutdown was not a ``significant safety issue,'' and rejected a request by Massachusetts officials for new hearings on Seabrook management and training. Six Massachusetts communities lie within Seabrook's 10-mile evacuation-planning zone, and state officials oppose the plant. The Seacoast Anti-Pollution League and the New England Coalition on Nuclear Pollution are joining Massachusetts in appealing the licensing board ruling. An NRC Atomic Safety and Licensing Appeal Board plans to hear the opponents' oral arguments and plant supporters' replies on Tuesday in Bethesda, Md.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's S&Ls Record Record Losses in 1989
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; ADDS byline; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The nation's savings and loans lost $19.2 billion in 1989, the worst performance ever and the third consecutive record, the government said today. With a $6.5 billion loss in the final three months of the year, red ink for all of 1989 easily topped the previous record of $13.4 billion in 1988. That had topped what was then a record of $7.8 billion in 1987. But James Freund, acting chief economist of the Office of Thrift Supervision, offered a glimmer of hope for this year, pointing out that the bulk of the losses occurred at institutions either taken over by the government or targeted for takeover. ``I would presume by this time next year ... the industry would be smaller and the losses would be smaller,'' he said. In the fourth quarter, for instance, the 485 institutions either under government control or targeted for government control compiled all of the industry's losses while the rest of the industry, 2,393 S&Ls, actually posted a slight profit of $28 million. The government's numbers also revealed the cost of the government's slow start in shutting down failed institutions. Losses on operations for the 485 totaled $2.6 billion in the October-December period _ an average loss of $29 million a day. Once these institutions are shut down or sold, the industry would no longer have to absorb that continuing expense. Since August, the government has disposed of 52 S&Ls and announced plans recently to close or sell another 140 by the end of June. Thrift industry deposits totaled $946 billion at the end of 1989, down $26 billion from a year earlier. Most of the shrinkage occurred as institutions sold off assets in order to meet tough new financial standards enacted last August. The number of institutions open _ both failed and solvent _ totaled 2,878, down from 2,949 a year ago and from a peak of 3,246 in 1985. ``1989 was clearly a year of substantial change and retrenchment for the thrift industry,'' Freund said.

The stock market staged a broad advance today, spurred on by a rally in Japanese stock prices and a drop in domestic interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 17.34 points to 2,721.62 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 813 up, 238 down and 420 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 24.29 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The recently battered Tokyo stock market began to rebound on Friday. Today it surged ahead nearly 5 percent for its second largest gain on record. Analysts said that prompted hopes that turmoil in the Japanese markets might subside without having caused many ripple effects in other financial centers around the world. At the same time, the dollar continued its recent climb against the Japanese yen in foreign exchange. The U.S. bond market, which has benefited from the dollar's strength, extended its recent rally today, pushing interest rates lower. Among actively traded blue chips, American Telephone & Telegraph rose { to 41|; Procter & Gamble { to 67}; Philip Morris [ to 39{, and Boeing } to 74. Precious metals stocks fell as world gold prices took a beating. Homestake Mining dropped 1\ to 17~ and Placer Dome 1\ to 16|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .92 to 186.37. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .27 at 361.34. On Friday the Dow jones industrial average rose 8.56 to 2,704.28, reducing its loss for the week to 36.94 points. Advances outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed issues, with 884 up, 571 down and 527 unchanged. Big Board volume came to 132.07 million shares, down from 175.93 million the day before.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
With BC-Coal Production List
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 20.5 million tons during the week ending March 17, up 2 percent from the 20.1 million tons produced in the previous week, the U.S. Department of Energy reported Monday. The U.S. coal industry produced 20 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. Kentucky ranked first among the 27 coal-producing states with 3.5 million tons produced. Wyoming was second at 3.4 million tons and West Virginia was third at 3.1 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 221 million tons, 6 percent ahead of last year's production at this time. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Drops By 15
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs dropped by another 15 this week as it continued on its normal first-quarter pace to total 893, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. The decrease in rig activity conforms to previous first quarters when the count generally is in a decline, according to Ike Kerridge Jr., an economist for Baker Hughes. The year-to-date count, however, remains well ahead of the 1989 tally when 766 rigs were working, Baker Hughes said. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely-watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil-producing states, Louisiana showed the greatest decline for the week, losing nine rigs. California, Wyoming and Ohio each lost three rigs this week, while North Dakota and Texas each lost two. Oklahoma showed the greatest improvement for the week, adding 10 rigs, while New Mexico added two and Kansas rose by one. The number of working rigs in Colorado, Michigan and Pennsylvania remained unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Review Ruling on Excluding Child-Bearing Women from Some Jobs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 11-23, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, accepting a case that could affect millions of working women, said today it will review a ruling that lets employers exclude all women of child-bearing age from some hazardous jobs. The justices agreed to study an automobile battery manufacturer's policy of banning women who cannot prove they are infertile from jobs that expose them to lead. A decision is expected sometime in 1991. A federal appeals court last year upheld the fetal protection policy, rejecting arguments that banning women from high-paying, if hazardous, factory jobs amounts to illegal sex discrimination. Exposure to lead, the principal material used in making batteries, is a health risk to workers and to the fetuses of pregnant workers. Since 1982 the battery division of Johnson Controls Inc., based in Milwaukee, has barred women at its factories from jobs involving exposure to lead and from jobs that, through transfers or promotions, could progress to lead-exposed duties. Eight employees and the United Auto Workers union challenged the policy in court. Among the women who sued was one who had submitted to sterilization to preserve her job and a 50-year-old divorcee. The suit alleged that the policy violated a part of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, called Title VII, barring sexual bias in employment. U.S. District Judge Robert W. Warren in Milwaukee ruled for Johnson Controls based on both sides' pretrial arguments. No trial was held. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld his ruling by a 7-4 vote last Sept. 26. In other action today, the high court: _ Agreed to consider giving federal regulators more authority to lower electricity rates, setting the stage for a decision that could affect more than 49 million homes. The court said it will review a ruling that barred the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from slashing rate increases to customers in 15 Ohio communities. _ Agreed to hear an appeal challenging the authority of states to house convicted murderers on ``death rows'' and keep them apart from other inmates. The justices said they will review the appeal of Nebraska death row inmate John Rust, who says such segregation is ``without penological justification'' and ``grossly disproportionate'' punishment. _ Agreed to review a ruling that, if upheld, could reinstate forced busing for the racial desegregation of Oklahoma City, Okla., elementary schools. The court must decide whether the city school board acted lawfully when in 1985 it returned to a neighborhood schools plan for children in kindergarten through fourth grade. _ Refused to revive a lawsuit stemming from one of the nation's most publicized cases of alleged child abuse, at the now-defunct McMartin Preschool in Manhattan Beach, Calif. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out the suit against a private child welfare group and one of its therapists by two of the preschool's former teachers. _ Refused to extend a key civil rights law to protect non-citizens from private, as well as governmental, bias. The court, over two dissenting votes, let stand a ruling that the First National Bank of Commerce in New Orleans did not discriminate illegally against Jeetendra Bhandari when it denied his application for a bank credit card because he is not a U.S. citizen. _ Rejected an appeal by a leading conglomerate found to have fraudulently obtained a $75 million bank loan to develop natural gas fields in Mississippi. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that could subject W.R. Grace & Co. to major punitive damages in a lawsuit by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. In the fetal-protection case, Judge John L. Coffey wrote for the appeals court that the differing treatment of women employees was based on a ``business necessity,'' and added, ``We are also convinced that Johnson Controls' fetal protection policy could be upheld under the bona fide occupational qualification defense.'' The appeals court concluded that the policy ``is reasonably necessary to industrial safety.'' Three of the appeals court's four dissenting judges wrote opinions, the most scathing of which was authored by Judge Frank Easterbrook, a conservative appointee of President Ronald Reagan. Calling it ``likely the most important sex-discrimination case in any court since ... Congress enacted Title VII,'' Easterbrook said, ``If the majority is right, then by one estimate 20 million industrial jobs would be closed to women, for many substances in addition to lead pose fetal risks.'' ``The law would allow employers to consign more women to `women's work' while reserving better-paying but more hazardous jobs for men,'' Easterbrook said. ``Title VII was designed to eliminate rather than perpetuate such matching of sexes to jobs.'' He added: ``Cases ... show that many additional women are affected by restrictions placed on other jobs, such as the X-ray technician jobs that exposed embryos to radiation. Concern about emissions from computers and their terminals has led to proposals that could restrict access even to traditional office jobs.'' Johnson Controls has battery plants in several states. A California appeals court recently ruled that the fetal protection policy is illegal sex discrimination under state, not federal, law. The case is International Union vs. Johnson Controls, 89-1215.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Mixed After Lower Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade after opening lower amid a raft of bearish developments and expectations. Crop weather in South America and the United States continued to improve over the weekend, prompting some of the initial selling. A sharp drop in gold prices and a strong surge in the dollar this morning also were viewed as negative for grain and soybean prices since a stronger dollar tends to discourage export sales. Analysts and traders also linked early selling to speculation that Soviet-Lithuanian tensions could hurt the Soviet Union's chances of receiving most-favored trade status from the United States. Trading this week is expected to be influenced by profit-taking as traders even up their positions ahead of Friday's USDA planting-intentions report. In early trading, wheat futures prices were 1 cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.57{ a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to 1 cent higher with May at $2.59{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1\ cents higher with May at $1.49 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 3{ cents higher with May $5.99} a bushel. Livestock futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork-belly futures were sharply higher. Live cattle futures were .12 cent lower to .15 cent higher with June at 72.65 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .13 cent higher with March at 82.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .13 cent lower to .30 cent higher with April at 53.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1 cent to 1.03 cents higher with May at 52.95 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Ships Version of 1-2-3 for IBM's New Software
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp. said Monday it has begun shipping a version of its popular 1-2-3 computer spreadsheet program for IBM's newest personal-computer operating system. The new version of 1-2-3 is designed for OS-2 and Presentation Manager. OS-2 is the latest operating system, or base layer of software, for IBM's personal computers. The Presentation Manager software allows computer users to run their IBM machines via an easy-to-use graphics display similar to that used on Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computers. Lotus, based in Cambridge, Mass., announced it was working on the new software, called 1-2-3-G, last year. Computer spreadsheets display rows and columns of figures and are among the most popular software. Lotus 1-2-3 is the best-selling spreadsheet program for personal computers.

DOC.HEAD: French Steelmaker Approaches LTV on Steel Buy
DOC.TEXT: A French steelmaker has expressed an interest in buying a minority stake in LTV Corp.'s steel unit, LTV announced today. LTV said the offer from Usinor Sacilor of France, Europe's largest steelmaker, was unsolicited and that no negotiations have been held or are scheduled. LTV is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. ``We will explore at the proper time and under the proper circumstances a business relationship between LTV Steel and Usinor Sacilor,'' said LTV chairman and chief executive officer Raymond A. Hay. ``This is a normal and appropriate endeavor for a company going through the Chapter 11 reorganization process.'' Usinor Salcinor is the second largest steelmaker in the world, operating three facilities in France and two in West Germany. LTV Steel is the third largest domestic steelmaker and the largest producer of flat rolled steel products for the automotive industry. The two companies, which currently have a technology exchange relationship, are discussing a confidentiality agreement as a prelude to any purchase, LTV said. LTV Corp. is a diversified manufacturing company in steel, aerospace-defense and energy products. The company filed for reorganization in 1986, citing heavy losses in the steelmaking division.

DOC.HEAD: Two Biggest Dutch Banks Start Merger Talks
DOC.TEXT: The nations' two largest commercial banks, Amro Bank and Algemene Bank Nederland (ABN), have begun merger talks aimed at eventually creating the world's 20th-largest bank, officials of both companies announced Monday. The merger would transform the two banks into a conglomerate that could act as a global player using the entire European Community as its home base, according to ABN chief R. Hazelhoff. But claiming that the talks were still in an embryonic stage, bank officials refrained from providing details on the projected merger, which surprised the Dutch financial world. With reported assets of 180 billion guilders, or $90 billion, Amro Bank ranks as this nation's largest commercial bank, while ABN ranks second with assets reportedly totaling 173 billion guilders, or $86.5 billion. ``Based upon recent developments in the markets for financial services, we are of the opinion that concentration of forces of forces is strongly advisable,'' the two banks said in a statement. ``Such a concentration will mean a stronger basis for our position in several segments of the domestic market,'' according to the statement. ``Internationally, as a result of both Europe 1992 and developments outside Europe, an important strengthening can be attained through a merger.'' Last year, a merger between Amro Bank and the Belgian Societe Generale de Banque foundered on what the Dutch bank called cultural differences. That planned merger was also inspired by the expected concentration of financial forces in the fully integrated European market, which is expected to be established by 1992. At present, ABN, which employs 32,000 people, has 711 offices in the Netherlands and 269 offices in foreign countries. Amro Bank has 762 offices in the Netherlands and 106 offices abroad, its payroll totalling 24,000 employees. Based on assets, the new combination would rank as the world's 20th-largest commercial bank just behind the Deutsche Bank of West Germany, according to figures provided by the trade journal Institutional Investor.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Calls for Greater Control of Diet Programs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with today's testimony. Picks up 8th graf pvs, A subcommittee staff.
DOC.TEXT: Weight loss clinics need closer scrutiny by the Federal Trade Commission, a congressman said today as he opened hearings to investigate the growing fat-fighting industry. ``Most lay counselors and specialists in commercial diet clinics are undertrained lay people operating without any medical supervision,'' said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. He said products sold in such clinics are untested, with little or no scientific proof of their safety and effectiveness. Officials of major commercial weight-loss programs declined to testify, the subcommittee staff said before the hearing. Wyden told FTC chairwoman Janet Steiger that he wanted her agency to check weight-loss clinics for possible fraud and to work with state attorneys general and other consumer fraud agencies to police them. Steiger, who was the first witness before Wyden's House Small Business subcommittee on regulation, said her agency has been trying to weed out the most outrageous of the weight-loss schemes _ diet pills that are supposed to make you thinner while you sleep, for example. ``Now we're taking a closer look at the weight loss clinics,'' she said. She advocated consumer education and said a task force within her agency is trying to find ways the federal government can coordinate with state government. ``We are encouraging state criminal enforcement where it is appropriate,'' she said. Witnesses included women who had had medical problems after going to weight loss clinics. A subcommittee staff report on the diet industry said that despite optimistic claims, an estimated 90 percent of all dieters who lose 25 pounds in a diet program regain the weight within two years. It said Americans spent $33 billion on weight loss in 1989, one-third of it for diet clinics alone. It cited a warning by the American Medical Association that some diet formulas could lead to complications and even fatalities among dieters. ``The worrisome trend is away from exercise and toward liquid protein diets, virtually all of them sponsored by physicians and hospitals, and so-called fast diets, which ignore nutritional safety,'' the report said. Much of the growth in the industry has been due to heavy advertising, which the FTC has largely ignored, the report said. The Food and Drug Administration has authority to regulate the diet products. ``But in reality, few if any of these diet gadgets, drugs or food have been tested for safety and effectiveness before patients and consumers become unsuspecting guinea pigs,'' the staff report said. It contended that many so-called diet experts, including physicians, have little knowledge about how to treat obesity. The products are often sold by people whose principal training is in sales, not nutrition or medicine, it said. The report cited industry research estimating the nation has 65 million dieters, including half of all women. It said 60 percent of all women are usually dieting in some form, and 18 percent of all adults are constantly dieting; 25 percent of American adults are obese and 13 percent are severely overweight.

DOC.HEAD: British Stocks Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed higher on London's Stock Exchange Monday, boosted by increased institutional activity, program trading and a shortage of blue-chip stocks. Buying in the stock index futures market also helped propel the cash market higher for most of the day, dealers said. A stronger pound, a perception that the West German central bank might not raise its interest rates and a strong start on Wall Street also were positive factors, they said. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 14.3 points, or 0.6 percent, at 2,298.2. Volume amounted to a modest 306.6 million shares, compared with 441.6 million shares Friday. The exchange moved its trading day up half an hour, effective Monday, to be open when more trading actually is taking place. Traders are allowed to deal outside exchange hours. The new hours are 8:30 a.m., or 3:30 a.m. EST, to 4:30 p.m., or 11:30 a.m. EST.

DOC.HEAD: French Group Offers to Buy Saatchi's Hay Unit
DOC.TEXT: Bernard Krief Consultants said Monday it has offered $120 million for Hay Group, a U.S.-based consulting unit of Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi Co. The offer was made through Citibank, which is providing financial backing, Krief said in a news release. Saatchi has been trying to negotiate the sale of its consulting operations since last June, the Krief statement said. Hay ranks among the largest of the units. The French consulting concern, which has offices in Paris, Washington, Moscow and Brussels, did not elaborate on its chances for success. Saatchi & Saatchi is ``negotiating'' but hasn't accepted the offer, a spokesman said. The advertising agency has said it wishes to refocus on its core communications operations. At the company's annual general meeting earlier this month, Chairman Maurice Saatchi said the group was ``in serious negotiations on all of the consulting companies,'' which had failed to perform to expectations.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Advances, Gold Tumbles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar, boosted by political tension in the Soviet Union and expectations of continued weakness of the Japanese yen, finished higher against most major currencies in European trading Monday. Gold prices plunged amid reports of massive gold sales, possibly by investors in the Middle East. It lost more than $30 an ounce in Zurich, Switzerland. In early afternoon trading in New York, gold traded about $20 an ounce lower than Friday's late level. Though the dollar moved higher against the major currencies, European dealers said market activity was generally modest. They added that most of the dollar's gains were driven by the market's continued focus on Soviet Lithuania where a Soviet troop buildup has raised fears of armed intervention. Dealers also noted some disappointment that Japan Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto was unable to secure any apparent monetary concessions from the U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady during weekend meetings. In late afternoon London trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.7155 Deutsche marks, up from 1.7100 marks late Friday. The British pound traded at $1.6135, up from $1.6040 late Friday. The pound also advanced to 2.7680 marks, up from 2.7412 late Friday. The dollar rose earlier in Tokyo by 1.33 yen to 156.40 yen, its highest close since Jan. 13, 1987. Later, in London, it was quoted at 156.35 yen. Other late dollars rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels included: 1.5275 Swiss francs, up from 1.5179; 5.7745 French francs, up from 5.7645; 1.9267 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9249; 1,261.50 Italian lire, up from 1,258.50; and 1.1748 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1751. Gold bullion moved sharply lower in heavy trading. Rumors of heavy selling swirled around world precious metals markets. The Saudia Arabian Monetary Agency was rumored to have sold gold and bought British pounds with the proceeds. Japanese investors were said to have sold gold to buy stocks. Meanwhile, gold also came under pressure from internal market dynamics as technical indicators triggered selling. The metal was quoted at $379.25 a troy ounce in London late Monday, down from a bid of $386.95 late Friday. In Zurich, the late afternoon gold bid was $363 an ounce, down from late Friday's $393.05. After gold fell through support levels around $388 and again at $385, selling accelerated in what some dealers described as a panic. ``It was a free-fall after those levels were broken,'' said one dealer in Zurich. Some traders said gold is now vastly oversold, and predicted a a comeback. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $5.49 to close at a bid of $384.94 an ounce. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery was trading at $368.25 a troy ounce in early afternoon, off $20.60 from Friday's settlement. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.95 a troy ounce, down from $5.04 late Friday. It was the first time silver had finished below $5.00 since June 30, 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Proxy Fight Ended, Two Chartwell Candidates Being Nominated to Avon Board
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc. and an investment group that owns 9.9 percent of Avon's common stock announced Monday they had reached a settlement to end a planned proxy fight by the group. The settlement also ends for now a challenge to the big cosmetics company's existing management by Chartwell Associates, a limited partnerhip. A joint announcement said the Avon board has agreed to nominate two candidates proposed by Chartwell for election to the board of directors at the annual meeting in New York on May 3. The board also will nominate two incumbent Avon directors. Under the settlement, the directors will establish a committee to consider ways of boosting value for Avon stockholders. Members of the special panel will be James E. Preston, Avon's chairman and chief executive officer, three incumbent members of the Avon board and the two Chartwell nominees. The panel will examine alternatives to maximize value, such as a recapitalization, asset sales, an outright sale of Avon or a leveraged buyout. Another key element of the settlement is the resignation of John P. Rochon as vice chairman of Mary Kay Corp., parent of Mary Kay Cosmetics, which is a Dallas-based rival of Avon's in the direct sales business. Rochon will become a consultant to Avon for a year and report to Preston. His assignment will be to assist the special committee, Avon spokesman John Cox said. Rochon is a principal of Chartwell, an investment group which owns about 7.5 percent of Avon's voting shares, or roughly 9.9 percent of the company's outstanding common stock. Chartwell recently launched a proxy fight to win four seats on Avon's 11-member board. Proxy fights essentially are attempts by outsiders to overthrow a company's management by obtaining enough proxies to influence a corporate election. A proxy is the legal right to exercise a shareholder's vote. Given the amount of Avon stock held by investors potentially hostile to management, it had appeared probable that Chartwell would succeed in capturing at least two seats if it continued to wage its proxy battle. The terms of the Avon-Chartwell settlement therefore recognize the inevitable while averting the expenses a proxy contest would have entailed. In addition to Rochon, other partners in Chartwell include members of the Fisher real estate family of New York and Gordon P. Getty, the oil heir. The Chartwell candidates who will be nominated to Avon's board are Anthony Fisher and Marc E. Leland, representing the Getty interests. Commenting on the settlement, Chartwell said: ``We believe that our agreement with Avon serves the best interests of all Avon stockholders. We look forward to working with Jim Preston and sharing ideas with him and with our fellow directors.'' Incumbent Avon board members who will be up for re-election are Preston and Charles S. Locke, chairman and chief executive officer of Morton International Inc. The incumbents not standing for election again are Emil Mosbacher Jr., an investor and independent oil and gas producer, and Merlin Nelson, former vice chairman of AMF Inc. Last year Avon, the world's biggest direct selling company, drew several unsolicited takeover proposals. In rejecting the offers, Avon speeded up its plans to improve profitability and focus on its core direct selling operations. Avon sales representatives market gifts, cosmetics, jewelry and other items. Avon earned $54.6 million in 1989 after a deficit of $404.5 million in 1988 when it had $546.6 million in losses from discontinued operations. Other major holders of Avon stock include Minneapolis investor Irwin Jacobs and a group led by Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Says Response to No-Ad Policy Has Been Overwhelming
DOC.TEXT: The Walt Disney Co. says moviegoers are applauding its refusal to show its films in theaters that run on-screen ads first. Richard Cook, president of Disney's Buena Vista Pictures Distribution, said anyone who ever heard an audience hiss the ads knows how unpopular they are. He said the depth of that hatred came out in overwhelming praise after Disney announced its policy last month. ``We had five boxloads of letters,'' Cook said. Some theaters have been showing no ads. Others have been, at least when non-Disney movies are playing. For example, the nation's largest theater chain, the Denver-based 2,700-screen United Artists Theater Circuit, announced last week it would go along with the advertising ban, but only on screens where Disney films are shown. No other movie distributors have joined Disney's no on-screen advertising policy. ``I applaud the policy as a consumer,'' 20th Century Fox marketing and distribution chief Tom Sherak said. ``But it's not up to me to tell them (theater owners) that they should or shouldn't do it. It has to come from their patronage.'' Sherak suggested that angering audiences may cost theater owners more than they make in ad revenue. ``Exhibitors should sit in their theaters and see what the public sees. They might see that they might be hurting themselves in the long run,' he said. Some observers believe Disney has a big extra motive for wanting no ads to be shown. Its arch-rival, MCA-Universal, has been running ads for its Universal Studios Florida theme park in most of the 1,930 theaters operated by Cineplex Odeon. The studio tour is a head-to-head competitor with the nearby Walt Disney World complex. MCA owns 50 percent of Toronto-based Cineplex Odeon. Cook, the Disney distribution chief, denied the MCA ads motivated Disney's policy. ``The impetus was not any one ad in particular.'' The exception to the ban is slide ads for soft drinks, car washes and the like, which Disney says may be shown when the theater lights are up during intermission and before the show starts. Also, Disney is allowing existing contracts to be honored. So some viewers of Disney's new release ``Pretty Woman'' may have seen commercials over the weekend. But when the ad contracts run out, Disney says theater owners must cave in to its demands _ or do without its pictures.
