DOC.HEAD: Schlesinger Warns of Higher Bill for Imported Oil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmitting to reslug to avoid confusion with daily AM-Oil Price sty; also moved on general news wires as AM-Oil Prices.
DOC.TEXT: Rising prices and growing demand soon will push the U.S. bill for imported oil higher than the nation's 1990 trade deficit, former Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger told Congress Monday. ``There is a strong possibility of a 30 percent or 40 percent increase in prices'' in the 1990s, Schlesinger said in presenting the Senate Energy Committee a gloomy summary of the world oil outlook. ``That we will have a price surge in the decade seems to me to be beyond question.'' U.S. demand for oil will grow by about 2 percent a year until there are steep price increases, Schlesinger said. In a recent month, he added, the United States had to rely on foreign sources to meet a record 54 percent of its oil demand. Schlesinger, also a former secretary of defense and director of the Central Intelligence Agency, said that U.S. imports should reach as much as 11 million barrels a day by 1995, compared with a net average of just over 7 million barrels a day in 1989. ``The oil-import bill then will likely exceed our present trade deficit,'' he said. The 1990 trade deficit is about $100 billion. ``That statement, if correct, is of profoundest concern to the U.S. economy,'' said Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., chairman of the committee. While domestic demand for oil has been growing, Schlesinger said, U.S. production continues to fall. Drilling activity is low by historical standards, he said, and the giant Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska is in declining production. ``Dependency (on foreign oil) will continue to grow, although the pace can still be affected by our policy decisions,'' Schlesinger said. While the U.S. appetite for imported oil grows toward 65 percent, ``the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (our chief surviving element of protection against a cutoff) will have shrunk in real terms from roughly 100 days to 60 days of imports,'' he said. ``We may as well acknowledge that over the past decade the United States as a practical matter abandoned the quest for energy independence _ indeed, even the quest for low energy dependency,'' Schlesinger said. ``If we are to limit our future vulnerability, either for national security or international financial reasons, we shall have to reverse course _ and take vigorous action.'' Schlesinger's formula for reducing imports includes increased conservation, more tax incentives for domestic producers and expanded drilling. Relying on renewable energy sources _ such as solar energy _ will not solve the problem because those sources do little for transportation, which is responsible for the growth in demand for oil, he said. Despite relaxed East-West tensions and the end of the Iran-Iraq war, Schlesinger said, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve should be increased from the present 750-million-barrel supply to 1 billion barrels. John J. Easton Jr., an assistant secretary of energy, was less pessimistic about the growth of oil imports and oil prices. ``Through concerted efforts to find and produce more of our domestic resources, we may be able to slow the rate of decline in U.S. production, but it is unlikely under current conditions that we will be able to reverse the trend,'' Easton said.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Post Record Losses
With AM-CenTrust S&L Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The savings and loan industry lost a record $19.17 billion in 1989 after posting its worst fourth-quarter loss, the government reported Monday. Analysts said the erosion would continue this year, although at a slower pace. The fourth-quarter loss totaled $6.5 billion, up from $4.97 billion in the July-September period, and pushed the yearly total to a third consecutive record deficit. The red ink was $13.4 billion in 1988 and $7.8 billion in 1987. James Freund, acting chief economist of the Office of Thrift Supervision, said most of the losses were suffered by institutions that have either been taken over by the government or are scheduled to be taken over under the S&L bailout law passed by Congress in August. ``OTS is carrying out (the bailout law) mandate of weeding out the insolvent and unsalvageable institutions that are compiling the big losses, and transferring them to the RTC's control for eventual sale or liquidation,'' Freund said. The RTC, or Resolution Trust Corp., is charged in the bailout legislation with disposing of the failed institutions. It has gotten rid of 52 S&Ls and announced plans recently to close or sell another 140 by the end of June. The RTC has been criticized recently for not acting quickly enough in disposing of the troubled S&Ls. Freund said that failure to shut down the institutions cost the government $2.6 billion in the fourth quarter _ an average of $29 million a day. However, Freund said ``the industry would be smaller and the losses would be smaller'' by this time next year. ``Despite smaller losses, they're still losses,'' said Bert Ely, an Alexandria, Va., financial institutions analyst. Ely said he saw a ``continuing and disturbing trend ... and that is a decline in the number (of S&Ls) making money.'' The OTS reported that 1,818 thrifts not under government control at year's end reported net earnings of $1.3 billion in the fourth quarter. That, Ely said, is 88 fewer than the number of profitable institutions reported in the third quarter. The other 779 S&Ls not under government control lost $3.4 billion, bringing to $2.1 billion the total fourth-quarter loss for all non-conservatorship thrifts. The 281 thrifts in conservatorship, or under government control, at year's end lost $4.4 billion, the OTS said, and the 84 other institutions transferred to the RTC since Jan. 1 lost $1.8 billion in the last three months of 1989. Another 120 thrifts targeted for transfer to the RTC had losses of $324 million. The thrift industry posted net losses in 33 states, net gains in 15 and no change in two states during the last quarter. The biggest losses occurred in Texas, $1.5 billion, and in Arizona, $1.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Dean Named To Head Stanford Business School
DOC.TEXT: A Harvard University dean was selected as dean of Stanford University's Graduate School of Business, university officials announced Monday. A. Michael Spence, 46, dean of Harvard's Faculty of Arts and Sciences, was picked to be the seventh dean of the prestigious graduate school. In his Harvard post, Spence, a former Rhodes Scholar, led 700 faculty members and 9,000 students enrolled in undergraduate programs, master's, and doctoral programs for all departments excluding the professional schools. Spence's Harvard post, comparable to the role of provost at other universities, is considered the second most powerful at the Ivy League institution. ``Michael Spence is an extremely able academic administrator,'' said Stanford Provost James N. Rosse. ``The selection committee developed a clear idea of the kind of leadership it wanted. There is no doubt we found the person who could carry that role.'' Spence, an economist who held joint appointments in the economics department and at the Harvard Business School before becoming dean, replaces Robert K. Jaedicke, who was stepping down after six years as Stanford dean to return to teaching and research. Spence, who taught at Stanford from 1973-75, takes over a Stanford business school attended by 660 students in the two-year MBA program, 42 Sloan Fellows and 84 doctoral students. There are some 120 faculty members. Spence serves on the board of directors of Polaroid Corp. and is a member of the World Economic Forum.

DOC.HEAD: Malek, Director of Economic Summit, Gets Ambassador's Rank
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave Frederick V. Malek the rank of ambassador Monday in his role as director of this summer's economic summit in Houston. Malek is the president of Northwest Airlines. He is working part-time preparing for the July 9-11 summit for the leaders of the world's seven largest democracies.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Spurt Higher On Lack Of Brazilian Sales
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose strongly Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade after an expected flood of Brazilian soybean exports failed to materialize. Grain futures also advanced. The soybean market had sold off sharply Friday on speculation that economic reforms aimed at stemming Brazil's runaway inflation rate would be implemented over the weekend, causing soybean exports to resume after a week-long lull. But the Brazilian economic picture remained muddled Monday and analysts said there was no appreciable increase in farmer sales or export shipments of Brazilian soybeans. ``Everybody's holding on to their tangible assets until the picture is clearer,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the gain in soybeans was ``strictly a Brazil play'' helped by technically inspired buying as prices rose. At the close, wheat futures prices were unchanged to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.59} a bushel; corn was { cent to 2\ cents higher with May at $2.60} a bushel; oats were { cent to 2 cents higher with May at $1.49} a bushel; soybeans were 5 cents to 8{ cents higher with May at $6.03{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Procter-Silex, Hamilton Beach Plan to Combine
DOC.TEXT: NACCO Industries Inc. said Monday it plans to combine its Procter-Silex Inc. subsidiary with Hamilton Beach, an appliance-making subsidiary of Glen Dimplex of the Republic of Ireland. NACCO Industries, based in Cleveland, would own 65 percent of the new company and Glen Dimplex would own 35 percent, NACCO said in a statement. The combined sales of Procter-Silex and Hamilton Beach would be about $350 million annually, company officials said. The agreement is subject to approval of government agencies and the NACCO board of directors. ``This is an excellent business combination,'' said Ward Smith, chairman and chief executive officer of NACCO Industries. ``Our product lines are compatible and complementary. Furthermore, the much broader product line will enhance our position in a highly competitive market.'' Smith said that because of brand-name recognition of certain appliances, the new business would not change brand names of products. Hamilton Beach was acquired by Glen Dimplex in 1985 and makes small electric appliances such as blenders, food processors and mixers. It has plants in Clinton, N.C., and Washington, N.C., its headquarters. NAACO's Procter-Silex subsidiary, based in Richmond, Va., produces small electric appliances such as toasters, irons and coffeemakers. It has two North Carolina plants, in Southern Pines and Mt. Airy, and a plant in Juarez, Mexico. NACCO Industries, a holding company, has two other major subsidiaries. They are Hyster-Yale Materials Handling Inc., which designs, manufactures and markets forklift trucks and related parts, and the North American Coal Corp., which mines and markets coal for electric utilities.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas City Southern Selling Controlling Stake in Martec
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ratiopharm GmbH is cq in lede.
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City Southern Industries said Monday it has sold a controlling interest of its Martec Pharmaceutical subsidiary to a German company, ratiopharm GmbH. It is the European company's first investment in the U.S. pharmaceutical market, said John Wilcox, who has been elected president of Martec. The sale closed March 22 but the price was not disclosed. Kansas City Southern will retain 49 percent of Martec but will not be involved in management, said Landon H. Rowland, president and chief executive officer of Kansas City Southern. The holding company, which owns the Kansas City Southern Railway and several financial services subsidiaries, had announced earlier this year that it intended to restructure its pharmaceutical operations.

The stock market worked its way higher today, helped by a rally in Japanese stock prices and a drop in domestic interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 15.09 points to 2,719.37 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 888 up, 587 down and 475 unchanged. The recently battered Tokyo stock market began to rebound on Friday. Today it surged ahead nearly 5 percent for its second largest gain on record. Analysts said that prompted hopes that turmoil in the Japanese markets might subside without having caused many ripple effects in other financial centers around the world. At the same time, the dollar continued its recent climb against the Japanese yen in foreign exchange. The U.S. bond market, which has benefited from the dollar's strength, extended its recent rally today, pushing interest rates lower. Among actively traded blue chips, American Telephone & Telegraph rose ~ to 42; Procter & Gamble } to 68; Coca-Cola } to 74~, and General Motors 1\ to 47|. Precious metals stocks fell as world gold prices took a beating. Homestake Mining dropped 1] to 17}; Placer Dome ~ to 17; ASA Ltd. 2[ to 52, and American Barrick Resources 1~ to 17|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .86 to 186.31. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .28 at 361.33. Volume on the Big Board came to 98.39 million shares with an hour to go.
Stock prices were slightly higher today after giving up some of a broad early advance. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 4.28 at 2,708.56.

DOC.HEAD: Penntech Acquired By Willamette Industries
DOC.TEXT: Willamette Industries Inc. on Monday announced the acquisition of Penntech Papers Inc. of White Plains, N.Y. for an undisclosed sum. Penntech, which produces specialty grades of fine paper, will be operated as a separate subsidiary of Willamette, said Willamette President and Chief Executive William Swindells. Willamette is also planning to make substantial capital improvements to Penntech's plant at Johnsonburg, Penn., said Swindells. Based in Portland, Willamette is a forest products company with 71 manufacturing facilities located throughout the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Best Western to Add 50 Asian Hotels
DOC.TEXT: Best Western International will add 50 hotels in southern Asian countries by 1993, the lodging chain said Monday. The initial hotels will be in Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. New Delhi-based Uday Management Services Pvt. Ltd. has organized the Best Western South Asia group and will establish Best Western's first affiliate hotels in the region, adding five hotels in the first year, said Anand S. Gupta, president of Best Western South Asia. He estimated that the affiliate hotels would generate nearly 50,000 annual room nights for the chain. ``The large and growing middle class of India _ nearly 80 million people _ has an increasing disposable income and an interest in travel. As the Indian government pursues its policy of liberalization and modernization, this country will experience tremendous increases in inbound and outbound travel,'' Gupta said. Best Western has more than 3,300 independently owned and operated units in 38 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Could Get Worse, Administration Says
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit is not expected to improve in the next two years to the extent that it did in the past two and it could worsen, the Bush administration said Monday. The administration said that achieving additional reductions in America's trade imbalance would depend on a variety of factors _ from the growth rate in foreign countries to the value of the dollar on foreign currency markets. Given the forecasting uncertainties, the administration said it could not rule out the possibility that the trade deficit would actually worsen in the next two years. It did not forecast an actual deficit figure. The administration's assessment was included in its ``Annual Trade Projection Report to Congress'' which is required under the 1988 trade law. The administration said it was possible that further progress will be made in reducing the gap between exports and imports, but it said any improvements would be at a slower pace than in 1988 and 1989, two years when rapid growth in export sales helped to boost the country's economic fortunes. The merchandise trade imbalance declined to $109 billion in 1989, its lowest level since 1984, after hitting an all-time high of $152 billion in 1987. But many private economists are warning that the deficit will begin rising again this year, reflecting slower growth in U.S. export sales.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Tumbles as Dollar Marches Ahead Against Yen
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices plummeted as much as $30 an ounce Monday in hectic selling linked to the dollar's strength and intensified by rumors of heavy sales by large international investors. Another dollar advance against the Japanese yen stoked the bearish attitude toward gold that has been building for weeks. Several negative forces joined to jolt gold. An unconfirmed report of a huge sale by Saudi Arabia plus rumored selling by Japanese and Soviet parties had a domino effect on precious metals markets as other investors dumped gold to beat further price declines. ``My guess is that there's been pretty widespread selling ... based on a technically bearish chart picture and expectations of continued strength in the U.S. dollar, which has been the main culprit in gold's weakness for several weeks,'' said Jeffrey A. Nichols, president of American Precious Metals Advisors Inc. in Toronto. Gold for March delivery closed at $365.80 a troy ounce on New York's Commodity Exchange, $23.10 lower than Friday's settlement price. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a troy ounce of gold at $366.75, down $22.35 from Friday's late bid. Gold tumbled to $363 an ounce in Zurich, Switzerland, from $393.05 late Friday. Gold was quoted at $379.25 an ounce late Monday in London, down from $386.95 late Friday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $5.49 to close at a bid of $384.94 an ounce. Among the rumored big sellers was the Saudia Arabian Monetary Agency, which was said to have bought British pounds with the proceeds from selling an estimated 3 million troy ounces. The agency acts as the country's central bank and is the main repository of hard currencies and gold reserves. Japanese institutions reportedly unloaded gold to raise cash for buying stocks. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index soared by nearly 5 percent Monday in its second-biggest single-day rise ever, rebounding slightly from this year's severe slump. It has been widely assumed that the Japanese had been selling gold for months, possibly to cover stock losses. Market reports also said the Soviet Union sold gold to raise money to help it cope with economic difficulties. John P. Norris, manager of the precious metals department at Citibank in New York, said returns on currencies have become increasingly attractive due to rising interest rates. ``There has been liquidation by large gold investors to take advantage of higher yields elsewhere,'' he said. Silver also was under pressure. Silver for March delivery fell to $4.955 a troy ounce on New York's Comex from $5.043 Friday. Earlier in London, silver fell to a bid of $4.95 an ounce from $5.04 late Friday, marking the first time silver closed below $5 an ounce there since June 30, 1986. The dollar has been bid up due to speculation that U.S. interest rates will remain at present levels or higher. There is a perception the Federal Reserve won't nudge rates down because economic growth appears adequate while inflationary pressures persist. Tension in the Soviet Union over the Lithuanian independence movement and forecasts of further weakness in the Japanese yen also have driven up the dollar. The dollar rose to 156.70 yen in New York from 154.30 yen late Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose by 1.33 yen to 156.40 yen Monday, its highest close since Jan. 13, 1987. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 156.35 yen. The British pound, benefiting from the reported Saudi sterling purchase, strenghthened to $1.6185 in New York from $1.6010 on Friday. Sterling traded late in London at $1.6135, up from $1.6040 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.7075 West German marks, down from 1.7135; 1.5205 Swiss francs, up from 1.5200; 5.7480 French francs, down from 5.7720; 1,256.00 Italian lire, down from 1,260.25; and 1.17595 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17505. Rates for the dollar late in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels, included: 1.7155 West German marks, up from 1.7100; 1.5275 Swiss francs, up from 1.5179; 5.7745 French francs, up from 5.7645; 1.9267 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9249; 1,261.50 Italian lire, up from 1,258.50; and 1.1748 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1751.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Building Tube Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `HDTV uses ...,' to DELETE incorrect reference to digital signal.
DOC.TEXT: Philips Display Components Co. said Monday it will build a $100 million television picture tube plant at Saline, about 10 miles south of its Ann Arbor headquarters. Construction will start in July on the plant aimed at keeping the subsidiary of Dutch electronics giant NV Philips in the high-definition television race. It will be completed early in 1992, said Dr. Iva Wilson, Philips Display Components president. The 400,000-square-foot plant is designed to produce 1 million 27-inch color picture tubes a year and make HDTV tubes in the future. Philips Display Components is the top maker of picture tubes, with 70 percent of its production going to Philips Consumer Electronics products including the Magnavox, Sylvania and Philco television brands. It also provides tubes for television makers such as Sharp, Toshiba, NEC, JVC, Hitachi, MIC and the Korean Gold Star and Samsung brands. The company moved its headquarters last year from Seneca Falls, N.Y. The Ann Arbor facility develops products for manufacture at a plant in Ottawa, Ohio. The new plant won't affect operations at the Ottawa facility, which employs about 2,000 people, Wilson said. The picture tubes are assembled into televisions by another subsidiary, Philips Consumer Electronics, in Greenville, Tenn. The Federal Communications Commission said last week it expected to set a standard for HDTV broadcasting by spring 1993. HDTV produces a sharper video image than conventional television and compact-disc quality sound. The FCC said it favored systems sending HDTV signals on separate channels from conventional programming. Philips Consumer Electronics said in January it was entering into a joint venture with a unit of France's Thomson SA and the National Broadcasting Co. to look at such a system. Zenith Electronics Corp., the last major U.S.-based television maker, is working with American Telephone & Telegraph Co. on that type of system.

DOC.HEAD: Weekly Production Slips
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,936,000 net tons during the week ended March 24, down 1.5 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 86.4 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steelmakers produced 1,966,000 net tons in the same wek last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year was 22,893 net tons, 2.8 percent below last year's production at this time, AISI said. Production by district for last week (previous week in parentheses): North East Coast 174,000 tons (220,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 312,000 tons (315,000 tons); Lake Erie 161,000 tons (159,000 tons); Detroit 163,000 tons (159,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 518,000 tons (492,000 tons); Midwest 207,000 (205,00); Southern 289,000 tons (304,000 tons); Western 112,000 tons (112,000 tons).

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Nosedive On Huge Overseas Sales
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices were swamped Monday by a tidal wave of selling that apparently began in the Middle East and swept through markets around the world, eroding prices to their lowest levels in more than five months. On other commodity markets, soybean futures surged; grains were higher; copper futures fell; pork bellies rose sharply while livestock futures were mixed; and energy futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $23.20 to $25 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in April at $366.20 a troy ounce, the lowest gold settlement price on the exchange since Oct. 13. Silver futures prices fell 8.8 cents to 10.7 cents in New York with the March contract settling at $4.955 a troy ounce, the first close below $5 since mid-1986. Analysts agreed the collapse was sparked by an overseas sale of as much as 1 million ounces of gold bullion, a huge amount, by a single source. Rumors were rampant but many experts traced the initial sale to the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency or to a commercial bank in Saudi Arabia that may have sold gold and bought British pounds. Another view was that China was the initial seller, exchanging gold for hard currency. Major investors quickly followed suit, analysts said, pouring up to 2 million more ounces of gold onto the market. ``We had three million ounces hitting the market at a time it was structurally a little weak anyway, and knocked it all to hell,'' said George Milling-Stanley, first vice president in charge of bullion sales at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Spot gold prices fell sharply amid heavy selling in Zurich, Switzerland, and ``panic selling'' in London before the New York market opened, said Don Tierney, an analyst with Stanley Bell & Co. in New York. At midday, the Commodity Exchange announced it was raising by $700 to $2,100 the speculative margin, or downpayment, needed to play the gold market, forcing further selling by traders who could not afford the extra margin. Tierney said some traders who would normally have been rolling their positions out of the soon-to-expire April contract and into the June contract chose instead to get out of the market entirely ``to see how far this thing is going to go.'' Some experts predicted a rebound on Tuesday but opinions varied greatly. Peter Cardillo, commodity trading adviser with Josephthal & Co, said the market was oversold. But he also said that the fact the April contract closed below its previous low of $370 ``is not a healthy sign.'' Soybean futures rose strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade after an expected crush of Brazilian soybean exports failed to materialize. Grain futures also advanced. The soybean market had sold off sharply Friday on speculation that economic reforms aimed at stemming Brazil's runaway inflation rate would be implemented over the weekend, causing soybean exports to resume after a week-long lull. But the Brazilian economic picture remained muddled Monday and analysts said there was no appreciable increase in farmer sales or export shipments of Brazilian soybeans. Wheat futures settled \ cent to 2\ cents higher with May at $3.59 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2\ cents higher with May at $2.60} a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1} cents higher with May at $1.49{ a bushel; soybeans were 5 cents to 7{ cents higher with May at $6.03{ a bushel. Copper futures fell sharply on the Commodity Exchange on news that union workers at two state-owned copper refineries in Peru had postponed a planned two-day work stoppage. Copper settled 2 cents to 3.3 cents lower with March at $1.262 a pound. Pork-belly futures rallied on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in reaction to Friday's monthly Agriculture Department cold-storage report showing a smaller stockpile of frozen bellies than the market had expected. Frozen pork-belly futures settled .80 cent to 1.67 cents higher with May at 53.27 cents a pound; live cattle were .12 cent lower to .27 cent higher with June at 72.87 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .22 cent higher with March at 82.87 cents a pound; live hog futures were .28 cent lower to .27 cent higher with April at 53.47 cents a pound. In lackluster trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent to 7 cents higher with May at $20.46 a barrel; heating oil was .31 cent to .78 cent lower with April at 54.68 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .01 cent lower to .26 cent higher with April at 57.70 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices ended narrowly mixed in light trading Monday, with little fresh news to stir the market. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 7 cents to $20.46 a 42-gallon barrel. Later months had smaller gains. Among refined products traded on the exchange, regular unleaded gasoline for delivery in April edged up 0.04 cent to 57.70 cents a gallon, May added 0.23 cent to 63.77 cents and June moved up 0.26 cent to 63.03 cents a gallon. Contracts for later delivery closed mixed. No. 2 heating oil for April, meanwhile, fell 0.78 cent to 54.68 cents a gallon, May declined 0.61 cent to 53.06 cents and June closed down 0.51 cent at 52.47 cents a gallon. Analysts said the market was quiet with many traders and participants attending a National Petroleum Refiners Association conference in Texas. In addition, many regular participants turned their attention to the precious metals markets, where prices tumbled sharply, said James Steel, energy analyst for Refco Inc. in New York. Steel said there were few other clear fundamentals to account for the market's activity. Most of the day's trading was concentrated in the products markets, he said. ``Players were buying gasoline and selling heating oil for no particular reason,'' said Steel, in anticipation of bullish statistics from the American Petroleum Institute. Last week's report by the API, the trade association representing the nation's major refiners, showed a sharp decline in gasoline supplies. Analysts said this week's gasoline statistics, scheduled for release Tuesday, are expected to be bullish for the market again.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Pushes Forward in Suit Against Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Olympic Federal, ``a little old Midwestern thrift that wants to stay around another 100 years,'' is trying to ensure its future by pressing ahead with a lawsuit against federal regulators, Chairman John J. Lanigan said Monday. Olympic, one of about 600 of 2,600 S&Ls nationally that fall short of federal capital requirements, sued to stop the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision from taking it over. That suit, initially upheld by a district court judge, threatened to disrupt the Bush administration's bailout of the thrift industry by prompting a flood of similar suits. However, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit moved to avoid such a deluge Friday when it lifted an injunction against a takeover of Olympic, saying ``the harm to the public outweighs the harm to (Olympic) in this instance.'' Olympic officials and attorneys are not upset by the reversal because the decision prohibits the thrift office from liquidating the suburban Chicago S&L and selling its $1.1 billion in assets. What officials of the Berwyn-based Olympic want from the lawsuit is about $100 million that they believe the government owes them, a sum that will enable them to accept a friendly buyout offer, said Lanigan. ``We're not asking for anything that shouldn't be coming to us,'' he said. Olympic also is asking the court to bar the thrift office from initiating a takeover until after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. rules on the purchase of the thrift by a bank holding company, said Olympic attorney Charles J. Cooper. The government has taken over more than 120 S&Ls since the bailout began and is expected to seize as many as 200 more institutions. Olympic contends that last year's S&L bailout legislation unfairly wiped out an accounting measure known as ``supervisory good will,'' dropping Olympic below the capital requirements, Cooper said. Before the S&L legislation, the government permitted an institution that bought an insolvent thrift to count as capital the difference between assets and liabilities of the failed S&L, Cooper said. That amount, known as supervisory good will, was to amortized, or written off, over time. At least four lawsuits have been filed against the government protesting the reversal on good will, said thrift office spokesman Paul Lockwood. Olympic took over seven insolvent S&Ls in the early 1980s and tallied $160 million in good will, to be written off over about 40 years, Lanigan said. Writing off $6 million per year, the thrift now has $115 in good will _ capital that no longer counts. ``They took what we used to count as an asset on our balance sheet _ all we want to say is, reimburse us,'' Lanigan said. Olympic's lawsuit seeks the restoration of the good will accounting measure or a government reimbursement. The thrift's suitor, whom Lanigan declined to name, is willing to inject $30 million to $40 million into Olympic if the good will is restored or reimbursed by the government, Lanigan said. ``No investor is going to come in and buy an asset that isn't recognized by the government,'' he said. Another court hearing on Olympic's suit is set for April 11. Olympic's suit also challenged the constitutionality of takeovers on the grounds that the director appointed as part of the bailout legislation and his replacement were not nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate as provided by the Constitution. It was on these grounds that the district court judge barred the federal takeover of Olympic. That argument would be moot for Olympic if T. Timonty Ryan Jr., a former Labor Department attorney, is confirmed as thrift office director. Ryan has been nominated for a five-year term and the Senate Banking Committee has scheduled a confirmation hearing for Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Asks Heightened Surveillance of Weight-Loss Clinics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 19th graf pvs, `Wyden's staff ...,' to UPDATE with diet center reax. INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs with testimony. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Overweight people need better government protection from weight-loss clinics that advertise slimness but deliver health problems, a congressman investigating diet programs said Monday. ``This subcommittee has found the medical field riddled with hucksters who ply their dubious wares and their miracle cures while government regulators sit snoozing on the sidelines,'' said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., chairman of the House Small Business subcommittee on regulation. Witnesses who said diet clinics caused them or their family members medical problems told their stoies to the subcommittee. One woman said she had to have a gall bladder operation after rapidly losing weight through one clinic. Wyden said he was glad to see the Federal Trade Commission going after the most outrageous of the get-thin schemes, such as diet pills said to work during sleep, mail order starvation-binge plans or ear molds that allegedly use an acupuncture-type technique to reduce appetite. But he said a potentially greater threat is the trend toward commercial weight-loss clinics and physician-supervised diet programs. He said the FTC is doing nothing about them. He also criticized the agency for inaction against ``the new tin men of television _ the `infomercial,''' lengthy product promotions often appearing to be documentaries or interview shows. ``The American people falsely believe they are well protected both by government and the ethic of commerce,'' said Wyden. He said that, under then-President Reagan, the FTC was particularly lax about pursuing fraud in diet advertising, leading to the problem he said exists today. ``In the name of promoting competition in health care,'' the commission ``fostered an environment that left us a buyer-beware medical marketplace in which the scam artists could claim virtually anything with impunity _ and did,'' said Wyden. Janet Steiger, named to head the FTC by President Bush, said the commission has been acting against phony weight plans since 1926, concentrating on the most egregious. ``Now we're taking a closer look at the weight loss clinics,'' she said. She advocated consumer education and said an agency task force is trying to find ways the federal government can coordinate its efforts with state governments. ``We are encouraging state criminal enforcement where it is appropriate,'' she said, listing several court actions taken against abusers in the 1980s. Sherri Steinberg, of Broward County, Fla., said she needed a gall bladder operation after rapidly losing 28 pounds through a popular, heavily advertised weight loss center. Loretta Pameijer, of Miami, said she paid $2,000 to a diet clinic, advertised as being supervised by a doctor, so that her 12-year-old daughter could lose 55 pounds in hopes of becoming a school cheerleader. She said the girl lost weight, began eating normally and about a year later, after a meal at a fast-food restaurant, had a gall bladder attack that required surgery. Mrs. Pameijer said her doctor told her that diets can lead to gall bladder disease. ``I had no idea that any die could do this,'' she said. Wyden's staff said officials of major commercial weight loss clinics would not testify to the subcommittee. William Rush, senior vice president of Optifast, a hospital-based weight loss program, said he asked to testify and was told he would be scheduled later. ``We think we're the good guys,'' he said. ``We only treat patients who are 30 percent or more over their ideal body weight, and we treat obesity like a disease.'' Rush said the type of weight-loss clinics found in shopping malls are fine for people with only five or 10 pounds to lose. About $33 billion was spent in 1989 on diets, said a report released by the subcommittee. ``There are 65 million dieters in this country,'' said the report. ``Sixty percent of all women are usually dieting in some form and 18 percent of all adults are constantly dieting.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market managed a small gain Monday on the strength of early buying encouraged by a rally in Japanese stock prices and a drop in domestic interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up about 20 points in the early going, settled for a 3.38 gain at 2,707.66. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 826 up, 664 down and 491 unchanged. The recently battered Tokyo stock market began to rebound on Friday. It surged ahead nearly 5 percent Monday for its second largest gain on record. Analysts said that prompted hopes that turmoil in the Japanese markets might subside without having caused many ripple effects in other financial centers around the world. At the same time, the dollar continued its recent climb against the Japanese yen in foreign exchange. The U.S. bond market, which has benefited from the dollar's strength, extended its recent rally, pushing interest rates lower. But activity in U.S. stocks set a sluggish pace all day, and as the session progressed prices failed to hold at their early peaks. Brokers cited worries about unpleasant surprises in forthcoming earnings reports for the first quarter. Among actively traded blue chips, American Telephone & Telegraph rose | to 41} as the company launched its venture into the credit card business; Procter & Gamble gained ~ to 68[; Coca-Cola \ to 74], and General Motors 1[ to 47{. Precious metals stocks fell as world gold prices took a beating. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for near-term delivery tumbled $23.10 an ounce to $365.80. Homestake Mining lost 1| to 17{; Placer Dome 1 to 16~; ASA Ltd. 2] to 51}; Newmont Gold 2~ to 46]; Amax Gold 1 to 16, and American Barrick Resources 1~ to 17|. Curtiss-Wright gained 2{ to 61. The company's new chairman said he had received notice from an unnamed party expressing interest in acquiring Curtiss-Wright. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 116.11 million shares, down from 132.07 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 143.14 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $4.29 billion, or 0.13 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .15 to 185.60. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose .60 to 391.94, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up .41 at 337.63. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 1.59 to 438.84. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.31, down .30.

DOC.HEAD: ECC Commissioner Says Treaty Needed To Settle Possible Disputes
DOC.TEXT: The United States and European Economic Community are considering an international agreement to settle possible jurisdictional disputes once internal European trade barriers are removed in 1992, Vice President Sir Leon Brittan of the European Commission said Monday. ``At present there is no means of resolving such a dispute,'' Brittan said. ``I therefore think that we now need to give serious consideration to the desirability of a treaty or less formal agreement between the Community and the United States to deal with such problems.'' Brittan said the tearing down of non-tariff barriers under a single integrated market system in 1992 will intensify European competition with the United States. Such a treaty would pertain to competition involving mergers within the economic community. Brittan, the European Community commissioner in charge of financial services and competition, made the remarks in a speech to the EC Chambers of Commerce in New York, where he wound up a one-week visit to the United States. The commission is the joint executive body of the 12 member countries. Brittan said he met with various U.S. Cabinet members and lawmakers in Washington during his visit, including Assistant Attorney General James Rill, with whom he discussed the proposed treaty. ``I was encouraged by his positive reaction and we will now be working up our ideas in detail so that they can be properly considered on both sides of the Atlantic,'' he said. Brittan said the substance of any such agreement would still have to be formulated. ``Such an agreement would provide for information gathering and exchange and would lay down a detailed procedure for consultations on cases and issues of common interest,'' he said. ``It might even contain an arbitration clause, although the political difficulties of getting that agreed should not be underestimated.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan Suggests 80 Policy Changes to United States, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Japan has suggested the United States tax more, wean itself from energy-wasting cars and limit the use of credit cards among 80 proposals for competing better with the Japanese, a newspaper reported Monday. The proposals were made during recent unofficial talks between U.S. and Japanese trade negotiators in Warrenton, Va., to discuss economic reforms aimed at shrinking the trade imbalance, the Yomiuri Shimbun reported. The measures were aimed at cutting the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit, curbing excessive consumer spending and helping balance the federal budget, the nationally circulated newspaper said. The Japanese Foreign Ministry had no comment on the report. The aggressive measures proposed by Japan include imposing a value-added tax, abolishing income tax deductions on housing loans and building high-speed railways to reduce reliance on inefficient cars, the newspaper said. In the latest round of meetings, dubbed the ``Structural Impediments Initiative,'' U.S. officials urged Japan to revise land-use policies, streamline its retail distribution system and boost consumption of imports through public investment. Japanese officials have, in turn, urged the United States to cut its federal budget deficit, increase savings and investment and improve worker training and education to boost the competitiveness of American exports. Last week, another Japanese newspaper, the Asahi Shimbun, said Washington gave Japan a list of more than 200 suggestions aimed at eliminating structural barriers it said prevent foreign companies from entering Japanese markets. The U.S. list included a proposal to increase public works spending from 6.8 percent to 10 percent of Japan's gross national product. Each nation is to come up with an interim report on the talks in early April. A final report is expected in July.

DOC.HEAD: Philips To Sell Toothbrush Division
DOC.TEXT: North American Philips Corp. said it has entered into an agreement to sell a division that makes toothbrushes and cosmetics packaging products to a buyout firm. Under the deal announced Monday, terms of which were not disclosed, Philips will sell Anchor Advanced Products Inc. to Anchor Acquisition Corp., a company formed by Thomas H. Lee Co. and members of the division's management. Thomas H. Lee is a Boston-based private investment firm. Anchor Advanced Products is the world's largest toothbrush maker, according to Philips, the North American arm of the Dutch electronics giant N.V. Philips.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Drops New York's Credit Rating
DOC.TEXT: New York's budget woes took a dramatic turn for the worse Monday as Wall Street's two major rating agencies lowered the state's credit rating, leaving it with the third worst rating among the 50 states. The credit downgradings could cost New York taxpayers millions of dollars in higher interest payments on the state's debt. Only Massachusetts and Louisiana are rated as worse credit risks than New York now. ``We're behind West Virginia, for Christ's sake,'' complained state Comptroller Edward Regan. Regan, a Republican, said he would not help Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Legislature balance the books for the coming budget year by jiggering the contribution formula for the state's public employee pension system. Cuomo has blamed the state's third straight year of fiscal problems on an unanticipated drop in state revenues stemming from the 1986 federal Tax Reform Act and the economic slowdown that has hit the Northeast. The state's budget deficit for fiscal 1990, which ends Saturday, is projected at more than $1 billion and a forecast gap of $1.5 billion for fiscal 1991 ``continues to grow,'' Standard & Poor's Corp. said in announcing its downgrade. Both Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service Inc. dropped their credit ratings on the $775 million in short-term funds the state will borrow on Tuesday to balance this year's budget. The new ratings are one notch lower than ratings for budget-balancing loans taken out a year ago. Standard & Poor's also went one step further and lowered the rating on New York's long-term debt by two notches to the lowest level in state history. The agency lowered the ratings because there are no responsible solutions in sight for New York's ``chronic fiscal imbalance,'' S&P analyst Hyman Grossman said. ``Obviously the situation has gotten materially worse and the solution is a bigger hurdle than it was only a few months ago,'' Grossman said. The move by Standard & Poor's reduced the state's long-term credit rating from double-A-minus to single-A. During the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970s, when New York City nearly went bankrupt, Standard & Poor's rated the state's credit at AA, three notches higher than the new rating. But state officials and analysts said the new rating didn't necessarily indicate that the current fiscal problems are worse than the crisis of 15 years ago. Moody's did not change its long-term credit rating for New York, but analyst George Leung said the agency would be watching the state closely. Moody's currently gives New York a rating of A1, which is roughly comparable to S&P's new single-A rating. ``An A is a mediocre rating,'' Leung said. The S&P downgrade affected the state's $3.9 billion in outstanding general obligation bonds. New York has a total of more than $20 billion of various types of debt outstanding. A lower bond rating typically forces borrowers to pay a higher interest rate to sell its debt. Cuomo said the lower rating on Tuesday's short-term borrowing alone would cost the state an additional $10 million in interest. ``The continuing delay in achieving progress on a new state budget has now taken its toll on taxpayers, as I have warned for weeks that it would,'' Cuomo said in a statement. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, also a Democrat, are locked in a battle with the state Senate's Republican majority over whether higher taxes are needed to help close the mounting budget deficit. Standard & Poor's criticized Cuomo and legislative leaders for failing to agree on the size of the state's budget problem and to devise ``a credible plan to address it in a fiscally responsible manner.'' The budget is supposed to be in place by the start of the state's fiscal year, which begins on Sunday, but that hasn't happened since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Reports: Japanese Cars More Reliable than American
DOC.TEXT: Japanese cars were the most trouble-free in 1989 and American makes lagged, although Detroit produced a handful of 1989 models that were more dependable than in previous years, according to Consumer Reports. Toyota and Honda led all automakers in producing cars that were on the road more often than they were in the shop, the magazine said in its annual car guide, which was in the April issue released Monday. Of the 31 1989 passenger cars that were rated better-than-average or much better-than-average, 28 were Japanese. Meanwhile, all but one of the 33 passenger cars rated worse-than-average or much worse-than-average were made by the Big Three automakers _ General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. The Jaguar XJ6 was the only import in one of those categories. The magazine's guide rated GM's 1989 Buick Le Sabre and Chrysler's 1989 Dodge Spirit@Plymouth Acclaim as better-than-average in reliability. The 1989 Le Sabre's better-than-average rating shows an improvement over previous years, the magazine said. The 1988 model was rated as worse-than-average. The Spirit and Acclaim, introduced in the 1989 model year, earned better-than-average scores. Consumer Reports based its conclusions on the repair records of more than 637,000 vehicles between April 1988 and March 1989. Readers were asked to rate their vehicles' repair record on a five-point scale: much better than average, better than average, average, worse than average, and much worse than average.

DOC.HEAD: Norwest Gets Approval To Acquire First Interstate of Wisconsin
DOC.TEXT: Norwest Corp. has received approval from the Federal Reserve to acquire First Interstate Corp. of Wisconsin. Under the agreement, announced in September, First Interstate shareholders will receive Norwest stock with a value of about $215 million. First Interstate, Wisconsin's fifth-largest bank holding company, has 1,250 employees and assets of more than $1.7 billion. Under the acquisition, Sheboygan-based First Interstate will become Norwest-Wisconsin. Minneapolis-based Norwest, the state's largest bank, has assets of about $24.3 billion. Norwest spokesman Larry Haeg said no other regulatory approvals are needed. First Interstate shareholders also have approved the deal, which is scheduled to close about May 1, Haeg said. Norwest also plans to expand with the acquisition of the 50-branch First Minnesota Savings Bank of Minneapolis under a deal announced in late February. Regulatory approval also is required for that transaction.
